column4: her prom pictures

column2: this is a great camera. Looking back
column3: I probably wouldve purchase the Rebel T7i instead
column4: but I didnt want to spend the higher amount for my first camera. The T7 is easy to use
column5: comes with a battery
column6: a battery charger
column7: the camera bag
column8: and this set comes with the extra lens. The 75-300mm lens zooms very far. From trying out the T7i in the store
column9: I think the pictures come out nicer on the T7i
column10: but the T7 still takes very nice pictures. A little bit of work learning how to take good pictures with different lighting. The battery lasts for a while
column11: could shoot for a few days (taking ~300-500 pictures a day) without the battery dying. Does not come with an HDMI cord
column12: but I wish it did."^4^Jul 26

Free88^/nikon-d5600-dslr-video-two-lens-kit-with-18-55mm-and-70-300mm-lenses-black/5715104?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^207^6^"As I write this review
column2: I have taken approximately 2000 shots and have put the D5600 and both kit lenses through most of the paces. I am an amateur photographer/videographer
column3: exclusively using my gear for home/family work. My advice for anyone growing into this hobby is always get the most camera you are willing to bring with you. If its too heavy
column4: too big
column5: too complicated
column6: too expensive
column7: etc.
column8: you wont bring it with you and you will just be throwing away money.

column1: The Nikon D5600 is the most camera I am willing to bring with me. The Canon T7i is a fantastic direct competitor as well
column2: and you should give it serious consideration. At the end of the day
column3: the T7i is slightly heavier
column4: considerably less battery life
column5: and more expensive. Although
column6: it does have better autofocus
column7: slightly faster fps burst
column8: and in camera stabilization. Whichever you choose
column9: they are both great overall entry level DSLR's. It comes down to what you value more. I highly value less weight and longer battery life
column10: and the D5600 wins these categories. The Nikon D3400 and D7500 are also great choices if you simply must get Nikon. I found that the D3400 (and similar) is just missing too lacking in many features and capabilities vs the D5600. It is less weight and gets even more battery life
column11: but they definitely cut corners on the D3400. Important corners. In fact
column12: many cheaper and more convenient point and shoots can perform the same or better than the D3400
column13: so why not just get something that fits in your pocket. The D7500 is better than the D5600
column14: but again its what you value. Image quality and low light capability differences between those two are not far apart
column15: and you would be splitting hairs to declare a winner. What you will get with the D7500 is faster fps burst with a deeper buffer
column16: better autofocus
column17: weather sealing
column18: in camera focus drive (for older lenses)
column19: better shutter life expectancy
column20: and a few other minor things. However
column23: and less friendly view screen. Seasoned pro's could probably carry the D7500 just fine for hours on end. I was tired of holding it just after 15 mins. Ive carried the D5600 for 4 hours and not got tired. That means the D5600 comes with

column1: After about 2000 shots and a few hours of video
column2: I am loving my D5600. It has met or exceeded all my photography and videography expectations. And
column3: I feel like I have room to grow with it
column4: which is also important to me. No
column5: it doesnt do 4k video. No
column6: its not high bitrate. The video capabilities are for the occasional video
column7: and its good enough for that. In find the photo capabilities to be outstanding for this price point. There are better cameras for photo
column8: but not anywhere near this price point. I have attached two samples
column9: since that is all BB lets you attach to reviews. These are with the 18-55VR and 70-300 (non-VR) kit lenses. The flower shot is not enhanced. The moon shot is minimally enhanced
column10: because
column11: well
column12: the moon is very bright.

column1: Speaking of the lenses
column2: dont listen to the naysayers. The 18-55VR and 70-300 (non-VR) are both very capable and perfectly serviceable lenses. The 18-55VR is a no brainer
column3: and you should absolutely get that one if you dont already have it. The 70-300 is not VR and that is a con in some situations. It is mostly a tripod lens
column4: but that doesnt mean you cant get at least ok shots with it (see moon shot). The 55-200 VR is currently on sale around one fifty
column5: you should consider that instead or in addition to the 70-300 non-VR. Yes
column6: there are better lenses than these. However
column7: they can get very expensive really quick. For the price of these three lens you cant go wrong.

column1: In summary
column2: this is a great entry level DSLR that rivals much more expensive cameras where it counts
column3: yet is small and light enough that you will want to bring it with you all the time. Sure
column4: it doesnt get 4k video. Its not going to get the low light capabilities of the full frames. It doesnt have ridiculously fast bursts with a buffer as deep as the ocean. As far as all around shooters go
column5: however
column6: you would be hard pressed to find this many features and capabilities in this small and light package
column7: and anywhere near this price point (outside of the Canon T7i). Eventually
column8: mirrorless interchangeable cameras may render the entry level DSLR obsolete
column9: but that day is not today. If thats your thing
column10: great. Have at it. Make sure to bring 3-4 extra batteries and a bucket of ice. If you dont want to spend your day changing batteries and continually have to stop for the camera to cool down
column11: the D5600 is a great choice for smaller and lighter."^5^Jul 1

column1: DCC111^/nikon-d5600-dslr-video-two-lens-kit-with-18-55mm-and-70-300mm-lenses-black/5715104?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^29^2^"This review is written from my standpoint as a stills photographer. I have no interest in video.
For 5 years I worked as a photographer shooting weddings
column2: portraits and selling an occasional fine art print. For that work I used Canon gear to include the 5D3
column4: 6D and L lenses. Due to a personal issue that arose I sold all of my Canon gear in 2015. I am thus purchasing camera gear with a clean slate without being locked into any manufacturer. I owned Olympus mirrorless E-M5 and E-PM2 for the past year but did not feel that they offered an upgrade path that would support low light photography should I choose to photograph weddings again in the future. The new E-M1 II does not appear to offer an improvement to ISO that I would personally consider useable beyond ISO 1600.

column1: I chose Best Buy so that I could compare 5 camera bodies in person: Canon SL2
column2: T7i and 80D. Nikon D5600 and D7200. Ultimately I chose the D5600 due to size
column3: features and build quality. I have found ISO 3200 to be very good and also believe ISO 6400 can be very good IF the picture is properly exposed. I have not attempted ISO values beyond that.

column1: I did successfully use SnapBridge this morning to connect and transfer images to my IPhone 6+. I certainly would like to see the app improved and made more streamlined and easier but it is useable with my phone. I transfered images
column2: edited them in PhotoShop Express and used the phone as a remote to the camera.

column1: I am looking forward to learning all of the features this camera offers and acquiring some high quality prime lenses to use with it.
Highly recommended!"^5^Aug 13

column1: Terry Holmes

ABShobbyguy^/nikon-d5600-dslr-video-two-lens-kit-with-18-55mm-and-70-300mm-lenses-black/5715104?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^0^"I got this to upgrade from the D3300 which also was a great camera so far I am happy with the flexibility of the screen and the fact that you dont need a separate dongle to use it with a phone"^5^Nov 17
blueisback^/nikon-d5600-dslr-video-two-lens-kit-with-18-55mm-and-70-300mm-lenses-black/5715104?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^0^"The Nikon D5600 makes for an excellent first camera
column2: but if you've already invested in Nikon or if your hoping to expand with legacy glass
column3: you're going to have to go to the next tier. (See caution below)

column1: I was shooting at a conference when my trusty older Pentax stopped working. So
column2: I ran out and bought the D5600 kit at Best Buy - it was on sale. The kit comes with two basic lenses that sync up beautifully with the body. Both have AutoFocus but only one has the built in image stabilization. If you have basic photo knowledge
column3: you can be taking photos as soon as the battery is charged - it took about 2 hours to charge mine. Once you get past the basics
column4: there will be a learning curve to get to the point where you can smoothly access the wide range of advanced features
column5: but
column6: once you can
column7: the D5600 should fill most of your photographic needs. Nikon does have a more basic model (D3500)
column8: but
column9: if you can manage the price difference
column10: the D5600 is worth the step up.

column1: Note of caution: the 5600 and the 3500 are designed to work with AF lenses with a motor built into the lens. Older Nikon compatible AF lenses need a motor built into the camera body. The 3500 and 5600 do not have a built in AF motor. If you've already made an investment into Nikon equipment or if you want to expand your lens collection with older lens through store sales or through Ebay
column2: you should save for the D7500 (or the older D7200 also at an excellent price on Best Buy). The newer lenses with the built in motors are a little pricey making legacy lens very attractive. Also keep in mind
column3: image stabilization is not built into the 5600 or 7500 or any Nikon camera. It is another feature that is built into certain higher priced lens. Again a lot of mint condition legacy lens are available if you shop around
column4: but there will be no image stabilization. Meaning your next purchase should be a good tripod for photos where hand shake would be a concern.

column1: I did end up returning the D5600 and getting the D7200 body only instead. It was an economic decision. At this point I can't swing the cost of all new
column2: state of the art lenses. So
column3: I chose some legacy glass on Ebay.

column1: 4 stars because it took some intensive research to realize I would need all new expensive lens with built in motors. Had I known that going in
column2: I would have saved time (and a restocking fee) and gone up a level right away. But you have been forewarned
column3: so you can make your choice and be confident tha the D5600 will take great photos."^4^Mar 21

column4: back button focusing
column5: exposure compensation/exposure editing

column1: If none of those words meant anything to you

column3: set it to auto
column4: hit the button
column5: and get awesome photos without learning any of it.

column1: However

column3: this camera can do the job."^5^May 25

column5: allowing you to experiment with different settings. I have seen comments saying the Snapbridge was inconsistent

column2: but colors are often not close. In the Manual mode the auto-focus did sometimes override the focus done manually.

column1: The NFC function did not work : the Snapbridge on my iPhone made vain attempts to connect to the camera
column2: and so was unable to copy pictures.

column1: With the camera on my tripod the pictures of an object taken using the same aperture and shutter speed
column3: S
column4: A and M images were not always equally sharp or bright; the focus and the lighting in the studio
column5: and the exposure value were exactly the same.

column1: The camera worked well in the Program mode and with many features and two telephoto lenses is good value for money.
I recommend this camera kit to anyone who wants satisfactory pictures."^3^Feb 16

Do not assume that WiFi means camera will connect to your WiFi to upload pictures. The camera has its own WiFi that your smart device can connect to and then interface to provide location
column2: date information etc.. as well as transmit pictures to your phone/smart device.

column1: The app that Nikon provides to do these functions is not intuitive. Set up is not straight forward like connecting other devices to a smart phone/device.
I never thought that a camera purchase would require research on WiFi and Bluetooth interfaces. As well as end user interfaces.
I expected the camera to connect to local network
column2: and allow user to upload to a specified folder or to cloud storage."^2^May 10

Nicky^/canon-eos-rebel-t7i-dslr-video-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens-black/5792700?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^17^0^"I upgraded to this camera from my Canon T5. Let me tell you. This camera is SO much better. Honestly
column2: you wouldn't think there would be such a huge jump in its main functions and capabilities
column3: but there really is. I think what I like most about this camera is it's ability to auto focus while it's recording video. No other canon camera model does this. It's the first of its kind. I'm also really enjoying the moveable LCD screen. I can adjust it to any position I need it
column4: and I can flip it 180 degrees to show others the photos I had taken. Naturally
column5: when you flip the screen
column6: the photo will flip too. The screen is also a touch screen which is pretty cool. Another nice feature is that they made it more friendly for beginners. It has a guide that will tell you what each setting is for
column7: and walk you through it just to make sure you have things set right. Naturally
column8: this setting can be turned off for the more advanced users. They also have a few new filters and pucture options built in such as HDR art
column9: candlelight dinner
column10: fisheye lens effect
column11: etc. the fisheye lens effect is especially nice. It does a really good job of mimicking an actual fish lens. If you like the look
column12: you won't have to go out and buy the lens now. This camera also has an inhouse stabilizer option for filming
column13: which is definitely a plus. They improved the inhouse microphone since the t5
column14: but not by much. Overall
column15: would highly recommend this product."^5^Jul 19

column1: BigAnt^/canon-eos-rebel-t7i-dslr-video-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens-black/5792700?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^12^0^"Im a beginner at photography and Im learning how to shoot videos for vlogs and this was great all around camera for me. It gets the job done and the 60fps is excellent quality ."^5^Apr 21
zeldafan311^/canon-eos-rebel-t7i-dslr-video-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens-black/5792700?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^14^3^"I read endless reviews on cameras and had experience with Canon
column2: and the consensus was the T7i was a nice leap from previous Rebels with the new auto focus system and the live view (looking at the viewfinder instead of putting your eye to the eye piece) performance was the same as the view finder (so if you like to use the SLR like a cell phone there is no drawback like some other cameras). The only problem I see is I should have bought the body only since the kit lens is now a base f4
column3: which lets a little less light in than prior kit lenses at f3.5. What this does is when taking shots inside in Auto the ISO gets jacked up by the camera which can introduce a little 'noise' which you may or may not notice
column4: or causes a slower shutter speed than you might like for moving things like kids and dogs inside. The lens is fine if you like outdoor shots but for inside I wish I saved the $100 and got the body only with either the 24mm 2f2.8 Prime/fixed lens or the 'nifty fifty' 50mm f1.8 lens
column5: or the Sigma 17-50mm 2.8 lens. All those lenses let more light in for indoor shots
column6: so it just depends what you are looking to do. Also I borrowed my friend's Sony a6000 with a $350 20mm pancake lense which I felt took sharper pictures. All in all this is a good entry to mid level SLR camera that has a nice heft and the lenses are cheap (the 2 Canon lenses - 24mm and 50mm and both under $150). I also got the 55-250 f4 Telephoto zoom lens for $150 (usually $300) and it is really sharp and gives nice blur to the background.

column1: Please note that I do have some experience with cameras (just didn't want to spend too much for a knock around camera for taking pics of kids and dogs and landscapes) and if you don't like the idea of swapping out lenses and/or you are a novice this camera and lens kit are probably more of a 4.5 stars."^4^Mar 2

column2: I planned to get the T6i because it was cheaper but my friend talked me into the T7i because of the updated technology. It does not disappoint! Photos are amazing! column2: the Canon t7i packs a punch for the buck. At 24mp it shoots big clear pictures with the kit lens but excels when you put it in video mode. Shooting 1080p @ 60 fps this camera is perfect for the parent looking to get into DSLR video or makes a great gift if your child is looking to get into VLOGGING. WIth an external mic input and a folding touch screen
column3: this camera is light and slips easily into a small bag for trips to the beach
column4: museum or Disneyland. Built in Wifi and Bluetooth make transferring photos to your smart phone or desktop computer a snap or
column5: skip the middle man and upload them directly to your social media account. The T7i features 45 all cross type sensors and shoots up to 6 frames per second in photo mode perfect for shooting your childs weekend soccer match. Dual pixel autofocus and face detection make shooting video a breeze. If you're looking for a DSLR with many of the features of a higher end camera but with a lower price point then this camera is the camera for you."^4^May 18

column1: Antivirus^/canon-eos-rebel-t7i-dslr-video-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens-black/5792700?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"So lets start this review off by taking a look at the build quality of the Canon T7i. Now if youve never used a DSLR before the T7i might seem like quite a large camera
column2: but in fact compared to most DSLRs
column3: its actually quite small. Just for comparisons sake Ive a Canon 70D right here and it really makes the T7i feel very light. And to me thats a great thing. Because the T7i is a little smaller
column4: I think that this means youll be more likely to take it out with you and to take more photos. For beginners and intermediates thats a great thing. Now I used the Canon T6i a lot last year and not too much has changed on the body of the T7i.Buttons are exactly where youd want them to be and easy enough to find.

column1: Like i said in my review of the Canon 77D however
column2: I do wish the buttons were a little more pronounced because they are a little flat and hard to find when youve got your eye up to the viewfinder. At the top of the camera here youll notice that this is a little to the bigger brother the 77D. On the right the camera
column3: we have your main mode dial. Essentailyl this where you can change the different setting that you want to shoot in whether that be automatic or the manual modes. One thing youll notice is that in the T7i youre missing the mode dial lock that we saw on the 77d. This isnt a huge deal to me but its one thing to be careful with so you dont accidentally change your settings. At the top here we have a dedicated record button which is nice to see as well.

column1: So overall the build quality is nice on the T7i. Its definitely a smaller build than most DSLRs which could be a big bonus if you like to travel or walk around with a lighter camera."^5^Apr 3

Mirza^/canon-eos-5d-mark-iv-dslr-camera-body-only-black/5578523?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^31^3^"I used original 5D and 5D MkII but skipped MkIII version due to lack of updates in sensor resolution and dynamic range
column2: especially noisy shadows. I've been using Canon 6D instead for the past three years
column3: and I think that it's one of the best values in camera world. I hesitated to even try out the new 5D MkIV and was contemplating jumping ship over to Sony and their amazing a7R II. Well
column4: I can say I'm extremely glad I went with MkIV. Camera is a huge upgrade from 6D in every sense
column5: especially AF
column6: but also enormous sensor quality upgrade compared to 5D MkIII. I'm using 1DX MkII as well
column7: and I prefer 5D MkIV. Camera body is very light
column8: super responsive
column9: AF performance is on par with 1DX MkII
column10: but sensor is simply phenomenal. Dynamic range is 90% identical to Sony a7R II but you get to keep Canon's beautiful colors and skin tones. 30Mpx is plenty (I'm printing 24x36 regularly) and the files are simply beautiful. I'm not shooting lots of video
column11: but from what I've seen so far
column12: the quality is stunning. Yes
column13: 4K video is using 1.7x crop and MJPG codec is using a lot of memory card space
column14: but the quality is simply amazing. Try it
column15: you won't be disappointed. I know I'm not!"^5^Oct 28

column1: MONDOTREKKER^/canon-eos-5d-mark-iv-dslr-camera-body-only-black/5578523?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^19^0^"I am in awe of this camera! It's my first full frame DSLR camera which I selected after many hours of research. Research can drive one crazy as there's so much material (ads
column3: reviews
column4: reviewer's and personal preferences
column5: etc.) to read before making a decision about such a large purchase. Do the research though to make sure you get the right camera for you. After nearly 3 weeks in Europe I'm sure I made the right choice. Performance was flawless and operation was easy on this feature-rich camera
column6: Menus are complete
column7: concise and rational. This is hugely important as making adjustments is fast - no searching through excessive or confusing menus to find what you need. While some camera menus systems are good some are absolutely Byzantine! Canon's is
column8: IMO
column9: the best. This is also my first Canon after being a lifetime Nikon shooter. Solid construction and great materials are evident. Button layout and overall ergonomics provide me the easiest handling for a camera of this size and weight. Other cameras of this level (which were all great) just didn't seem as easy to handle or were as nimble in my hands. Not having any full frame lenses made the brand change easy for me. As is said 'One buys a camera but marries the lens system.' IMO it is difficult if not impossible to beat Canon L glass. Some reviewers did not rate this camera at the top for video performance but the few videos I experimented with looked really excellent to me. I'm not a skilled videographer so take that into account. Still shots are off the chart amazing though. The features of this camera are mind-boggling! I was able to learn a limited number of features and modes before my trip so I was able to get some amazing shots. I expect better after I've read the rest of the 600+ page owner's manual. This is a serious camera one grows into and it will remain functionally relevant for a very long time. I LOVE THIS CAMERA.."^5^May 27

column1: Guillermo^/canon-eos-5d-mark-iv-dslr-camera-body-only-black/5578523?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^14^1^"The day I got the camera was a early morning so that I could take it to Mt Hood. Right away I loved how fast it performed and tack sharp it was. I've been rolling with the canon 70d for the longest time as a amateur but later turned it from a hobby to a proffession. I watched a lot of reviews and would visit Best Buy to see which camera I would love. I checked out the Sony A7R iii and saw how many Canon users switched to Sony. But really didn't want to be apart of that group with there expensive lens
column2: plus not spend a lot to change and sell my other Canon lenses like Amy other user would. And it was to small for my not so big hands and to light
column3: which is a good thing for others but I wanted something I could have a good grip and a good weight. And I knew if I was to ever drop the Sony I wouldn't be happy. But I'm happy with the Canon 5d marl iv. And soon to be taking more beautiful photographs. The picture I posted isn't the full resolution one because I can only post a 5 mb image"^5^Aug 2

column1: FlDoc^/canon-eos-5d-mark-iv-dslr-camera-body-only-black/5578523?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^14^2^"After looking at all the online reviews I was not sure that the 5DMarkIV would be enough of an improvement over the Mark III or even over the 7D Mark II. The camera is much better that the reviews. The clarity with high ISO is remarkable. Much better than I had with the Mark III and way better than the 7D. Frames per second is very good for 30 megapixel. I have this paired with my 2.8 70-200 II and 2.8 24-70 II and the results are outstanding. Much better than I had with Mark III & 7D except for the reach on the 7D. You will absolutely love the touch screen. While the controls are very similar to previous body's I started trying the touch screen just out of habit from using smart phones. The touch screen is great. Overall great product. Could it have been better
column2: sure. Is it worth the upgrade from Mark III
column3: I certainly think so!"^5^Oct 15

column1: CvilleNeal^/canon-eos-5d-mark-iv-dslr-camera-body-only-black/5578523?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I decided to upgrade from my EOS 5D to the current model. column2: though I use Lightroom to process the pictures rather than the Canon software. I used the camera to shoot a number of pictures in Bryce at night with a full moon and the camera performed well. I used the Canon app to operate the camera in the dark which meant that I could dispense with a cable release/remote. The app is not entirely intuitive
column3: but it works well and allows you to operate the camera remotely with ease. I have had the camera for only a month
column4: but so far it has been excellent and without defect."^5^Oct 11

column1: Jason302^/canon-eos-5d-mark-iv-dslr-camera-body-only-black/5578523?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^13^26^"Hi
column2: I am a long time canon user and will continue to be. I have owned the mk3 the 6d the t3i and the t2i. I am heavily invested in canon and their glass so I was extremely excited and waited a very long time for this camera to come out.

column1: I purchased it from the local Best Buy in launch day
column2: it is a spectacular camera for stills and 1080p video. The autofocus system is excellent
column3: it's fast and even in live view it is nearly as fast as it is through the viewfinder.

column1: I also love the touch screen it makes navigating the menu and making adjustments so much quicker and you can pinch to zoom on your pictures.
I had a major problem with the 4K though
column2: the codec this camera stores it in is so huge that it was unusable on my early 2016 MacBook Pro. It would lag while watching it and even trying it edit it was nearly impossible. I'm unsure why canon went with such huge codec but I returned it because of this. It's not enough different for me to justify the expense with the 4K codec. I will just wait for the next 6d and hope the issue is resolved by then. If your looking for a great stills camera by all means get this bad boy
column3: if you have a mk3 and want a 4K upgrade its not quite there yet unfortunately"^3^Sep 11

column1: Petey^/canon-eos-5d-mark-iv-dslr-camera-body-only-black/5578523?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^17^"Not a huge upgrade from the mark iii but a very welcome one!"^5^Sep 9

bravoleader^/canon-eos-5d-mark-iv-dslr-camera-body-only-black/5578523?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^19^"Love the image quality! High ISO is really good. Menus and touch screen are excellent. Focus system is very good. Build quality is great. Pictures coming out of this camera with a Canon 70-200 F2.8 IS are breathtaking. Color rendering is very very true to real life. BEST images i've ever seen. Now for the bad news. Coming from a Nikon D800
column2: the 5D button layout is horrible. The nikon is way more friendly to the user (except for the confusing menu's in nikon). Canons menus are much much better. However
column3: I despise the shared function of buttons on the 5D and where they are make no sense really. If i could put nikon's buttons on this camera

column1: tomasmartone^/nikon-d3500-dslr-video-camera-with-af-p-dx-nikkor-18-55mm-f-3-5-5-6g-vr-lens-black/6296213?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^2^"Had the D3400 for about two years and love the camera
column2: so decided to get the new version
column3: which is essentially the same camera. Everything works as expected. This is a great starter camera. And
column4: Nikon does not disappoint. It has quality built into it. An added feature is that it now has wireless. But
column5: for the most part
column6: this is essentially the D3400
column7: with a few tweaks. So
column8: this review is basically for both cameras... The D3500 (or D3400) has a lot of great features. I prefer to use the Raw files
column9: but you can get a lot of excellent photos using the Effects button. If you have PhotoShop
column10: you can do similar later on
column11: but if you have a good idea for visuals and don't have time for PhotoShop (or access to it)
column12: I recommend giving the Effects a try. I've gotten some 'Wow' shots using it and the only downside is that they are jpg only (not raw)
column13: so what you see is what you get. Other than that
column14: this is a good
column15: dependable camera that will not disappoint
column16: and it will provide years of reliable use if taken care of. Here's a photo that I just took today. Just a quick basic shot..."^5^Feb 28

column1: Andrew^/nikon-d3500-dslr-video-camera-with-af-p-dx-nikkor-18-55mm-f-3-5-5-6g-vr-lens-black/6296213?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"Recently purchased 2 of these cameras for the girlfriend and I. Bought this and the kit that included the large zoom lense.

Advice Id give is to skip the more expensive kit with the zoom lense and use the saved money on a 50mm fixed lense if your using it for an all around camera. The 300mm lense has no vibration reduction so a tripod is recommended.
Attached is a photo I took with my D3500 with 50mm lense."^5^Aug 16

column1: ODH3^/nikon-d3500-dslr-video-camera-with-af-p-dx-nikkor-18-55mm-f-3-5-5-6g-vr-lens-black/6296213?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^6^"I actually bought this as a B-roll camera for some location video
column2: and as the base DSLR in Nikon's lineup it has some significant limitations especially for video. The lack of a microphone input is a bummer
column3: and I miss having a Manual-Auto Focus switch on the kit lens
column4: but having said that
column5: the autofocus is much quieter than a similar but older Nikon 18-55 zoom I have. And since I record audio separately anyway (as anyone doing quality audio would) the lack of a mic input is not that big of a deal. For still photography it's really terrific quite light and small
column6: with some very intuitive automatic modes. And I LOVE the ability to override autofocus with a quick grab of the focus ring. Even at full price it's a great value
column7: but when you get it on sale it's a steal. One more thing: the face-tracking focus is really effective!"^5^Jan 11

column1: D3500^/nikon-d3500-dslr-video-camera-with-af-p-dx-nikkor-18-55mm-f-3-5-5-6g-vr-lens-black/6296213?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Good entry level DSLR

column1: I'm disappointed that the ML-L3 IR remote that works with most Nikon DSLRs doesn't work with this one. iflymaui^/canon-eos-rebel-sl3-dslr-4k-video-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens/6346259?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^0^"I carry a camera constantly. Along with high-end lenses (Canon L-Series).
I travel for a living so I always have the camera engaged in my travels; both business and personally.
I have a Canon 6D Mark ll body and a Canon 5d Mark iV body. Both are stunning cameras but heavy.

Along comes Canon's SL3. Still a SLR but at a fraction of the price. Made of plastic. Made in Taiwan. Lightweight (sometimes even cheap). I disliked Canon's SL1 and SL2 models so I'm very impressed that their SL3 is such a performer.
SPECS can be found on Canon's website if you're looking for details. However
column2: I first want to add that this camera has Canon's fast-performance DIGIC 8 processor. For reasons unknown
column3: Canon introduced the DIGIC 8 on the SL3. It's a 2019 processor of high speed and amazing performance. Expect no shutter lag
column4: no lighting issues and when paired with a good-quality SD card (I use 300MB SD cards from SanDisk)
column5: the camera does everything you could expect of a $1500-$2500 body for basic shooting.

column1: It's underpriced. It's a value for certain.
What I do dislike about it is the inferior lens that comes with the camera when you buy the KIT VERSION. It's a plastic
column2: cheaply designed and low performance starter lens. It is a EF-S lens but the SL3 will take both EF and EF-S lenses. Thankfully I have many EF L-Series lenses and it's a much better camera when using a quality lens.

column1: Very impressive SLR from Canon."^4^May 10

Greauxe^/canon-eos-rebel-sl3-dslr-4k-video-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens/6346259?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"This tiny DSLR is just a little chunkier than a small mirrorless camera and gives some unique alternatives. You can shoot it as a DSLR with a nice
column2: clear optical viewfinder with 9 focusing points or you can shoot it as a 'mirrorless' camera using the back screen which gives you many more focus point
column3: eye AF and Canon's legendary Dual Pixel Auto Focus that smoothly acquires focus without hunting back and forth. For video people
column4: you can clean HDMI output to an external recorder and get 4:2:2 10 bit at 4k! The new Canon 90D doesn't have this feature according to the specs. The battery life is unbelievably good and will outlast ANY mirrorless camera by far. THE BAD: 4K looks great but is not very flexible in as much as you have only 23.98P and no DPAF! Rolling shutter is pretty bad in 4K. Also
column5: 4K has an additional crop so you'll really need a wide lens for it to be useable. This camera has two levels of electronic image stabilization which works with Canon's optically stabilized lens but crops your video further still! The sensor is really clean and almost free of noise at 6400 ISO and is very useable up to 12
column6: 800 with level one high ISO noise reduction turned on. I didn't see any improvement from 1
column8: or 3 in terms of in-camera NR. The SL3 has a setting that makes the camera take 4 photos every time you press the shutter which it samples and then produces a single noise-free The creative filters are actually really handy and in some cases can provide a more interesting photo than even the most experienced photographer could take.  It has focus-peaking for manual focus or focus-pulling and the autofocus on the back screen does an incredible job following faces or whatever your subject is
column9: keeping them in focus."^5^Aug 30

column1: TugboatWilly^/canon-eos-rebel-sl3-dslr-4k-video-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens/6346259?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Ive been getting by with  the top shelf point and shoot cameras since finally(almost permanently) stepping away from my beloved 35mm.  Ive taken some wonderful pictures with those cameras and will always keep one for the sheer convenience.  It has to be said though
column2: that these cameras will always be limited by their lenses or rather their lack of options.  That was my main reason for stepping back into the SLR realm.

column1: I chose the SL3 because it looked to be a good step as a DSLR while maintaining many of the features Ive become comfortable with in the point and shoots.  I had a done a lot of research on it predecessor the SL2 and went to look at it and was told that the SL3 had just been released so I snatched one up.  Its very easy to use and will actually tutor you as you use it.  Gives helpful suggestions but you can turn those off if youd rather not.  Has a good Auto focus and in the full automatic setting it is consistent.
I would recommend not buying the kit with the 18/55 mm lens.  Buy the body and go an extra few hundred bucks for a better lens.  The kit lens feels cheap but does an adequate job.  Its very plastic.
All in all
column2: its a good buy and easy
column3: step into DSLRs.  Priced under 600.00
column4: its hard to beat and Canon packed all of its latest and greatest features into it."^4^Jul 20

column4: the image processing chip and image sensor itself is fantastic! It certainly is not a top-end camera but it provides images that can rival them. There are certainly a few things I do not like but not enough for me to knock off stars. column5: it simply is not that big of a deal to me. Overall this camera is a gem and at a great price point. You can spend a lot less but not get a body that is as sturdy or reliable. The power zoom accessory takes some getting used to though. column1: MaltBalls^/canon-eos-80d-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-135mm-lens-video-creator-kit-black/5446701?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I did a lot of research on digital cameras with solid video recording capabilities. This is my first non-point-&-shoot camera
column2: so all the tech specs were a bit overwhelming. One thing I promised myself is that I wasn't going to buy a DSLR as a point-&-shooter; I needed to actually use all the bells & whistles.

column1: I've only used the camera for a couple of weeks. I took it on a wildlife cruise - along with the manual. I took a few hours to read the manual to understand what this camera could do. I then went out the next day on a great whale watching adventure and got some great shots. I absolutely love the continuous shutter feature. I ended up with lots of shots I need to delete
column2: but I also captured 'the' shot I was looking for in each instance.

column1: I still haven't taken any serious videos with it yet
column2: but I suspect I will be pleased with the results. I've got a couple of photography books I'm going to work through to become more proficient with this camera. I'm excited I now have a tool to help me up my photo/video game."^5^Mar 11

column1: princeton^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-two-lens-kit-with-18-55mm-and-70-300mm-lenses-black/6346180?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^1^"I own two Canon 35mm SLR cameras (A-1 and AE-1) for over 40 years.    Decided to go digitally and purchased the Nikon this time
column2: because my daughter purchased a similar Nikon kit as we can share lenses.

column1: Took this camera on a trip to Alaska and took beautiful pics.   I particularly like the SnapBridge feature
column2: as it allowed me to immediately download the pics to my phone and laptop.   The D7500 is user friendly.

column1: The only downside is the 18-55m lens as it has a button on the outer barrel which causes confusion on the focus and lock.   I had to turn the camera off and on to reset the focus.   Perhaps I need to take a camera course at BestBuy to relearn how to use this lens properly.    This was a minor inconvenience.  The 70-300mm lens however does not have this button and is easier to work with.
Kudos to my saleswoman
column3: at the Princeton NJ BestBuy as she took the time to explain the various features and comparisons on the digital camera brand selections.   She also was extremely helpful with the explanation of features
column4: sale
column5: and preparation of the Nikon camera and recommended accessories for my vacation trip.  I will give her my future business and recommend her to family and friends who wish to purchase a camera in the future."^5^Sep 1

column1: Roirat^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-two-lens-kit-with-18-55mm-and-70-300mm-lenses-black/6346180?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"Bestbuy Modesto had a good selection of Nikon cameras on the table top that you can handle and operate. I was very impressed with the higher end cameras but stayed within budget picking a comfortable
column3: incase I do go on that Antarctic trip.

column1: The kit lenses are ideal for learning the 'how tos' and pretty much all one needs for travel
column3: wildlife
column4: portraits
column5: astrophotography
column6: family
column7: events etc. Get a 10-20mm flat wide angle lens and that would pretty much fill the gaps.

column1: Don't forget lens cleaning kit if you don't already have one and some clear protective lens filters
column2: extra battery and some high quality memory cards."^5^Aug 23

column1: FactObserver^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-two-lens-kit-with-18-55mm-and-70-300mm-lenses-black/6346180?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"My wife and I jumped back into photography as a hobby by buying this camera and lens package. We are so glad we did. The D7500 with the included lenses (we need to adjust our cropping thinking) is almost totally flexible like a pro camera but not close to pro prices. We are getting truly clear balanced stills and maybe better than iPhone videos. Not heavy. We recommend it highly for an every day every situation shooter - the perfect bring along camera. Note - there is a learning curve with these dslrs. And we transfer photos by removing the memory card and inserting it into our Mac - simple."^4^Jun 1

column3: I would mention

column1: Maureen^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-two-lens-kit-with-18-55mm-and-70-300mm-lenses-black/6346180?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^2^"I bought this camera for my son as a gift for his graduation. Cindy^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-two-lens-kit-with-18-55mm-and-70-300mm-lenses-black/6346180?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^4^"I bought this and bought a filter for it but it did not fit. So I had to drive another 40 miles for another one because it was the wrong one"^4^Jun 23

Andrew^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-two-lens-kit-with-18-55mm-and-70-300mm-lenses-black/6346180?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^26^"This seemed like a good starter set so I bought it with the intent to photograph birds on my proprety and at city parks. After receiving it I saw that the lenses are very low quality. Many pictures
column2: even those not taken in direct sunlight
column3: suffered from chromatic aberration to the point many birds I photographed had glowing blue and purple wings. Even those in shadow on my deck inexplicably glowed to the point I could either spend hours re-touching countless pictures in Photoshop or just be left with a poor quality picture. My $120 Canon point and shoot from 2015 takes better pictures in this regard because it does not produce this color fringing.

column1: I also had a lot of difficulty getting the auto-focus to work correctly. There are a multitde of tracking options but it seemed regardless of what I chose the camera had difficulty recognizing the bird from the background scenery and the bird ended up out of focus. Most pictures came out blurry to varying degrees
column2: to the point where even a duck sitting still in the middle of the pond was fuzzy. Not all this can be blamed on the auto-focus but also speaks to the low quality of the lenses.

column1: Lastly
column2: this is a full DSLR with a ton of menu options and configurations. The instructions are less than helpful because they only tell you a feature exists
column3: not how to use it or what exactly it can even do in some cases. I had to end up watching videos and tutorials online but still found it very complicated to get the right balance of shutter speed
column4: aperature
column5: ISO
column6: and metering system to produce a decent quality image. This camera can in theory shoot at 1/8000th of a second
column7: which for birds sounds amazing
column8: but upon trying it all my pictures came out almost entirely black. To compensate you have to crank the ISO to absurd levels and that introduces too much grain and noise for the picture to be usable. Even at 1/2500th speed the quality takes a hit as other factors need to be changed to let enough light in. Instead of going fully manual you can set one factor and let the camera auto calibrate the others for best results
column9: but even with that most were too dark or too light because it mis-judged them and gave me an unusable image. Considering I mainly bought it to take pictures of birds which are very active and do not remain sitting still on a branch for more than a few seconds I don't have time to be fumbling with the settings and reconfiguring the values until I get the right combination. Auto-focus and other adjustments need to work immediately and that was the biggest failing of this camera aside from the horrid color fringing issues
column10: which admittedly I think are mainly the fault of the lens. I used the 70-300mm one which I believe retails for $400 alone. I'm honestly surprised for that price the quality was so bad.

column1: What I'm saying is this is NOT a beginner friendly DSLR and the picture quality from these bundled kit lenses was not greatly better than my previously mentioned point and shoot
column2: and in many cases worse. If you have a kid that puts this on their Christmas list think twice about it
column3: because even though the camera itself is probably decent
column4: it's going to be severely held back by these included lenses. You're better off buying the camera alone and spending much
column5: much more money on better quality lenses
column6: but at what cost? I only got this because it was a bargain on sale at $999 but was not even worth that price. Best Buy forced me to pay $150 just to return it
column7: which I find absurd since I had returned another bad camera to them in 2015 for free (also Nikon btw). I feel scammed but paid just to be done with the aggravations this camera brought me and losing $150 is better than wasting $1000 on something I'll never want to use again. Very upset Best Buy changed their camera return policy and will doubtful be buying from them again since I lost a lot of money buying this product."^1^Jun 2

The only drawback for me is the 6.5 fps as I do a lot of fast action
column3: thus

column1: MEKELLY00^/canon-eos-6d-mark-ii-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/5959400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"I still own the previous version of this camera body. At the time it was a HUGE step up from my aging crop-sensor 50D. Full frame brought me back to my 35mm roots and I'm loving it. Canon made a number of improvements on this second version of the 6D. For starters
column2: Auto focus points.... MUCH more on this camera. Is it more than the 5D MK IV? No
column3: but still it has (45) of them and they are cross-type. I would have preferred that they were not so clustered together
column4: and that Canon would have spread them out more over the viewing area
column5: but still a huge much needed and welcome step up. There is a considerable bump in image size from 20.6 to 26.2 but nothing to get overly excited about there. There are complaints from a lot of pro reviewers and and tech outlets that the 6D Mk II has a very limited dynamic range. Well
column6: if it does I am not seeing it. I put the camera to the test with some low key lighting setups right out of the gate
column7: and it has not disappointed me yet. There are a couple of sample images attached for review. So
column8: unless you are shooting in some horrendous conditions and you don't know how to compensate
column9: I really don't think Dynamic range should be too much of a concern. I was also wanting more FPS (frames per second)
column10: and this MkII doubles that compared to the 6D. Up from 3 FPS to 6.5 FPS. So great improvement there. Lots of complaints and hemming and hawing about the lack of 4k video capability on this camera as well..... BIG DEAL! Its made to be a feature limited full frame pro-am camera anyways... what did you expect? On the plus side Canon did give us auto focus tracking on the Mk II which they did not have on the 6D Mk I. So when you do decide to shoot some video the auto focus automatically tracks your subject without you having to manually refocus all the time. The flip out screen I was on the fence about
column11: but I like it for a couple of reasons. One
column12: you can flip it over when the camera isn't in use to protect the screen from getting all scratched up. Two
column13: it's kinda handy when shooting at extremely awkward angles. The touch screen I don't really care for. I could do without it
column14: but it is nice to be able to jump to a completely different part of the in camera menu without having to scroll through all of the headers to get where you want. There are a couple of the things that are annoying me at present. I can't get this camera to auto rotate my images. I don't mind turning the camera to the side to see my portrait images full screen. I just wish it would do that itself. My bigger issue is Canon felt the need to over complicate HSS (High Speed Sync) on this camera body. It should just work. I use HSS capable off camera studio strobes
column15: but the HSS feature doesn't work for some reason. It works fine on my original 6D MK I
column16: but on the Mk II I need to setup HSS on the in camera menu
column17: and I keep getting an error message saying that my flash is not compatible even though it is listed as a compatible device. So maybe an update on that later.

column1: In closing
column2: this camera is a beast of an upgrade if you are coming from a 6D MK I or lower. If you are contemplating spending some extra cheddar on the 5D MK IV
column3: consider the following....

column1: All you are really getting for that $1600 is 4k video capability
column2: 20 more auto focus point that are more spread out
column3: slightly better dynamic range
column4: 1.5 FPS faster continuous shooting
column5: and a small resolution bump.

column1: If that's worth $1600.00 then go for that big rig and tear it up
column2: but if not this camera is definitely suited for professional and by no means should be considered and 'entry level camera for beginners'."^4^Apr 29

column1: MM135^/canon-eos-6d-mark-ii-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/5959400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"As an owner of the original 6D I was happy when the Mark ii was announced. After getting many bad reviews

JCinBTV^/canon-eos-6d-mark-ii-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/5959400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I just received my 6D II yesterday.  I am impressed
column3: when I saw the thickness of the owner's manual I almost had heart failure!  It's over an inch thick!  But...it's in three languages so that explained a lot.  *Whew*  I immediately charged the battery and took some test shots.  Totally impressed.  The experts may not be too crazy about the 6D II but I am!  I upgraded from my trusty 40D and I am not sorry I did.  I use two L series lenses:  24-70 f/2.8 and a 70-200 f/2.8.  The 6D II will make those lenses shine even more.

column1: The attached images were taken with the 6D II with the Canon 24-70mm f/2.8 L lens-hand held with only available lighting.  Aperture priority setting and auto ISO.  RAW converted to .jpg with Photoshop Lightroom.

TAKE NOTE!:  RAW images taken with cameras manufactured after 12/2017 are no longer compatible with most older Apps and/or programs.  My LR 4.0 could not read the RAW images taken by the 6D II.  You will/may need to upgrade.  I had to forsake my trusty LR 4.0 and became a paying member of Adobe's Creative Cloud family.  I chose to download just Lightroom.  $9.99/month plus applicable taxes.  There are some work-arounds but I chose to simply upgrade.
For some
column2: not having 4K video may be an issue.  Did not matter to me as I seldom use video.

column1: This WILL be a great upgrade to an enthusiast's full-frame.  I still have lots to read and learn about the 6D II so I just may be adding to this review.  Enjoy!!"^5^Oct 19

column1: trs0722^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/5852906?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^43^3^"I picked up the D7500 over the weekend. I haven't put it through all of its paces yet. I may come back to update this later. But I figured I'd put some quick thoughts together for anyone on the fence. I've been using a D7100 for a few years and so far the D7500 is definitely worth the upgrade. I have already noticed a big difference in image quality and speed
column2: things that are very important to me. I have not tested it with all my lenses and flash. The autofocus has been very good although it's not the same as with the D500. I have yet to test out running children/dogs in AF-C to see how the focus does. I also haven't done extensive low light testing but the few that I took around 800-1600 ISO looked really good.

column1: Some things you should be aware of...these are not necessarily 'cons' to me but they may be for you:
1. Adobe and Apple have not released updates for this camera yet. Therefore
column2: Photoshop and Lightroom will not import or process the files yet (JPG or RAW). Video files were recognized by my computer and LR5 though. There are workarounds via free software but it's more time consuming. These may be a disruption to your normal work flow as it has been to mine. Hopefully these updates will be out soon as they normally do.

column1: 2. The top window is noticeably smaller than the D7xxx series. However
column2: the shutter speed and aperture # are prominent and fairly big. The other info is squeezed closer together and a few things are missing (i.e. file type). But it's all there on the bigger info screen on the rear.

column1: 3. You cannot put a battery grip on it.
4. There is only one SD card slot.
5. Battery life is supposed to be a little shorter than the D7100/7200.
But again there are some good pros:
1. Best crop frame sensor available now by Nikon
2. Noticeably lighter than the D7100/7200
3. Better in low light than D7100/7200
4. Touch screen functions
5. Can send pics via wi-fi to your phone.
I've read a lot about the D500
column2: which the D7500 is sort of the baby brother of. That thing is a beast that can compete with some of Nikon's full frame cameras. However
column3: it's not for me and I suspect many other people: it is big
column4: fairly heavy
column5: and approaching the cost of a full frame camera. It also only has one SD slot (I don't use the other type it has) and doesn't have a built in flash. Yes
column6: built in flash isn't always the best but I'd rather have it than not. For those of us not wanting or needing the D500 or an entry level FF
column7: the D7500 is a no brainer. An alternative is to wait and see what Nikon does with the updates for the D750
column9: and D810
column10: which may be coming soon. It's possible the cost of FF bodies will come down. However
column11: I for one
column12: am not ready for that leap yet and think the D7500 will serve me well for years to come. Hopefully
column13: I don't eat these words once I put it through more testing as my workflow is restored."^5^Jun 19

column1: jmz48^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/5852906?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^20^1^"After using NIKON D7000 for five years it is like changing to Ferrari...
Can not find anything to complain about. New 180K-pixel metering sensor proves to be the real technical advance. It is better then I was expecting. Would buy it again."^5^Jun 8

column1: BirdmanofVA^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/5852906?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^3^"First a background... I am a Pentaxian and will always be a Pentaxian. I love my Pentax DSLRs. I wanted to try Nikon so I purchased the D7500 at Best Buy. Overall
column2: I think it's a great camera. I own the top of the line professional Pentax DSLR (the K-1)so I will not compare it with the mid-level Nikon D7500. But just looking and using this camera for what it is
column3: it's pretty solid. I paired it with a Nikon 200-500mm VR lens. Yes ithe D7500 only has one SD card slot..so what. It's not a deal breaker
column4: takes 10 secs to place a new SD card. So it has far less shots it can take with the fully charged En-EL15a battery than the Nikon D7200..solution: purchase a back-up battery. So it has only 20MP vs a Nikon D7200...who cares. End of the day
column5: no one will notice it. Buy the Nikon D7500
column6: you will love it."^5^Jul 4

column1: 1987^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/5852906?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^0^"Purchased on the first day it was available in stores and couldn't be more pleased. Upgraded from an entry-level Nikon DSLR which I found to be a nice camera
column2: but I needed more speed to keep up with my sons' swimming. I considered the D500 for its speed (10 fps)
column3: but decided the D7500's speed (8 fps) was more than sufficient

column5: who doesn't like having the newest thing available?"^5^Jun 30

column1: trs0722^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/5852906?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^3^"I bought this a week or two after it was released as an upgrade to my D7100. While the D7100 has been great
column2: the D7500 is a very worthy upgrade. I considered the D500
column3: the D750
column4: and waiting for Nikon's new full frame releases but ultimately decided crop frame is still right for me at this point. The D7500 is basically the little brother of the D500
column5: which (from what I've read) is incredible and bumped the D7200 as Nikon's new top crop frame camera. However for me
column6: the D500 was too big
column7: lacked a pop up flash
column8: and was almost the same cost as some of their FF cameras.

column1: Pros:

1. New sensor (same as the D500). The colors and sharpness are excellent...noticeably better than my D7100. The noise and autofocus are considerably better too. There's also a new group focus point option and auto fine tune that I'm still experimenting with.
2. Lighter and slightly smaller than the D7100. Much easier to carry around.
3. It's FAST!....much faster than my D7100.
4. Rear touch screen that also tilts...comes in handy. Had that in my first DSLR (D5100) and it's nice having it back

5. 4K video and wi-fi/bluetooth. Haven't taken full advantage of 4K video yet but even the 1080 looks better than my D7100. I can now upload pics if I want on the fly (takes a few steps but great option to have). To save battery I leave it on airplane mode until I want to upload.
Cons:

The main con for me is that the D7500 only has one SD slot. I loved having an extra slot in the D7100...mostly only as a back up when I left my main one in my computer. I only used the 2nd slot during a shoot a few times in 3 years. So
column2: now I have to be more aware of where my card is or keep extras in my bag or vehicle. I've seen complaints about this but many countered (and I agree) saying that 2nd slot rarely
column3: if ever
column4: 'saved' a shoot when the first card went bad.

column1: Others have complained that you cannot put a battery grip on it. This was not a big deal for me. Nikon also dropped the total megapixels and reduced the monitor resolution from the D7200 and D500. These changes will not even be noticeable to most users.
The last thing to consider is some editing programs (Lightroom and Photoshop in particular) have not added this camera profile to their software yet. Therefore
column2: they will not recognize the NEF's or JPG's from this camera. This has been an inconvenience for me b/c to view and edit my photos
column3: I've had to open the RAW files in Nikon Capture NXD (which is free)
column4: convert them to TIFFs
column5: and then import into Lightroom where I can then work on the files. It usually takes Adobe some time (a month or two) to do this so I expect an update to be coming soon."^5^Jul 15

column1: BobW^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/5852906?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"Love the features. Looking forward to taking to the Holy Land to shoot in low light conditions in Churches. Lighter and sharp images. Fast."^5^Jun 30

It's lighter and has a little better grip than the D7200. The pictures are vibrant and sharp. The different functions are setup in a logical way. The tilting
column2: touch screen is a real boon. Allow yourself some time and patience to learn all of what it does and it does a lot. column1: RBrylawski^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/5852906?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I've been a Nikon shooter since before digital. Nothing in my humble opinion compares to Nikon. This camera replaced my Nikon D7100
column2: which is still a very capable camera
column3: but the D7500 is several steps ahead. With fewer (but larger pixels)
column4: this camera shoots with stunning clarity. It's faster with 8 FPS continuous and the inclusion of what makes the top end D500 such a great camera
column5: is also shared with the D7500. I love how this camera weighs fractionally less than the D7100
column6: but has a more weather sealed body and the inclusion of an articulated screen is a nice addition. This camera sacrifices one memory card slot
column7: but with memory so inexpensive these days
column8: a 128 GB card will hold more photos than I could possibly take at one time. It's also a great addition that this camera is fully Bluetooth and Wifi enabled and communicates easily to Nikon apps to quickly and seamlessly transfer your pictures to your mobile device.

column1: This is a great addition to the Nikon lineup and is perfect for someone who is looking for something that will challenge their creative abilities more than the less expensive gear
column2: but won't break the bank like their top end gear."^5^Dec 22

column1: Knight86^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/5852906?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"At first I could not decide between the 7200 and 7500 but after getting this camera I will say its worth the money. JohnK^/nikon-d7500-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/5852906?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Moved up from a D5500 and am enjoying the additional 3 frames per sec (to 8)
column2: better high-iso performance in lower light and additional ability to access frequently used functions more quickly. The negatives most commonly cited (single card slot & no vertical grip) were not issues for me. Also

column5: I seem to be getting 1 or 2 stops of additional ISO performance to get images of comparable noise & 'quality' (just my unscientific observations). If you're looking to upgrade from a d3xxx or d5xxx series
column6: it'll definitely be worth it. If you already have a d7200

column1: smfitch^/nikon-d5600-dslr-camera-with-af-p-dx-nikkor-18-55mm-f-3-5-5-6g-vr-lens-black/5715101?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^0^"We purchased this camera as an upgrade to our extremely old D80. The first thing I noticed is how light the camera was compared to our old one. It's also a bit smaller. Not exactly pocket size
column2: but not a burden to carry around.

column1: The settings are easy to understand
column2: and you can see the settings on the LDC screen. Speaking of the LCD screen
column3: it's nice feature is being able to flip out
column4: around and upside down. Basically can be at any angle (to allow you to take pictures behind that giant of a man standing in front of you).

column1: But the best feature has to be the Snapbridge. This allows you to link your phone to the camera via bluetooth. As you take that perfect picture with your camera
column2: it'll sync up with your phone moments later. You can then immediately post that perfect picture on your favorite social media.

column1: My only complaint is that snapbridge is a bit finicky. It's saying it won't connect
column2: then moments later it's connected. Can't figure out when or why. Otherwise
column3: it's a great camera that takes incredible pictures.

column1: Oh
column2: and just to give my background-i'm an extreme novice when it comes to taking pictures. I really don't know the difference between an ISO/Aperture or shutter. But when I use the camera settings based on day/night/auto the pictures look great."^5^Jul 19

column1: ailurus^/canon-eos-90d-dslr-camera-body-only-black/6373125?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"Wasn't too surprised when my old Canon 60D finally gave up after almost daily use over 8+ years. column2: sticking with latest version in the line made sense. Handling is virtually identical (but feels more solid and smooth) with a couple controls moved and added
column3: so the transition was easy. A minor thing
column4: but the shutter/mirror mechanism seems quieter and more 'substantial' sounding. With the 33 megapixel sensor (vs 18MP in the 60D)
column5: image quality is a very noticeable step up (as are the file sizes). Much higher frame rate (10 fps) is nice to have available.  I don't shoot much video but the 90D offers a lot more flexibility for that when I might need it. All in all
column6: a more capable camera in a familiar package and very happy upgrading to the latest."^5^Nov 25

ADMonty^/canon-eos-90d-dslr-camera-body-only-black/6373125?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^4^"In a head to head comparison EOS 90D to 7D MK-II after much testing at ISO 100
column4: same Tamron Lens
column5: same focal length
column6: same Time value
column7: with VC enabled and a constant architectural subject
column8: it is my conclusion that the Canon 90D has about twice as much noise as the Canon 7D MK-II when images are enlarged in PS CC to 200% and more.  At 100% (normal) magnification
column9: the noise difference is perceptible but doesnt distract from the overall image quality
column10: making the 90D a good camera at the price point for the casual photographer.  I personally like the color saturation of the 7D MK-II but thats a personal choice and easily adjusted in PS on 90D images.  Bells and whistles the 90D has it all over the 7D MK-II.  Conclusion: for the Professional the 7D MK-II wins hands down.  For the amateur or aspiring Pro the 90D is a good entry point.  In retrospect
column11: were money not an issue when I got into digital
column12: full-frame is the way to go and despite its age my choice would be the Canon EOS 5D MK-IV
column13: but my lens investment keeps me with Canon APSC sensor EOS-S lens mount systems.  I tried adaptors but constant lens focal ratcheting
column14: even when not actively focusing
column15: proved a disqualifier.  The GOOD rating is a little generous because of the noise issue
column16: which for me is a BIG issue in my photography"^4^Nov 24

Camerabug^/nikon-d5600-dslr-camera-body-only-black/5715100?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"OK Im going to cut to the chase and list some built points for the features I like and the others I wont use. I like and have enjoyed this camera
column2: the reason for 4 stars is the wifi feature. If they just left it off and included IR remote shoot I would rate it 5 stars.

column1: Pros:
I wanted a camera easier to use with manual mode
column2: this works. The command diel on the top of the camera is easy to use.

column1: The large screen makes it easy to review shoots for sharpness
column2: composure and make sure you have the shoot you want. If you do not want the screen to illuminate
column3: leave it reversed. The touch screen makes it easy and faster to change settings and mode.

column1: Pictures are very sharp
The size and weight of this model works for me. Lighter and smaller than most.
Auto focus is fast and accurate
I like the live view better than I thought I would. I find situations where you cannot frame a shoot otherwise. It is good for close ups of flowers where you need to be low to the ground.
Cons:
Not impressed with the wifi features and the fact they choose to leave off the IR remote shoot. Im just going to bundle all of the wifi features into one and say
column2: Nikon could have invested there time and money in a better way."^4^Jul 18

column1: Reggi803^/nikon-d5600-dslr-camera-body-only-black/5715100?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"I just bought this camera before the arrival of a new Grand child but I didn't get many pictures due to clarity issues. Of coarse
column2: in the hospital they ask that you turn the flash off which I did and the pictures still came out but almost too bright and this made the pictures kind of blurred. Maybe it's my fault but this is my third Nikon DSLR camera and although I am not much more than an point and shoot photographer this is the first camera that gave me these issues. I will work with it and see if I can master it but it does upset me some that I had to rely on other people to share pictures they took with their phones when I spent so

column1: much on the camera just for this event. Others may not have this problem I will have to look at more reviews since there just might be a problem with this one camera and not all cameras from this model."^4^Aug 18
Remy^/nikon-d5600-dslr-camera-body-only-black/5715100?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"I understand that this isn't a full frame camera
column2: which is most coveted by a professional
column3: but this camera has proven to be not just an immense upgrade from my D5300 but a solid choice for anyone looking to up their photography from a cell phone or lower level camera.

column1: This 24MP sensor is still as sharp and clean as ever
column2: especially without the anti-aliasing filter (also known as a low pass filter) on it. That filter is meant to take out moire but at this resolution
column3: it's absolutely not needed and the improvement is clear. Cropping down and sharing to any social media shows no real degradation of quality so if your shot is slightly off and you need to straighten or crop in
column4: you have room to do so.

column1: Burst shooting is immensely improved compared to my old D5300 with what feels like a faster burst rate and a far larger buffer
column2: allowing for more shots to be taken in succession. The readiness of live view is also a MASSIVE improvement
column3: going from shot to shot. In the D5300
column4: if you take a shot in live view
column5: it'd take a good 4-5 seconds before it's ready for another shot. Now
column6: it's more like 1-2 seconds. In comparison
column7: it feels instantaneous. I prefer using the optical view finder
column8: but those low shots are very easy to get to with the flip out screen and live view activated.

column2: the SnapBridge app is immensely approved compared to previous utilities. Once tethered via Bluetooth
column3: and/or Wi-Fi
column4: it also automatically geo-tags pictures as you shoot. It can also move over full size JPEGs and not just 1.2MP versions of the shots you take. RAW transfer to a phone or iPad will require a physical connection. Good news is that it now uses micro USB vs. a proprietary connector!

column1: The grip is deep and easy to handle
column2: the touch screen is responsive and bright
column3: battery life leaves nothing to be desired but I do recommend you only get extra batteries by Nikon ONLY
column4: no third parties. Bonus: the touch screen can be used to select your focus point when you're shooting in single point AF mode.

column1: In all
column2: it's a great value and there should be no hesitation in purchasing. If you're getting this from scratch
column3: get the package with the 18-140mm lens and the Nikon 35mm f1.8 lens to get yourself started. Best investment you can take to take your photography to the next level."^5^Nov 9

column1: Enough about the app

column1: Edward^/canon-eos-rebel-t7i-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens-video-creator-kit-black/5886203?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^3^"This bundle might seem appealing for anyone who is interested in picking up photography and videography. The camera is easy to operate
column2: but it does have a learning curve if you are new to DSLR cameras. The camera is definitely worth checking out! However
column3: beware of the Rode Go mic included in the bundle because it is defective. Rode is aware of this problem
column4: but they aren't doing much to fix it. The microphone is notoriously known for picking up lots of interference from Wi-Fi. So
column5: if you plan on using it near any device that uses WiFi then tough luck because you are going to get video footage that is unusable! The Rode Go will pick up interference which sounds like a thumping/clinking sound and is nearly impossible to get rid of this in post-production. Depending on where you live
column6: you might have to pay a restocking fee to return the bundle. Therefore
column7: just save yourself from this and buy something else. There are solutions to fixing the mic's defect
column8: but why go though the trouble to fix it when you can get something that will work perfectly fine from the start. Check out the photo to see the fix !"^3^May 30

column1: SnapshotJay^/canon-eos-rebel-t7i-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens-video-creator-kit-black/5886203?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"The Canon EOS Rebel 7i is absolutely the best camera in it's price range. column1: djh2000^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-with-af-s-nikkor-24-120mm-f-4g-ed-vr-lens-black/8753767?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^4^"I love this camera and recommend it to anyone looking for a FX based body. I am still getting to know the camera but there are so many resources out there to help you get the needed knowledge. I am struggling with the video in terms of keeping focus on a moving object but I am thinking that it's just a matter of learning the camera and it's focus features. Bestbuy did a great job at the time with a few bonus extras and I also get the $ back in points so they were the best choice for me. I suggest buying the camera from a good known source such as BB as I hear lots of nightmares buying unknowably international versions for less in the US at other online retailers. I for one want to be able to get support should I have any issues with the camera. I have heard some chatter about lens flair when shooting towards the sun (why would you do this anyway?) but I have not seen this happen while using the camera so far. I think folks that bring this up either do not own it or maybe have a Cannon and are jealous maybe?
PROS - Size compared to other FX bodies
CONS - Price
column2: but hey you get what you pay for :)"^5^Jan 12

column1: David^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-with-af-s-nikkor-24-120mm-f-4g-ed-vr-lens-black/8753767?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^17^4^"The Nikon D750 is an incredible camera. From build specs to image quality
column2: there are incredibly few cameras that can beat it especially at this price point. I've had it for approximately three days now
column3: and this is my real world review.

column1: Before I start my review
column2: I would to point out if one is going to shell out over $2
column3: 000 for a camera
column4: one should be aware that this not a camera for beginner photographers. Yes
column5: there is an auto mode and other scene modes. Yes
column6: it is a professional camera built into a semi-pro body. But to bring out the full potential and appreciate the depth of this camera
column7: one should have an in depth knowledge of photography. With that said
column8: here begins my review.

column1: Build/Handling:

The Nikon D750 is a sturdily built with a mixture of carbon fiber and magnesium alloy. Carbon fiber is an incredibly strong material and will not yield unless put underneath incredible pressure. Rest assured knowing the camera body will not crack if you accidentally bump a wall with it. The articulating screen is also well protected and for people worried about the cable breaking with the screen out
column2: Nikon has taken special steps to ensure it will not unless one physically reaches in and tears it out. The handgrip is nice and deep
column3: and should fit for the bill for the majority of users. Weight wise
column4: it is very light
column5: but the 24-120mm lens is not. Know that if one attaches this lens to the body or other heavier pro grade glass
column6: the camera will tilt forward. Weather sealing is admirable on this camera
column7: and a light mist or deep cold will not affect it
column8: but try to keep out of potential downpours. There are reviews stating this camera could go out through a hurricane and survive. Maybe it will
column9: but why take the risk? Also
column10: the Nikon warranty will not cover rain damage.

column1: Image Quality:
Absolutely stunning. Even when shooting up to 12
column2: 000 ISO images were clear and crisp in both JPEG and RAW format. To get the best out this camera
column3: I would highly recommend shooting in RAW and using Lightroom or Adobe Photoshop for post processing. Colors are accurate and spot on. With good glass
column4: one will never be disappointed. I was shooting downtown in some pretty poor lighting
column5: but this camera kept up to the task especially after post processing the images. Even in bright sunlight
column6: it was very difficult to take a photo and have it be overexposed.

column1: Is this the camera for you?
I'd write about about buffer speeds
column3: video quality
column4: etc
column5: but there are scores of reviews for this camera online written by photographers who have had years more of photography experience than myself (and I have a decade). This camera is excellent for all fields of photography. It is a full frame camera
column6: and yes one will get higher quality images than an APS-C camera if the photographer knows what he or she is doing (hence not a beginner's camera). If one is willing to pay the extra money
column7: go for it. This camera is worth every penny."^5^Mar 7

column1: I shoot events as well as my kids (who are 7 and 10) and the 6.5 fps burst mode is more than enough to capture a cool sequence of movement. It's a little bit of spraying and praying but can provide a cool 3 or 4 photo sequence print that would look great on a wall.
The HD video on D750 is tack sharp
column2: clean and beautiful for your everyday family moments and gatherings. If you're a weekend wedding warrior this camera will definitely provide great looking footage
column3: however

column5: depending on your primary use you may want to consider the Canon 5D MKIII.

column4: really
