I am amazed with the performance of the camera body as well as the lens that came with it. I had been borrowing my parents camera for a few years
column2: a Nikon D3000. I did a lot of research after saving enough money to purchase my own camera
column3: and decided the Nikon D750 would be a good fit for me. I do mostly portrait work
column4: including seniors
column5: children
column6: and families.

column1: The Nikon D750 has been a dream to work with thus far. A few of the features I enjoy the most are the double memory card slots
column3: and accessibility options.

column1: Memory Card Slots:
Upgrading from a D3000 is a HUGE step. You now have capability to use 2 memory cards at the same time. This is perfect for days that you are shooting more than one family
column3: large events
column4: whatever it may be. Worrying about switching memory cards is not a concern while using this camera
column5: which resolves stress.

column1: Battery Life:
The battery is also very impressive. When purchasing the bundle from Best Buy
column2: a spare battery is included. This is a nice bonus
column3: especially since both of the batteries are very long lasting. I have shot multiple sessions in one day with the use of only one battery; at the end of the day the battery still had life left.

column1: Accessibility Options:

One of my favorite features of this camera body is the ability to switch settings with ease. Photographers are always focusing on what is in the frame and it is helpful to be able to adjust settings quickly. The settings are customizable and easy to adjust
The Nikon D750 is a great investment for photographers. The price may seem high if you are a first time photography equipment purchaser
column2: but this really is a great deal. If you are looking for a camera to take your images to the next level
column3: this is a great buy for you. Overall
column4: the camera performs very well and I am more than pleased with my purchase!"^5^Feb 9

Nean^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-with-af-s-nikkor-24-120mm-f-4g-ed-vr-lens-black/8753767?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^2^"I love the full frame capability of this camera and the wifi! Choosing between the D810 and the D750 was a hard decision! I went with the D750 for two reasons. Wifi and the ability to shoot in auto. I shoot manual 100% of the time and highly recommend it but the rest of my family doesn't. I chose that option so others could borrow my camera or for the odd time when there simply isn't enough time to get the perfect settings before the photo opportunity passes. To be completely honest
column2: it does take a bit of time to learn the entire camera. I'm a nerd
column3: and read every manual cover to cover
column4: and was still a bit confused on some of the menu choices. No worries though. There are plenty of videos out there on YouTube to help. I recommend Jared Polin with Froknowsphoto. I primarily shoot this camera while scuba diving using the Nauticam housing. I'm shooting in low light situations or even in the dark if wreck or night diving. It performs wonderfully in these conditions with dual underwater Sea and Sea YS-D2 strobes. I'm especially enjoying the exposure metering! It's not always spot on
column5: but it gives you a very close place to start. If you're comparing this camera to another camera
column6: be sure to watch YouTube videos on the subject so you can make an educated decision. I'm really happy I did!"^5^Dec 17

column1: Photomom77^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-with-af-s-nikkor-24-120mm-f-4g-ed-vr-lens-black/8753767?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^7^"This is a follow-up to my review of Sept 6
column3: describing a 'burned in image' inside the viewfinder. I will start by saying that the gentleman at the Florence
column4: Ky Best Buy store did satisfactorily resolve the problem
column5: by replacing the camera and adjusting the charge for 3 year Geek a Squad protection. But I have great concern with the warranty service provided by Best Buy.

column1: I am not a novice with a camera
column2: and have always taken extreme caution and excellent care of my cameras for more than forty years. I have always used Minolta and Sony
column3: and continue to use them today. I purchased the Nikon 750 in October
column5: and noticed the 'burn-in' in the viewfinder in September
column6: 2016. I returned the Nikon D750 to Best Buy
column7: Fields Ertel location in Cincinnati
column8: Ohio
column9: in the original box with all of the original packaging
column10: to be sent out for repair (I do not know if it was sent to an authorized Nikon repair facility or was examined by the Geek squad). After approximately 10 days
column11: I was notified that the camera was approved for replacement
column12: due to 'impact damage'
column13: which is not covered by the manufacturers warranty
column14: but WAS covered by the Geek Squad warranty
column15: which would replace the camera. The problem???? The camera was never dropped
column16: mishandled
column17: and was in perfect condition when I turned it in for repair. I am upset that I now be would be responsible for purchasing another warranty for the replacement camera at a cost of 299.00!!! My concern is that I have no recourse
column18: as the camera was not returned to Best Buy
column19: and I have no validation of the stated impact damage. I feel that the 'impact damage' statement is simply to void the manufacturers warranty. As I earlier stated
column20: the Florence
column21: Ky Best Buy store did adjust the warranty price (there has been a price drop of 200.00 on the camera since I originally purchased 11 months ago)
column22: but I have significant reservations towards any major future purchases with Best Buy due to this incident.. Lastly
column23: each email update that I received from the Geek Squad lists the phone number 1-800-433-5778
column26: etc concerning the repair. I attempted to call to obtain information
column28: the hours for this service are 7am to 11pm

column1: LuteFP^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-with-af-s-nikkor-24-120mm-f-4g-ed-vr-lens-black/8753767?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^1^"I am upgrading from the D7000
column2: and this is the perfect choice. The obvious reason for buying this camera is the full frame sensor
column3: but what I really like is that the body is only a littler larger than the D7000. I know some people think more
column4: bigger hardware makes for a more professional appearance
column5: but one of the main reasons it took me so long in life to get into DSLR cameras is the sheer bulk of the hardware. The D750 is the smallest of Nikon's full frame cameras
column6: and I like that.

column1: Aside from that
column2: the camera operates much like my D7000
column3: which is nice because it was a very easy transition
column4: I didn't have to spend weeks learning to use the camera. Of course
column5: there are many additional features
column6: some I will use
column7: many I will not. The fact is
column8: most modern higher-end DSLRs have feature-itis
column9: and I suppose some people like that.

column1: At the end of the day
column2: this camera does everything I want and so much more
column3: but above all it takes fantastic photographs. I can see the superior low-light capabilities of the full frame sensor in my images
column4: and that is ultimately why I made the leap from the D7000. This is a great camera."^5^Jul 25

iflymaui^/canon-eos-rebel-sl3-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens/6346261?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^0^"I carry a camera constantly. Along with high-end lenses (Canon L-Series).
I travel for a living so I always have the camera engaged in my travels; both business and personally.
I have a Canon 6D Mark ll body and a Canon 5d Mark iV body. Both are stunning cameras but heavy.

Along comes Canon's SL3. Still a SLR but at a fraction of the price. Made of plastic. Made in Taiwan. Lightweight (sometimes even cheap). I disliked Canon's SL1 and SL2 models so I'm very impressed that their SL3 is such a performer.
SPECS can be found on Canon's website if you're looking for details. However
column2: I first want to add that this camera has Canon's fast-performance DIGIC 8 processor. For reasons unknown
column3: Canon introduced the DIGIC 8 on the SL3. It's a 2019 processor of high speed and amazing performance. Expect no shutter lag
column4: no lighting issues and when paired with a good-quality SD card (I use 300MB SD cards from SanDisk)
column5: the camera does everything you could expect of a $1500-$2500 body for basic shooting.

column1: It's underpriced. It's a value for certain.
What I do dislike about it is the inferior lens that comes with the camera when you buy the KIT VERSION. It's a plastic
column2: cheaply designed and low performance starter lens. It is a EF-S lens but the SL3 will take both EF and EF-S lenses. Thankfully I have many EF L-Series lenses and it's a much better camera when using a quality lens.

column1: Very impressive SLR from Canon."^4^May 10

Greauxe^/canon-eos-rebel-sl3-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens/6346261?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"This tiny DSLR is just a little chunkier than a small mirrorless camera and gives some unique alternatives. You can shoot it as a DSLR with a nice
column2: clear optical viewfinder with 9 focusing points or you can shoot it as a 'mirrorless' camera using the back screen which gives you many more focus point
column3: eye AF and Canon's legendary Dual Pixel Auto Focus that smoothly acquires focus without hunting back and forth. For video people
column4: you can clean HDMI output to an external recorder and get 4:2:2 10 bit at 4k! The new Canon 90D doesn't have this feature according to the specs. The battery life is unbelievably good and will outlast ANY mirrorless camera by far. THE BAD: 4K looks great but is not very flexible in as much as you have only 23.98P and no DPAF! Rolling shutter is pretty bad in 4K. Also
column5: 4K has an additional crop so you'll really need a wide lens for it to be useable. This camera has two levels of electronic image stabilization which works with Canon's optically stabilized lens but crops your video further still! The sensor is really clean and almost free of noise at 6400 ISO and is very useable up to 12
column6: 800 with level one high ISO noise reduction turned on. I didn't see any improvement from 1
column8: or 3 in terms of in-camera NR. The SL3 has a setting that makes the camera take 4 photos every time you press the shutter which it samples and then produces a single noise-free The creative filters are actually really handy and in some cases can provide a more interesting photo than even the most experienced photographer could take.  It has focus-peaking for manual focus or focus-pulling and the autofocus on the back screen does an incredible job following faces or whatever your subject is
column9: keeping them in focus."^5^Aug 30

column1: TugboatWilly^/canon-eos-rebel-sl3-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens/6346261?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Ive been getting by with  the top shelf point and shoot cameras since finally(almost permanently) stepping away from my beloved 35mm.  Ive taken some wonderful pictures with those cameras and will always keep one for the sheer convenience.  It has to be said though
column2: that these cameras will always be limited by their lenses or rather their lack of options.  That was my main reason for stepping back into the SLR realm.

column1: I chose the SL3 because it looked to be a good step as a DSLR while maintaining many of the features Ive become comfortable with in the point and shoots.  I had a done a lot of research on it predecessor the SL2 and went to look at it and was told that the SL3 had just been released so I snatched one up.  Its very easy to use and will actually tutor you as you use it.  Gives helpful suggestions but you can turn those off if youd rather not.  Has a good Auto focus and in the full automatic setting it is consistent.
I would recommend not buying the kit with the 18/55 mm lens.  Buy the body and go an extra few hundred bucks for a better lens.  The kit lens feels cheap but does an adequate job.  Its very plastic.
All in all
column2: its a good buy and easy
column3: step into DSLRs.  Priced under 600.00
column4: its hard to beat and Canon packed all of its latest and greatest features into it."^4^Jul 20

The guide that comes with the book is pretty useless and the advanced user guide that you can download is 500 pages.  In the automatic mode it took all pictures at f stop 4.5 or 5 so there was very little depth of field."^3^Jul 17
tower41photography^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^131^10^"This is the fifth Nikon DSLR that I've had
column5: D300s
column6: and now the D750). I've been waiting for years for Nikon to produce an upgrade to my now 5 year old beloved D300s. As a professional photographer
column7: it was really important that my next camera met my strict set of needs and wants. Sure
column8: Nikon produced the D7000 series
column9: but that took a professional camera and dumbed it down. While the D800/810 are almost unanimously the best out there
column10: I can't shoot a wedding with 36MP photos. I don't even want to think about how many memory cards I'd need to shoot the 1-2000 RAW photos taken at an average wedding. The D4S is lovely
column11: but I can't quite justify paying that much for a camera. The D600 was a bit plagued
column12: and after shooting with a rental D610 I was left with lots of frustration and questionable images. The D610 had some weird white balancing and exposure issues. Also
column13: for my large hands the grip felt incredibly cramped
column14: which is a big deal breaker when this camera is going to be attached to my arm for 12 hours a day. Could Nikon not produce a proper successor to the D300s/D700 in 5 years?

column1: Luckily
column2: the D750 really seems to be that camera.

column1: -The grip
column2: while as narrow as the D610
column3: is much deeper
column4: which makes all of the difference in the work.

column1: -Focus is incredibly fast and accurate
column2: even in really low light settings.

column1: -Photos are crisp and full of detail (even with the AA filter).
-The rotating screen
column2: while built very solidly built does scare me a little
column3: so I'll use that sparingly. It's bright
column4: and the addition of white (as well as RGB LEDs) really bumps up the readability. The screen isn't quite as nice as a retina display
column5: but it's not far off.

column1: -The top screen (while much smaller than the D300s) is bolder and easier to read.
-Speaking of easier to read...the viewfinder display is unreal! It's white and bright and an upgrade that I love but I didn't even think about.

-Controls and menus are a bit frustrating. Had an issue with autofocus trying to focus before every picture in a burst and it took quite about 30 minutes on the phone with Nikon to figure out what was causing the issue. It was a stupidly simple fix. Once I figure out this camera and get used to the slightly different button order
-Speaking of burst
column2: 6.5 fps may not be the fastest out there
column3: but it is plenty fast for me. A little sad that the addition of the grip doesn't add an extra fps or two.

column1: -Shutter sound on normal continuous high is actually quieter than the quiet mode on the D300s; a huge plus for me.
-Wireless capability. I'm not going to lie
column2: this was a HUGE draw for me. I've used EyeFi cards
column3: and they've been great
column4: but their range was about 5 feet and the connection took quite a bit of time. The Nikon built in WiFi is fast and was able to trigger the camera from my phone from 25 feet away. Brilliant.

column1: -And I saved the best to last. The low light performance of this camera is unlike anything I've ever seen. I think it may even be better than the D800. Completely usable photos up to 6400 ISO
column2: and I wouldn't hesitate using a 51
column3: 200 ISO photo in a pinch. They were surprisingly low noise. Honestly
column4: the 51
column5: 200 looked cleaner than a 6400 photo on the D300s

column1: And now the negatives.
-First is the biggest one. The buffer. It's just ok. I could shoot burst mode for days with the D300s but the D750 only allows for a few seconds. I wish that it had the same buffer as the D810.
-Screen is a little bit slow to wake up when turned on with MENU or PLAY
-Camera is a bit too small for my hands
column3: but I'll definitely be purchasing the grip soon.

column1: -WiFi is unsecured?!? A big oversight for Nikon
column2: which should (hopefully) be corrected with a firmware upgrade soon.

column1: -No screen protector? This is the first Nikon that I got that didn't come with one. Even though it has the tabs to attach it
column2: Nikon doesn't currently have a screen protector for the D750 (I spoke to Nikon customer service) I'm sure this problem will also be corrected soon
column3: but these are the problems that you get when you get one of the first cameras off the line.

column1: -Why does it have the spin dial controls at the top instead of the 3-4 button controls of the D800/810/D4s?
-The photos are too.... beautiful?
Honestly
column3: I couldn't come up with more than those slight complaints. Sorry this review was a bit long
column4: but I am psyched about this camera
column5: and thought it was deserving of a full review."^5^Oct 4

column1: mago^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^38^2^"I have been shooting Nikon cameras since 1989. My last camera was the D300. I wanted to have a camera capable to shoot clean shots at high ISO
column2: with better auto-focus and with more resolution than the D300. The DX option was the D7100
column3: but even though this is a very good camera
column4: I was waiting for another DX equal enough to the D300 or much better in all respect. Obviously
column5: the D7100 was tempting me but I was waiting for the rumored D400 that probably will never be created.

column1: The D600 was not an option due to the oil getting in the sensor. Nikon tried to fix the problem by introducing the D610 which in my opinion
column2: was not either an acceptable option as well. The D800 / 810 were too pricey and the D4
column3: way too expensive for my wallet. I was waiting for either the rumored D7100 replacement or another camera FX in between the D610 and the D800 series when the D750 showed up !

column1: I decided to buy this camera and move to a different world
column3: which demand the use of better lenses and technique. I do have 3 professional lenses already : Nikon 70-200 f/4
column4: Nikon 105 f/2.8 and Nikon 16-35 f/4. The experience and technique was there also. I was ready to move and gave this camera a shot and let me tell you
column5: I won't go back to any other; I am simply impress with this camera. I am able to shoot at ISO 12800 and the results are amazing
column6: great colors at that high ISO and clean shots. The AF system of this camera is super fast and infallible. Set it up for AF-C Group and the camera will not stop shooting very sharp pics of your model regardless of their movement speed. This is a plus to me because I shoot weddings and even though you can get kind of the same result with the D7100 by setting that camera in AF-C 3d
column7: still that function is not as perfect like the one in the D750.

column1: Before
column3: I had to use at least 2 speed lights to get the shot done while shooting indoors. Now
column4: I do not have the need to use flashes anymore. My D750 is capable to 'illuminate' any dark room and turn it into a very bright one. It does not fail ! It is capable to shoot even in dark environments
column5: something that is not possible with the D7100.

column1: I also have the capability to shoot almost 6 frames per second; the color rendition are excellent
column2: the body is very light and ergonomic
column3: the shutter feels secure under your finger
column4: excellent life battery ( more than 1k shots ); believe it or not
column5: this camera shoots excellent jPEG pictures even at high ISO. The body is weather sealed. The other night I was shooting under a light rain and I did not even bother trying to protect my camera. For me
column6: it has been a great move and worth the investment. The only flaw is that at the moment
column7: you are not capable to download your RAW files ( I shoot in RAW ) directly from the camera to your photo processor unless you do have a RAW converter. I use aperture and I bought the ExifChanger program from Apple for $10 dollars and with that little program
column8: I am capable to convert my RAW files as if they were shot with the Nikon D5300. As a temporary solution
column9: it is a great choice
column10: till Nikon release the RAW file format.

column1: I won't give you my opinion about the video capabilities of this camera because I am not a videographer and I do not really care about that at all. I am a photographer 100% and as such
column2: if you are looking for a camera that will help you to improve your pics in any kind of environment
column3: assuming that you have the lenses and the experience
column4: this is your camera. Not that expensive as the D800 or D4 but at the same level of those cameras. The D750 produce much better clean shots than the D800 and its AF-S system is on par with the top of the line
column5: D4 series. Isn't a great choice ? In my humble opinion
column6: yes it is by all means !!"^5^Nov 15

column1: YRaj^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^29^0^"I am professional photographer who mainly shoots events. I have shot with the D40
column4: D700 and D800. The D800 is an amazing camera but moody. Along comes the D750
column5: billed as an 'Action' camera. When I heard that it was only 6.5FPS
column6: I was sorely disappointed and was very critical of Nikon. However
column7: after reading a review by a world class wedding photographer about the D750. I decided that this was the camera I needed to work alongside the D800 at events.

column1: After using the camera for 3 weeks
column2: I have to say that I am completely floored. The problem
column3: that I feel guilty about
column4: is that I am not picking up my D800 anymore.

column1: Pros
I can say this enough...the autofocus beats the D700
column3: D7100. I was able to shoot some volleyball shots that came out clearly at ISO 10000
column4: and 90% of the shots were keepers even when blindly shooting at the action. It also focuses quickly in low light..one of 2 main reasons for purchasing this camera.

column1: Autofocus - on Area mode auto...which means the camera picks the focal point. Amazing!!! It automatically focuses on the eyes. This means that when shooting portrait shots
column2: you are able to shoot continuously freely which results in better candid shots.

column1: Low Noise! - I shoot at ISO 10800 with no fear. This is a game changer for me allowing me to shoot more creatively without having to focus and recompose.
WIFI - love the fact that I can post photos to social media while out in the field. Transfer is fast and effortless on my Note 4. See image of Heron.
Cons
FPS - I would have liked more than 6FPS on this latest camera from Nikon. Still this did not prevent me from getting great bird shots..see image.
Grip - does not increase FPS."^5^Nov 24
Photoman^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^22^2^"I was a little hesitant about buying this camera since I already had the new D810

LouisK^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^16^8^"I tested both the D750 and D610 for my upgrade to FX. The D610 is a great camera and I would recommend it without hesitation
column2: but the D750 is so much more.

column1: The first thing I noticed on first using it was it's ergonomics. The grip feels better that the grip of the D610 and my older DX bodies. Also
column2: it is significantly lighter than the other bodies. Even with a heavy lens attached
column3: it is still comfortable to wear for hours around the neck.

column1: The second thing I liked was the high ISO abilities. I can routinely shoot at 800 to 1600 ISO and have the noise level equal that on the D610 at 400-800. These were also shots that I usually missed out on with the DX bodies.
Another night thing for a transitioning photographer is the ability to adjust the recorded frame size from FX to DX. The D610 also has this feature
column2: but the D750 adds a mid step in that I find very useful and use often with my DX 10-20 lens for landscapes.

column1: The last thing I want to touch on was the speed. This is the fastest camera I have had in recording the images to card. I shoot both RAW and high quality JPGs. This camera takes two SD cards
column2: and allows to record RAW to one card and JPG to another
column3: but I configured mine to use the second card as overflow instead. Even with writing both to the same class 10 card
column4: I never have it get too slow. It does slow down due to filling the buffer
column5: but I can sustain approximately a 3-5 FPS on continuous shooting (low). The variance depending on what I am shooting. Regardless
column6: I have not lost a shoot on high school sports shoots due to filling the buffer the way I did on my older bodies.

column1: The Only thing I don't like is the spread of the autofocus points. As it is still supporting DX lenses
column2: Nikon couldn't put the autofocus points out too far. The spread is greater than that of the D610
column3: but if you like to compose with your point of focus off from center be prepared to focus then recompose."^5^Oct 13

column1: BoardBurtonVT^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^2^"This camera is a solid upgrade over the D610 and provides a lot of the utility that the D810 gives you
column2: while only losing resolution. 99% of the photographers of the world would have no need for a 36 mega pixel image (in fact it will probably just eat up your hard drive space twice as fast and be a problem). The focusing is fast
column3: the low light focusing is great
column4: ISO noise is nearly undetectable at f8 or higher up until 7200 or so.

column1: Live view is much improved from my old DX camera (D5200)
column2: the video capabilities are great (1080 at 60fps!). The controls are smooth
column3: the grip is comfortable and the WiFi lets you use your cell phone as a remote shutter

column1: I've used the 24-70mm 2.8g and the 85mm 1.8g
column2: as well as the 18-200mm DX and 10-24mm DX lenses. Its sharp with everything

column1: Nikon really hit a home run with this camera. If you are wavering between this and a D610

column1: BDahl^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"Finally decided to take the step up to a professional level DSLR. My last camera was a Canon Digital Rebel T1i. I had a price range of $3000-$4000 in mind for the body and lens combined. My last DSLR purchase included an 18-55mm lens. While the zoom was a nice feature to have
column2: I was not too terribly impressed by the build quality of the 'stock' lens that came with the camera.

column1: For this purchase
column2: I decided that the D750 body would be in the right range for my needs
column3: I am very happy with 24 megapixels. While I have not taken full advantage of some of the custom settings and added features in this model
column4: I can say that it takes some amazing pictures when paired with the Nikkor 24mm f/1.4 lens. I am very happy that I purchased a lens separately; although I am sometimes limited by a lack of zoom
column5: the Nikkor 24mm lens is a beautiful performer and I can crop my pictures reasonably well while still keeping the images a decent size
column6: thanks to the 24mp sensor. Just after purchasing the set
column7: Nikon announced their latest 24-70mm zoom lens. If I had a little more cash in the budget and a little more patience
column8: I would probably had purchased the zoom lens.

column1: I don't regret switching from Canon to Nikon and am glad I didn't have much stock in Canon lenses. I plan on sticking with Nikon for the future and plan on adding to my lens collection over the years to come. Lets hope they don't change the mounting system any time soon. All in all
column2: the Nikon D750 is a great first entry into owning a professional DSLR and I am very pleased with my purchase."^5^Aug 17

column1: jhonny0099^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^4^"Being a part-time working professional
column2: I've been waiting for a decent entry to full frame (not the D600/D610) without going to the 36MP monster D810 or the outdated D700. When the D750 was announced
column3: I knew it was time to send my D7000 to backup duty and upgrade.

column1: The 24MP sensor is imo the perfect mix of resolution that allows for more cropping while maintaining great low-light capability and manageable file sizes. At first
column2: I thought it performed similarly to my D7000
column3: which is great
column4: but once you take a closer look at images shot at ISO 6400+
column5: it's crazy how clean it is. ISO 12800 is actually usable
column6: and at normal size
column7: is almost indistinguishable from ISO 3200.

column1: The larger viewfinder is a definite plus
column2: however I do wish the points were spread a bit wider. I haven't had a chase to put it through a real test yet
column3: but the AF does seem awesome. It will pick focus in a nearly black room
column4: even with an outer point. Still need to experiment with the AF-C and new Group Area
column5: but seems promising.

column1: I LOVE the grip and how light the camera is without feeling cheap. It's actually lighter than my D7000. The grip is taller and much deeper
column2: which allows me to hold a heavy 70-200 more comfortably without straining my fingers. On my D7000
column3: I could never do that without a battery grip. The control layout is mostly familiar to the D7000
column4: although I would like a separate ISO button and AF-ON. I don't plan on using the tilt screen much
column5: but it seems sturdy.

column1: I am a bit disappointed in the white balance performance
column2: although I shoot RAW so kind of a non-issue
column3: but it's nice to get it close in camera. It seems that the AWB indoors tends towards making things very green/goldish. I have dialed in some compensation
column4: but I hope a firmware update will fine tune this.

column1: Overall
column2: a great mid-range full frame that provides enough capability for a pro
column3: all in a lightweight body. I hear many wedding photogs are trading in their older D3S or D4 bodies to go with D750s instead of D4S."^4^Mar 30

column1: clyde57^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I was debating whether to get the D810 or D750. I decided to get the D750 and if it didn't meet my needs I would return it and get the D810. Well

column1: Waknstak^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I bought this camera primarily for its ability to shoot at higher ISO with little to no noise. column1: straightoutta818^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^1^"Research and come to your own conclusions as far as needs
column2: wants and budget. There is nothing that I can say that has not already been said...this is a fine piece of art and technology.

column1: I made the jump from DX to FX and have had it only for a couple of weeks. My conclusion is that this camera is a monster for its price point. It has fantastic dynamic range and sharpness. Low light performance is great. The D750's features
column2: performance and price are unique in the Nikon FX lineup. Extremely happy with it so far.

column1: Pros:
Smaller size and less weight when compared to Nikons higher end FX bodies.
Great low light performance. Images stay clean up to about 6400 ISO in most circumstances. You can see in the dark if you have to.
The custom user settings (U1 & U2) are a godsend.
It has a titling rear display that can come in handy with odd angles.
Price vs performance feature set ratio might be the best in the market.
Auto focus is accurate and fast.
Cons (Notice that all but one of the issues below have nothing to do with taking a good photo!):
AF area is bunched up towards the middle of the sensor and does not reach the outer edges of the frame.
Has wireless but you cant do much with it. The Nikon WMA app is pretty limited.
No onboard geotagging. Not a huge issue if you do something off camera like Geotag Photos Pro on a smartphone. I dont care for the Nikon GPS solution as its a pain to sync and is a battery killer.
Video is 1080P at best which means either now or down the road you might want something with 4K capabilities.
Shutter is pretty loud regardless of what mode you set it in.
The reviews are right

Russell^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"I upgraded from the Nikon D7000 and have been taking photos over 15 years. The camera has amazing high ISO performance letting me shoot at 4000 ISO with clean photos and even up to 12800 ISO when needed to still get the shot. I really like the ergonomics as it fits my hand very well even for many hours of shooting. I use the tilt screen to get some great shots/video from the ground. This is the least expensive full frame camera you can with with the professional level autofocus and metering systems from the highest end cameras. I prefer to have the 2 SD card slots so one is a backup at all times. Also
column2: the U1 and U2 custom user setting modes on the dial are extremely useful.

column1: I highly recommend going to the closest Best Buy that has a camera store and try it out for yourself as that is the only real way to know if you may like it or not."^5^Jun 8

This is not a 'next step' this is a giant leap. The d750's ability to shoot in lower light situations is amazing
column2: the increased resolution is amazing.... and I've only used it twice to get used to it. It will go into service this weekend at its first wedding...."^5^Jun 2

column1: Joel^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^1^"We upgraded from a D3300. The D750 is Nikon's full frame camera in between the D610 and D810. At $1900 (plus lenses if you dont already own) this is a strong value for an aspiring pro
column3: or perhaps a backup or more portable model for a pro who already has an 810 or D4S. More autofocus points than the D610 and can switch aperture while shooting video. It makes little sense to buy this camera if you dont know what you are doing or at plan to learn
column4: or if you dont already own or plan to invest in quality FX lenses. But if you have the $ and passion
column5: I dont see much sense in investing in a 7200 new when the 610 and this 750 are just a bit more. Full frame does make a difference. The 1.8G FX primes are a great value
column6: we use the 85 and 50 for my wife's family / portrait gigs
column7: have our eye on a 24
column8: and one day the 2.8 zooms. Be sure to calibrate your monitors and perhaps use a colorcard if you shoot raw."^5^Dec 28

column1: Camerabug^/nikon-d750-dslr-video-camera-body-only-black/8753712?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I am a novice at best but recently upgraded myself from a D7100 to this D750 for full frame experience. The camera itself is very light weight in fact much lighter than the D7100. Outstanding images with 24.3 megapixel CMOS image sensor with crisp sharp photos. The camera is awesome in low light situations with auto ISO but is expandable. So far the battery life has been great for all the functionality of the camera for stills and video. The LCD monitor offers great flexibility for live view and video recording as you can tilt and angle to get a better view of your subject. I'm not shooting movie type video but the quality I'm seeing of my kids soccer games and outdoor activities has been very good so far. My D750 was bundled with a Nikkor 28-300mm 3.5-5.6G ED VR lens which is a really great option for a kit lens since it covers such a vast range of focal lengths. I have been able to capture some nice wide angle landscape images and zoomed in on wild life with really sharp images at both ends. I'm really liking the move to a full frame camera and have already added some additional lenses to my camera bag. If you want to upgrade to full frame but don't want to spend a huge chunk of change on a professional level D810 the D750 is a great option. For me the D750 was a good intro full frame with a ton of features."^5^Dec 27

column1: I was back and forth between the D500 and D750. Finally

column1: D750 has a great Dynamic range and an extremely impressive low light performance. I am in love with the image quality
column3: the tones and the sharpness. Paired with a good quality glass
column4: this is a beast of a camera in a rather light compact body. Idea mix between studio cameras and travel gear.

column1: Pros: (that i have experienced)
-Light Weight
-High Dynamic Range (details across the frame)
- Full Frame Sensor (high sensitivity)
- In-Built Wifi (click and transfer convenience)
- Dual Card Slots
- Super Fast Autofocus
- Gimmick Free Design
- Programmable interface
- Comfortable Grip
- Great Selection of Glass
- Tilting Screen
Cons:
- Focus Points concentrated in the center
- no ISO 60 option
- No Split Display Zoom
- no 1/8000s Shutter Speen"^5^Jan 25

column2: but after using for several weeks
column3: not so much. When I pick up my D3100 now it seems like a toy in comparison! After much research
column4: I opted for the Nikon body only and purchased 2 Sigma lenses--a 24-105mm F4 (fast autofocus using D750's back button
column5: and sharp!) and a macro/telephoto 70-300mm. I think these are decent lenses for what I paid for them--much less than Nikon lenses go for. The D750 is a lot of camera
column6: and I am still learning to use some of the customizable features. YouTube tutorials have been indispensable in this regard. The more I learn and practice
column7: the more I love this camera. I'm a little disappointed in the low-light performance. When I put the camera on shutter-priority (I like to shoot handheld
column8: so usually set the fastest shutter speed I can)
column9: the camera seems to bump up the ISO higher than needed
column10: resulting in some noisy shots. I often turn off the auto ISO to find the sweet spot. But this is likely more a limitation of my lenses than the camera. Overall
column11: you can't go wrong with the D750! Best Buy sent some freebies w/ this purchase: a 32 GB card
column12: a sling-type camera bag that I'm really liking much more than expected
column13: an extra battery (not Nikon
column14: but works fine)
column15: and a Shutterfly book coupon. So kudos to Best Buy for some good swag!"^5^Aug 2

Deutschlandreform^/canon-eos-77d-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens-black/5774201?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^5^"According to Canon
column2: the 77D represents a new category of advanced amateur EOS cameras
column3: supposedly a step above the Rebel series. However
column4: the design of the 77D is very much like previous Rebels and therefore owners of preceding Rebels will find the camera feeling pretty familiar.

column1: Compared to some of the previous Rebels
column2: the 77D has even more pre-set shooting modes and filters
column3: which Canon grouped under SCN
column4: respectively Creative Filter mode. The camera also features slow continuous shooting. Related to this
column5: one might note that with the 77D the frame rate of Canon entry-level DSLRs has increased to 6 fps - which should be adequate for most amateur photographers. In any case
column6: but especially when shooting RAW
column7: a fast memory card which can handle a lot of data is advisable.

column1: The main new features of the 77D worth noting are the 45-point all cross-type AF system and the DIGIC 7 image processor. The improved and now very responsive display with swipe functionality makes looking through the pictures a lot faster and easier.
Amateur photographers looking for a compact
column2: lightweight DSLR camera with an extensive feature set and great image quality for a reasonable price
column3: will enjoy the Canon EOS Rebel 77D. (Beginners who do not care about the top LCD panel and the rear quick-control thumb dial
column4: might as well save $100 and buy the basically identical T7i instead.)"^4^Jul 30

column1: RachelR^/canon-eos-77d-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens-black/5774201?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"This is an amazing camera for semi-beginner photographers who want the ability to grow into more advanced features. This camera is almost identical to the Canon Rebel T7i
column2: but where the two cameras differ is in their capability for manual function - which
column3: if you plan to transition into intermediate or professional photography
column4: is essential to become comfortable with. The Canon 77D is incredibly easy to learn how to use
column5: especially if you choose to enable the guided mode (the user-friendly interface that comes preset on the Canon rebel series). Another great feature is the WiFi-enabled Canon connect app
column6: which allows you to transfer your photos directly from your camera to your phone. The 18-55 mm lens is a great lens for close-range portrait shots
column7: but if you plan to take any photos outside
column8: then you need to purchase a polarized lens to attach to the end of your lens - this will ensure that your colors are crisp and clear. Overall
column9: the Canon 77D was a great purchase
column10: and I have no complaints."^5^Jul 22

column1: NateF^/canon-eos-77d-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-55mm-is-stm-lens-black/5774201?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"I came to the 77D from the Canon T4i and I couldn't be happier. This model added everything I wished my beloved T4i had: more megapixels
column3: top LCD panel
column4: and more focus points. I've been very happy with this camera's performance. I actually do some portrait photography on the side and my clients have been happier than ever with the results. The camera takes great pictures though and handles well in low light for pictures. It does fall short for low light video recording though. It's dual pixel auto focus is fast and accurate. column1: PhotosByFry^/nikon-d850-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/6084300?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^16^1^"I have owned 3 Nikon Hi-Res dslrs the D800
column2: D810 and now the D850. Every model has been a leap in tech but what Nikon has done now is truly stunning. I just love this camera and battery grip! And it shoots 4k views and 8k time lapse.

column1: Key Specifications:
45.7MP BSI CMOS sensor
7 fps continuous shooting with AE/AF (9 with battery grip and EN-EL18b battery)
153-point AF system linked to 180
UHD 4K video capture at up to 30p from full sensor width
1080 video at up to 120p
column2: recorded as roughly 1/4 or 1/5th speed slow-mo

column1: 4:2:2 8-bit UHD uncompressed output while recording to card
1 XQD slot and 1 UHS II-compliant SD slot
Battery life rated at 1840 shots
3.2' tilting touchscreen with 2.36M-dot (1024768 pixel) LCD
Illuminated controls
19.4MP DX crop (or 8.6MP at 30fps for up to 3 sec)
SnapBridge full-time Bluetooth LE connection system with Wi-Fi
Advanced time-lapse options (including in-camera 4K video creation)
High resolution

The use of a backside illuminated (BSI) sensor means that the light collecting elements of the sensor are closer to the surface of the chip. This should not only increase the efficiency of the sensor (improving low light performance) but should also be expected to make the pixels near the edges of the sensor better able to accept light approaching with high angles of incidence
Like the D810 before it
column2: the D850 continues to offer an ISO 64 mode
column3: that allows it to tolerate more light in bright conditions. The D850 promises the same dynamic range advantage as the D810
column4: meaning it should be able to compete with the medium format sensors used in the likes of the Fujifilm GFX 50S and Pentax 645Z.

column1: High Speed
In addition to the increased speed
column2: the D850 also gains the full AF capabilities of the company's flagship sports camera: the D5. This includes all the hardware: AF module
column3: metering sensor and dedicated AF processor
column4: as well as the full range of AF modes and configuration options
column5: which should translate to comparable focus performance combined with high resolution.

column1: Given the D5 possessed one of the best AF systems we've ever seen and could continue to offer that performance in a wide range of conditions and shooting scenarios with minimal need for configuration
As part of this system
column2: the D850 gains the automated system for setting an AF Fine Tune value. It only calibrates the lens based on the central AF point and for a single distance
column3: but it's a simple way to ensure you're getting closer to your lenses' full capabilities
column4: which is handy given you'll now be able to scrutinize their performance with 46MP of detail.

column1: It just blows me away every time I use it."^5^Apr 11

LexamusPrime^/nikon-d850-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/6084300?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^14^0^"I've owned the camera since it came out and I must say that it is by far the best I've used. I owned the D810 and D500 before it and it flawlessly combines everything I LOVED about those cameras and adds up to something even greater. The focus system is incredible. The low light quality is 2nd to none. I've printed 8.5x11 pictures shot at iso 12800 and people didn't believe the iso they were shot at. The view finder is HUGE and even wearing glasses I can see EVERYTHING without a problem. I also LOVE that I can shoot in a crop mode and the view finder will actually black out everything not being used. Shooting 1x1 aspect ratio through the view finder is a different experience than cropping after the fact and it changes the way you compose.
The color is flawless. The new auto daylight white balance is very handy. I've found ZERO about the camera I don't like."^5^Nov 4

the D850 drops the CompactFlash card slot that was on the D810 in favor of an XQD slot and the performance advantages that brings (although at the moment Nikon is the only manufacturer to take up this storage format on its cameras)
column2: while the SD card slot supports cards up to UHS-II.

column1: The D850 gets Nikon's SnapBridge connectivity for wireless transfer of images
column2: which establishes a low-energy Bluetooth connection between the camera and your smart device. Images can then be transferred from camera to device via as you shoot at either 2MP or full resolution (though we'd avoid this with 45.4MP files)
column3: or individually if you select images on the camera. For speedier Wi-Fi transfers you can use the app to browse and select the images you desire.

column1: SprocketTracker^/nikon-d850-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/6084300?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Have been shooting Nikon gear for a lot of years. 13 years with a Nikon D50 APS-C and then stepped up to the D7500. When I was presented with an opportunity to buy the D850 I jumped on it and have not been disappointed. The transistion from APS-C sensors to a full frame sensor took a bit to get used to especially with the resolution being 8 times the D50 and over 2 times the D7500
column2: but was quickly overcome by changing some of my shooting habits. The resolution is great and the color is awesome straight out of the camera. I already had a collection of full frame lenses so I did not need to buy a a bunch of new gear to transition to full frame
column3: so keep that in mind if you're moving into a full frame for the first time from a crop sensor camera
column4: because full frame lenses work great on crop sensor bodies. BUT crop sensor lenses do not work well with a full frame body unless you switch the capture mode to DX (crop/APS-C) format
column5: in which case its a waste of a great sensor and you should look at the D500 or D7500. I have taken low light
column6: night time
column7: long exposure
column8: and full sun pictures and have had no problems and love the quality of low light and night photos that can be taken with this camera. The menus are natural and intuitive for me since I am a previous Nikon DSLR shooter. I can say this camera is not for everybody due to its size and weight (body alone) and then add in high end all glass lenses and the weight can be a bit much for long day shots for some. I have weighed one of my combinations of the D850 body and Tamron 150-600 and it comes in at just about 7 pounds. So if weight and big size is an issue be warned this is a bigger camera but not un-manageable even for my girlfriend who has small hands."^5^Oct 7

PWPhoto^/nikon-d850-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/6084300?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I waited 7 years for this camera. It replaced a D800. Talk about a difference. This camera is the real deal. For me
column2: the best things about this camera are:

column1: 1. It very much improved autofocus system. It is so much faster and accurate than the D800.
2. The much improved low light ability.
It allows me to shoot lower ISO in situations where I had to shoot higher ISO on the F800 causing me to have a lot more  noise to deal with.
3. The much wider and better dynamic range. This translates into a much smoother image with less artifacts and noise.
4. The almost double the frame rate over my D800 on still photography. Since I do have the battery grip and EN-EL18 batteries
column2: I ca nmaximize the speed and get the full 9fps from it.

column1: 5. The true silent shooting. This is a big thing for me. I shoot in some situations
column2: where the smallest sound can create a missed and lost shot. Being able to shoot true silent allows me to get images if certain things i could not get before. It is also a dream to shoot in very quiet events where you shooting images of it should not be what holds the attention.

column1: If you have been on the fence about this cameras do yourself a favor and buy it. I chose not to buy the D810 because
column3: it wasnt enough of an upgrade over the D800. Others disagree on that
column4: but it wasnt enough for me and that's why I patiently waited for the D810 replacement. It was worth the wait."^5^Jul 12

codyl1992^/nikon-d850-dslr-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/6084300?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This camera is Nikon's culmination of decades of product development and digital SLR's. It takes ultra high resolution and combines it with high speed
column2: and does so in a truly polished manner. This is a digital SLR
column3: not a mirrorless camera
column4: so it may not have all the tech of a new mirrorless camera
column5: but it's one of the best digital SLR's ever made. Anyone with full frame Nikon lenses who wants resolution and speed in one body will be absolutely pleased. Over the D810 (which can be found used for half the price) it has more resolution
column6: a tilting screen
column7: enhancements to JPEG processing
column8: 4k video (although if you're serious about video
column9: get a mirrorless camera)
column10: silent time lapse modes that don't wear out the shutter
column11: much faster continuous shooting
column12: and a more sophisticated focusing system.

column1: Don't let XQD sway you away by the high prices of the cards. They are so fast that even 45 megapixel raw files get written almost instantly.

The resolution is truly incredible. The amount of cropping available to you is game changing if you've never shot on this kind of resolution before. One can shoot far off wildlife and not worry about getting perfectly centered framing
column2: crop to the equivalent of APS-C/DX mode
column3: and still have 19.4 megapixels. That turns my 200-500 lens into a 750mm equivalent still retaining almost 20 megapixels of detail. And it has the focusing system to keep up.

column1: This camera will suit all kinds of photography. This is not a 'first camera.' It's a camera for a Nikon enthusiast or pro who can look at the benefits over cheaper bodies and see a real advantage in their kind of shooting. It's for people who absolutely know what shutter priority
column3: etc mean. Paying 3000 dollars for a camera won't make you a better photographer
column4: but having 45 megapixels and a killer autofocus system might help you crop for better framing and give you more keepers or more 'reach' with your lenses. These are the things that must be weighed when determining if you should buy this camera. For many types of shooting
column5: a D750 or D7500 makes more sense. I believe that for me
column6: this is the last digital SLR I will ever need due to the emergence of mirrorless. Mirrorless offers promise of more technology to help make pictures easier since DSLR's have reached a bit of a plateau
column7: inherent to their design. I also own a Nikon Z6
column8: and for casual shooting without action
column9: its a great camera; and the Z cameras will continue to get better. But right now
column10: the D850 is simply unbeatable for all uses except video
column11: where the Z cameras have an inherent mirrorless advantage.

mikenic^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^45^5^"Got the D500 to upgrade from my D90
column2: and man what an upgrade it is!

column1: D500 is a beast
column2: this camera does everything much better than the D90 as one would expect. Where is really shines is on the edges of performance
column3: the speed both of focusing and of FPS is just spectacular. I'm VERY glad I waited till the 500 came out
column4: I had played around with D7000/7200
column5: to me the 7000 was just not worth the money when it came out
column6: the 7200 would have been a nice step up
column7: but this 500 is not a step
column8: it's a leap. The white balance is simply worlds better than on the 90 and so is the jpeg engine with high ISO shots. These are both very important to me as I take both RAW and jpeg
column9: but I don't want to have to spend my whole time in Photoshop correcting. With the jpegs right out of the camera they are stunning.

column1: On my D90 I would never shoot above 1000 ISO as it was just too noisy
column2: with the D500 it has been on ISO 2000 for the last few days and I have gone up much much higher with great results. I just love this camera as I did with my trusty D90 that has served me well over the last 8 years. Hopefully the 500 will also. The shot of the chipmunk was done on the D500 with the 200-500 lens. A VERY highly recommended lens"^5^May 1

column1: DigitalCMH^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^25^0^"I never thought I'd go back to an APS-C sensor camera. I love full frame and figured that would be all if ever use. I started from Nikon's D70
column3: D300 (got stolen) and for the last years I've been using the D700. I've been. Drooling for the D810 for its 36mp but never pulled the trigger on the $3000 price tag.

column1: In the last 2 years I have gotten into wildlife photography which lead me to the Tamron 150-600 and to my current Nikon 200-500mm lens. Great gear
column2: but on a 12mp body and only 5 FPS
column3: I find myself struggling with small and nimble birds. Missing focus and the 'money shot'.

column1: I have only had the D500 for a couple weeks but because of the 1.5 APS-C crop and the MP boost from 12 to 20.9
column2: I am seeing details I have never been able to manage before. It's blowing me away! And 10 FPS is getting some really good action that I usually miss.

column1: Why not stay FF and pick up a D610 or D750? Buffers are too small for high speed RAW shooting. Even my D700 slows me down. But so far the D500 appears to be a home run."^5^May 6
RyanY^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^2^"I upgraded from at D7100
column2: which I think is still an excellent camera
column3: despite it's tiny buffer. The D500 is Nikon's flagship DX camera
column4: aimed at enthusiasts and professionals alike. The layout (as you can see)
column5: is that of it's typical 'pro-line' cameras
column6: such as the D810
column7: and the D500's predecessor the D300/D300s. The grip is along the same
column8: comfortable feel as the D750
column9: with a deep well that's comfortable for bother smaller hands and large hands. Potentially
column10: you can change all of your on-the-fly settings (shutter
column11: Aperture
column12: ISO
column13: Exposure Comp) with one hand with the ISO button placement. My favorite feature is most certainly the multi-selector (usually reserved for professional bodies like the D5). While you can still use the direction pad to move the AF point
column14: the multi-selector just makes it more intuitive
column15: and the placement makes sense
column16: being so close to the AF-ON button. Pressing the Multi-Selector will also engage auto exposure lock if you need it.

column1: Speaking of the Auto-focus
column2: it's amazing! It uses a 153-point AF system that covers the image end-to-end (left to right). There are 55-selectable points in both AF-S and AF-C
column3: but it still uses the other 98 points as support
column4: which works particularly well in AF-C mode. Another tidbit (and something all DSLR uses should be doing) is that upon inspection of where the AF point focuses with a single AF-point box (center-point)
column5: the actual coverage area expand beyond the box on all sides. I assume that that this is the work of the unselectable AF-points that surround a single selectable point (excluding the AF-points along the edges).

column1: ISO Noise is another surprise I was not expecting. Yeah
column2: it has a sizable range of 100 to 51200 with extendable ranges of 50 on the low end and 1
column4: 000 on the high end. I won't get into low ISO performance (which is good
column5: unless you're at an extreme EV number... don't know why you would do that in the first place)
column6: but at higher ranges
column7: it performs flawlessly.. mostly. My experience came down to the overall lighting situation
column8: as well as what lens I use. Yes
column9: good glass matters with ISO. I've done some outdoor portrait shoots in varying lighting. I was at ranges between 400 and 1600
column10: mostly sticking to 1600 using either a Sigma 24mm f1.4 Art or the Nikkor 70-200mm f2.8G VRII. The pictures came out amazing. In pixel-peep mode
column11: the noise was very fine
column12: and it looked even better when I went black and white In fact
column13: I even introduced more noise to the pic (very little.. but enough) and it looked like a shot I took from my Nikon F3 on ISO 800 film. Then
column14: when I actually printed them out
column15: there wasn't any noise at all. It doesn't stop there
column16: folks. I set this up alongside my Sony a7SII for some astrophotography
column17: and I was getting same noise in a ISO 1600 shot from the a7SII as I was with the D500 at ISO 800. The conditions were not as ideal as I want it (scattered clouds in heavy light pollution)
column18: but I was able to pull part of the galactic center with the D500 as I could with the a7SII. The reason why I would rather use the a7SII for astro overall is that it's full-frame
column19: and the mirrorless-centric features like Focus Peaking and Bright Monitoring are amazing tools to utilize for astro.

column1: Overall
column2: the Nikon D500 is about as good as it comes in an APS-C format camera. This camera is for certain making full-frame counterparts like the D750 run for the hills and Nikon has managed to close the gap between FX and DX bodies in terms of noise handling considerably. I'm surprised how well the D500 manages ISO noise
column3: it's plenty fast for it's true purpose (sports and wildlife)
column4: but is well capable as a portrait and astro shooter. I think Nikon's future is bright because this camera and the D5 is paving the way for future FX products. For what it does
column5: the price to play is well worth it. I highly recommend what will become the next legend in Nikon's lineup."^5^May 10

column1: Fixmeister^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^0^"I have been shooting Nikon cameras since the D70 came out. I've owned the D70
column4: D7200 and now the D500
column5: They all have been great cameras (except maybe the D7000 with its back-focus issue). I still have my D7200 and have no plans to sell it. It still is an incredible camera.

column1: But while the D7200 has more megapixels than the D500 it pales in comparison when things start to move. The autofocus in the D7200 is pretty good but the D500 is amazing. Every reviewer will tell the same story. It finds focus and locks on. So why the 'but'?
The D500 is a professionally built body and has professional controls and capabilities. And the autofocus
column3: is not the same beast as the D7200. The 'Dynamic' in particular is a bit troubling and does not behave like previous generations of Nikons did in that autofocus mode. If you shoot birds in flight (BIF) you will have better success in 'Group' or '3-D' modes. I'm still experimenting and practicing with it but can affirm that once you begin to understand how the system works
column4: your keeper rate will skyrocket.

column1: Some things to know about this camera:
Its really
column2: really fast. 10fps is addicting and you'll wonder how you got by with anything less.

column1: If you have a remote cable from a 7000 series Nikon
column2: it's not going to work with the D500. The D500 cable remote uses a 10-pin
column3: screw-in style cable attachment and not the plug in ones used in other cameras. I had one leftover from my D200 and it is the same one used by the D500. Glad I saved it.

column1: To get the maximum possible capture rate without buffer slow down you will need to budget for an XQD card. They weren't cheap before and they've gone up. Right now only one manufacturer (Sony) is making them and with no competition
column2: they can charge what they want. But
column3: before I purchased one
column4: I used a reasonably fast SD cart and couldn't slam the buffer. So
column5: if you don't think you'll be shooting 200 consecutive shots in a row
column6: a fast SD card will probably be just fine.

column1: I wasn't able to develop any confidence in the 'Auto Fine Tune' feature of lens calibration. Frankly
column2: if you think you have a lens that is back or front focusing
column3: you're better off with a lens calibration target and a tripod. And a cable release.

column1: Battery grip... the thing is ridiculously expensive for what it is
column2: but I bought one anyway. And I can honestly say it's the first Nikon grip I've added to any of my cameras that does not move or wiggle once installed. I prefer the feel of a camera with the add-on grip and this one does not disappoint.

column1: There are a ton of customization options available for this thing and you will come to appreciate that.
Now... about whether you should buy one... it depends. If you shoot family gatherings and landscapes
column2: you won't realize any benefit over a D7200 or D7500
column3: if you have one. In fact
column4: my D7200 is a better camera for that
column5: especially if you have a CLS Nikon flash and intend to use the pop-up flash to fire it. The D500 has no built-in flash and if you intend to control other flashes wirelessly
column6: you'll need a controller or another flash to do so.

column1: Also
column2: the 24mp cameras have more resolution and although the difference doesn't seem like much
column3: it IS noticeable. Especially if you are looking for maximum pixel-peeping. If you have a D7000 or D7100
column4: it will be a big step forward.

column1: Is it $800 better than a D7500 or $1200 better than a D7200? That depends on whether you are a sports or wildlife shooter. If you are
column2: the answer is a resounding 'yes'. If not
column3: then probably not.

column1: But if you ARE a wildlife shooter
column2: this is the best of the best out there. I highly recommend the Nikon 200-500 F5.6 lens to go with it. It's a great combo. You won't be disappointed... after you spend some time with it. This camera does not suffer fools and will require you to spend time getting to know it. But that's true of any high-performance product.

column1: I highly recommend this thing to anyone who can and will use it for what it's designed to do. Hope this review helps someone on the fence about buying one.
Tom"^5^Apr 22

EricBowles^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^17^2^"I love the D500. I've had more than a dozen Nikon DSLR cameras and this one is great. I photograph professionally and teach workshops.
The WOW features on this camera are the frame rate and the low light performance. At 10 FPS
column3: but more importantly
column4: with a fast XQD memory card like the Lexar Professional 2933X XQD
column5: the write speed is nearly enough to keep up with the frame rate so the buffer never fills. You can rattle off 200 frames in a burst
column6: then repeat with another burst of the same size. Not everyone needs this kind of speed
column7: but for sports or wildlife it is very helpful.

column1: ISO performance of the D7200 was already quite good for a DX sensor
column2: and this is just a little better. The advantage comes at higher ISO levels - great for low light. The D500 is about a half stop better than the D7200 under low light conditions making it nikon's best DX camera.

column1: Handling is typical of Nikon DSLR cameras - a solid
column2: well built body with controls easy to access. I had no problem adjusting settings without every taking my eye from the viewfinder. The key change is the Mode and ISO buttons have been switched from the typical layout. This places the ISO button next to the shutter - easy to access and make changes that can be seen in the viewfinder.

column1: Card speed matters with this camera. Get a fast XQD card for best performance - a Lexar Professional 2933x or Sony G XQD card. Other cards will not perform at peak speeds and will fill the buffer in a shorter time.
In the SD slot there are several options. I bought a Lexar 2000x UHS-II SD card
column2: but there are some issues with this card and I would not recommend it until the issues are resolved. Be sure to get a UHS-II card for best speed. UHS-II has a second row of contacts and requires a new reader for peak speed. The Sandisk 280 MB/s UHS-II or Toshiba Exceria Pro UHS-II are good
column3: fast cards. Stay away from slower cards like the Lexar 1000x or any UHS-I card. The camera can use UHS-I SD cards in an emergency
column4: but they operate in compatibility mode and are much slower.

column1: This camera is the nice upgrade to the D300. It's a solid choice with a lot of great features. My bread and butter camera is still my D800E
column2: but this camera is a very good compliment and my choice for moving wildlife and sports."^5^May 10

column1: DusterBuster^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^2^"The Nikon D500 is a camera that professionals and enthusiasts have waited 7 years for. It replaces the D300s and is at the top of the APS-C market. The closest comparable competitor is the Canon 7D-MKII
column2: and even it can't touch the build quality and performance of the D500. Now
column3: lets talk about what makes the D500 great:

column1: -20.9 megapixel sensor with EXPEED 5 image processing. This processor is top of the line and the only other camera that has it is the $6500 D5.
-153 Autofocus points that cover the sensor edge to edge with 99 of the points being cross-type. Shooting with this camera doing sports and wildlife shooting in bursts
column2: the AF tracking is superb and unrivaled by any alternative.

column1: -ISO covers from 100-51
column2: 200 natively! This is unheard of in an APS-C body until now. This means this camera performs well even in low light situations. Look up some of the ISO tests on this camera and you will see that it impresses even at these higher ISO's. It can shoot up to 1
column4: 000 ISO
column5: but that is not natively and is not recommended by Nikon.

column1: -4k Video. You may have heard that it does have a 1.5x additional crop factor when shooting video. Don't worry too much about that
column2: if you are shooting with the correct lense
column3: it won't be a problem. That said
column4: the 4k video is amazing and looks great on my 4k TV.

column1: -Dual card slots. This camera includes one SD and one XQD card slot. While expensive
column2: XQD is blazing fast and virtually eliminates the buffer so that you can continuously shoot. Speaking of buffer
column3: even with SD
column4: this camera is no slouch. Even shooting with SD only
column5: I've never had to stop and wait for the buffer when using the continuous shooting features.

column1: -10FPS. That's right
column2: you can capture 10 shots per second when shooting continuously. This is a feature you will find VERY useful for sports and wildlife photography.

column1: -Snapbridge is a new feature
column2: exclusive to the D500 at the moment
column3: that lets your camera connect to your phone via NFC/Bluetooth for image sharing among other features.

column1: All-in-all
column2: this camera is a beast and an absolute must-have for any sports or wildlife photographer. Yes
column3: it's no slouch for weddings
column4: landscapes and portraits as well
column5: but Full-frame sensors will surely outperform it in those areas. I would personally pair this camera with a D810 and use this one for the sports/wildlife and the D810 for Weddings/Portraits/Landscape.

column1: If you are in the market for a new high-end professional grade APS-C sensor
column2: this camera is the one for you. Definitely buy it!

column1: Below
column2: I've included a pair of photos taken with the camera."^5^May 31

column1: Clickasaurus^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"As a retired photographer
column2: I've been all Nikon since 1973 when I purchased my first Nikon F. I've owned at least 20 professional Nikon cameras over the years. After 12 days with my new D500
column3: I'm blown away! I also have a D810 and D750
column4: and bought this for the Dx sensor for wildlife.

column1: The D500 build feels really strong... It reminds me of the D810 except slightly smaller and lighter. The sensor is amazing
column2: and can be cranked up to 51
column3: 200 ISO for uncapturable captures in VERY low light. The ISO can go higher
column4: but the images become very noisy.

column1: The shutter is fast! The 10 FPS shutter is flawless
column2: and the auto-focus keeps up with your moving targets. I have not had to fine-tune at all
column3: even with my 600mm F4. This camera is a bargain! Great build
column4: great sensor
column5: great shutter

column1: svllc^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"I'm going to start with what I don't like about the camera!

column3: Tilt screen and Touch screen.

column1: This camera is geared towards sports
column2: action and wildlife photographers. Those are features that are not needed for these types of work
column3: (with the exception of the tilt screen for some video footage). Snapbridge and wifi should only be on the entry level cameras (IMO)! If you're in a rush to post to social media
column4: chances are that the photo isn't that good to begin with!

column1: Specular Highlights: Very temperamental and often blows them out if not careful!

Lightroom: I find the color rendering to be off during import into lightroom. It's an easy fix though. A quick adjustment to the color profile in the camera calibration panel to camera flat or camera neutral brings the files back to a good starting point!
Pros: AF speed
column2: Accuracy and continuous AF tracking is nothing short of amazing and is where this camera really shines!

column1: ISO Performance: Excellent for a DX body. I personally wouldn't go beyond iso 4
column2: 000 but that's very good for DX IMO!

column1: Ergonomics: A+. If you own a D810
column2: switching between cameras is like night and day.

column1: Overall
column2: this is a solid performing camera for it's intended purpose and I highly recommend add it to your kit."^5^May 17

column1: James^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^1^"This is Nikon's best DX body and it really delivers. The 10 FPS shooting speed
column3: and fast autofocus puts it in the same league as the top-of-the-line pro D4 / D5 bodies. Think of this as a 'D5 mini'.

column1: The ergonomics and build quality is as solid as any of the best full frame Nikon pro bodies. The controls are positioned in a similar way as the pro bodies and I especially like the placement of the ISO button. The grip is a little deeper and lets me handle the larger pro lenses a little easier.
The focus fine tune function is one of those 'why didn't they do this before?' features for DSLRs. After making manual focus adjustments in Live View mode
column2: you press 2 buttons and the camera will make the micro adjustment to exactly match the body and lens. Even the best lenses benefit from this feature and the resulting images are tack sharp.

column1: There really aren't many negatives to this camera. It's about the same price and same size / weight as the entry level full frame bodies. But I would skip the comparably priced full frame bodies and get the D500 because it's the next best thing to a D5."^5^May 25

column1: ChuckieSF^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"To start
column2: I'm a hobbyist. I bought this camera primarily to shoot photos of my daughter's volleyball matches but it's done extremely well for just about everything else that I used to use my D610 for. I primarily shoot landscapes so I had to borrow my friend's AF-S 12-24mm f/4 Nikkor and it's been great.

column1: The AF performance has been outstanding as is the general overall handling of the camera. Image quality is as expected from a pro level Nikon
column2: which is to say that it is outstanding.

column1: Don't let anyone tell you that this camera has better low light performance than full frame cameras. It pretty much keeps up with my D610 up to about ISO 6400 but the D610 at ISO 25
column2: 600 has about the same noise as the D500 at ISO 12
column3: 800. The lack of a built in flash means that I need to carry one with me if I think I might need it. Since it's already larger and heavier than the D610 that means even more weight and bulk. Shooting video in 4K has its challenges as there's an additional crop factor on top of the DX crop factor so wide lenses are no long so wide (a 12mm lens has an equivalent field of view as an 18mm lens when taking photos and it has an equivalent field of view as a 27mm when shooting 4K).

column1: Overall
column2: it's an outstanding camera. It offers me more possibilities than my D610 did for everything except for trying to get the least amount of depth of field or where I can't use a flash in a low light situation
column3: both cases where the larger FX sensor has its advantages."^5^Aug 20

DaBears^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^1^"So I bought a D7500 bundled with a couple of lenses and some other stuff from Costco. It was a really nice camera. After using that camera for a while and continuing to read camera reviews
column2: I decided to return that bundle and just buy the D500 body from Best Buy. I did this because every review listed the D500 as the 'best' DSLR you can buy today. Well
column3: I usually like the best
column4: so why not?

column1: In another lifetime I owned a Nikon D80
column2: but the shutter stopped working on that so I went into 'strictly iPhone camera' mode for a while. That old D80 took a lot of great family photographs which I now cherish. Since I spent a bundle on this D500
column3: I decided to recycle some old equipment from the D80 ... such as my trusty 18-135mm f/3.5-5.6G ED-IF AF-S DX Zoom-Nikkor lens and my SB-800 Speedlight. The lens is a great 'all-around' lens and has worked great on my camera so far. The Speedlight works fine
column4: too
column5: but haven't needed it much since this camera does so great in low-light.

column1: Now ... I'm not a photography genius and I am someone you can usually find using the 'auto' settings. But wait ... there is no such thing on this bad boy. Well
column2: it did take some investment of time ... mostly watching YouTube videos ... but I think I've now got some of it figured out. And it turns out there are still some ways to get the camera to do things for you
column3: aka 'auto
column4: ' they just don't exactly call it that and designate a dial or button for said function. Probably to maintain the image as a photographer's camera LOL.

column1: Anyhow
column2: the pictures this thing takes are stunning. FPS ... when cranked up ... sounds like a machine gun. Put on the right settings and you will freeze every step of your son's next drive to the hole! Snapbridge software where pictures transfer to iPhone right away is pretty cool.

column1: Aside from camera
column2: I've jumped into some of the Adobe software for post-processing and that provides another learning curve all its own.

column1: Bottom line ... great camera ... but expect you will have some learning to do if you are coming in from the cold or the dark ages. But I think you already knew that! ;)"^5^Mar 11
