column1: If your looking for a great crop sensor camera that feels and performs like a high end full sensor then I would seriously consider this purchase!"^4^Nov 18

Camptws^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^1^"The D500 and the Nikkor 200-500mm is probably the best wildlife setup out there. The 20mp APS-C sensor has incredible dynamic range. This provides greater recovery of those shy animals in the shadows and the noise at high ISO insanely low. I have been able to push my recovery of blown out or dark spots almost 2 stops over my Sony A7RII. You may loose a stop of light with this camera but with better recovery
column2: who cares. I only have 3 gripes. One is that this camera sucks for video. Video quality is good
column3: but the camera is not very user friendly and I wish I could see what I was recording through the viewfinder. That brings me to the second grip
column4: no EVF. Having an EVF is invaluable. Third grip is that all the controls on the left side of the camera force you to break your workflow to use them when using a large lens. A right handed camera should be RIGHT HANDED. Buy the Lexar Professional XQD card and blaze away
column5: never missing a shot do to a full buffer. I have never been able to fill the buffer when using that card."^4^Oct 27

column1: JamesD^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I purchased the Nikon D500 body because I was going to shoot a very important wedding and I normally don't shoot weddings. I own a D800 for the portraits and now I wanted a body with some speed to it. I found that after using the camera for a week I really fell in love with this camera body. This is faster then I expected! The focus was instant and I was able to capture MANY spontaneous candid moments and the camera actually kept up with me and as I was using it I kept pushing it harder and harder. It held up to my testing and my wedding turned out to be the best one I have done so far! I am so please with it that I am now ONLY using my D800 and My D500 for ALL my professional work!"^5^Aug 19

column1: MisterE^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^5^"I had a D7000 prior to getting the D500. I needed a new camera that could autofocus quickly to keep up with my 3 year old. I settled on the D500.

I will say that the camera is built like a tank and has an incredible autofocus system. Those are the two things I miss on my current camera. The D500 doesn't have an auto mode so keep that in mind when purchasing. I saw this as a positive as I don't use auto mode anyway. The rear screen is great and high resolution. The viewfinder is also huge and crystal clear. A true pleasure to use.
The photo quality is quite good
column2: even at high ISO ranges. It's amazing how well you can take photos in low light. There is no flash built in so you'll be pushing your ISO up unless you bring an external flash along. As heavy as this camera is you probably won't want to though. A fast lens and higher ISO worked just fine for me. I used this camera for my family and found it to work well. I also wanted to use it for astro-photography. This is where things fell apart a bit.

column1: The illuminated buttons were a big feature for me. I wanted to use them at night while taking pictures of stars and planets. However
column2: within 3 weeks the illuminated buttons stopped working. Not all of them
column3: just half. I am well versed in cameras and know it wasn't that the lights were turned off. They simply failed. Given the price of this camera I couldn't believe something like that would happen. I ended up returning the camera as I was disappointed in the quality form Nikon. As a result of this and other quality issues from Nikon lenses I sold all of my Nikon gear and switched systems. I use Fuji now and enjoy photography more because of it."^3^Oct 17

column1: GregP^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-body-only-black/4870600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^5^"I bought a D500 to replace my D300 for multiple reasons
column3: increased resolution
column4: better autofocus on fast-moving wildlife
column5: better low-light performance
column6: and remote control through my smart phone. Except for the remote control by my iPhone
column7: all of my performance requirements were met or greatly exceeded
column8: as reflected in the other reviews; however
column9: I found the wifi and bluetooth features on this camera to be so dysfunctional
column10: including frequent connectivity drop-outs with my iPhone 6S
column11: that I returned the camera for a full refund. I was able to pair the phone and camera and take photos
column12: and found the live view through my phone a great feature
column13: but the inability to reliably connect my phone to the camera was way overly frustrating. The response I received from Nikon's tech support is what sent me back for a refund: 'Unfortunately
column14: Nikon is still testing the compatibility with Snapbridge and the updated iOS 10.2. It is not recommended to use this application until the testing is completed.' SnapBridge is a Nikon app and the only app available for the D500. When spending $2000 (body only) for a high end camera
column15: I expect it to work perfectly all the time
column16: so I will either wait until Nikon gets their act together or go buy a competitor's product."^3^Jan 9

column1: JonSolo^/canon-eos-80d-dslr-camera-with-18-135mm-is-usm-lens-black/5005633?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^49^0^"There has been much said on this camera and on this series. I will add my brief thoughts:
To begin with this camera is sharp. Don't believe all of the critics out there. It is not as CRISP as some cameras but it is quite sharp. Lenses make a lot of differences
column3: do not skimp on your lens. If you don't this camera will take advantage of what you attach to it and deliver fantastic results.

column1: My first outing was in Colorado on a nature hike/shoot. I was shooting with the standard lens that came with this bundle (24-135mm USM) and I found it to be more than capable of capturing exactly what I wanted in a walkabout lens. It was clean and easy to use. For the first few days I kept it in automatic and got fantastic picture and video results.

Within a few days I was ready to go manual and again this camera did not disappoint. I did a little research online and found some great videos and suggestions on setup which made it quick and easy for me to get along with manual mode even though I am merely an enthusiast. Again the pictures turned out great and sharp.
My next step was to take pictures at a wedding. Again I am no pro
column2: but my results made me feel confident in my abilities and I credit great advice online and a great camera with the 80D. Even though the reception was much lower light
column3: and I loathed the idea of using the built in flash
column4: I got some great results. My latest venture was to shoot the super moon and again with some great advice
column5: and this fantastic camera
column6: I got results that I could never get from a point and shoot or a phone.

column1: For professionals
column2: you already know what you want and will buy it. For enthusiasts or even beginners this can be a great step in the direction of professional photography.

column1: I opted this over the Sony A6300
column2: even though the video is not 4K. The video performance is fantastic for my usage and I am planning on making a Sony purchase (the A6500) in the next month. But this camera is really spot on for daily usage all around.

column1: I had to lower the resolution of the attached photos to be able to upload them."^5^Nov 18

Powderhound^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-with-16-80mm-lens-black/4880600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^25^0^"I had tried the D7500
column2: which is the little brother of this camera. Ultimately decided to buy this camera with the 16-80 lens and the battery grip when it went on sale at Best Buy. I liked the D7500 but found the autofocus system to be lacking for sports and action shots. The D500 has the same focus system as the D5. Its amazing.

column1: The focus system and build quality is better than the D7500. I thought that I might not like the extra weight and size but find that it adds necessary stability
column2: when shooting with telephoto lenses. I own the 200-500 zoom and the D500s focus system
column3: which covers nearly the entire screen area
column4: is amazing.

column1: I also love the ability to backfocus using the joystick and the other back-focus button
column2: independently. This allows me to assign different focusing systems for each of these buttons. The joystick
column3: which I had thought I wouldnt use much
column4: is very useful. I used to backfocus on the D7500 and then would remove my finger and recompose. I dont have to do that anymore. Further
column5: shooting action shots requires access to different focusing systems
column6: on the fly and with speed. Shots dont wait to be taken. Time is of the essence. I use 3D for tracking moving subjects and single or D25 for stationary subjects. This camera just works very well.

column1: The controls are also well placed and there are so many options for customizing the controls. I also like the fact that I dont have to spin the left side dial to change from A
column3: P and M and A. I just push a button and can set them easily. There are no gimmicky programs. There is also a custom option to allow you to just push the button and not have to keep holding it down and then spin the front or back dials on the right side of the top of the camera. I use this setting and it makes things easier for me.

column1: There are a lot of useful YouTube videos that outline some of these custom options. I suggest everyone purchasing the D500 to spend the time to view them.

I do have a few complaints. The touchscreen doesnt work for moving around the the menu settings (it works for the photos review and other options). Dont know why Nikon doesnt write a software upgrade for this since the screen can do it. This is not a deal breaker since I can move around the custom settings pretty easily using the directional buttons. Yet
column2: this should be addressed by Nikon.

column1: The 10 FPS is amazing as is the buffer. I bought a super fast SD card that has a very large buffer and works well with 4k video.
I dont like live view for video. The focus system is slow and hunts
column2: casusing noise and some temporary blur. I havent used the video much but figure I will buy a tripod and a separate microphone that wont pick up the noise from my lenses looking for focus. However
column3: the video quality is as advertisedoutstanding.

column1: I have held off purchasing the XQD card since I dont have a reader for it and my SD card is so fast. I will probably purchase one when the prices for a 64GB XQD card drops. It is a nice feature that the camera can write raw or video to one card and jpegs to the SD card. I know that some will want the XQD card so there is redundancy. However
column2: I have never had an SD card fail and dont shoot professionally. A pro would want redundancy.

column1: I wasnt sure whether I would like the battery grip but I have used it and its great. The camera can access that battery first
column2: so you have two batteries in the camera. More importantly
column3: you can shoot vertically and ithe grip has the same controls (joystick
column4: separate back-focus button and shutter) that the camera has. So its really seamless to turn the camera
column5: if there is a telephoto on it connected to a tripod
column6: or to just turn it in your hand if hand-held.

column1: Now a few thoughts about the 16-80 2.8 lens: I love this lens. I have both a 35 and 50mm prime lenses which are faster. However
column2: they arent VR. I havent missed a shot indoors when I shot without a flash with the 16-80. The pictures are really impressive. Very sharp but also a beautiful creamy color and nice Bokah. I havent used the prime lenses much on this camera because the zoom is that good. The zoom lens is much heavier than the two prime lenses. So
column3: I might use them if I take my external flash with me and want to reduce the total camera weight. I have used the 18-55 kit lens that came with the D7500. Thats a cheap lens and was better than I expected. It is also very light. However
column4: the 16-80 is far superior in every respect. The extra range (effectively 24mm to 120mm) allows true wide angle and allows you to use it as a portrait lens. The Best Buy bundle for the D500
column5: with battery grip and 16-80 2.8 lens is a really good deal.

column1: I would caution anyone buying this camera that it is best in the hands of a photographer that is an enthusiast who will also shoot some action or wildlife photography. The controls require hours to truly understand and master. If someone is just looking for a great all-around camera that doesnt need all of the D500s capabilities
column2: I would recommend the D7500 or D7200
column3: both of which have the same less impressive autofocus system. The D7500 does shoot 4k and has a touch screen and is definitely an upgrade over the D7200. The D7500 also shares the D500s new metering system.

column1: But
column2: I highly recommend this camera bundle if you have the money to spend and contemplate shooting wildlife
column3: your kids soccer game or any action. The lack of a flash on the D500
column4: which the less expensive Nikons have
column5: is not a big deal to me since I never shoot a flash directly at a subject.

column1: So all in all
column2: the D500 is probably the best DX camera out there today. It is so capable and customizable in the right hands. It is built like a tank and weather sealed. The touchscreen has amazing resolution and a better build quality than the cheaper Nikons. The superior resolution makes image review and zooming in on a focus point
column3: a pleasure. You cant go wrong with the D500 and bundle."^5^Dec 2

column1: LojIQ^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-with-16-80mm-lens-black/4880600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^16^0^"My passion for photography fades in and out through the years
column2: and recently it has been reignited primarily to capture as many moments for my 2 and 4 year olds as I can. I have gone through a Sony a6000
column3: and Olympus OM-D E-M10 mark ii
column4: and more recently a Nikon D7200. Sorry to say the mirrorless ones couldn't keep up with my needs and failed me either in low light or focus tracking. The D7200 was great while it worked
column5: but about a month after purchase it had a shutter malfunction and I decided to return it while I still could. Enter the D500...

column1: I actually almost gave up on Nikon. I was trying to find every reason to pick up a Canon since I still wasn't invested in any system
column2: but on paper nothing came close to Nikon. Then it was the DX vs FX debate...I was SO close to getting the D750 since the price point is similar. However
column3: in the end as much as I would have liked a full frame
column4: the D500 won for a few reasons: I'm fine with DX format
column5: and while FX would have been less of a gamble in low light
column6: the D500 has a silly ISO range and actually delivers. Next
column7: and probably my biggest concern right now
column8: the D500 should be near future-proof. Lots of new Nikon tech made an appearance on this bad boy: New sensor
column9: chip
column10: autofocus
column11: tilt and touch screen
column12: 4k
column13: Snapbridge
column14: etc.... .I don't think I will be itching to pick up another body since everything on here should last a few years without feeling outdated ( I feel the D750 already is). As a matter of fact
column15: the D7500 was just announced and I'm still glad I picked up the D500. A final factor for me was the pro/semi-pro body. This thing is a beast
column16: and seems to be much better built than the D7200. The grip feels significantly better
column17: performance is more than I could ask for
column18: and overall I don't think many cameras out there can touch this (for me).

column1: The D500 has been excellent and I have really USED it in the few weeks I've had it. Low light performance is amazing
column3: and the autofocus takes everything my kids can throw at it. Lack of a pop-up flash is not a con for me as it does great without it
column4: and when you have a camera like this you probably should have an external unit anyway. Battery life can drain quickly if you have it set to keep sending every photo you take to your phone
column5: so you will need to keep that in mind (Airplane mode).

column1: The only thing I will say is that you should be comfortable with the fundamentals of photography before picking this up. I don't feel this is very suitable to most beginners. There is no 'auto' mode
column3: A
column4: S
column5: P and that's it. I guess you could keep it set to P
column6: but in that case you are really wasting your money. It is highly customizable
column7: with tons of features and lots of programmable settings and buttons
column8: which is all a true waste if you are just using it for point and shoot. Otherwise
column9: I think the D500 will bring a pleasant surprise to most people that pick it up. Regarding the price
column10: that is of course a matter of perspective. Was it worth it for me? Definitely!"^5^Apr 16

column1: rickt183^/nikon-d500-dslr-camera-with-16-80mm-lens-black/4880600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^0^"I bought this body after the death of my D7000 in a car accident. This camera is far
column2: FAR better than I expected it to be. I shoot candids in low light

column1: The autofocus of the d500 is a vast improvement over my d7000. I'm getting a ton more keepers than I did before - the days of yelling 'Just take the picture!!!' as the autofocus hunts are gone. I'm still getting used to it because there are low-light shooting situations where I normally wouldn't even bother to try that are now possibilities. I'm still shocked every time I use it.
The ISO improvement is pretty insane
column2: too. The reviews of useable 51k made me giggle a bit
column3: but it's true! You really can do things with this body that you can't with others. Matched with my 50mm 1.4 I can pretty much shoot in the dark.

column1: Overall I can't say enough good things. If this body is in your budget just do it. This is one of the rare times where the equipment really does matter- it's that much better than previous offerings from Nikon
column2: and lets you get shots that weren't possible previously. If anything
column3: you will get many more keepers with this body than you did before.

column1: Downside- it costs a lot for a DX body

column1: JerryMD^/nikon-d5600-dslr-video-camera-with-af-s-dx-nikkor-18-140mm-f-3-5-5-6g-ed-vr-lens-black/5715102?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^43^0^"My wife and I were looking for a quality DSLR without breaking the bank for an upcoming cruise and to capture the rest of our lives together and our research led us to the Nikon D5x00 series.
If you made it this far
column2: you are probably like me and found Nikon had a slightly updated version of the highly touted D5500
column3: and while the differences are not massive
column4: there are a few notable ones:

column1: 1) Snapbridge support offering NFC and Bluetooth connectivity on the D5600.
2) Touch screen support of picture advance/scrubbing in review mode
3) Automatic time lapse feature
column3: day changes automatically

column1: 4) Slightly smaller body
Otherwise
column3: and we ended up choosing this over the Canon Rebel T6i/s competitors because it was smaller and did 1080p/60 video instead of 1080p/30. The difference in price over the older D5500 was only $100 more and it also offered the 18-140mm kit in a bundle while the D5500 did not
column4: so we ended up buying the D5600 just as it came out via pre-order.

column1: The main reason we ended up choosing this popular 18-140mm lens kit bundle was due to some research and youtube videos stating it was the best all-day carry type lens that gave some telephoto zoom
column2: but also good results up close and in some lower light situations. Apparently
column3: others came to similar conclusion since this kit is now showing as 'SOLD OUT'. We are looking forward to touring the Mediterranean with this camera in tow!

column1: We also ended up getting the Nikon 35mm f/1.8G as well for an indoor low light and portrait prime lens
column2: so while we will minimize the need to swap lenses outdoors
column3: we will still swap to the 35mm indoors.

column1: As for the camera itself
column2: overall it performs very well but we haven't had a chance to really test it too much in the dead of winter. Snapbridge is still a bit quirky and annoyingly
column3: does not auto-connect to the Wi-Fi on your phone
column4: you have to manually navigate to it each time to use the phone control feature. We ended up buying the handheld remote instead to simplify the process.

column1: Some negatives of the kit itself
column2: it is very sparse. There is no hood or lens bag included. The battery doesn't even come charged. There also isn't an SD card included
column3: even a tiny one that would let you get shooting right away
column4: so make sure to have one beforehand. I noticed some of the older camera kits included these kinds of things.

column1: We bought a couple extra batteries
column2: and a Lowe Pro Slingshot 250 bag to store everything using BestBuy's 25% off combo
column3: as well as a few filters
column4: 67mm UV for protection and 67mm polarized for outdoor bright glare shooting. Overall very happy with the camera and everything we purchased so far
column5: we'll be sure to test it out more in the future!"^5^Jan 26

column1: Eeyore75^/nikon-d5600-dslr-video-camera-with-af-s-dx-nikkor-18-140mm-f-3-5-5-6g-ed-vr-lens-black/5715102?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"I previously had a D5300 that I adored and this one is a slight upgrade. Took a little getting used to because some of the controls are a little different
column2: but I like it. My old 18mm-55mm lens aggravated me because I was switching it out very often for the 55mm-300mm lens. With this 18mm-140mm lens the need to switch lenses is greatly reduced
column3: but the tradeoff is that this lens is heavier. The camera itself is lighter than my old 5300
column4: so it's really not much different other than now I have to pay closer attention to keep from bumping my lens when I'm in crowded places or climbing on and off rides (ex: Disney World). Overall I think it is worth it to avoid having to switch lenses as often. The picture quality from this camera is wonderful. I've had more than a few people comment on my photos asking if I was a professional."^5^May 23

column1: I upgraded to this camera from the Canon T6s
column3: and other really nice features that this camera doesn't have. which is why I gave it 4 stars instead of 5. Granted

column1: I shoot outdoors predominantly

column4: but it's still a nice feature to have. I simply don't have the need to use my phone or tablet to control the camera.

bllackeagle^/canon-eos-5ds-r-dslr-camera-body-only-black/3779204?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^0^"I've had it for a week
column2: and it is everything that I was expecting. Instead of using Macbeth Color charts or other measurement tools
column3: I just took it into the field and shot landscapes and scenics (what I do). It is incredibly sharp and detailed. I photographed some flowers without a macro lens and cropped them. Beautifully detailed images. I have the 5DSR
column4: and I do not see any moire patterns. I tested some low light pictures
column5: and I did see some noise in the shadows like other Canon cameras. However
column6: I HDR'd the same images and created stunning files. Shooting at f22
column7: I experienced the same type of diffraction as with any camera. So
column8: the optimum apertures are still in the f8 to f11 areas. I only shoot raw
column9: so I cannot say how it handles jpegs. I processed my images in Lightroom CC. Because of the image sizes
column10: I noticed a very slight slow down in processing but nothing inconvenient. I used both Photomatix and Lightroom CC to process HDR. The processing time was slower but not intolerable. Overall
column11: I have the same thrill of when I went from 35mm to 2 1/4 back in the film days. This is a bigger jump. I have a 5D Mark II. I would say this camera is equivalent to going from a 2 1/4 to a 4X5. You have the flexibility of shooting handheld. I am excited that Canon made this move..."^5^Oct 9

column1: LRDi^/canon-eos-5ds-r-dslr-camera-body-only-black/3779204?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I love this camera! I returned the 5DVI to get this camera again because of the quality is so much better on the 5DSR. There's a lot you can do with 50mega pixels:
(1) it's like having an extra lens because you can crop very tight and still have a perfect image. I shot sports a lot and my clients always ask how do I get tight shots. This is my secret.
(2) More editing power! the ISO on this camera is low
column2: but not really. Because there's so much detail
column3: you can pull so much detail from shadows it's amazing. Very low noise and if there's some
column4: when you increase the luminance or any noise tricks...it's changing very tiny pixels compared to bigger chunks.

column1: (3) Down sampling improves picture quality. It's the same logic of video ppl recording in 4K to downsample to 1080p.
Negatives:
(1) 5fps is slow...I wish it was at least 7fps.
(2) 50mp means every file is at least 50mb. That's a lot of data
column2: so get a fast CF card.

column1: (3) Video is cool
column2: but I wish there was at least 60fps for 1080p.

column1: Final thoughts:
If you're a photographer who likes to print
column2: wants the best quality from a DSLR
column3: and loves Canon...this is for you! Get the sigma 50 art!"^4^Dec 24

dcisive^/sony-alpha-a77-ii-dslr-camera-body-only-black/6249442?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^38^0^"First and foremost this is a sports shooters dream. Aim and fire and you can be assured of a flawless 12fps experience. The focus speed is blinding fast and accurate with more choices than you can count. The Jpeg engine of Sony has FINALLY been improved. You'll be tempted to shoot more in Jpeg than before as details are better retained without the characteristic Sony 'smudging'. The Viewfinder and LCD are simply 'state of the art' good. The build is all magnesium
column2: light but like a brick strong and weather sealed. The shear choices in custom setup assure you of it being just as you want it when you want it with custom memory setting provided as well. It is NOT a high ISO monster however. It's strong suits are without a doubt ISO50-ISO1600
column3: Once you reach ISO3200 if you are viewing 100% on screen
column4: however in print it's just fine. ISO 12800 is pretty bad from there on up
column5: but most cameras are. It is a great professionally qualified tool. I feel it would easily keep up with a Canon 5DMkIII in all aspects other than high ISO. Not bad for an affordable body. Pair it with a 16-50 f2.8 kit lens and a 70-300G lens and you're good to go."^5^Jul 27

Yosoybrod^/canon-eos-7d-mark-ii-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-135mm-is-stm-lens-black/8753867?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^28^12^"Just wanted to point out that this camera does not have WiFi built in. Your specs list this camera as having WiFi built in."^5^Sep 18

recruiter89^/canon-eos-7d-mark-ii-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-135mm-is-stm-lens-black/8753867?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^0^"Went back and forth between this one and the 70D and glad I spent the extra money on this camera. I upgraded from a Rebel T4i which actually to me was not that great a camera. It lacked a lot of extra features and just everyday functionality that I required and I am by no means a professional photographer. This camera is first off a lot heavier piece of gear than the Rebel series and has every bell and whistle you could imagine. It lacks a flip out back screen and Wifi but I do not find any of those features useful
column2: in fact I purchased an Eye-Fi card which gives this camera Wifi functionality anyway.

column1: Not being a professional but not wanting a point and shoot camera and loving the DSLR functions
column2: I wanted the best and this certainly gives Nikon and all other DSLRs a run for the money. It is a bit to get used to
column3: however it resembles other Canon models with similar buttons and menus. The one feature I do love is the speed and also the 65 point auto focus which also blows away the 70D 16 point auto focus. Pictures come out crisp and clear and with 18-135mm lens is beautiful. Just understand this is a big camera and does not look like any of the Rebel series or the S1 and is even bigger than the 70D. However it is well protected with a serious outside housing and is also weather resistant which is also a nice feature. If you are going to spend $1300 on the 70D
column4: do yourself a favor and spend the extra $700 on this baby! It is well worth it!"^5^Dec 9

column1: PrettyGoodPhotographer^/canon-eos-7d-mark-ii-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-135mm-is-stm-lens-black/8753867?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^12^0^"Very fast and accurate automatic focusing even in video mode. The first version of the 7D could only be manually focused in video mode
column2: which often put audible noise into the video and was almost always inaccurate.

column1: Great color rendition
column2: silent zoom and focus with 18-135mm STM kit lens - particularly good again for videos. Pro-level sealing against dust and water. Cropped sensor (1.6 multiple of full-frame lens focal lengths) is especially good for sports and wildlife
column3: but nothing is lost for great portraits or landscapes. A 50mm prime lens on this camera gives similar results as a much more expensive 85mm portrait lens on a full frame camera.

column1: All 65 focus points are cross type and the center point is also diagonal type. This allows you to selectively focus on subjects near the frame's edges. Even the 5D Mark III has only 45 cross type of its 61 total focus points. The previous version 7D had on 19 focus points and the more expensive (full-frame) 6D has on 11 focus points.

The menu system is identical to 5D Mark III including 6 focusing cases (options) to ignore or include objects coming into your view that might otherwise interfere with your subject. Focus cases also allow tracking of subjects that make quick and unpredictable movements.
Although the 7D Mark II does not have a touch screen for quicker focusing in Live View
column2: it does have silent focusing in video mode using the touch pad surrounding the Quick Control Dial.

column1: This camera has 252 metering zones versus the original 7D's 63. It also has a 150
column3: 000-pixel sensor on the Canon 1DX that costs almost 4 times more!

column1: 1080p videos can be made at 60 fps so that slow motion playback at 30 fps is smooth. Not even the 5D Mark III can do that!
This camera is solid and make no mistake
column2: it's a great camera that will give you years of terrific photos and videos."^5^Dec 18

column1: Gusalo^/canon-eos-7d-mark-ii-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-135mm-is-stm-lens-black/8753867?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^3^"Just pointing out another error in the description. This camera does not have a touchscreen."^5^Oct 28

Atltech2014^/canon-eos-7d-mark-ii-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-135mm-is-stm-lens-black/8753867?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I can't say enough about how much Canon improved the Canon 7D Mark II over the original Canon 7D. The low light is absolutely incredible. The original 7D lens had several known issues. Lens creep if you purchased the camera with the lens was a nightmare. The third original 7D that I received didn't have any
column2: but the first two were awful. The 7D Mark II has a lens lock which solves this problem. The original 7D had a serious overheating issue when shooting video. The 7D Mark II now has SD and so far hasn't shown overheating issues when shooting longer videos and saving to the SD. In video mode the 7D Mark II now has the ability to auto focus and can be set to focus on a subject in the cameras view. The original 7D didn't have this feature. The only two negative things would be that they should have integrated Wi-Fi and SD UHS-II. The 7D Mark II is an amazing camera and the improvements make it well worth the pricing difference between the two."^5^Dec 8

column1: Catnip^/canon-eos-7d-mark-ii-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-135mm-is-stm-lens-black/8753867?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"This was an upgrade for me from the Canon 60D. The 7D mkII is a great choice for someone who is comfortable shooting in manual mode and is looking to upgrade. While it is a crop sensor camera it can compete with the higher end Canon full frame sensor models at a lower cost.
Having a shot rate of 10fps makes this camera great for shooting sports
column2: wildlife and other situations where one needs to keep up with the action. I have gotten some very nice shots of birds in flight that would have been difficult to capture with the 60D and its slower fps.

column1: The autofocus works well in keeping a moving target in focus when using ai servo and back button AF.
The lens that comes with the camera is good for a kit lens
column2: all of the pictures I have taken with this lens are sharp and clear.

column1: One other thing I have noticed is that this camera has a much quieter shutter than the 60D
column2: while this may be nit picking and irrelevant to some
column3: it was something I noticed from the start.

column1: Overall I think it's a very good camera and a good choice for someone looking to upgrade without the expense of a full frame sensor camera."^5^Jan 30
Jerryrigged^/canon-eos-7d-mark-ii-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-135mm-is-stm-lens-black/8753867?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^2^"I owned this for about a month before returning. I was really torn
column2: because the video features are really nice! Plus
column3: there are a lot of pro-grade elements on the camera - dual card slots
column4: clean hdmi out
column5: weather-proofing
column6: etc. The dual-pixel autofocus system is amazing for doing live autofocus during filming
column7: and the video image quality is very good. AND I was willing to give it the benefit of the doubt on still photo quality. I upgraded glass to Canon's L series lenses to see just what the camera was capable of. However
column8: I had also tried those lenses on a Canon 6D full-frame camera
column9: and that camera and lenses were amazing! I could NOT get those same results with the 7DMII. I could get good results with 7DMII
column10: but not the amazing results that I get from 6D. Overall
column11: I'd say this is a very good camera
column12: especially for videographers
column13: but if you're going to spend this much money
column14: I'd recommend going with 6D instead."^4^Feb 8

column1: ustraveller^/canon-eos-7d-mark-ii-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-135mm-is-stm-lens-black/8753867?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"I bought the camera in mid November in order to have for the events of the holiday season. I took photos in many different locations and lighting environments. The photos would look decent in preview mode
column2: but when uploaded to the computer I began to notice how soft and blurry many of them were. The keeper rate was really low. I read several other reviews on various sites with the same issue

column4: but is disheartening if you end up with one of the lemons. Since exchanging the camera the new one has a much higher keeper rate. I look forward to seeing all it can do over the next couple of months."^4^Jan 17

column2: solid camera. But I have all Canon compatible parts for mine. Then I found this open box deal and thought it was too good to be true. I bought it and haven't looked back. column3: so no longer do I have to look at the LCD screen while adjusting my F-stops

column5: or ISO's. The auto-focus is instant and the quality is superb. It has two card slots (CF and SD). If you are looking for a fantastic DSLR (and you know how to shoot on full manual

column1: bbrossard^/canon-eos-7d-mark-ii-dslr-camera-with-ef-s-18-135mm-is-stm-lens-black/8753867?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"We purchased our original 7D from Best Buy in 2011. It has served us well since then and still is a great camera. Purchasing the 7D Mk II was a no-brainer upgrade from our original 7D.
Some of the nice upgrades include:
-Built in GPS for geotagging photos and/or logging trips.
-Greatly improved AF.
-Now has 10 fps burst mode (the original 7D had 8 fps).
-Improved video features
column2: including a headphone jack for monitoring audio during recording

column1: -Dual card slots (one for CF and one for SD). This makes using a wifi SD card possible without an SD to CF adapter if you want cheap wifi.
-New dial around the joystick that by default changes AF modes
column2: but can be programmed to other functions if you want.

column1: -Improved ISO performance over the original 7D.
The one con I would have against this camera is the lack of onboard wifi. While I understand the metal casing on the camera reduced wifi performance
column2: the only way to add official wifi is with a pretty expensive external wifi device (upwards of $700). You can
column3: of course
column4: use a SD wifi card for transferring files
column5: but it does not allow remote shooting like the official wifi adapter."^5^Jul 9

Liyah^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-video-creator-kit-black/5722731?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"Just started my YouTube channel and the clearness of the screen and the ease of using each piece of equipment just makes my videos come out so flawless. I also got this on sale so it was a really great purchase and I recommend anyone who wants to start their own YouTube channel or vlogging to definitely buy this camera.
Please subscribe to my YouTube channel liyameerah"^5^Jan 24
GTYellowJacket^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-video-creator-kit-black/5722731?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"Knowing I was taking a 3 week trip to Hawaii
column2: I researched Point and Shoot cameras to find one to take with us.  This camera received rave reviews.  After the newer model came out a couple of months before my trip
column3: I thought about purchasing it but it seemed to get bad reviews about its auto-focus ability and everyone said this older model was better.  So
column4: about 10 days before departing on the trip
column5: I ordered this camera bundle from Best Buy.  As you will learn later
column6: this was a horrible purchase.

column1: Before I review the camera itself
column2: let me start by saying this is the most pathetic tripod I have ever used.  I did not take my older tripod because this one was smaller and I assumed it functioned like every other tripod I have used.  Boy was I surprised when I tried to attach the camera to the tripod to take a picture in a 'vertical' orientation.  The swivel head only swivels maybe 45 degrees to the side and therefore you can never use this tripod to take a 'vertical' picture.  This seems completely stupid.  Almost every time I needed a tripod
column3: it was for a vertical shot so I completely regretted not discovering this before I left home.  If you never need to take a vertical shot
column4: this tripod is fine but I fail to see the point of making a tripod that isn't able to take a vertical shot.

column1: Now on to the review of the camera.  Before leaving home
column2: I took a couple of shots with the camera to make sure I could show my husband the basics of using this camera as he would be the primary user of it.  The camera worked fine.  Once we arrived in Hawaii
column3: we took a couple of pictures that evening before going to bed and once again the camera worked fine.  The first full day of our trip was the first day the camera would really get used to take multiple shots in multiple situations.  That morning we had booked a tour to take us around to different locations used in the TV show Hawaii 5-0.  We had been on the tour for a couple of hours and were in the van riding to the next destination when I heard the camera make a clicking noise.  I looked over at the camera in my husband's hands and the lens was retracting itself back into the body of the camera.  He showed me the screen and it said 'lens error' before the camera went off.  He tried turning the camera back on and the same clicking noise and error occurred.  We had to finish the tour without the use of this camera.  I took the battery out of the camera and after returning to the hotel room we decided to try the camera again.  After reading online to try to focus the camera on the floor as you turn it on
column4: I tried this and the camera magically began to work again---for 5 days---and then the error happened again.  This time
column5: we were taking a 'selfie' using the camera and the clicking noise happened again.  I tried taking the battery out of the camera for a while and focusing on the floor again.  This time
column6: the camera kept giving the error.  Then
column7: I tried turning the camera on and immediately trying to zoom.  This allowed the camera to stay on.  However
column8: as soon as I tried taking a picture and barely touched the zoom
column9: the same clicking noise and the same lens error occurred.  I called Canon technical support and the representative did not seem surprised at all when I told her what had happened.  She said the only thing to do was to send the camera back to Canon and they would send me a new camera.  She said they do not even fix cameras with this error they just replace them.  I explained that I was on a 3 week trip to Hawaii and still had 2 weeks left in the trip and now would have no camera but that didn't matter.  I was given no other options.  So
column10: for the last 2 weeks of our 3 week trip
column11: this camera became not so affectionately referred to as 'the brick'.  Every now and then I would try 'the brick' again to see if I could get it to work but it never worked again on the trip.  When we got home from the trip
column12: I tried the camera again and it still did not work.  Because of the Christmas season
column13: it took me a few days to get the camera packaged up and sent back to Canon.  Just before I packed it up
column14: I tried it one more time.  Guess what?!  It worked.  I tried it several more times for a few days and it continued to work.  I called Canon back and explained this to them and they said to go ahead and send it back to them even though it was currently working.  I have not received any communication back from them yet but that is because of the New Year's Holidays.  I really hope they don't just send me back 'the brick'.  However
column15: no matter what they send me
column16: I will always be afraid that the next shot will be the one that gives me this error.  The other thing is
column17: if the camera had not 'fixed itself' on the first day of my trip
column18: I was still within my return window at Best Buy and there was a Best Buy location on Oahu where I was.  By the time the camera broke again 5 days later
column19: I was on an island that did not have a Best Buy location.  I regret not taking it back to Best Buy on Oahu but who wants to spend a valuable day of their vacation dealing with a problem on a very expensive piece of brand new equipment that should have worked out of the box
column20: especially when it is working again?

column1: The bottom line is I still don't know what Canon's resolution to this problem will be and even if they replace the camera
column2: I will definitely never take it as my only camera on a trip.  I really wish I could just return the camera because I will never have confidence in it after this experience.  I had bought this camera based on reviews but also based on the fact that I had a very old Canon Camera that worked great for years.  I was loyal to the brand but I will not be loyal to Canon anymore.  They have broken my trust.  I explained to the first Canon representative that I bought this camera because I didn't just want to use my phone to take pictures on my trip.  I wanted to use a real camera.  The lesson I learned is that I would have been better off using the money this camera cost to buy one of the newest iPhone models which would have taken excellent pictures and never given me a lens error.  It's gotten harder and harder to find 'real cameras' since the advent of the camera phone.  Perhaps Canon should think about the reason for the decline in sales is because of dependability!!!  And
column3: perhaps you should think long and hard before you spend this kind of money on a BRICK!"^1^Jan 2

column1: Taz104^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^74^15^"OK. Although the video on this camera is very good
column2: I am not a vlogger and I am writing this review from a casual photographers point of view. I wanted a new camera and wasn't sure I was ready for a DSLR. I've had other point-and-shoot cameras that were 'OK'. The main problem I had was shooting in low light without streaks or other artifact. Enter the Powershot G7X MII. This camera fits the bill. Even on full auto
column3: pictures are amazing in daylight and night scenes. Great color and sharpness. This camera also has many manual settings that I have started to play with and learned how to improve the quality in different situations. It shoots RAW and JPEG and you can shoot both simultaneously. It's a little more than I though I would spend on a point-and-shoot camera but with an f1.8-f2.8 lens with a 1' sensor I am not having buyers remorse. This camera is fantastic! I've seen other reviews about battery life being mediocre. I can say I have not had this problem. I bought another genuine Canon battery to have on hand but so far I haven't had to use it."^5^Aug 23

column1: terryd75^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^71^17^"I wish I could give the awesome camera a higher rating than 5 stars. It really is one of the absolute best cameras I have ever owned
column2: I decided I wanted a point and shoot camera for the times when I just didn't want to carry my full size camera. SO
column3: I started doing some research to find one that would satisfy me. I am only an amateur photographer
column4: but I won't settle for less than the best. The end result was a comparison between the Sony RX100 and this Canon G7X. So
column5: I went to Best Buy to actually try them both. To hold them in my hands and play with them a little. For the life of me
column6: I cannot figure out how the Sony was rated so highly. My personal comparison showed the canon to be FAR superior in many ways. One of the reasons the Sony reviews rated it highly was due to it having an pop up view finder. I tried it.....and it is so flimsy and fragile that I was afraid I would break it. The Canon doesn't have this feature
column7: but is manufactured so well that It's an engineering wonder. I urge you to take a very close look at this G7X before making a final buying decision. It's so well built.....I just cannot find the words to do it justice. And the features that is does have? Wow! I love the fact that us will shoot raw photos. I love the auto focus feature that keeps the moving part of your picture in focus. I love the beautiful touch screen and the way the screen folds out. I love the built in wireless and how well it works. The locations of the controls and the ease of operation. I could go on and on about this camera. And
column8: it costs quite a bit less than the Sony. I've had this G7X for a couple of months now and am so happy with it that I'd strongly recommend it to anyone looking for a really good point and shoot camera with features that you usually only see on a full size DSLR. No.....it wont replace the full size DSLR
column9: and you can still do far more with the full size DSLR. But
column10: if your looking for a point and shoot that will satisfy you when you don't have your DSLR
column11: here it is
column12: ..... It doesn't zoom as much as I'd like
column13: or get you in as close as a DSLR with a zoom lens
column14: but that is about the only real disadvantage I can find on this camera. But within the normal range of this lens it can't be beat. If you need to be able to shoot pictures that are at a distance
column15: and bring them close........then you may not be so happy with the G7X. But hey
column16: there is no single camera that does it all
column17: is there? They all have their pro's and con's. But if you need image stabilization
column18: excellent auto focus
column19: fast FPS
column20: and the ability to shoot in the raw format...and great built in wireless....This is by far the best choice for a point and shoot. Don't take my word for it. Go to your local camera store and compare it to the Sony and You will see what I'm talking about."^5^Jul 22

column1: EanX^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^49^9^"This camera was releasing on June 9th

column1: katnv^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^36^0^"We began purchasing Canon Powershot cameras back in 2003 with the A series and have been through six - upgrading each along the way. In general
column2: we love the Powershots and how well they hold up. I take a lot of pictures and have taken in excess of 75
column3: 000 pictures on each of the cameras before we upgrade.

column1: Prior to this purchase we were using the G15 and I didn't think it could get any better
column2: but the G7 Mark II has completely impressed me. Out of the box
column3: it is smaller and lighter than the G15 and other Powershots that came before. I have been a fan of the flip and twist LCD but I realize it adds bulk. The new flip up design of this LCD is surprisingly useful and they still managed to package it into a smaller case.

column1: In general
column2: the shooting options seem identical to the prior versions but seem more accessible as they are easily selected either by dial or touchscreen. There are also some great bonus features like face recognition with identification that allows for data to be imprinted into the file for future searching.

column1: As I have come to expect from Canon
column2: the picture quality stands out. I have especially been impressed at the low light capabilities. In fact
column3: I am learning to 'trust' the camera more and more as I play around with situations in which I would expect to need a flash and yet the camera doesn't indicate the need. You virtually always get a better picture when you don't have to rely upon a flash and this camera allows you to to get those pictures more often.

column1: In summary
column2: I highly recommend the G7 Mark II to anyone looking for the convenience of a point and shoot but still wanting the ability to create high quality photos."^5^Nov 18

column1: Sjoy13^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^25^0^"I needed a camera so i can film while travelling!
This is a great camera and takes good quality photos and videos."^5^Jun 27

Darlene^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^26^6^"I finally found a point and shoot camera that I love! This is the perfect camera to travel with. I recently took it on a trip where I visited a lot of museums and insides of churches (low light environments). I took about 5000 pictures! It worked very well in low light situations and captured images that I could not have gotten with other cameras since it goes down to a 1.8 aperture. (I think my Rebel with its kit lens would not have been able to capture the pictures that I took with this little camera.) It worked great in the sun
column2: too. It has a special scene mode called 'hand-held night' that captured beautiful night images--even through a bus window while moving. I found the battery life to be very good. I have it set to ECO mode in the menu. I brought 4 batteries with me
column3: but never needed more than 2 batteries in a day. It is small enough to fit in my fanny pack or shoulder bag yet has a good solid feel. The only thing missing is a panorama mode. I mostly left it on Auto or P mode and had peace of mind knowing it was probably going to get the shot. It had trouble with selfies--either the person or the background would be out of focus. You can fix this by putting it on Av mode and picking a small aperture. It cost a lot of money
column4: but well worth it."^5^Jul 7

column1: CMCM^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^20^2^"After a lot of research and consideration looking at all the small
column2: pocket-purse sized cameras available and what they offered
column3: to my own surprise
column4: I ended up choosing the G7XII. I started my search by liking everything about the more expensive G1XIII EXCEPT for that high price I wanted a zoom that went to 100 or more rather than 72
column5: and I especially wanted the faster f/1.8-2.8 lens because I wanted to shoot in some low light interiors in particular during an upcoming vacation. I didn't initially like the G7XII because I wanted a viewfinder and had previously decided I would not buy another compact camera without one
column6: but the G7XII had enough great features I wanted now compared to all the other cameras available that I broke down and got it as I was about to leave on vacation recently. I have mostly been very pleased with this camera
column7: more so than I anticipated. The focus and exposure are almost always spot on for the scene and light I've shot in
column8: which ranged from low light interiors to late day shots
column9: sunsets
column10: and sunny day landscapes. Focus is reasonably fast
column11: although DPAF would be better! In fact
column12: this camera is so good I got lazy and ended up mostly shooting on auto just to make things easy. The G7XII allows you to concentrate on composition instead of fiddling around with various settings. I'm not a big video shooter
column13: but I did a few short videos and the video capability is quite good and enough for my needs. (I don't care at all about 4K video). I played around with digital zoom a couple of times
column14: and it's barely passable if not zoomed out too far
column15: but not good enough to use unless you absolutely have to. I especially like the touch screen functions
column16: and the tilt screen came in very useful a few times so I'm glad to have that. The LCD screen is large
column17: bright and clear. To my surprise
column18: I found I didn't especially miss the viewfinder except in a few overly bright light situations. That said
column19: I'd still rather have a viewfinder (as with the next G5X or G1XIII). The menus are very good and quick to access
column20: also very intuitive. The G7XII is probably heavier than some other small cameras
column22: solid build that I really like. Despite its small size
column23: it feels like a real camera and not a toy. Unlike many small Canon (and other brand) cameras
column24: it has a nice little grip on it so it's not a slippery bar of soap like so many tiny cameras. Overall
column25: I don't regret my purchase although I do hope Canon makes future improvements to this very popular camera or perhaps to the G5X (needs a bigger sensor perhaps

column1: Dereklee82^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^16^2^"I am a photographer and needed a good point and shoot to scout locations. Pictures are crisp and works well in all environments ( bright and low light )."^5^Oct 29

Skydivetr^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^3^"This camera DOES NOT use dual pixel AF or any other phase detect AF system in it. Manage your autofocus expectations accordingly. Especially in low light and in video. However
column2: it does have a noticeable improvement in speed over its predecessor and for most situations it's fine.

column1: What this camera excels at
column3: is stills. It has excellent low and mid ISO image quality. I prefer the Fine Detail setting as my picture style as it provide excellent sharpness and punchy
column4: great-looking colors by default. But there are a number of other picture styles to suit your tastes. I also love that this camera now has in camera raw processing
column5: which can be useful.It seems also like Canon has quietly made some improvements to the lens because it seems a bit sharper than the one on the G7X even though they are supposed to be the same.

column1: Video quality is also excellent and quite sharp. The autofocus is pretty good but because it's contrast detect
column2: you will see a little bit of back and forth motion with the focus from time but otherwise it's not bad. Great for casual uses such as vlogging.

column1: The camera controls are well laid-out. I like the chunkier grip and that the exposure comp dial has better feedback to it. The one its predecessor could be a little hard to turn (but kudos to Canon for at least including one - Sony RX100 has no such dial on top). The LCD is bright and clear and also is more flexible
column2: which means it's a lot easier to compose on in bright sunlight. Battery life is not stellar but once again
column3: this also an improvement over the original G7X. It should last you a day of shooting.

column1: Complaints? I think the major one is
column2: and this seems to be an issue on both the G7X and the RX100 series cameras
column3: is that dust can easily get inside the lens. Even though the camera has a built-in automatic lens cap
column4: it does a poor job at keeping dust and other particles out.

column1: But overall
column2: a great enthusiast compact camera. The 1' Sony sensor inside is still relatively small compared to APSC rebels or mirrorless but it punches above its weight in image quality. If you really don't see yourself going much beyond the kit lens if you were to buy a Rebel
column3: this could be a great alternative. It takes great photos and video
column4: has improved AF and battery life over the original
column5: and it comfortable to shoot with."^5^Mar 25

column1: TechMom^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^1^"This is an AWESOME camera!!! It's a worthy replacement for my old Canon G12 that served me well for many years

column1: Leebo^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"I originally purchased a mirrorless DSLR as I am going on a trip later this year
column2: but after evaluating the package decided to go with this camera instead. This was due to smaller size for travel
column3: previous reviews and performance. The camera does not possess a electronic viewfinder
column4: but for what I am going to use it for it should be fine. Also note that the camera does NOT have the ability to be water resistant nor is the lens protected when the camera is open. If you want to use it wet weather or even underwater there is an optional external case you can buy from Canon but it is expensive. A better option if you are going to use it outdoors is the Canon GX3 which is weatherproof but an older camera and is more expensive and is quite a bit larger. The lens protection problem can be accomplished with a lens filter adapter from Lensmate and a UV filter mounted on it. The adapter and 3 filters is available in a kit and is around $55. Do this to protect your lens
column5: but it does add some thickness to the camera (livable). Better to destroy a UV filter than your lens!.Overall a great camera so far and takes great pictures
column6: allows many of the manual controls that the less expensive point and shoots do not have
column7: but is also a good beginner camera as it basically is a point and shoot out of the box. A big bang for the dollar! I have not had this camera long
column8: so the long term jury is out

column1: Mark^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"I was looking for a portable camera that I could carry in my pocket. I have a couple other Canon cameras
column2: so I naturally decided to purchase the G7X Mark II.

column1: Overall
column2: it's a good camera. The image quality is great in good lighting
column3: but the amount of noise in higher ISO images is a bit disappointing. It's auto-focus is fairly quick
column4: but sometimes it doesn't lock the first time. It has a good zoom range for a compact camera
column5: and the lens quality is good.

column1: I took pictures and video in a variety of lighting conditions. It does very well for shooting video in low-light
column2: and is a very impressive camera in this regard.

column1: On day 2
column2: I noticed that the camera had a hot pixel while shooting video. Ultimately
column3: I returned the camera for this flaw
column4: so I did not have much of an opportunity to test it beyond a few days. I could not find an option in the menu to remap the hot pixel. The time I did spend with it was a pleasure
column5: and it was a good camera.

column1: The image colors are true to Canon
column2: and embody the warmth that Canon is known for. If the still images were sharper in lower lighting conditions and if it did not have the hot pixel during video
column3: I would have kept the camera."^4^Nov 26

AppleAddict^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-video-camera-black/5015000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^2^"Compact design. Tilt Touch Screen LCD to ensure you're composing the shot you want and focusing where you need to be on the run. Perfect for theme parks and on-the-go when coupled with the Mini Joby Gorilla Pod. Respectable optical zoom and full range of functionality from as automatic or manually set as you'd prefer. Acceptable pop-up flash (fragile). Full HD Video recording at both 30 and 60 fps.
So Why No 5 Star Rating You Ask?? Simple. 3 Major Points.
- This Canon is NOT capable of 4K video.
- The Battery life is sub-par IMO (pick up a couple of extras batteries)
- The Mic is in a less-than-ideal location. The natural position for holding the camera tends to cover up the mic. So avoid temptation
column2: pay attention and refrain from natural instincts.. in time your muscle memory will kick in and you'll get use to it."^4^Jan 30

column1: pauldar^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^80^21^"At the tender age of thirty-five (1978) I purchased my very first Polaroid Land Camera. Oh my! It was the SX-70
column3: Polarsonic Autofocus Model 2 camera. What FUN. It was the very first
column4: Instamatic-film-camera for me and I thoroughly enjoyed using it. I took hundreds of FUN pics of my family and friends
column5: and
column6: also as photographic evidence of just how large that fish I caught actually was. So
column7: when I had the opportunity to evaluate a complimentary
column8: Polaroid OneStep2
column9: I jumped at the chance to re-live those nostalgic memories of over forty years ago in exchange for an honest and comprehensive review.

column1: The Polaroid Originals - OneStep 2 Viewfinder Analog Instant Film Camera is a very simple instamatic camera to operate. Maybe a little too simple in my world. I was able to take pictures
column3: within ten minutes including loading a film pack in the camera. However
column4: it took me over five rolls of color film to finally get the same caliber of developed analog pictures I was once familiar with so many years ago. I was ready to 'give-up'
column5: but still wanted to love this type of camera. Then
column6: I began meticulously pouring over the directions and soon realized that there were certain steps that had to be followed to the letter for bang-up photos. This I-Type film is not inexpensive when used as haphazardly as I did at first
column7: wasting much of it. Fortunately for me
column8: my local Best Buy had an ample supply of I-Type Color Film in stock. I got overconfident because I had a Polaroid back in the late 70's
column9: which I thought
column10: made me an 'experienced' user. No way! Most of my prints had that washed-out look because I did NOT keep the developing print safely out of the light. So
column11: first
column12: let me make one important point about the Polaroid OneStep2  Immediately after taking a photo
column13: plunge the developing print into total darkness as is available while it is still under the film shield. I started to carry an old black camera bag around with me every time I used this Polaroid OneStep2. It is not only handy for carrying the camera and film
column14: but most importantly
column15: provides a dark space to keep the ejected film print from being exposed to light (see attached pics). Remember that 'light' is your friend while taking photos with the camera. But
column16: because of the light sensitivity of the film
column17: 'light' becomes your enemy while the print is developing. The Polaroid OneStep2 is an analog instamatic camera
column18: which gives you sharp and clear
column19: color
column20: or
column23: developed prints. As long as you take the time to follow all the steps necessary to take great photos in the first place. It is NOT a digital camera like the ones on your Smart Phone measured in megapixels with preview and edit functions. The Polaroid OneStep2 gives you an instant print that you can actually touch and feel and share immediately with family and friends.

column1: *** After more then two weeks of use and five rolls of film
column2: this is what I found to be strategic in getting the best quality photos from this Polaroid OneStep2: ***

column1: * User Manual  Thoroughly read the User Manual and become familiar with the 'mechanics' of taking quality analog
* Polaroid Website  At 'Support' there is a link to 'How to get the most out of Polaroid Originals film'. It details many important items like proper storage of film
column3: temperature
column4: exposure compensation
column5: light shielding of 'just-taken' photos
column6: preservation of developed photos
column7: etc.

column1: * How To Take Great Photos  Helpful steps are found on the inside of the cardboard container the film pack is housed in
column2: of all places. I found the points outlined in this carton to be so vital for successful prints. Read and Heed.

column1: * Use The Viewfinder Correctly  Since the focal length of the fixed focus lens is 106mm
column2: and your objects or subjects are mostly over three feet from the camera  they will turn out great. Keep in mind that 106mm focal length is almost telescopic
column3: but just fine for photos over three feet away. Pics less than three feet must be compensated through the viewfinder by taking pics aiming lower and to the right of what you 'see' in the viewfinder
column4: especially for close-up shots. The viewfinder does not look directly into the lens of this camera. But the viewfinder tube helps correct for any parallax error so your photos should be perfectly framed!

column1: * Hold Steady  It is very important the you hold the camera as steady as possible. Since this Polaroid StepOne2 is NOT digital
column3: there is no anti-shake software to steady your photo shoot. It comes with a neck strap and if you hold the camera to your cheek pushing out on the neck strap as you gaze through the viewfinder
column4: you can take a pretty steady photo. I ruined several dozen photos from NOT holding the camera steady enough. There is a standard tripod connection at the bottom of this camera. But
column5: I was able to take very non-blurry pics after learning how to keep the Polaroid camera from shaking by using the strap.

column1: * Shielding Developing Pics  I ruined so many photos
column3: from NOT shielding them correctly from the light right after taking them. Polaroid Originals I-Type film is sensitive to light even after it has been ejected from the camera. During these sensitive first few seconds
column4: the film shield installed on your camera will extend on top of the photo and protect it from light. This allows enough time for the blue opacification layer to spread over the whole image. Shielding the photo during development time will ensure that you get deeper saturation
column5: sharper details and that your final image is not washed-out
column6: like so many of mine were. Polaroid suggests to shield your just taken photo for at least six minutes. You can place the developing print into a bag
column7: pocket
column8: or any other dark place you can find. Be prepared. I eventually learned to put my developing pics in my black camera bag to shield them from light sensitivity while developing. Polaroid also states that it takes approximately fifteen minutes to fully develop I-Type photo film prints. A bit longer can't hurt.

column1: * Light Adjustment - If you are shooting using your cameras built-in flash
column2: make sure that the lighten/darken wheel or slider of your camera is adjusted to the middle position at first. I have never had to adjust this setting from the middle position
column3: even outdoors. Keep in mind that the built-in flash on Polaroid cameras is usually only effective in a range of 1  2.5 meters (3.3  8.2 ft) indoors. You have the option to turn the flash OFF. However
column4: unless you are really trying to save battery life
column5: or
column6: taking many photos exclusively outdoors
column7: I could not find a reason to ever turn the flash OFF.

column1: * Film Storage - Polaroid Original film packs should be stored in their unopened
column2: sealed packaging in a cool and dry environment. Polaroid recommends storing your film flat inside a fridge at a constant temperature between 4  18C / 41  65F.

column1: * Regularly Check Film Rollers - Their are two rollers inside the film door of your camera. They are responsible for spreading the chemistry between the negative and positive part of the photo. If they are dirty
column2: the chemistry will not be spread evenly. This is the most common source of undesirable film defects according to Polaroid. So
column3: Polaroid suggests to inspect the rollers each time you load film into the camera. It is good practice to carry a cloth with you for cleaning the rollers each time you insert a new pack of film. I now keep one handy in my camera bag. It took me four rolls of film to finally figure out the rollers needed cleaning. YUK!

column1: *** Conclusion: ***

The Polaroid VF OneStep2 Analog Camera is a lot of FUN to use if you take the time to thoroughly understand the mechanics and necessary steps to insure successful photos. I wasted good film by not taking the time to realize the relevant basics. I do now and really love using this camera. What is interesting is that family and friends want a photo they can keep too. So
column2: I wind up taking the same shots twice a lot. But
column3: that is what this camera is really about - Instant photo prints to touch
column4: keep
column5: and share. WooHoo! I highly recommend this camera
column6: especially for 'beginners' and kids over the age of ten. It is easy to operate and gives younger folks opportunities for impromptu photos
column7: that would otherwise be forgotten and eventually deleted on a Smart Phone. I am only giving this camera four stars because I think Polaroid could do a much better job emphasizing one of the most important steps
column8: shielding the developing photo print immediately from light. I don't ever remember having to do such with my old SX 70 forty years ago. Polaroid could recommend better ways to do so other then sticking the developing print in your pocket
column9: etc. They could feature and make available a camera bag similar to what I use for buyers of their Polaroid OneStep2 Analog Camera. Still
column10: I think you will enjoy taking pics with this camera. It is FUN seeing the finished product in your hands
column11: and
column12: like they say
column13: A picture is worth more then a thousand words."^4^Jun 12

column1: optimummind^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^28^8^"======= Summary =======

The Polaroid Originals OneStep 2 camera is a neat retro-cool camera that satisfies your desire for a physical printed photograph minutes after it has been taken. The pictures have a cool retro vibe and atmosphere to it that some people will find artsy and attractive. Although the Black & White pictures come out fantastic
column2: the quality of the color pictures fall a bit short compared to modern digital and smartphone cameras. As long as one is okay with that and is willing to keep paying for the relatively expensive Polaroid film refills
column3: the OneStep 2 will delight you with its atmospheric and artsy pictures.

column1: *** Pros ***
-Cool retro design and vibe for those who appreciate this kind of stuff.
-Near instant gratification of having a physical photo in your hands after shooting sessions.
-Black and White pictures look great.
-Retro and atmospheric color photos.
-Easy to operate and use.
-Easy charging through micro USB.
*** Cons ***
-Big and bulky compared to modern devices.
-Viewfinder is very small.
-The film refills are expensive - $1.99 per picture (before tax).
-Colors are muted and lack vibrancy.
======= Design & Useability =======
I find the design of the OneStep 2 to be retro-cool and somewhat cute. Initially
column2: I was kind of shocked at how big and bulky it was compared to modern-day shooters. But I quickly got used to the size and to all the buttons and levers. Using it was dead simple. Load up the film pack
column3: turn it on
column4: and press down on the big red shutter button.

column1: The included neck strap is a nice touch and that's how I carried the camera around with me.
The camera has a simple design and is therefore easy to use and maintain.
======= Picture Quality =======
When it comes to consistency in photo quality
column2: I had much better luck with Black and White photos. When shooting in Color
column3: I had mixed results. Sometimes my subject was too blurry
column4: sometimes too washed out
column5: sometimes too overexposed
column6: etc. But when I did get the right shot
column7: the color shots looked decent with enough detail and color vibrancy.

column1: Colors
column3: come out too muted and I wished for more vibrancy and dynamic range.

column1: Still
column2: I had lots of fun shooting with the OneStep 2 and got many decent shots out of the film pack.

column1: The Polaroid OneStep 2 is a fun camera to have around. After a few minutes of development time
column2: you have a photograph right there in your hands. It is very simple to operate and use although photo quality consistency could be better (through better exposure control). As long as you're using the OneStep 2 as an additional supplemental and 'fun' camera and not a replacement for your smartphone or point-and-shoot camera
column3: you won't be disappointed.

column1: I give it 4 Stars due to the high cost of the film packs and muted colors."^4^May 30

VADarkstar^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^12^4^"Polaroids new Viewfinder i-Type camera system is a disappointment in almost every dimension of its functionality.

Its form will feel familiar to anyone who has used any earlier iteration from this line of cameras - the only major difference is that this camera uses an internal rechargeable battery (so there isnt a wasteful battery included with every packet of film). Loading and unloading film is very simple and the viewfinder really makes this a true point-and-shoot camera.

But nearly everything about the images is disastrous - and in ways that dont even make sense for a company that should have had all these problems solved years ago. The i-Type film now comes in color packs and black-and-white packs - but the color photographs never pop like the old Polaroid shots did - and in every black-and-white picture I took
column2: the blacks werent strong and the whites werent really white so all my pictures looked washed-out and not fully developed. Every picture I took looks awful.

column1: And somewhere between the camera and the film
column2: there must be a breakdown in how this system is supposed to handle daylight - the only pictures I took that looked exposed properly were ones taken inside using the flash with a subject that was at least five feet away - the pictures I took outside were so overexposed that you could barely tell what I had photographed.

column1: I dont think Polaroid should be marketing such an instrument of nostalgia when their technology and chemical processes worked so much better over 35 years ago."^1^May 30
FlyingC^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"This camera is bulky
column3: has a viewfinder and a neck strap
column4: uses film
column5: doesn't save your pictures to the cloud...and I LOVE it! The Polaroid is a work of art
column6: a legend
column7: and it just makes me smile to hold this camera in my hands and take photos with it.

column1: I like that you have to actually think about framing the photo
column2: which usually means moving yourself into the right position to take it. At about a dollar a photo
column3: you slow down and think before you hit the shutter button. Then you carefully shield the photo from sunlight while you wait a few minutes for it to develop. The whole process is magical.

column1: One modern touch is a rechargeable battery which is really nice. It runs the rollers for spitting the film out
column3: and lights up the quaint 'remaining photos' LED lights. The film packs load very easily
column4: and you know when they're in properly because it spits out the cardboard cover piece.

column1: Sure
column2: the photos aren't crisp HD quality prints. But they are clear and have a wonderful nostalgic look to them. (I've attached a photo of a couple examples.) Best of all
column3: in 80 or 100 years when people are trying to puzzle out how to read that old JPG computer file format
