column1: RalphHenry^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"This instant camera is not for all types of events nor is it for detail work where you need a crisp image; however if you want the fun of creating your photo and passing it around at a party or a wedding
column2: then it is a really useful camera. I think some bad reviews are caused because the user had an expectation of picture quality similar to an expensive digital SLR camera. If that is what you need
column3: then this camera is not for you. If you just want a simple easy to use and enjoyable camera to play around with
column4: then you will like this camera. One other note before I get into some of the details of my review: Many people found it troublesome that the viewfinder did not show you the actual view from through the lens. Polaroid has made an update that is an extension to the viewfinder that solved this problem. Be sure you purchase one with the extended viewfinder.

column1: This camera will accept i-Type or 600 film. 600 film has a battery in it which you dont need since this camera has an internal re-chargeable lithium battery. The battery is good on one charge for 15-20 8-shot packs of film. Just get the i-Type film which is cheaper. I did see that Polaroid Originals warns against using the film in temperatures colder than 55 degrees Fahrenheit.
Youll need to shoot from 2 to infinity so close ups are not something you can do. It has a built-in flash and you need to use the flash at all times indoors. Outdoors
column3: you can simply hold a button on the back of the camera which is in-line with the shutter button on the front so it is easy to do. It has a self-timer which is necessary to get the shooter in a party shot and it was fun to use.

column1: The color photos are sort of tinged a tan-yellow color for all images whether exposed indoors or outdoors. You do need to understand that once you take a photo you need to let it develop about 10 minutes before you can expose it to light. So instant just means you dont need a printer or a photography studio to see the photo you took
column2: but you dont see it right away. Again as long as you understand this
column3: it is still a hoot to use these cameras at parties  you just make a game of placing the photo face down for a few minutes at least. One easy way I found to protect the image is to turn the camera upside down while you remove the photo from the black roll-up tongue that covers it
column4: then place it face-down. The black roll-up tongue goes back in the camera by itself once you slip it off the end of the photo.

column1: The included neck strap is a little difficult to assemble
column2: but it does hold securely once you attach it to the camera. There is a  20 tripod mount on the bottom which is very useful when doing a timer shot. A very nice manual is included and you do need to read it
column3: it tells you how to know battery status and many details that are simple enough
column4: but you need to learn them. By the way
column5: there is a way to do multiple exposures with this camera
column6: just Google it on the web
column7: and youll see how.

column1: Now here is why I would buy this camera personally: the black/white film is super nice. The picture is much clearer with more detail than the color film; and the retro look of b/w is very cool I think. I love this camera anyway and this b/w film makes it really wonderful."^5^Jun 1
CAPNDigital^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I wanted so much to enjoy this throw back camera

column1: mikeheel^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Retro instant film cameras really began it hit the market hard a few years ago. Polaroid
column2: one of the original 'old guard' of instant film cameras
column3: recently introduced the Originals Onestep 2 as a budget-friendly entry into the market.

column1: The camera can use either I-type film or more expensive 600 film. Since the OneStep doesn't need 600 film
column2: I'd recommend you stick with I-type unless you're also using another camera that requires 600 film.

column1: The OneStep produces pictures that are larger than most other modern instant film cameras. Each image is about 3 inches square
column3: that also means the film is a bit more expensive than the film used by some other instant film cameras that produce smaller images. It's a trade-off: larger image at greater cost per image or smaller image at lesser cost per image. I tend to like the larger images.

column1: Plus
column2: the OneStep looks a lot like the original Polaroid cameras I recall from when I was a kid. As many items are in a retro design phase now
column3: from cars to cameras
column4: I think the OneStep will blend right in.

column1: In terms of image quality
column2: the black & white film is terrific. The images show excellent contrast and strong levels of detail. Frankly
column3: I was pleasantly surprised.Color images are not quite as rich
column4: but they are good enough for the medium.

column1: Specs from Polariod:

tube strobe

Neck Strap and USB charging cable included
Using the OneStep is super easy. Basically

column3: eject the film cover slip
column4: and then start taking pictures.

column1: The viewfinder is large and makes it pretty easy to properly frame the shot. Just like the Polaroids of yesteryear
column2: the OneStep does not offer much in terms of controls. You do have a shutter button and an EV compensation switch
column3: but that's about it.

column1: The USB charger is in a handy location on the back

column1: Overall

column3: but is still portable and easy to use."^4^May 29

column1: Roberta^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I bought this camera for my daughter's birthday and she really likes it. It is easy to use and you get instant

abl001^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^3^"The Polaroid Originals OneStep 2 was a mixed experience for me. While I appreciate the retro experience with instant tangible pictures that you can pass around
column2: I also love the amazing quality that modern cameras produce at a fraction of the cost.

column1: First
column2: the design and build just feels awkward to me. I get that it is essentially a replica of the original cameras from back in the day
column3: but I just feels clunky to me. Personally
column4: I'd rather have a modern sleek design that spits out a great Polaroid. Second
column5: the viewfinder isn't a true viewfinder. That is to say what you see through the viewfinder isn't a true representation of what the lens is seeing. To me
column6: that could've been so easily done
column7: but wasn't.

column1: Picture quality is something that you have to adjust your expectations. You're not going to get a DSLR quality or even a cell phone quality picture with this camera. Hence
column2: I think it is more of a novelty item. Would it work well for parties as an instant hand out? Sure. To me
column3: it's like a portable photo booth. Quality isn't great
column4: but it's fast enough to give instant gratification and either impress or distress some of those who aren't used to pictures without filters and editing.

column1: As someone who is very cost aware
column2: the $1-2 a photo is enough to be all but cost prohibitive. Even as a teenager (before the days of cell phone and digital cameras) I loved taking pictures. Film and development costs were cheap enough you didn't sweat a few extra pictures to make sure you got a good one. With this camera
column3: you better make sure you're happy with the first one because it won't be cheap if you need multiple tries.

column1: In conclusion
column2: I just can't get behind this product for anything other than a novelty item. Maybe for a young kid or a special occasion as something to give guests an immediate takeaway. Either way
column3: it will be quite costly given how we can easily take 10s-100s of pictures on any given event! The design
column4: picture quality (expected given the format)
column5: and cost just make this a product I believe will have a very limited market.

column1: Pros:
*Novelty
*Immediate tangibility
Cons:
*Design
*Cost of film ($1-2 a picture)
*Picture quality"^2^Jun 14
btb2k^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Just like the original Polaroid
column2: there is a learning curve for using this camera and there is a use case for them. Knowing the best conditions to take pictures in is key to enjoying this camera -- read the instructions inside the film box carefully for best results!

column1: The good: It's simple
column3: to setup and use! Pull it out of the box
column4: charge it up
column5: load your paper and make sure that your subject has good lighting!!!

column1: The bad: Lacking experience with this type of camera
column2: you'll make mistakes and waste very precious photo paper! The subject MUST be still
column3: and well lit otherwise it will not turn out like you think. I lost a few trying to take pictures with my family and lost a few precious moments due to movement which made me wish I'd taken the photo with my smartphone instead.

column1: Being re-invented
column2: I wish that the Polaroid Originals company would have considered adding a little bit more tech to help with the learning curve with this camera and help optimize for the best condition (like a shutter delay that is triggered when it senses no motion after the button is pressed and the proper lighting is present). The view in the viewfinder is slightly different from what will actually turn out which I didn't mind but it was noticeable. The quality/consistency of shots will definitely vary as conditions for lighting change constantly and again movement in any lower light situation will result in a blurry photo. Always keep the flash on would be some advice from my experience.

column1: Having stated that
column2: the intent is that this camera is supposed to mimic the old Polaroids so it's to be expected that it would work similarly. So
column3: if you're looking for that and don't mind wasting photo paper to sharpen your skills with it you'll be set. Once you do though
column4: like me
column5: I was able to turn out some good 'old school' pictures which was fun! The color photos are okay but I liked the B&W photos the best
column6: hands down!

column1: I'd recommend this camera overall as it is fun and does bring back nostalgic memories of Polaroids
column2: but where there are issues with the viewfinder matching
column3: and inconsistency with photos and there is no modern tech used to help maximize your success of taking a great photo I'd give this camera an average rating. For those looking for a Polaroid like experience that's closer to the original
column4: this would be great so I'd give it four stars."^4^Jun 3

column1: WhiskeyTango^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^3^"Polaroid OneStep 2
The new Polaroid OneStep2 is a significant evolution of the classic '600' OneStep series of insta-cameras. While still a fixed focus 'box' camera
column3: there's a rechargeable battery
column4: inside the camera
column5: supposedly good for 80+ shots per full charge.

column1: OneStep 2 specs: optically coated
column3: USB-rechargeable Lithium battery (1100mAh
column4: 60-days on full charge); power on/off slide switch; manual +over/-under exposure override slide switch; built-in
column5: always on
column6: auto-flash; manual
column7: per shot
column8: auto-flash suppression button; tripod mount; film magazine form factor same as classic 600; new I-Type film magazines (no internal battery); fixed focus lens 2ft/0.6m-infinity
column9: 106 mm focal length; 41 degrees vertical x 40 degrees horizontal field of view.

column1: [ Just for comparison
column3: SX-70 OneStep Sonar): all glass optics
column4: variable radar (or manual) focus
column5: disposable flashbar
column6: no self-timer (but remote trigger-able)
column7: many manual exposure settings
column8: close-ups/macro shots

column1: I-Type film: no battery inside the magazine
column3: if no battery?). Allegedly
column4: I-Type film is *chemically identical* (but not colorimetry identical) to classic Polaroid 600. OneStep 2 can also use 600 magazines (even with dead magazine batteries). Both film types are best stored under refrigeration.

column1: 8-LED-dot remaining shots indicator
column2: rather than a numreric countdown window. Once a magazine is loaded
column3: don't open the loading door again until the magazine is completely expended (or unless you know how to manually re-insert a black/blank card on top of unexposed shots remaining in magazine).

column1: Always keep fingers clear of the ejection port when shooting. Easy to forget this until you develop this grip as automatic habit.
Viewfinder is high and left of the lens
column2: so viewfinder aiming needs to be lower and to the right of what you 'see' through it
column3: *especially* for closer shots.

column1: You can quickly teach yourself exactly how to off-center viewfinder framing by attaching a pivoting unipod to the OneStep 2's camera mount
column2: extend the unipod by 2ft and point the leg of the unipod straight ahead toward your subject. The tip of the unipod
column3: within the viewfinder will be the very nearly true center of the film frame. Once you've scoped center
column4: fold the unipod down
column5: out of frame
column6: and snap away.

column1: Generally trust the OneStep 2's automatic exposure metering
column2: before playing around with manual over/under-exposure override. Indoor light metering is strongly biased for auto-flash ON
column3: not only for exposure
column4: but color temperature 'accuracy.' For non-extreme lighting/contrast shots
column5: neutral auto-exposure
column6: with auto-flash on
column7: almost aways gets the shot right. (Much more so than with my classic 600 fold-up Polaroid.)

column1: Given the plastic lens
column2: it would be a nice touch to have a removable lens cover for protection during transport.

column1: Multiple-exposure trick: first exposure
column2: press & *hold* shutter button (film is not ejected)
column3: immediately power OFF OneStep2
column4: release shutter button (film held in magazine)
column5: power ON OneStep 2
column6: film is now ready for 2nd exposure. Repeat the press & HOLD shutter button as many times as you think you can get away with (might want to manually set OneStep 2 to UNDEREXPOSE each frame in some multi-exposure shots). Press and normally release shutter button on final exposure. You might need to blackout tape the autoflash
column7: if you want no flash multi-exposures
column8: because successful snap & hold is trickier than it initially seems.

column1: Multi-exposure shots will
column3: throw off your remaining shot count
column4: because the One Step 2 counts shutter actions
column5: not film ejections.

column1: Not every double exposure will be a keepsake
column2: but those that are can be magical.

column1: OneStep 2 color film white balance is off
column2: recording 5k Kelvin daylight white as a greenish toned 3.8k Kelvin
column3: skewing blues toward green. This doesn't happen with Fuji Instax film and it's even slightly greener than original 20th century Poloroid film.

column1: That color shift is OK by me
column2: because there has always been an 'impressionistic'/artistic component to opportunistic/candid Polaroid photography. It's Polaroid's instant photography answer to sepia-toned-by-natural-aging B&W photo prints. A lot of people
column3: myself included
column4: like it for what it is.

column1: Optically
column2: the OneStep 2 doesn't capture anything close to the same level of fine details as Fuji Instax. For absolute color and detail accuracy
column3: the OneStep 2 falls well behind Fuji Instax. (I also like the color accuracy of Fuji Instax
column4: but for completely different reasons.)

column1: There is a whole realm of artistic
column2: instant photography that was created using Polaroid cameras/film. Call it both point-and-shoot spontaneous and impressionistic (warmer color pallet
column3: softer focus) in memory.

column1: Another big thing is giving your snapshot away to your subject. Recalling a kinder and gentler time.
I like this re-invented OneStep 2
column2: even though it will never replace my prized SX-70. The OneStep 2 is destined to go on more riskier jaunts.

column1: If you are a fan of Polaroid's impressionistic capture
column3: then I recommend this one for you to try. No easier way to join the ranks. It's fun.

column1: My only lament is that Polaroid needs to fully replicate the photographic colorimetry of the no longer made 20th century Poloroid film
column3: using the current film chemistry. This might wind up requiring a change to the optical coating on the polycarbonate lens
column4: rather than trying to fully replicate an elusive original film recipe (the one that developed faster and required no frog's-tongue/window-shade light-cover-on-eject kludge). Polaroid should seriously work on this and
column5: perhaps
column6: come up with a user swappable lens."^4^Jun 2

dronedad^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This fun retro throwback is one of the great things about technology in 2018. This camera looks and feels like the old polaroids
column2: but it has been updated and modernized with an internal rechargeable battery
column3: flash
column4: and LED indicators for battery and film remaining. The film is a little pricey compared to the other options on the market
column5: pricing out to about $1.95 a photo if I did the math right. Also make sure you carefully read the instructions on the film
column6: as mishandling during the 'processing' could lead to imperfections or mis-exposures. I felt a little bit like the colors weren't as bright as they could be
column7: but I haven't gone through more than one package of the film yet. For nostalgia lovers
column8: this is your gig. One has to remember the old Polaroid quality of the 80s and expect that instead of perfection. If you're looking for a modern instant camera I would invite you to compare this to some of the available instax models. Fun to shoot and play around with! Overall I love it and will probably keep the film in stock at home."^3^Jun 20

column1: BBReviewer^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Bringing back the popular instant camera from the 70's seems like an interesting idea
column2: and it can be fun. But gone are the days of needing to wait 10-15 minutes to get that printed square photo. With smart phones we can get immediate photos that we can send to anyone or save forever. We can get them printed at lots of places (even Shutterfly) for about 5/photo. The film for this camera costs about $16 for 8 photos ($2 each).

column1: This camera is simple to use... Point
column3: wait 10-15 minutes for your photo to develop. Oops! Too dark... Adjust the brightness... Oh no! Too light. That's $4 already in the trash. This camera is also big and clunky. There is a neck strap
column4: but who wants that big camera hanging on their neck?

column1: I just don't get the need for this camera in this day and age. It is too difficult to get that good shot especially for the price of each photo and it is basically featureless. What seemed like a good idea just isn't worth it."^3^Jun 13

RacineTechie^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"The design and feel of the camera is just about exactly like the old models I used in the 70s/80s -I'm old(er) and this camera made me feel like a kid again. It worked like a charm and in minutes we had shot our first snapshot and were hooked.
We used it at a yard party and parade and looking at the photos was hilarious. Seeing them in this format again for the first time in years
column2: they instantly looked like 'old photos' from an album.

column1: I think it is also interesting for younger people and kids to see what it was like in the old days - our nieces both have the pic-300s now and get a kick out of them. Buying film with their allowance is also teaching them about the value of money and how they spend it. The film isn't cheap
column2: so they have to pick their shots carefully."^5^Jun 12

column1: DarthNeyehilus^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This camera is cool.
Really
column2: it is. Everything about it works well
column3: and it looks great. Basically
column4: if you're looking for a functioning
column5: retro-infused camera
column6: this is it. The only real cons are that the initial price tag is steep
column7: in my opinion
column8: and the photos on the film used could be better.

column1: The good: upon unboxing
column2: it's clear this is a no-frills camera. It houses a rechargeable battery
column3: and that's about the only external function. Buttons to adjust lighting are there
column4: and taking a picture is easy. Viewfinder is very clear. Pictures print fast
column5: and don't take long to develop. It's a smaller camera
column6: but still too big to fit into a purse. Battery lasts quite a while (have it yet to die after two weeks and 16 photos through it.)

column1: Bonus: you can use older 600 style film with this camera.
The bad: doesn't come with any trial film
column2: the photos printed take a bit of trys to have a nice look to them
column3: only 8 photos per cannister
column4: and the price.

column1: If you can get past those issues
column3: smaller version of a Polaroid camera
column4: look no further than this one."^4^Jun 8

column1: skylord^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"There are lots of options out there for cameras. If you are in the market for an instant camera then I think this one fits the bill nicely. Prints take about 15 minutes to develop and come out clear. I would definitely advise shooting outside
column2: inside light just doesn't do these shots justice. It's great fun and an instant keepsake memory. Set up and use is easy. This is an entertaining piece of nostalgia worth picking up and taking with you to gatherings and events."^5^Jun 3

column1: stevefromtheburbs^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Having been someone who took way more Polaroid pictures in my lifetime
column2: I can tell you that this is a great balance of performance with todays technology
column3: with the cool factor of being able to take and hold a picture in your hand
column4: watching it come to life as it develops before your eyes.

column1: I'm old enough to remember the 1970's Polaroid pictures and what they meant to us back then
column2: and through the years. I've watched my kids look at this technology and some feel the exact same way. They can take a favorite picture
column3: and place it into a picture frame
column4: put on the dashboard of their car
column5: hang not their bathroom mirror
column6: all the stuff we did with them
column7: and see how while you can take a million pictures today and only print the ones you want
column8: somehow taking that picture and holding it in your hand is as cool to them as it was to us (and still is to us).

column1: It seems the quality of the pictures coming out are of a better quality than I remember of the old ones

The camera has a battery that is rechargeable and will last upwards of 60 days (I haven't had it that long to confirm that). But you'll likely charge it before use anyway. Polaroid cameras were something you took with you to go take pictures
column2: so you'd know and have it ready to go.

column1: The film isn't cheap to buy
column2: but you need to remember that you are buying a photo lab with each picture. Printing pictures today cost money too
column3: just not quite as much. But you have to go somewhere to get it processed
column4: and so far
column5: I haven't found anything that replicates the look of Polaroid with anything other than a Polaroid.

column1: Treat yourself. Treat a young person to something that they haven't had a chance to grow up with like we did. Let them see and hold a picture in their and watch their faces as they see it develop. One of my new favorite picture is an impromptu Polaroid picture of our family. Does it look like it was taken with a 16MP fancy camera? No
column2: but it is not supposed to look that way - I like simplicity and the reliability of this camera.

column1: Thanks Polaroid for brining this back - not only for my benefit
column2: but so my kids can live out the fun taking Polaroid pictures for themselves.

column1: You'll have to just try this on your own to see what you think....me? I am totally down memory road and it feels good to use this camera again
column2: but in a more positive fashion."^5^May 31

column1: 1ShadowFox1^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Polaroids have gone away long enough to almost be forgotten...but wait....they are back! Several companies have been making similar products as of late
column2: but this camera has the size and feel of the old Polaroids that I remember.

column1: This camera is fairly simple to operate (except an awkwardly placed shutter button)
column2: has a USB cable for charging
column3: and easy loading film. There is an adjustment for brightness of your pictures
column4: but the adjustments are pretty limited. I used an entire roll of color film this Memorial weekend
column5: and the first few looked pretty foggy after developed
column6: possibly due to me needing to adjust the brightness. I made some on the fly adjustments and kept snapping away. The later shots
column7: in shady environments
column8: came out pretty well...as much as can be expected from a Polaroid anyway. But the end results look very 1990s. But that is almost the point
column9: isn't it?

column1: This is not a digital camera. No
column2: it will not compete with modern cell phones. I would really like to see this camera
column3: even if at a higher price point
column4: incorporate a digital memory slot to also store the pictures digitally. That way you have the feel good throw back picture
column5: but also the higher quality digital copy that you can send or print out as many times as you wish. I understand they want to sell film
column6: but consumers would use both. I am sure of it.

column1: This is a great camera to relive times past and have pictures to put up on your pin board in your scrap room or office. The film is a little pricey
column2: but this camera is what you would expect in a classic Polaroid. If they add a couple modern touches
column3: this would be gold."^4^May 30

column1: callmeageeth^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Analog film is making a comeback. Me personally
column2: I rarely print any photos anymore. If I take a great photo
column3: I generally only show it to someone on my phone. It's just too much of hassle (and I forget) to get prints made. But I loved old Polaroids and love the idea of taking a picture and instantly having it printed to put on my fridge
column4: or clipped onto a cool piece of artwork.

column1: If you're familiar with Polaroids
column2: you'll know that Polaroid photos have a distinct vintage feel
column3: with muted colors. Personally
column4: I love it. This new Polaroid One replicates what you remember from Polaroids of years past to a T. It takes great vintage photos that you can immediately view and share. I love the rechargeable battery and the automatic timer (more on that in a moment). The film is easy to load and unload.

column1: HOWEVER
column2: in an age when we take photos with our phone on a whim
column3: literally snapping a photo of anything and everything
column4: a Polaroid forces you to think about your shot. This is both a good thing and a bad thing. You only get 8 shots per roll of film and at $19.99 for 8 shots
column5: they're quite pricey. But going through the effort of making a good picture allows you to do just that
column6: get a great and memorable photo. With your phone you might take 3 or 4 pictures really quick in hopes you'll get the right one. But now you have to make sure everything is lined up beforehand.

column1: As for the timer
column3: but it's tough to get right. For example
column4: if you want to be in the picture with your friends (and there's no stranger around) you have to find something at the appropriate height to put your camera on
column5: line it up just right
column6: and seemingly hope for the best. This is standard protocol for any self-timer
column7: but the stakes are higher for the previously listed reasons: price of the photos.

column1: At the end of the day
column2: if you're one that wants some cool vintage looking shots
column3: this is the best instant camera. But know that you will be limited in the number of shots you can take given the price. 8 photos in today's digital world is not a lot."^4^May 29

column1: MarkyMark14^/polaroid-originals-onestep-2-vf-analog-instant-film-camera-summer-blue/6333139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"I bought this camera but returned it before I ever used it. My wife wanted the larger square Polaroid film and there are only a few cameras that use it. After looking at reviews I saw a comparison of this Polaroid camera with the Fujifilm Instax SQ6 which also has square film but in a smaller size. The quality of the Polaroid pictures was just like the old cameras. They were not very clear and the colors were not very accurate. The Fujifilm camera took much better pictures when it comes to clarity and colors. So if you want that nostalgic look
column2: get the Polaroid. If you want the square film with the white borders but better quality (even though it's smaller in size)
column3: then get the Fujifilm Instax SQ6."^3^Jan 16

BeezNutz^/canon-powershot-sx740-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6287924?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^43^18^"We upgraded from our Canon PowerShot SX720 HS 20.3 MP Compact Digital Camera - 1080p a camera our whole family truly loved. Great photos

column1: The good is this camera looks and feels great. Comes with an upgraded processor
column2: 4k video and timelapse and a ton of bells and whistles. That is about where the good stops and the bad starts.

column1: With the upgraded processor it seems to have some lag from when the shutter is pressed and when the image is taken. Big problem
column2: I am trying to capture action and you really have to adjust your timing
column3: but that is just the start.

column1: The 4k video in a bright room was grainy and almost unwatchable - i didn't even share any of the dozen or so videos I took because they are so far from the quality I am used to. The focus on the video is another huge problem. It had trouble and would keep adjusting the focus during recording also adding to make these unwatchable.
The photos also leave a lot to be desired. I tried every mode and auto and the same result. Grainy
column3: even in good light. Low light forget it. The 4k timelapse was okay
column4: it takes 24 minutes to make a 24 second clip and that was okay. The photos/video just did not cut it for the pricetag. I took this back. I may buy another of the camera I bought this one to replace.

column1: I returned this unit for the video/photo quality - out of focus
column3: even in good light. Check other reviews and judge for yourself - better yet go try one in person before buying to help avoid yourself the trouble of a return."^1^Oct 3

rhettw^/canon-powershot-sx740-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6287924?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I am normally a DSLR user and have had several including my current a 7D mk 2.  That being said
column2: I bring it for photos of my daughter and her friends at the Friday night football games.  She wants me to video the entire show and not her zoomed in so I wanted something with a wide zoom and 4k for the video.  The video in this camera looks amazing.  Under the dim high school lights you can see the difference between this camera and my 7D but it still looks good.  The zoom on this camera is CRAZY!  I do not use the digital zoom.   This was my first game to use the camera tonight and what I did not like was where the record button is and how it feels.  My other cameras have the button on the back where I can see it and it is easy to press.  The record button is small and level with the camera.  I had a hard time finding it without shaking the camera.  I am attaching two images to show what the optical zoom can really do.  I had to reduce the quality slightly so I could attach the images.   The game clock in the 2nd image is at max optical zoom.  That same game clock is in the middle of the zoomed out picture.

column1: I would not replace my DSLR for taking pictures on a regular basis but so far I am enjoying using the camera."^4^Oct 5

column1: Tesla^/canon-powershot-sx740-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6287924?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^3^"I'm an electrical engineer might be more critical than the average reviewer. I have the original first generation of this camera SX700HS. This new camere is the 4th generation

Kittie^/canon-powershot-sx740-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6287924?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I have been using this camera about a month now. I have had no issues. It does have a neat function where you can bluetooth sync your phone and camera to use your phone as a remote. Just be warned it does seem to change the formatting on the card to do this. Once this is set up the card will no longer be able to read by pc. You will either have to use a cable to transfer from the camera to the pc or use the sync function to move the pictures to your phone then to a pc if desired. There is stuff that says you can sync it with your pc wirelessly though I have not found a working version of this I trusted.

I added a picture taken with the camera. I had to cut the image size down due to file size limitations. At full resolution files are about 10-12MB each. This has been resized to 65% to meet file size requirements"^5^Jan 20

column1: TheDuke^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^44^4^"Though the actual Polaroid brand has been defunct for many years; the name has been sold (and resold) - eventually becoming Polaroid Originals (as of 2017). And
column2: with the new name comes a new version of the classic OneStep camera from 1977.

column1: The OneStep+ is a nearly identical refresh to the OneStep SX-70 model
column2: but the nostalgia may not be widely appreciated at such a high price. The + is incredibly fun to use (especially for those who grew up using the originals)
column3: but the enjoyment is quickly snubbed out when you realize just how expensive it is.

column1: The camera is more expensive than anyone would guess
column2: and the Film (which is not included) costs around $16. If that doesn't sound like a lot
column3: keep in mind that you only get 8 photos - which means that you are literally paying $2.00 for each picture! And dont forget that with Polaroid
column4: each photo is a gamble. Waiting up to 15 minutes to see your image might be exciting at first
column5: but soon comes the realization that most results are mediocre (at best) and there is a reason that the simplicity (and high quality) of Digital has taken over the photo landscape.

column1: Not having to develop film is no longer novel as it once was. In the past
column2: this feature may have saved time and offset the high cost of the camera & special film. But
column3: now that we all have the ability to take high definition digital photos
column4: nobody is driving to an awkwardly placed photo-hut to pay for film developing. We actually can see our pictures instantly. We can retake them and even edit them to our liking.

column1: This camera is not all bad  in fact
column2: it is simple and enjoyable to use (if you dont mind spending money up front
column3: and continuing to spend money every time you take a picture). Synching the OneStep+ to your phone is a welcome innovation and is incredibly quick and easy. This helps users learn to use the camera and adds features that otherwise could not have been included (without adding buttons or a screen that would have further increased the cost). Using the phone as a shutter remote is convenient. It is also quite satisfying to see your picture automatically pop out of the camera after the phone hears your subjects say CHEEEEEESE! The best feature
column4: by far
column5: is the double exposure which allows you to layer two pictures on-top of one another for a truly artistic result.

column1: The only disappointment is that the phone is not able to display what the camera sees. This leads to many awkward moments of looking through your viewfinder while also awkwardly fumbling with your phone. I wish that Polaroid would have found a way to further utilize the capabilities of our smartphones. Oddly
column2: most photo-shoots conclude with the user taking a cell phone picture of their Polaroid picture. Now else are we to share our blurry hipster vignettes?

column1: It is always hard to convince people to pay something that they can get for free  and this is the challenge that Polaroid now faces. I truly do want this camera to be a success. But Sadly
column2: I believe that the skill of taking a great Polaroid picture will continue to be a lost art.

column1: The original Polaroid company went bankrupt in 2001. The 'new' Polaroid company went bankrupt in 2008. Let's hope Polaroid Originals can finally find a way carry nostalgia into the future.
PROS:
+ Comes with a rechargeable battery built in
+ Pairing with a phone is extremely easy
+ View finder is covered with rubber making it more comfortable to hold up to your eye
+ Has a solid build quality
+ Has physical buttons & switches for a more retro feel
+ Lens adjusts for portraits (close up) or standard (distance) photos
+ Has multiple picture options: The most fun being double exposure
+ Allows for Manual adjustment of aperture
column3: shutter speed
column4: etc - which allows a higher level of personalization.

column1: + Can be mounted on a standard tripod
+ Shutter can be triggered by noise (when the group says 'CHEESE!' the Camera snaps the picture)
+ Bright & useful flash
+ LED lights show how many pictures are remaining in the camera
+ Comes with neck strap & charging cable
CONS:
- Cameras price is high
- The Camera does NOT come with any film
- Film is expensive
- Only holds 8 pictures
- Size is bulky and not particularly portable
- Lens is exposed and does not come with a lens cap
- Viewfinder is small and a bit awkward to use (as often you are trying to manipulate your phone while also looking through the camera)
- Cell Phone cannot be used as a viewfinder (it does not display the image of that the camera sees)
- The paired phone cannot be used to view the picture taken
- Picture quality is not any better than Polaroid cameras from decades ago
- Film takes a long time to develop (between 5 & 15 minutes) (which also seems as though it should have improved over the years)
- Comes with a USB charging cable
column2: but not with the adapter to plug it into a wall"^4^Sep 19

column1: Daddio^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"Older People like me think of 1970s cameras as dinosaurs with no practical modern value
column2: but perhaps its because Im living as a (very) mature adult and forgetting how young people socialize. When I asked my 22 yr old daughter to suggest a birthday gift I was surprised to hear that she really wanted one of these modernized Polaroid OneStep+ cameras after seeing one used at a party. Of course most everyone carries a technically far superior cameras to this one on their cell phone
column3: but in a crowded table at a restaurant or party its not very practical to hand your cell phone around to everyone in the room
column4: to get a laugh at a funny or poignant picture you just took. Thats a good way to lose a cell phone. Apparently a real film camera that produces a physical picture that they can actually handle and pass around is a unique and conversation starting experience for todays young people. Most of them have seen Polaroid cameras in movies
column5: music videos and old TV shows
column6: but theyve never seen one of them function in person. Its quite a novelty.

column1: What makes this modern duplicate of the original OneStep+ camera a modern camera
column2: is its Bluetooth connectivity. Not only can the OneStep+ shutter be controlled (remote
column3: manual mode
column4: self timer
column5: double exposure
column6: noise trigger
column7: light painting) from a free phone App
column8: the App also saves every picture taken digitally and allows the user to email copies with captions to anyone they want to. Its the best of old and new
column9: blended together into a real party pleaser.

column1: FEATURES:
- The user can experiment with three different film pack types (2 color
- Light exposure is adjustable.
- The OneStep+ camera electronics and flash can be charged from any cell phone charger or USB port through the included USB to Micro-USB cable. 60 day battery life.
- 1 year warranty
- Produces both physical and digital copies of each photo.
- Self timer and shutter can be triggered on camera or from cell phone within Bluetooth range.
- Close-up (1 foot) or wider lens can be selected with manual lever
PROS:
- Lots of fun at an adult party or for children at a family event.
- Three different film packs available for different effects and light conditions.
CONS:
- The different Film packs cannot be removed
column2: swapped and reused without losing one picture each time
column3: because of light exposure to the top film sheet.

column1: - It doesnt fold flat like the higher end old Polaroid cameras
column2: so it is bulky to pack or carry by its neck strap.

column1: CONCLUSION:

I never would have considered this reimagining of an old film camera if my daughter had not expressed interest. It is affordable and it will gather lots of attention wherever you use it. Enjoy."^5^Sep 19
stoptheclocks^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"I was really excited to get this Polaroid OneStep instant film camera. I mean
column2: it is retro and retro is in right now.

column1: When I opened the box
column3: the Polaroid OneStep. It looks like something I remember. Once I unboxed everything completely and held the camera
column4: it actually felt a little cheap with all its parts being plastic. It is a great thing that this camera comes with a neck strap so it wont fall and break into pieces. It is put together like the orginals Polaroid
column5: which draws on nostalgia. But dont let the plastic outside fool you
column6: this Polaroid has some real nice features and of course instant film.

column1: The built in flash makes sure you have adequate light when taking pictures. The pictures I took turned out better with the flash on
column2: than off. This is also a light sensor that you can adjust. It helps with pictures taking when it is bright or a little darker. That is very convenient especially in evening time pictures. The viewfinder
column3: it shows what you will take a picture of
column4: obviously. There are two lenses portrait and standard. Simple
column5: portrait will take close up picture 3ft and in
column6: and the second lens is for wider shots around 2 ft to whatever distance away you would like to take. It is nice to have a choice. I took a portrait picture of a friend and it turned out fine and met my expectations of what a Polaroid camera pictures take. Which is analog not digital and pictures are not perfect
column7: but that is considered a charm of this camera
column8: like the originals 1970s.

column1: There are a set of 8 small lights on top of the camera that will tell you how much film you have left. A little disappointed here because one pack of i-Type film will only give you 8 pictures. I wish it would hold more
column2: so you dont go through film so fast.

column1: Of course there is a power switch on the top back of the camera. Easy on/off switch that you can slide up or down.
The film is easy to insert. You can choose only color or black/white when you purchase the film. It is a pack of 8 instant camera film. To open the film deposit
column2: slide the switch on the front right above the opening that the film will go in. The bottom of this area falls and you can insert the correct side up. The film tells you on the pack which side to place up or down.

column1: The difficult part of the camera should be the easiest: Bluetooth. I followed the instruction to a tee and I could not get the camera to link the bluetooth to my Smartphone. I tried for a long time to get this to work and found that
column3: I had to adjust how I did it. Now I dont know how if everyones experience was the same as mine
column4: but here is how I hooked up Bluetooth.

column1: Go to Bluetooth settings on your smartphone. Input Find other devices and an Icon for the camera should show up. I tried to pair with Bluetooth by pressing the + on the camera. I was not able to pair the two together. I tried a lot of different ways and finally found a way that worked. Others who have this camera and their smartphone may have an easier time.
So I opened the Polaroid app first
column2: then I turned on the Bluetooth on the camera by pressing +. The phone having detected the camera in Bluetooth mode
column3: recognized the polariod device (but wouldnt pair). Then I went into the already open app and selected and selected the OneStep bar. Then it hooked up the camera to my smartphone. Once I knew this is how it worked
column4: I had no problems pairing the two together.

column1: On the smartphone it gives you several ways to take pictures
column3: Self timer
column4: Double exposure
column5: Light painting
column6: noise trigger and manual mode. This is way more advanced than the original and more fun too
column7: with Bluetooth.

column1: This Polaroid OneStep+ is for the individual who likes retro products with a modern take. The picture quality comes out very similar to the original. Dont expect digital quality because this is analog. The instant film is nice to get right away
column2: but it has to set in for 10-15mins before the picture will truly be a finished product. The film is a bit on the expensive side at $16-$18 for 8 pictures! Make sure each picture counts and have fun. I am giving it three stars because of the Bluetooth problem I had and the expensive nature of the film. Also it is made of plastic
column3: which make it kind of vulnerable to drops or mishandling. But I love the idea and the reality of this camera introduced to a new generation of people having never seen anything like this in their life. It is a fun device to play with
column4: and will be a hit around different events where you can take pictures and make memories."^3^Sep 20

column1: RedScorpion^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^3^"Brief Summary: The OneStep+ is an expensive
column2: finicky nostalgic throwback. It works with the Bluetooth on your smartphone to take timed shots and to scan in your photos (among other features)
column3: but at roughly $2+ a picture
column4: you would be better off sticking to the Polaroid Snap Touch or purchasing a photo printer.

column1: Nostalgic tech is everywhere these days. My girlfriend and I are building our own vinyl record collection. Modern tech is working to make some of these old analog trinkets work better with our digital devices. The OneStep+ aims to recapture the nostalgia of the old OneStep cameras
column2: but it adds Bluetooth functionality to enable timed shots and double exposures. Problem is its just all a bit too cumbersome. Setting up the analog levers on the camera
column3: lining up the shot
column4: and then snapping with the phone is just a hassle. I do like the ability to scan in my Polaroid pictures with the app
column5: but it was a bit difficult keeping the glare out of the scan.

column1: Then there are the actual pictures. The cartridges come in packs of 8. My black and white pictures look good. But my color pictures on the i-type film were awful. 2/8 pictures came out. At $2.00 a picture ($16 - $20 for a cartridge of 8)
column2: I cant see myself wanting to practice or make this into an actual hobby. I read later that the color film is more sensitive to light and that those pictures need to be shielded for up to 6 minutes. The black and white pictures came out better
column3: but
column4: again
column5: this is a hassle.

column1: I like the idea of instant prints
column2: but the OneStep+ is too cumbersome and difficult to be much more than a novelty. I cant see myself using it much until cartridges come down in price a good deal. I love the look and this did give me a nostalgic thrill
column3: but it also reminded me why I love my digital camera and my smartphone."^3^Sep 19

column1: TechTux^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I really enjoyed the Polaroid camera as it brought back a lot of nostalgic memories. The feel
column2: look and functionality of the camera all felt natural. The only issue was the limitations of picture quality and cost of the film itself. However that smell of film when installing the film cartridge brought back so many wonderful memories.

column1: Pros:
Rechargeable Battery
Lightweight
Actual Buttons / Switches
Light indicator of pictures left
Able to be mounted on a Tripod
Bright Flash
Portrait and Landscape Mode
Multiple App functionality via Phone
Cons:
Cost of Camera
Cost of Film
Average Picture Quality
No Lens Protection
::Setup::
It is ready right out of the box
column2: easy to insert film cartridge turn on and shoot. Even the strap is nostalgic trying to get those darn straps through the small plastic bindings. It takes about 30 seconds for the flash to charge and be ready when turning on. The App setup was very easy as well and comes with video guidance. You just hold down the Bluetooth button on the camera and it easily connects to the phone. The app provides a lot of additional features which I will go into later.

column1: ::Ease Of Use::

The camera's case is plastic which makes it lightweight and easy to hold steady for that perfect shot. There is no way to know how the shot will look before taking so it falls back to old school of looking through the view finder and making an educated guess. The button responds perfect to the touch and the film pops out without issue. It takes about 15 minutes for the film to develop so must be patient and keep out of the sun. Battery life is days and not a worry as more then likely you will run out of film before running out of battery.
::Picture Quality::

The picture quality is average and is geared more towards those looking for a nostalgic shoot. It is very important to keep out of directly sunlight and allow 15 minutes for the picture to fully develop. Also just like back in day do not shake/wave the picture trying to make it develop faster as it could ruin the picture. There are two types of film cartridges
column3: however both cost the same 16 dollars at the time writing this. $16 dollars for 8 shots = $2 per shot is very pricey so expect to pay a lot for your pictures.

column1: ::Phone App::

I was really impressed with the features Polaroid provided through the application. Understandable they are limited with the camera hardware itself yet was able to add a lot of useful features. You have the ability to take pictures remotely through the phone which works like a charm. The self timer is always useful along with the manual mode to have the customization of aperture / flash / timing. The fun features is the double exposure / light exposure and noise trigger. The double exposure provides a fun ghost like image or dual image. The light exposure provides a rave like look making it fun and very creative. The noise trigger is great when wanting to capture that moment of laughter or surprise !
::Scanner (Phone App::

The Scanner function was by far the most used feature for myself. After you take a picture using the camera you can then use the scanner option to save the picture to your phone. This is ideal for being able to keep a digital copy of your original shot. You hold the phone at an angle and the software automatically adjusts and capture just the picture itself. It scans it perfectly without any issues and save the picture in your picture gallery.

Overall I really enjoyed this camera and it brought back so many great memories. Unfortunately that comes at a cost as the camera is very pricey and the picture quality itself is average. In addition the cost of the film per shot is very expensive
column2: I can see myself only using this on special occasion. I would recommend this camera for those who wan the old school feel and nostalgic shot."^4^Oct 8

column1: VADarkstar^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Polaroids OneStep+ is a modern update of an old classic with a rechargeable battery an a snazzy app - but these adaptations arent sufficient to rescue the system from mediocre results. The camera is ostensibly a point-and-shoot camera - it has a switchable lens that allows you to shoot larger spaces (3 ft. to infinity) and close-ups (1-3 ft.) - it defaults to flash mode but there is a flash override - and the camera allows adjustment of exposure. Little lights on the top of the camera show you how many exposures you have left in your current film pack.

The application designed to accompany the camera appears to be in testing mode but I didnt encounter any problems with it - I think it is well designed. The camera communicates directly with the application by bluetooth and allows for remote triggering
column3: light painting
column4: noise triggering
column5: manual exposure mode
column6: and a couple other features - the features I tried worked flawlessly. The connection between camera and app does NOT upload images to your device - though the app does have a scanning feature that photographs your images and adjusts them appropriately (assuming you arent capable of holding them perfectly square or perpendicular to your device) - but scanning your Polaroid picture means youre taking a picture of a picture which seems like a bit much to me.

column1: But at the end of the day
column2: Polaroid film is VERY light-hungry and the OneStep+ pictures are only successful when taken outside on a sunny day or taken inside as a portrait using the flash. And the exposures I have tried so far using the new i-Type film look very washed-out. I have found that flash close-ups inside are the most successful pictures but successful pictures arent necessarily compelling. The i-Type Black-and-White film had a nice rich range of grays but I dont think that they are enough to recommend this camera overall. The OneStep+ is designed for the new i-Type film but it also accepts the older Color 600 type film (I havent tried that older style film - I know that I loved it back in the 1980s when I owned several predecessors of this new Polaroid for the 21st century).

column1: The camera and the film (at least the i-Type film) are a pair and even though the film is most likely the source of the unsatisfying results
column2: you gotta have the film to sell the camera and I dont think this film does that adequately. Polaroid used to sell miracles back in the day - now they just seem to be selling meh."^2^Sep 26

column1: couponkingofjax^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Overall: I would highly recommend this camera if you're wanting to get back into Film. They have done a great job keeping the camera simple while adding a ton of new features for 2018. And there's something to be said about having a photo instantly in your hand.

I grew up with Polaroid cameras so its nice to see they're making a resurgence with a few nice updated touches. The camera itself works relatively the same as an old Polaroid. The difference now is that the camera can connect through your bluetooth on your phone. Setup was SUPER easy and only took seconds. Honestly it was probably one of the easier devices i've setup lately so bravo to them for that. The ability to use software add's a lot of new features to the polaroid camera:
Self Timer - the ability to set a timer before the camera takes a picture.
Remote- The ability to use your phone to fire the camera remotely.
Double Exposure - The camera will take 2 photos before exposing it on the film.
Light Painting - Ability to use light externally to add brushes of light to the photo. This is best done with a flashlight or bright spotlight that you can move around and create trails.
Noise Trigger - ability to fire the camera using a loud noise.
Manual Mode - what you would expect from a manual mode
column3: time and flash.

column1: All of these options open up a lot of possibilities for the camera itself and I think make the Polaroid a viable option again for people wanting to get back into Film. There's something to be said about having a tangible photo in your hand immediately as opposed to it just getting lost in your Phone. I felt that feeling immediately with the first picture of my dog Chloe
column2: which I now have hanging on my fridge. The first one in a LONG time thats ever made it to the fridge
column3: so there's something to be said for that. I definitely recommend this Camera."^5^Sep 25

column1: TheTruQ^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I remember the days of the original Polaroid cameras. The ability to take photos and instantly see them was a convenience that was greatly appreciated. Now
column2: we have digital cameras built into just about everything we use for media consumption. No more waiting for pics to develop
column3: and you can send them to anyone in an instant. So why the Polaroid One Step Plus? Well
column4: nostalgia
column5: for starts. Also
column6: I like the idea of going back to the insta-picture days

column1: The One Step Plus comes in a nice tight box. Polaroid has packaging that rivals some of the better electronic devices I have purchased. The box is tight with a cardboard cushioned interior. Included with the camera is a USB cable for recharging and a lanyard for carrying. There is a quick start insert along with an instruction booklet  in several languages. I opened everything
column3: and was eager to begin snapping photos.

column1: Well
column2: thats where my problems began. My first bit of advice is to not only carefully read the instructions
column3: but
column4: in some cases
column5: follow them to a tee! What do I mean? Adding new film? Make sure the camera is turned off. I forgot to turn the camera back off and added my film. It confused the camera. It would not do anything
column6: and it didnt give me an indication that it recognized I added a film cassette. I had to turn the camera off
column7: remove the film
column8: and re-insert the film before it recognized the cartridge. I also recommend charging the unit prior to use. I first used the black and white film. That didnt go well. Something had happened to the film. The pictures would come out with random unprinted areas. I almost thought I had done something wrong  maybe I did. All I know is I had 8 very bad photos. I decided to just move on. I added a color cassette
column9: following the instructions on the guide. First photo Good picture! Finally
column10: the Polaroid I remember. It seemed a bit cumbersome to get started
column11: but that may be because I have now become accustomed to the ease of non-mechanical photography. The photos generated by this camera must be kept out of the light for about 5-10 minutes while they develop. They shouldnt be shaken or blown on  not what I remember as a kid. The photos looked pretty good. They were a bit of an improvement over the Polaroid of old. It would be nice if there was a higher grade of film providing and even better output.

column1: Next
column2: I tried connecting the One Step Plus to my phone. Downloaded the Polaroid Originals app
column3: enabled the Bluetooth on the camera
column4: and Nothing. The instructions say that the camera will just begin pairing when you open the app. So
column5: of course I shut down the app and restarted Nothing. I uninstalled and reinstalled the app. Nothing. It appears I needed to tap the red One Step+ button
column6: but this was not stated in the instructions. Once I did that
column7: the device synced. The Polaroid Originals app allows you to have a greater level of control over the camera
column8: doing things like remote picture taking
column9: combining double photo snaps
column10: sound activation
column11: timer triggered photos
column12: light painting
column13: and manual control of the camera  aperture
column14: exposure
column15: etc. This is a nice suite of tools that work well with the camera. I will say
column16: I was a bit disappointed because I was expecting at least one more feature: The ability to take a photo and transfer a digital copy to the phone. As far as I can tell
column17: that functionality is missing from the One Step Plus. I feel this alone would have taken this device to another level  One Step Plus  Digital
column18: maybe?

column1: I like the Polaroid One Step Plus. It is a neat camera for taking quick photos when you want an immediate hard copy. Im hard pressed to feel this can become preferred over a mobile phone camera
column2: or any other digital shooter. The lack of a digital presence hurts it
column3: in my opinion. The shape of the camera is great for the purposes of nostalgia (looks like one of the early models)
column4: but it is large
column5: by todays standard
column6: and that makes for a difficult choice when travelling or moving about. This one is all about feel
column7: in my opinion. If youre feeling a bit of old school vibe
column8: this is the device for you
column9: but all others will probably not see the need."^4^Sep 19

column1: TECHBEENGOOD^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Polaroid Originals OneStep+
Its possible to reach back in time in your photography
column2: recreating those analog processes you (or your grandparents) once considered state-of-the-art. Grab this grapefruit-size (and weight) Polaroid camera. Make sure its been charged and loaded with either the B&W or color film (8 image packs)
column3: and youre ready to capture family events
column4: or special projects
column5: or create some art. As long as youve got a mobile phone in your pocket anyway
column6: the Polaroid (iOS/Android) App lets you accomplish special effects (double exposure
column7: light painting and long exposures) was well as other timing controls. The Polaroid Originals One Step+ offers a very different approach to picture-taking that can be recommended to imaginative and motivated photographers.

column1: SETUP: Out of the box youll want to charge up the One Step+ for a couple of hours which prepares you for shooting 15-20 packs of film. There is an included Micro-USB to USB cable
column2: but no charging wart. The large
column3: EASY-to-read startup guide will familiarize you with the camera and the film loading process. Bluetooth connection is a bit different. Slide down the back panel RED POWER button and find the BT + button on the front panel and press. Make sure your Bluetooth is on in you mobile phone
column4: but dont try to link from there. You need to be in the Polaroid App which is downloaded from either the Apple or Android App stores. I needed a few tries to get connected . . . I think. The BT LED stayed solid but the App was non-responsive after the first tries. Like I said
column5: it all worked
column6: eventually
column7: but Im not sure when or what I did in those head-scratching minutes. There is a SCANNING feature in the APP which lets you scan your finished photos (and anything else
column8: actually) so you can add these photos to your digital collection. This is especially nice if your Polaroids are in demand and you want your own copy. Couldnt do that back in the 1950/60/70s.

column1: PERFORMANCE: TAKING PICTURES was as easy as Polaroid photography has even been.  Select the correct lens with the top panel slide based on your distance from the subject
column2: Choose the flash setting (go brightest unless in direct sunlight  trust me)
column3: Aim and Press the Red Trigger button to take your picture. The picture pops out of the front tray and around 15 minutes later youve got your developed 3 x 3 photo. Its retro
column4: but there is still a magic to it all. Ive grown accustomed to the easily after-the-fact exposure corrections on my phone
column5: so I was disappointed with the darker images I kept getting. Id also add that images in color were not as contrasty
column6: colorful or as sharp as weve come to expect. Some of this was my fault
column7: cause real photos demand real lighting which I wasnt supplying. B&W pictures were more satisfying on every count.

column1: RECOMMENDATIONS: Students
column3: artists
column4: designers and serious photographers will get a nice set of tools by using the Polaroid App to exploit their creativity or address their unique needs for an instant-print camera. The B&W film resulted in nice photos
column5: color pictures were just OK
column6: but be sure to provide sufficient illumination. The fully manual exposure controls
column7: the ability to do tricks by painting with light
column8: and easily controlled double exposures are all useful for the right person. The Polaroid One Step+ is recommended for the serious photographer looking for another tool. Many casual photographers will wonder why they need more than a mobile phone with camera and will be frustrated with the effort and outcome."^3^Sep 19

column1: ILUVFREEWIFI^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"A flash from the past refreshed.

Glad to see it available."^5^Sep 19

Player^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Bought as a gift and they LOVED IT! Cant wait for the multiple Polaroids! They also loved the fact that you can use your phone to use as a remote and such. Overall

column1: RangeExtended^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"So I liked the design and the retro feel. To me this is a camera for a child or teen learning the basics of subject framing. I don't like that it connects to a smartphone which defeats the purpose of an instant camera. Why would I use it over my cell? instead of trying to add bells and whistles Polaroid needs to focus on image quality. Film price. and most importantly improving the battery. There was a time when they had this market cornered but others are doing it now and better. There is nostalgic value to the name and design but for me that's all."^2^Sep 28

column1: InsaneDiego^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"1970 called and it wants it's camera back! Nostalgic people can rejoice that the beloved Polaroid camera is back! Make no mistake. This is not like any camera you are using today. You will not find crystal clear super colorful images. Instead you get muted or slightly faded colors with images that are less than pristine. One of the main differences between this version and the original 1970 version is the speed of development. I am old enough to have had the original and it seemed like you'd have you picture in about 5 minutes. This new version takes about 15 minutes before the image is fully developed. Keep in mind that this camera uses film. I'm sure you knew that if you are reading this but I'll say it again. It uses film. That means you have a limited
column3: number of shots. 8 to be exact. The film is not cheap. I wish they could get the price of the film down substantially. Right now it's running about $2 a picture. I'd like to see that cut in half. That's the short story. Now for the downsides.

column1: The camera uses a rechargeable battery. The quick start guide should have said to charge the camera as step 1. It makes no mention of this. The main marketing thrust of this version is the mobile app that gives the camera extra functionality. My experience with the app was pretty bad. After starting the app and getting it connected
column2: it wasn't really connected. Ultimately I realized that you are truly connected when the plus button on the camera front is solid blue
column3: not blinking. I had to shut down the app and restart it to get the solid blue. The second issue was that the connection only lasted for one shot. After that I'd have to rinse and repeat. Shut down the app
column4: restart it. Third problem was the app crashing which it did way too regularly. I have it connected to a Samsung Note 4 which isn't that old and it should have been sufficient for a connection. The 3rd and final issue I had with the app was the double exposure. I had it on that screen and when I went to shut down the app my finger must have brushed the shoot button. Tada
column5: you have now made your first shot. Now take another! I had no recourse to undo that action. A bit harsh but I'm not sure what else can be done about this. Just be careful when you are on that screen. Overall
column6: I found that I would rarely use the phone connection. I would tend to use the camera more as it is without the enhancements. The double exposure and time lapse though did work well.

column1: A few issues I had with the camera itself. The flash is always on. There is no 'switch' to turn it off. Instead you have to use two fingers to take the shot. One on the shutter button and another on the back side of the camera to hold in a button to turn off the flash (flash override). I'd much rather have a switch than doing some slight finger gymnastics. Next is the lens setting. You can switch between Portrait and Standard lens. I didn't really notice a difference. We then move to the Lighten/Darken switch. The switch is black on a black camera and the text to say what is lighter and darker is embossed in black. In other words
column2: you need great light to see which way to flip the switch. The most jarring issue was the viewfinder. It was misaligned. It pointed too far down which means that what you think is the top of the photo when you shoot it is really about 1/4 to 1/3 down the photo. That leaves a lot of empty space on the top. Once you know this you can adjust but it's way off so it's a bit strange.

column1: In summary
column2: I really wanted to love this camera. I wanted to be taken back to my childhood. I think it did that to a large extent but there are a series of compromises to get there. It will be great to use for some special occasions but it certainly wouldn't be a camera I'd carry around all the time due to the cost of the film. I wish I could give 1/2 stars out here. I'd give it 3 1/2 stars. 1 star off for the cost of the film and 1/2 a star for the different settings that are a bit difficult to set."^3^Sep 21

column1: What I like it most about this camera is that it has a manual mode with control over shutter speed

column1: Nabob^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"With the popularity of mid-century modern homes
column2: it only makes sense to bring back one of the iconic technology devices of the 60s and 70s. I had several Polaroid cameras when I was young. One of them was the One Step (SX-70). Now this classic camera comes back as a retro device which now offers modern-day technology.

column1: The updated 'Polaroid Originals' version of the camera has BlueTooth capability with the addition of an App. In the app
column2: you can view and edit photos taken by the camera. After my initial use I think I'll be using the digital side of the camera versus printing out photos.....but showing my kids what a Polaroid camera did/does took made us go through the first pack in minutes!

column1: It's a little expensive for what you get when you compare the price to digital cameras today. The nostalgic look and feel of the device helps justify the cost. After downloading the App
column2: I was able to get up and running quickly. Generating effects was intuitive and fun. The camera is large and a bit clunky as well
column3: but that's only due to the comparison with the the size of today's digital devices.

column1: This is a great device for people of all ages but I suspect the baby boomers will purchase this for themselves or their kids (or grandkids)."^5^Sep 20

Spartan114^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"The Polaroid OneStep+ is a great mix of a traditional instant camera and new photo technology. The app integration is easy to use and features like double exposure and light painting are very cool. I especially like that it has two lenses built in and that the app features a Polaroid scanner
column2: so I do not lose my photos to fading over time."^5^Sep 20

column1: aved0n^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I had all but forgotten the fun of playing with a Polaroid camera. We used to have one at almost every gathering
column2: back in the day and anyone who wanted to take a picture could.

column1: This is not a professional level camera. Polaroids never were. What they are is cool. This camera is fun. Kids are awestruck to see the image appear before their very eyes.
Worth having for the fun of it. If you have a kids party let the young uns have at it. That alone is worth the cost of a film pack.
Enjoy"^5^Sep 19

jaybot^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I personally love the look of the older cameras. Its design stays some what true of older Polaroid models. Its a bit smaller than the originals and its all plastic. Being mostly plastic its still a bit heavier than you would expect. Comes with a good manual and starter guide which I found super helpful. A charging cable and a strap so you can hang the camera around your neck.

From my experience you need a lot of light in the shot to get the pics to turn out good. If indoor even with normal light I would still use high flash. After you take the photo shield it from light until it fully develops which takes a few mins.

From what I can tell the biggest difference between this OneStep+ and the last model the OneStep2 is that this one has bluetooth and a companion app. The app allows you to apply some pretty cool features to the pics.

I would personally never replace my digital camera with this but I do find myself using it quite a bit. I do find that people love it when I take their picture with this. It just gives that nostalgic feel and retro look to the photo. Something you can hold onto
column3: and you don't get that with most digital cameras. Yes you can apply filters to a digital photo but its still not the same. Its a really awesome thing to have. Oh and don't forget to put some writing on the bottom of the photo to give that finishing touch. I cant really con the quality of the photos or the size of the camera because its does what its meant to do and looks the way its meant to look. I think my biggest concern with this is the price of the photo paper. In all really fun camera."^4^Sep 19

column1: swagstff2^/polaroid-originals-onestep-analog-instant-film-camera-white/6333622?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^2^"Aweful product! Stick with Fuji... ruturned and got a new one

column3: just JUNK product."^1^Jan 16

column1: olvertroy^/canon-powershot-elph190-20-0-megapixel-digital-camera-blue/4866810?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^86^16^"I have used this camera multiple times since purchase and it takes great photos for a point and shoot camera. My only complaint is the charging system

column1: Battery life is limited - you will need a second battery if you are going to take many pictures (50 or more) on one charge.

Finally
column2: photo/video transfer by removing the chip and inserting into a computer is the ONLY way to transfer data. Any other means is just too slow!"^4^Mar 2

column1: JoeyT^/canon-powershot-elph190-20-0-megapixel-digital-camera-blue/4866810?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^4^"Ok
column2: so a few things regarding this camera. I really loved how compact it was and easy to take anywhere. It shot nice photos and the wifi transfers were super easy. I do wish they had different colors with the wifi capability but blue is all I saw available. Great point and shoot camera that I would recommend to anyone. The only thing I did not like was it did not have a panoramic shot setting!! I like to take photos of nature and things so it was something I really wished it had. It was quick to shoot photos and adjusted well but I really couldn't live without panoramic shots so that's why I couldn't stay with just this one. I'm not an avid photographer but I do like having that option. If you can live without panoramic shots then I totally recommend this camera."^4^Jun 22

column1: JimC^/canon-powershot-elph190-20-0-megapixel-digital-camera-blue/4866810?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^17^4^"Camera is light
