column1: The specific paper is still pricey and you HAVE to have it in order for the camera to work
column2: which is ridiculous IMO. You have a paperweight the moment they decide to stop making this specific paper."^2^Apr 25

column1: Ponskippa^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-pearl-white/6344861?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^3^"As a longtime photographer who had his start with film I was initially excited to try the Canon Ivy Cliq+. After all
column2: it does have a very modern and sleek beautiful design. The camera is made of a slick hard plastic. It is quite slippery and besides the textured film cover on the back
column3: there isn't much to grip onto with this camera. I recommend the first thing you do is attach the wrist lanyard that is included with it. The big round mirror in the front acts as a selfie mirror and has framing guidelines etched into it. The white ring around it houses multiple led bulbs for a 'flash' In my opinion
column4: they aren't the brightest and if you use them as a fill light
column5: they tend to wash out the colors in your photos. The camera does not have a screen on the back but it does have an optical viewfinder with a helpful frame also etched into the glass to help frame your shots. You can insert a micro sd memory card into the camera to save the photos you take with it. It is charged by micro usb and canon includes a short cable for you
column6: but no power supply. I was able to charge it up with my phone brick. In my use
column7: The battery held just enough charge to use a 10 pack of 'film' It will need to recharge by the time you are done printing a 10 pack. The 'film' Canon chose to employ for this camera is of the zero ink type
column8: also known as 'Zink' It takes the digital image and transfer it to the paper with heat. The camera has a 8mp sensor
column9: there is no mention on lens specifications. I was a bit disappointed with the picture quality produced by the sensor and lens in this camera. The camera meters exposure just ok
column10: but the colors and contrast aren't consistent. In other words
column11: I would not depend on this camera to save your lasting memories
column12: or the film for that matter. I did go out of my way to purchase a couple packs of Canons Zink paper
column13: and it is better quality than competing brands. The adhesive seems stronger and the paper itself also seems stronger. The 'zink' technology is very cool
column14: but in my opinion the results are poor at this price point. The best thing about this camera is the ability to connect it to your phone via bluetooth and print photos that you may have taken with your phones superior camera
column15: or even a real digital camera that you may already own! The app is easy to use and transfer photos to the printer simply and quickly.I have included two photos i Printed with the ivy cliq
column16: but that were taken with my mirrorless camera. It is hard to recommend this camera to somebody that wants to take photos to cherish lasting memories with because the 'film' is expensive and yields low quality images. This camera is a toy at best
column17: or perhaps for a child whom you want to teach the basics of film and photography too. If you simply must have a hybrid camera / printer that makes stickers out of your photos for you
column18: then perhaps you'll enjoy it."^3^Apr 25

column1: ZBMILLER^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-pearl-white/6344861?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"The Canon Ivy Cliq+ is a nice concept
column2: back to the poloroid instant print cameras. I really was surprised with the side of the device
column3: most phones nowadays are larger than this!

column1: The camera works well
column2: it took a little adjusting to get used to the framing of shots
column3: there is a little frame to help get your shots
column4: just keep in mind that this is a rectangular shape on the circular lens or selfie mirror on front. The prints photos aren't anything you'd praise
column5: but my kids definitely love capturing photos
column6: being able to stick them onto a surface is a fun little feature of the film.

column1: The Mini Print app is a pretty neat feature also
column2: you can take a photo using your phone
column3: or one you already have saved
column4: and add text
column5: filter or emojis and print them if you choose.

column1: The concept is great
column2: and can easily appeal to the younger crowd. I would definitely recommend if you are looking into instant cameras you check this one out."^4^Apr 24

column1: Linksys^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-pearl-white/6344861?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^1^"If you purchase this for novelty or for a young child then I could recommend it. Being able to print your photos and have them as stickers is cool. Scrapbooking
column2: parties or just as a keep sake and I think youll be happy with the photos. The camera isnt bad but isnt great
column3: its really best used in good lighting even when using the flash. My biggest issue with this camera is that there is no way to preview the photo before it prints
column4: even if you use an SD card. Removing the paper and having only the SD card in it
column5: wont allow you to take the photo and save it to the SD card either. I know back in the day you couldnt preview your photo
column6: but when marrying old tech with new
column7: this to me seems like an oversight. The biggest reason
column8: the paper is not cheap
column9: the paper runs about $25 for 50 or $.50 each if its not on sale. You should have been able to turn on/off a preview photo before print feature within the app. Im not sure if Canon can implement this through a software update
column10: but if they can that would be very huge. This one feature alone could save people a lot of wasted paper. When using this to print photos from your phone
column11: you can obviously do this and change things about the photo
column12: why Canon did not at least add the option to do that in the app is beyond me. This may seem like it would be redundant since you could just take it with your phone
column13: but you would at least not waste a lot of paper on bad photos. With that said
column14: if youre mainly going to print photos from your phone
column15: you might as well just buy the printer and save some money. I have and love the Canon ivy printer and was hopeful for this
column16: but not at least having the option to preview your photo before you waste paper is a let down."^3^Apr 23

column1: Keirmeister^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-pearl-white/6344861?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^2^"I think a young child would enjoy this Instant Film Camera
column2: but if you're looking for high-quality photos and prints
column3: this device falls short. I had a difficult time getting a good light-dark balance. I think pictures came out much better outside in natural light...but in a darker space inside? Forget it. Also
column4: the prints are noticeably washed out.

column1: Here's what I liked:
* It's a good size for a quick camera that prints out your pics.
* Setup and connectivity (to a phone
* The selfie lights and mirror are a smart addition.
* Smooth and consistent prints (no lines like on an old inkjet)
But I ran into many problems:
* The image quality isn't great for both the saved image and the print (see sample photo).
* The case has texture with tiny dimples. This is good for gripping
* 2'x3' prints have limited usefulness. How many things can I stick them to?
* Replacement paper is relatively expensive
* Without paper
This last point is important: If you run out of paper
column2: the camera will not take any pictures - even if a memory card is present! This is even stated so in the FAQ!

column1: So I wonder who the target customer is for this. Even sending a photo from a much better camera resulted in a washed out print; and if there's any way to adjust this directly on the device
column2: I have seen nothing to document it.

column1: In the end
column2: I think this device is a novelty
column3: or better suited for younger children. If you're getting this for a child
column4: he or she is going to love it!"^2^Apr 23

column1: JayDubsFL^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-pearl-white/6344861?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Camera is small and fits nicely in your pocket. We took it to a wedding this past weekend and shot some photos
column2: it was great to have photos in hand before the ceremony was even done
column3: although the photos are very small and the colors are a little off
column4: much like the Polaroid cameras in the days of old. Photos are either 2x2 inches or 2x3 inches (selectable) Does what we expected it to ! My only concern is this - where do I buy more paper for it? It only comes with a 10 pack and those are all gone now!."^4^Apr 23

column1: 30stmrox^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-pearl-white/6344861?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^1^"I am a Canon camera lover

column3: the camera is suppose to be 8mp but the quality just isnt there
column4: the pictures look faded when they are printed
column5: the paper is ink less & develops instantly but its expensive & the pictures are only 2x2 or 2x3 with a sticky back. There is a blue sheet that must always be in the paper compartment or the color is even worse. I also printed a picture from my phone that I had taken with my good Canon camera & it was also very faded. The camera itself seems cheap
column6: the paper cover keeps coming off & is very flimsy plastic. Camera can only be charged by usb & the charge didnt last very long . Operation is easy with only power button
column7: flash button which must be in the fill position to activate the led selfie ring. There is a large selfie mirror where the lens is & you must look through the viewfinder to take pictures
column8: there is no screen on the back. You can add stickers & text to pictures through the app where youll also find the complete owners manual. This comes in a lot of colors too
column9: but I believe theres only 3 colors that are Cliq+. Im not into selfies so I would say this would be a great camera for a teen/tween or someone who just wants fun pics without quality. Ill stick to my digital."^3^Apr 23

teasten^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-pearl-white/6344861?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^2^"The Canon IVY Cliq+ is an interesting product

the phone software means you don't have to take photos with the IVY Cliq+

column4: printing
column5: and hoping you took a good photo.

column1: The big thing you need to know with the IVY Cliq+ is what is the photo quality like. If you keep in mind
column2: it's printing photos in something about the size of 2 decks of cards side by side
column3: the quality is good. That said
column4: the photos do look very much like the old school polaroid style even though they print borderless and come out ready to view (no need to wave the photo paper about). The photos are small
column5: roughly a little bigger than a business card and are OK for fun prints but not great for keeping forever.

column1: That's the thing about the IVY Cliq+ it feels like a lot of compromises
column2: so it's not a replacement for your phone
column3: or a decent photo printer
column4: or printing photos professionally. It's more a fun camera. We used it over the weekend at a birthday party and everyone enjoyed using it and loved printing photos (and the lens has a great selfie mirror built in). It's just not a camera you would use every day
column5: more something you would pull out for a special occasion.

column1: I think the perfect place to use the IVY Cliq+ is for weddings
column3: or birthday parties. Putting it somewhere that all guests can pick it up
column4: take a photo and post it on a wall during the day/night would make for a cool and different experience. 10x better than buying and having half a dozen disposable cameras (can you even still by them) and then having to develop film.

column1: In summary
column3: love that you can connect the IVY Cliq+ to use as a photo printer for your phone
column4: just don't expect it to print great photos."^3^Apr 23

column1: Regardless of the above

column1: RunningMan^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-pearl-white/6344861?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"Although these days your mobile phone is your everyday camera. Hauling this camera around would be for the sole purpose of having instant photos

column5: unlike some other instant cameras I have seen that are bulky and all plastic. The quality of the photos are decent in terms of instant photography. The mobile app adds additional functionality such as adding effects and stickers to the photos as well as giving you the option of printing photos off your mobile device

column1: Parkersspace^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-yellow/6333187?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"Previously on vacation I would buy those waterproof throw away fuji film cameras
column3: pay to develop the photos and get what came out.  It is very difficult to view anything underwater on any small camera
column4: so you kind of point it and hope.  I did get used to viewing the screen through my goggles and could at least make out a large rocks or a shell I would aim for with lots of fish or coral near it.  I could then zoom
column5: focus and shoot.  I am a semi professional photographer but not underwater.  The quality of the photo when taken in highest quality and largest size
column6: though the camera over processes like all point and shoots
column7: when edited to clear haze and shrunk to a 2500px longest side was great and hid most over processing artifacts created by the camera. It did a colour reproduction in and out of water but it is not my professional DSLR.  For the money it was awesome.  Fun and easy to use.  I quickly learned the set up and appreciated being able to adjust the white balance and have jpg's with a high enough quality and size to edit. I snorkeled two days for 4 hours each day
column8: had the camera under water the full time and 0 issues
column9: it worked flawlessly and much better than the throw away i would normally use.  It will pay for itself in 4 snorkeling days.  Attaching photos
column10: they have been edited to remove haze and to my liking.  The wonderful thing about the camera is i can take photos
column11: throw away those that don't work without paying to develop them and keep what i want
column12: and edit them to my liking
column13: unlike the film throw aways."^4^Nov 4

column1: Firsttimediver^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-yellow/6333187?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"I was looking for an underwater camera for snorkeling/scuba diving in Tahiti.  Was hoping for a good camera that didnt break the bank!  This fit the bill!  My pictures/videos (even at 50 feet) and sharp.  Great purchase for the price!"^5^Aug 17

Scooterpie^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-yellow/6333187?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"Took this camera to Bali. Only used it once and actually my dive master used it. It produced nice clear pictures. I really liked the video.
I wish it had a better zoom."^4^Aug 2

snorkelgirl^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-yellow/6333187?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"Pleasantly surprised by the quality of the underwater photos.  I bought it for snorkeling photos and discovered it takes good images of land subjects as well.  Even takes video!  Light weight and easy to carry on land or sea!"^5^Jan 9

mgmdad^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-yellow/6333187?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"My daughter went to Alaska this summer and was complaining about her iPhone camera. Phone replacement was high dollar
It takes picture much better than a phone. It is easy to transfer from camera to phone so she c as n post them. Highly recommended."^5^Jun 14

Calmini^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-yellow/6333187?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^1^"I purchased this camera because of the high ratings on camera review websites. It always ranked in the top 5 of underwater cameras. I used if for snorkeling and ran into several big issues
column2: the main problem was the camera would take a long time to focus or not focus at all. When you would zoom the problem got worse. The other problem was 'bubbles' on all video or photos. Not sure if water got in between the lens and waterproof glass or condensation. The final issue was the glare on the screen while snorkeling
column3: it made it almost impossible to see what you were shooting. Oh
column4: one more thing. While taking a video when you would zoom you could here the motor noise in your playback. No good. I bet I deleted 80 - 90% of photos and videos. Lucky we brought our GoPro Hero 7 black on the trip. I am returning the camera."^2^Oct 11

column1: Robert^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-yellow/6333187?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Works easily. Great pictures. only error I noticed was the operator error."^5^Sep 27
Carol^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-yellow/6333187?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"The price seemed a little high for this 'standard' camera
column2: but I was in a rush to purchase and this was the only waterproof camera in store at the time.

column1: Pictures look good.
The delete photo feature is confusing and one is easily able to delete all photos by mistake
column2: which is what happened to me. A friend decided to delete a photo she took with my camera
column3: and unfortunately deleted all my vacation photos before I could download them. I was extremely upset because of the loss."^4^Aug 2

column1: kevinS^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-yellow/6333187?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I went on a week long river rafting trip. I needed a camera that could take some abuse. It survived getting dunked in water several times. It survived getting dropped a few times too.
Pros:
- Pictures were good. (not great...)
- The multi-shot mode was great for action shots
- Easy to use
Cons:
- The screen is not visible when wearing polarized sunglasses
- I wish it had an exposure bracketing setting . (can be done manually)
spare battery (s) can be helpful...
Overall I'm happy with this purchase."^4^Jul 27

Jac83^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-yellow/6333187?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"This camera started acting up on DAY ONE! I was in 2 feet of water working fine for about 5 minutes and thenit wouldnt turn off
column2: wouldnt respond to any buttons being pushed. Finally
column3: the battery died and it worked again once I recharged it. Very next time using it
column4: same thing. Over and over and over. Now it wont even turn on. Complete waste of money"^1^Jul 23

column1: Rookie^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-yellow/6333187?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I am still learning this camera. The 4K video is horrible. It is very shaky. I haven't messed with any settings but
column2: the auto settings do not produce crisp 4K video. The WiFi download to my phone is hit or miss
column3: confusing and sometimes takes a long time. This all may just be that I am a rookie at taking pictures but
column4: my other cameras/phone worked great for an amateur point and shoot person. I have not tried it in the water yet. I was hoping to get a better grasp of it before pool or beach action. Based on price and expectation to be waterproof
column5: I would recommend this to a friend but
column6: for great video and/or pictures
column7: I am still undecided."^3^Jun 11

column1: Terri^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-yellow/6333187?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I bought this camera because I wanted one I could use while camping and kayaking and also because I was going to Scuba dive in Greece while I was on vacation there. First thing I noticed is this camera eats up battery power if you leave the Bluetooth feature turned on (which allows you to sync the photos to you phone or tablet via the app which is way cool IMO). It takes good pictures
column2: in fact my snorkeling pictures are better than my diving ones. It also take good pictures on land. All in all
column3: I would recommend this camera for its small size
column4: ease of use and quality of photos. Just be sure to get extra batteries and a charger."^4^Jun 8

column1: JDShoots^/canon-powershot-sx730-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5847201?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^46^0^"I bought this camera for it's zoom capabilities...it does not disappoint! I want to take this on vacations and shoot wildlife. When at max zoom

column1: Tabi^/canon-powershot-sx730-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5847201?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^40^8^"I am still trying to decide if this purchase was entirely worth it or not...

Let me first start by saying I am using this camera more so for video rather than pictures. I have another camera (DSLR) I use for photography but it is too bulky to really use for easy video recording. So
column2: this review will focus on its recording capabilities...

column1: First
column2: the quality of the footage recorded and the options are good. Are they they best? Prolly not but for the price
column3: the quality is great! So
column4: that is a plus.

column1: Second
column2: the battery....SUCKS! You can really only get roughly about 45mins to a little over an hour recording time with the battery. The crappy thing about this is
column3: you cannot plug this sucker in! Even though it has a port to plug into a power adapter
column4: all the camera allows you to do when it is plugged in to a power source is look through previously recorded or taken pictures. It will NOT allow you to use it to record or take pictures with. Its like the camera's programming just turns into safe-mode or something. It is weird and annoying! With that being said
column5: if you are planning on using this camera for long-term/all-day video taking
column6: go find yourself a bunch of batteries and charge those suckers up!

column1: Third
column2: if there is not a lot of movement in front of the lens
column3: the camera turns off after about 25-30mins. I was trying to make a time-lapse video and there was minimal movement in front of the camera...but it was still movement that I wanted recorded for the duration of the project. After 25mins it basically did a quick 'inactivity' type of pop-up on the view screen and proceeded to turn off. I thought at first it was a fluke...no
column4: this happens every time I try to capture similar videos. I just turns off...so if you are using this to video capture things such as you painting
column5: building something
column6: or anything that requires you to pop it on a tripod and record a scene...expect the camera to randomly turn off after about the 25min mark. Maybe there is a setting I am missing? Maybe there is something in the options I accidentally clicked? Not sure...but it is annoying and this is probably one of the biggest reasons why I kind of regret purchasing this camera. It is also the major factor that is giving this product a low star review.

column1: Fourth...SD Card memory. I usually use a large SD card so that is not an issue when it comes to space. However
column2: even when recording on high quality (the highest is can go)
column3: this lil sucker does not waste space. It is good at conserving space on SD cards...at least from what I can tell.

column1: I think that is about it...it is not a bad purchase but because of the random shut-offs and short battery life (without the ability to power it through a power source/adapter) I do regret buying this. However
column2: if you are looking at this camera for photography or small video captures...this might be the camera for you."^2^Jun 2

column1: Ace27^/canon-powershot-sx730-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5847201?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^25^0^"First lets remember what this is
column2: Point and Shoot. I've read a lot of reviews knocking the camera without really knowing how to use. I've been a canon User for about 15 years from Full frame all the way down to this. I bought this specifically for travel or when i am hanging out with the kids . Here are my pros and cons after using it in many places.

column1: Pros:
super zoom its amazing . (works best with a Monopod or Tripod)
Colors are beautiful if you have a good light source. ( I wouldnt say its great in low light but it does ok
Video quality is amazing hands down. Yes no 4K
Face detection is pretty good
Cons:
avararage battery depletion at around 240 photos (at least for me )
You can not manually focus with focus points (my opinion not really a deal breaker)
This one hurts me : no RAW only JPG
column2: I suggest take your time if you really taking an important picture to avoid grain or color distortion.

column1: no Audio Jack (unless you can do it Via usb somehow
Overall I am pleased with the camera. Can it be better
column2: absolutely. Its takes better quality image than a Cell phone. if you are a true photographer you will notice the difference. This is for the consumer that like to VLOG
column3: travel light to take quick snapshots. I will show pictures of a Yankee game where i zoomed in all the way sitting on Left field. images are straight out of camera with no editing whats so ever. I think the pictures can speak for themselves
column4: i think they are very decent quality for memorable moments."^4^Aug 15

column1: Rocket62^/canon-powershot-sx730-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5847201?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^12^0^"I can't recall the number of cameras I reviewed and how I was really wanting a larger type removable lens... This has 40x and 160x digital zoom. Like me
column2: you may recall some of the older cameras with digital zoom that simply pixelated the image. This is nothing even remotely like it. I tried it out at the store and was impressed with the clarity and detail of the zoom.

column1: After purchasing I found it even easier to use in the 'Manual' mode. Say what? Yes
column2: you can easily dial the shutter speed
column3: F stop
column4: ISO and it shows you on the screen what the photo will look like at that setting. No more taking a few shots
column5: look
column6: adjust settings
column7: repeat until you get the settings just right the picture you want. Before you press the button to take - you know what it will look like.

column1: The moon shots are now so easy to take
column2: but for the long digital zoom you will need a tripod or something to stabilize the camera
column3: but well worth it.

column1: I uploaded a few images. 1. The close-up of the moon is around 140x digital and the other in the 60-70x range.
Lots to learn
column2: but I love this camera and highly recommend it.

column1: The only thing it needs is a remote trigger. Perhaps it has that and I haven't read up enough on it. Otherwise
column2: I have been setting the photo to delay taking for two seconds to ensure no movement of the camera on the tripod."^5^Mar 14

GeoffK^/canon-powershot-sx730-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5847201?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^0^"Overall this camera does what it should and it takes pictures in a somewhat compact form factor. It has the settings you would want from a point and shoot
column2: and some extra settings for those who like to tweak their settings a bit. Essentially
column3: it is a Canon point and shoot as you would expect it to be
column4: and I certainly expected it to be as it was going to be my 4th Canon in the last 10 years.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: this camera was just underwhelming picture after picture. I bought this camera right before a trip to the Colorado mountains
column3: excited to get some great pictures of snow and wildlife. Everything looked great on the tiny display
column4: and it seemed like everything would be just as great as I expected it to be once I transferred them to my computer. It was not.

column1: The colors were dull
column2: the pictures were grainy even with a minimal amount of zoom applied
column3: and ultimately it was a poor showing. Thinking maybe it was just a settings issue
column4: I went out and tried some more picture with different settings. Still just as dull and underwhelming. This $450 point and shoot was no better than a $200 knock off
column5: at best.

column1: I returned it and went against every bone in my body and bought a Sony. Not that Sony isn't also a great brand
column2: but I have never been a fan of their camera either point and shoot
column3: or SLR. Instantly the pictures from the Sony were easily 10x better. Colors were bright and vibrant both on the camera and on the computer. Zoom wasn't distorting pictures like you had taken it with a smart phone. The point and shoot I expected from the Canon
column4: was here in my hands without a Canon name.

column1: I think they simply missed the mark with this version
column2: and hopefully when I check them out again next year they will have fixed whatever issues they may have had here."^3^May 3

richardlpalmer^/canon-powershot-sx730-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5847201?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^2^"Having had quite a few Canon cameras
column2: I can get a bit critical when new models come out -- particularly when I'm replacing one that I love. My wife and I were going to be out of country for several weeks and wanted to be able to take pictures
column3: but also be on the go the whole trip. I ditched my large body camera and picked this one up. Absolutely wonderful decision!

column1: The image quality is excellent
column3: size & ergonomics excellent
column4: video quality excellent and that zoom! Wow! The zoom makes this camera a must-buy for me.

column1: It also has the option of plugging in a microphone
column2: making this a really decent option for recording live events.

column1: With the retracting lens its pretty compact and not overly heavy. There are smaller/lighter cameras out there
column2: but none with this amount of optical zoom and features.

column1: The one ding to this camera is the flip-up screen. I've been spoiled by Canon's articulating screens. This one ONLY flips up
column2: not out or down. So if you want to hold the camera above your head to get a picture of the stage
column3: you can't look up at the screen. Or if you want to hold the camera flush up against something and flip the screen to the side
column4: you can't. It only flips up -- great for low shots or selfies
column5: but not much else."^4^Mar 22

dranreb^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4866801?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^28^2^"This camera is small and lightweight. It easily fits in a pants pocket or purse (even a very small purse). I was very happy with how easy it was to carry around and use when traveling. I wish it came with a case though. The large
column2: bright screen makes it easy to compose pictures. Anyone familiar with the Canon Rebel series would find the menus on this camera similar and easy to use. The camera gives you a lot of control in manual settings
column3: but I also found the AUTO mode to be quite effective for most of my needs. I am very impressed with the photo quality
column4: especially the accuracy of colors
column5: like a blue sky. (I have seen other cameras 'wash out' a blue sky but not this camera.) The camera also does an excellent job in scenes with high contrast. The photos come out great and require little or no editing. Battery life is excellent and I like that the charger does not have a cord. One less cord to drag around. The charger's prongs fold up
column6: too
column7: so it is very portable.

column1: One minor complaint is that I wish the lens had a wider angle in order to take more impressive landscape photos. Another complaint
column2: which causes me to knock one star off the rating
column3: is that the wifi is very clunky. It requires you to download an app onto your computer and sign up for a Canon image service. I would have expected to only need to download an app. Not create some kind of account. The wifi is a useless feature to me and I am happy to continue putting the SD card into my computer or printer slot.

column1: Overall this was a great purchase and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a very portable little camera that has a good zoom and takes great pictures. It is good for travel because it does a great job in a variety of shots
column2: whether you are taking landscape photos
column3: close-ups
column4: or photos of people. I brought this camera along on a trip where I also used my iPhone 6s for some pictures. The Canon ELPH 360 took better pictures
column5: hands-down."^4^Feb 28

TallBill^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4866801?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^2^"I previously had a PowerShot SX120
column2: and this camera (PowerShot ELPH 360 HS) has all of the same features and much more. It does lack a true manual mode
column3: however (allowing the user to set shutter speed and aperture manually). The control buttons on the back are flush with the case
column4: making the camera somewhat difficult to use in very dim light conditions. As with all point-and-shoot cameras that have no viewfinder
column5: the display will be hard to see in direct sunlight. It has a lens cover that opens and closes automatically
column6: which prevents losing a separate lens cap. The camera has connectors on the right side for USB AV out and HDMI interfaces
column7: but they are covered by a cheap plastic cover that is difficult to get open until you file off the catches a little bit. The Li-Ion battery is small (only 800 mAh)
column8: and I have not yet determined exactly how long it will last (the manual claims 180 pix). I have only used the USB port to transfer pictures directly to my computer without going through an online service. I have not tried setting up the Wi-Fi interface yet to see if it would be easier to use. This camera has both High Speed Burst mode (about 7.2 pix per second) that will group the pictures and Continuous Shooting Drive Mode
column9: which allows pictures to be taken continuously while the shutter button is held depressed (about 2.5 pix per second; pictures are NOT grouped)."^5^Jul 31

column1: LoneBiker^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4866801?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I have several PowerShot SX's and I like them. But I've been cycling a lot lately and I wanted something smaller and lighter. I didn't expect to find it to have almost twice the Megapixels as my last SX so that was a pleasant surprise. If you're use to using PowerShot then the User Interface is about the same thing. Design choices come down to compromises. I would have preferred a screen that tilts up but I like getting so much picture taking power in something smaller than my hand with a good image stabilizer capability. I really like being able to carry this little guy around my neck or tucked into a little gadget bag on the bike. I haven't considered mounting it on the bike because I think that the vibrations may be a little harsh for it. I like to stop to take a drink and shoot a few pictures and then attach the images to my ride maps on MyMaps."^5^Nov 13

column1: And really liked the Canon 300 better. It was much easier to use and when you would take pictures on the VIVID they didn't look FAKE. Today I went taking pictures of the changing of the leaves and Used the vivid and also the regular. The Vivid looks so fake. I was disappointed because I had to delete over 1/2 my pictures. However
This camera dose take good CLEAR pictures. I am sharing 2 pictures. One of the regular setting and one on Vivid."^3^Oct 19
Harry^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4866801?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^14^"I purchased this wonderful camera on February 15
column2: 2019. I downloaded the required software and then spent about 3 hours trying to get the Camera connected to my computer. I then went on-line and downloaded the 157 page used guide but the chapter for connecting to a computer was for Windows 7 users. Canon customer service told me that the Camera worked perfectly on windows 7 but there are problems with windows 10. They blamed the problem on windows 10 but their camera was 'perfect'. The person asked me to make a number of changes (adjustments) to my computer so that the camera could upload pictures. I had no idea what I was doing but I was told that my adjustments would not hurt my computer or prevent any other software from operating correctly. The Camera still didn't work after about an hour of discussions and making computer changes. I was told that I could use a USB cable but I could still use Wi-Fi. I was told that sometimes it takes about 50 or more tries to connect the camera to a computer that uses windows 10. Each try takes about 5 minutes. Forget it. I returned the Camera on February 18th.

column1: I question Canon's comment that the Camera works perfectly on windows 7 - you can't even purchase a computer that uses windows 7. Why does Cannon continue to sell this? Why don't they pull it from the shelves. And why doesn't Best Buy
column3: and other vendors inform their customers that Wi-Fi only works on Windows 7. What a colossal waste of time."^1^Feb 19

column1: HPforMe^/hp-sprocket-2-in-1-photo-printer-white/6167606?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"I got this in exchange for my honest review. Honestly
column2: I love how portable it is! It is easy to throw in the bag and use on the go. It is compact and easy to use. I am a middle school teacher and brought this with me to use on a project we were doing with a book. The students had a GREAT time using it and were begging me to get more paper to use again...and again...now and in the future on other projects. The paper is pretty amazing...love the thought of being able to peel and stick (made for a super cute...and EASY...bulletin board)!

column1: The pictures that this take are not the best quality
column2: but shoots and prints out as good as I would have expected. I was pleasantly surprised at how well the pictures printed from my phone to the printer (I LOVE that we were able to open the app and add some fun flair to our images)! I have since used it with the family on a dinner outing and we all had a bit of fun experimenting with our photos and printing them out. I do wish I would have ordered extra paper to print out the pictures (I honestly didn't even think about it when I placed the order)."^5^Jan 29

column1: Pickett^/hp-sprocket-2-in-1-photo-printer-white/6167606?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^2^"I received the Sprocket 2-in-1 to try out in exchange for my honest opinion
column2: and I absolutely love it! I brought it to my 'welcome baby shower' so I could have guests take photos and add them immediately into a baby book along with a bit of writing. Since we could take and print the photos on the same device
column3: it was much more convenient than having to collect photos from everyone's phone to print later. The paper it prints on is also sticky backed
column4: so I didn't need to worry about bringing glue or tape to add the photos to the book. Everyone was so in love with my baby and the Sprocket 2-in-1
column5: I had to keep a close eye on both of them! ;)

column1: I have also used it at other parties
column2: and even let my sister take it to her middle school dance. It was a hit
column3: and she loved being able to take 'old fashioned' photos with her friends all night. They all had their photo stickers on their binders the next day.

column1: Overall
column3: and I love having the app to be able to crop
column4: edit
column5: and add fun stickers to the pictures before printing. The camera quality isn't quite as good as your phone
column6: but it is perfect for on the go or for kids and teens. You can also print photos from your phone gallery if you want a higher quality print. The app itself is very easy to navigate and has a lot of fun features. I would highly recommend it!"^5^Jan 28

column2: and it has been a hit with the whole family. The compact portable printer prints on 2x3 sheets. column1: TheStuffofSuccess^/hp-sprocket-2-in-1-photo-printer-white/6167606?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^8^"The HP Sprocket 2 in 1 is a compact portable printer. I received one in order to provide my honest opinion. It prints on 2x3 sheets - this particular size of printout is alot of fun! I can easily print photos right off my phone whenever I want to. Just open the app and select a photo or photos and watch as the photos are printed out. They are really cute and easy to tack up on bulletin boards etc... But this is even more than a printer - it is also a camera. I can now take selfie photos with this camera and the photos print right out. So not only can I use it as a printer but also as a camera.

This is perfect for our life with our horses - we can take our selfies right then and there and get immediate results! All of our friends are going to be standing in line waiting for photos with their horses!"^5^Dec 16

column1: Jbravo70^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-vi-21-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6259643?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^36^8^"Ok

column3: it had the multifunction hotshoe which I could also attach an external mic for better audio.

column1: So fast forward
column2: I see the new camera mark VI come out and with an impressive lens range of 200mm. I was excited! I bought the markVI and began taking pictures. When I started to download the pictures I noticed that they werent really different from my markIIs in sunlight. So I started taking pictures inside bouncing the flash. The pictures To my surprise didnt pop like the markii. So I began taking pictures with both cameras same settings
column3: same positions. The MarkII pictures are so much better by a lot! Even changing every setting in the markVI did nothing to compare it to the markii. I dont know if its just the flash
column4: the new lens
column5: software...but it doesnt take better pics than the markII. Sorry to say it went back. The new features are totally awesome and Im sure the video is better
column6: but the pictures sucked compared to the markii. I dont know what Sony did
column7: but they messed up big time. I really wanted this camera to take the great pictures like the markii but it doesnt. The new features are awesome
column8: especially the 200mm range and the selfie feature
column9: but if the pictures arent better I cant keep it. Im not going to gripe about the price because this camera is in a class of its own for being so compact. My brother has a markV which I intend to compare to mine. But until then Im saving my money for the upcoming Sony A7000 or Baby A9. Im just going to keep my markII cause it takes awesome pics. Hope this helps guys."^3^Oct 27

column1: NOTanseladams^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-vi-21-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6259643?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This was the most expensive point and shoot camera available
column2: so it took some soul searching and research before I decided to buy it.  I have no regrets.  I had been a dedicated DSLR user even on vacations
column3: but several professional photographers told me convincingly not to be a slave to a big heavy DSLR while on vacation.  Even mirrorless cameras were too big and beyond my needs.  Technology has advanced where a point and shoot camera can deliver spectacular results and slip in your pocket when not in use.

column1: Why not just use a smart phone camera?  Several reasons.  The image sensor on the sony is about 3x larger by area.  Larger = sharper.  The flash is far better than a smart phone.  But the most important reason is the zoom.  The sony goes from 24-200 and this is all optical. Zooming is essential for creativity and flexibility.  Doing selfies with this camera is also far better than with a smart phone.
After a week in Amsterdam and Brussels
column2: this camera did not disappoint.  I wore shorts and dedicated a pocket for the camera with nothing else in the pocket to potentially scratch it.  I would pull it out
column3: shoot and put back.  Using this method
column4: turning on and off constantly
column5: which advances and retracts the lens each time
column6: only yielded about 150 shots per battery charge
column7: however I was also viewing them during the day
column8: which uses battery.  There is no build in location tagging but you can do it if you turn on the blue tooth and sync it to your phone but I'm sure that will use more battery.  Having an extra battery was important.  Bestbuy had a bonus with purchase of camera with an extra battery
column9: camera grip and SD card.  I opted to buy the separate battery charger since opening the little flap on the camera and plugging the cable into it was a pain.

column1: I did not post photos since Bestbuy only allows images to 5mb so the photos would not give you a true sense of the resolution quality.
If you are interested in this camera
column2: check out the Ken Rockwell review."^5^Jun 23

Cwhiz^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^204^10^"I've been a long time Nikon shooter owning four Nikon cameras. Currently I have a D700
column5: a Fuji X100s
column6: a Panasonic Lumix LX3 and a Sony camcorder. I was happily surprised as I was not expecting what I discovered with this new camera.

column1: First
column2: the menus are a bit simple for me as I'm used to the extensive controls on my other Nikons. It does give you a lot of range to work with though and I like the user presets. I love the articulating screen and the nice solid feel of the camera in my hands. I haven't used all the features yet
column3: but am downloading the full manual to get to them (it comes with a 'starter edition' instruction book which is very basic#.

column1: The features of the continuous high speed captures were amazing. This camera takes pictures before you fully press the shutter
column2: then captures up to 20 for you to pick the best shot as well as a BSS #best shot selector# selection. It captures all very fast and I use a San Disk Extreme card with it. You can turn off shutter noise too!

column1: The manual settings
column2: are easy to work with the two wheels
column3: making the adjustments easily with nice firm movement. All the shooting modes #EV+/-
column4: macro
column5: flash and ISO# are easy to get to and use as well as the other settings in the menus. The zoom function has many stop points to set for quick use and a pre-set zoom feature.It has a convenient function button to use for a favorite feature for which I use for a quick change to high speed shooting selections.

column1: Now for the Zoom function which blew me away altogether! After a few test shots
column2: I saw the pics were fairly sharp with the great built in stabilization working
column3: although my hands are not as steady as they once were. I took some license plate shots over a hundred plus yards away and these were as clear as if I was ten feet away! I went in for a shot of a pool ladder in a back yard five houses away #see pic I uploaded here#. When I zoomed in on the pic on the monitor I was in disbelief #as was everyone I showed it to# as I was able to read the impressed warning label in full detail. I was barely able to see the ladder from where I was standing at first.

column1: I tested it at a beach nearby the next day and got some beautifully rendered seascapes
column2: sunsets and close-ups of a bridge almost three miles away that I could make out the antennas on it. I could see from the slight fuzziness of these long shots that to really get the great shots
column3: you'd need to use a tripod with the stabilization feature turned off and possibly a remote control or the built in shutter timer which would remove most of the unsteady hand held movement the camera has to deal with. I do this with my other Nikons as well to insure the clearest shots.

column1: The Wi-Fi is a great feature that hasn't been tried yet as I wouldn't use this camera for a photo shoot anyway. It's one of my 'fun' cameras and I'm really enjoying what it can do
column2: especially the great 'on-the-fly' bird shots I've been able to capture so far as well as a few airplanes flying over. Will give it a good run this summer when the landscape is full of things to shoot.

column1: I'm very happy with it and am looking to accessorize it with filters and such. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who wants the best Nikon has to offer in a very long zoom at a great price to be sure considering what's in it!"^5^Apr 7

SafariAhoy^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^164^11^"Deciding on this camera: We bought this camera to take on safari. We have been using point-and-shoot cameras with smaller zooms (15X and 25X) for travel
column2: but we wanted to make sure the animals we saw were not just little dots in the pictures when we return from the Serengeti. We looked into purchasing a DSLR; however
column3: to get a similar zoom plus the camera body seemed like it was going to cost over $1K. The most informative review on the P900 was at Photography Life (https://photographylife.com/reviews/nikon-coolpix-p900) by John Sherman. He highlights the features
column4: at times in comparison to his expensive professional DSLR
column5: and includes many sample photographs. Sure some quality is lost in the picture of the eagle at full zoom; however
column6: the camera that took the crisp
column7: clear photo cost him over $21K! For many people
column8: lack of RAW format was a disappointment; however
column9: my version of editing is using Google's Picasa to sort through (and occasionally crop) the 100s (or 1000s) of photos I take with the point and shoot. Thus
column10: JPEG format is fine for us.

column1: Purchasing: Finding the P900 in stock was a challenge
column2: but we were able to get one from Best Buy following the advice in one of the Amazon reviews that suggested checking the stock on the Nikon webpage each day. Basically
column3: there is an option on the P900 Nikon page to 'Where to Buy' that actually lists the online suppliers and whether they have the camera in stock. I looked everyday for about a week in mid-June
column4: and one morning it was listed as 'In Stock' at Best Buy. I bought the camera and then looked back at the 'Where to Buy' on the Nikon page
column5: and it said out-of-stock again.

column1: First impressions: The camera case is a lightweight plastic that some reviewers thought looked/felt cheap. However
column2: carrying the camera around at the Botanica Gardens in the heat
column3: I was very appreciative of how much less the camera would weigh than if it were made of metal or heavier plastic. I was able to hold onto the camera with one hand via the grip with the strap wrapped around my wrist for a little extra security for the hour we were out without tiring. I used my left hand to stablize the camera whenever using the zoom or when I was not in direct sunlight.

column1: Using the super zoom: When I first tested the camera indoors or in the shade with the zoom fully extended
column2: it was difficult to get a non-shaky picture. However
column3: when we went to a local nature reserve
column4: I was able to get pictures of birds we only spotted with our 10X42 binoculars at full zoom with the camera supported only by my two hands (not even bracing my elbows against my chest as I did in the shade pictures). There is enough detail to see that the birds eyelids are open in one picture and closed in the next. I used the 'bird watching mode' under Scenes
column5: which takes up to 7 pictures (in 1 sec) when you press the button. This increased the odds of getting a good picture of the bird
column6: but had the downside of waiting a few seconds after each burst of pictures for the pictures to write to the SD card (16 MP picture quality
column7: 90MB/s memory card). The camera has this great function when the zoom is extended and you lose the bird you are trying to shoot called 'snapback zoom'. With your left hand you hold down the button on the side of the lens and the camera will zoom out. A black box appears in the view finder
column8: move the camera to get the bird in the box and then release the button to zoom in on the bird. This is super efficient and less nauseating than trying to search for the bird at full zoom.

column1: Continuous shooting mode: We had great fun photographing animals that stayed primarily in the same place. However
column2: we will need more practice to be able to catch a flying bird. The continuous shooting mode at max rate is 7 frames per second but it stops after the 7th frame and starts writing to the card. The pre-shooting cache is partial way around this. You press the shutter release half-way down
column3: and it starts taking pictures. When the animal does something interesting
column4: you press the shutter release the rest of the way down and the camera saves the previous 5 pictures and then 10 more. I was trying to use these functions to take pictures of my nephew going down a circular slide at the park. He got frustrated when I asked him to go again and again. I was only catching him appearing around the first loop. In retrospect
column5: what I really needed was to use 2 fps (one of the slower continuous modes) so I could keep taking pictures until he reached the bottom. 7 fps was just too many pictures for the slide action.

column1: Battery Life: I bought 2 Watson brand batteries as they were $40 each at B&H photo
column2: instead of $80 for an extra Nikon battery. Then at Best Buy a few weeks later
column3: I saw their generic brand on sale for $10 per battery (normally $30) and bought 3. The P900 uses the same camera battery as the P600. They tend to last about half-a-day depending on how much I use the view finder vs the screen. The other issue is that if you are trying to track animals to photograph
column4: this also eats up battery so the picture estimate that others have given (~260 photos) may be much less (if you have to wait sometime for your shot) or twice that if you use continuous shoot. We shot ~600 photos of birds (7fps
column5: 1 sec at a time) over a ~2 hour period at a bird reserve last weekend.

column1: Automatic vs Manual Modes: On my previous point-and-shoot camera
column2: I had relied on the 'intelligent auto' function. For the P900
column3: the automatic button (green) takes reasonable pictures but you can make very few adjustments. Under SCENE mode on the dial
column4: there is an auto scene selector as the first option that works more like the 'intelligent auto' on other cameras. There are many great scenes to choose from including the bird watching. To use some of the great features such as 'Active D-lighting' to bring objects out of the shadows
column5: however
column6: we have had to take a crash course in manual settings for photography (using many free web resources). This overall has been very rewarding
column7: and we are now primarily using aperture mode for everyday shooting with the camera. Note that for the manual mode
column8: there is an option under setup to have the screen reflect the exposure level before the photo is taken. This is good for reducing the number of too dark photos.

column1: Other cool features: The camera has a time lapse mode for taking pictures of cityscapes
column2: sunsets or night skies. We have tried the 50 minute series for sunsets twice now with great results. It takes several pictures a minute and then quickly compresses it into a 9 second movie."^5^Jul 22

column1: Sparrow^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^72^5^"This is a great camera for a beginner or anyone wanting to take high quality pictures at a low cost. It has a great zoom with a fast focus. People that see my bird pictures think that they were taken with a DSLR because of the detail and sharpness. The p900 is a big step change from the previous 2 models. I rarely write reviews but wanted to tell people that this is a great camera for taking bird pictures. I almost spent much more money for a DSLR trying to find the reach and quality of this camera. I've attached a sample that was taken the first day I used the camera."^5^Jul 23

bpwright^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^37^2^"One of the best bridge cameras Nikon has put on the market. Takes fantastic pictures and excels in telephoto and micro capabilities. Not a professional camera

column1: KayH^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^26^2^"I have had many cameras through the years and shoot with both dslrs and point and shoots. I'm not a professional photographer
The P900 is not a small camera. It's about the size of a dslr
column2: though it feels much lighter to me. I can carry it around my neck for extended periods and not find it a strain. When carrying my dslr my neck and upper back always get tired and sore.

column1: I currently have a dslr and a 150-600mm lens
column2: which I use to shoot wildlife and birds. It's big and its heavy
column3: and it's just too much to carry around while hiking or taking walks 'just in case' a deer or a fox crosses my path. I had purchased a small Sony HX50V with a 30x zoom to fill that niche
column4: as a 'grab and go' camera for hiking and whatever might come up
column5: but I soon found that I sorely missed having an eye viewfinder to look through. On bright sunny days I can't see what I'm shooting.

column1: I just recently purchased the Nikon P900 to give me a great zoom
column3: and still be light enough to carry around with me. I knew going into it that a small sensor zoom camera can not deliver the kind of image quality I get with my Canon 70D & Tamron 150-600 lens. That said
column4: my Canon 70D & Tamron 150-600mm lens can not come close to zooming in to 2000mm. So the Nikon P900 can photograph things that the Canon & Tamron lens can't even see
column5: and not break my back when I carry it.

column1: The Nikon P900 is not a camera for 'pixel peepers'. If you like to zoom in to full size on your computer and inspect your images
column2: you will not like what you see at full size. Detail is smeared
column3: especially on shots at 2000mm. But
column4: if you are content to look at a photo at a size that just fills your computer screen
column5: you may find you are very pleased with the shots from the P900.

column1: I took the P900 to a family reunion the other day
column2: and didn't really plan to take many photos with it. I took a Sony A6000 mirrorless camera and a 60mm lens to use as my priimary camera that day
column3: but I found that I just couldn't put the P900 down
column4: because it was so versatile. A cousin was shooting with a Canon Mk5 and 135mm L lens
column5: and at one point he was having to walk backward further and further and further to try to frame a shot that I was able to just zoom out easily to get with the P900. When someone pointed out an adorable 'kids eating ice cream cones' photo opp
column6: I sat where I was and zoomed in across the lawn and easily captured it without getting up. When I got home
column7: I was pleasantly surprised with the photos I had captured. Photos taken at a closer range are much better and have much better detail than those shot at the full 2000mm.

column1: Would I recommend the Nikon P900? If you are willing to compromise on image quality to have amazing zoom range and versatility
column3: YES
column4: YES. But if you want National Geographic quality photos
column5: this is not the camera for you.

column1: I would strongly recommend doing some internet research on Flickr or other websites to get a good sampling of what the Nikon P900 (or any camera you are considering) can do. Check out real world samples taken by real world people
column2: and see if the images you see are up to your standards.

column1: For me
column2: I'm a happy camper. I still have my big
column3: heavy
column4: cumbersome Dslr and 150-600 lens when the situation demands it. But for everyday grab and go fun
column5: I'm thrilled with the Nikon P900."^4^Jul 11

column1: BlueBloodAl^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^21^4^"I originally purchased this camera as a replacement for my mother's camera. After briefly using to learn it so I could help her with it

column1: SpiderWayneWLD^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^13^0^"The picture and video quality could be better but overall not a bad camera.
Great reach:

See the photos I took and keep in mind that I was nowhere near these creatures. Getting close would cause them to run or fly away so having a super zoom is really helpful. Also works like a macro lens without having scaring off subjects by trying to get too close to them.
Decent images:
Yes the images and videos could be better but the good thing is they can be cleaned up pretty good in editors like Lightroom.
Price:
This is the cheapest camera I own and for the image/video quality
column2: amount of zoom you get it's well worth having.

column1: Stabilization:
It has optical stabilization that works pretty darn good. All the images I took were hand held.
Continous Shooting:
Up to 7fps at 16mp. I just figured out it has this. I wish I would have known when trying to capture the hummingbird photos.
Manual Focus:
There is no focus ring but it does have a focusing slider with peeking and it works pretty.
*** Cons ***
Only takes jpg:
I wish it shot raw photos because the jpgs are way over saturated but can be corrected a bit in an image editor like Lightroom.
Preview:
I don't always shoot in burst mode but having to preview each image after shooting can cause you to lose a shot . I wish I could turn on the image preview.
No Touch Screen:
It would be nice if it had a touch screen at least for hitting focus points.
No Mic Input:
I really don't like not having an option for an external mic.
No Hot Shoe:
It has a pop up flash but when the lens sticks out you get a shadow. Plus it would be nice to be able to add an accessory like a light or a mic... oh wait
Overall this is no pro camera but what it is
column2: is a really fun camera for getting shots you would normally not be able to get. The image quality is decent as long as you do a little cleanup in an editor like Lightroom. I almost returned this camera but after having some time with it I decided to keep it. It's long zoom and decent image quality makes it unique to my small of cameras and makes it useful."^4^Sep 24

column1: familyof4^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^0^"While I spend an above average time in the outdoors (fishing
column3: hiking
column4: and biking)
column5: Im definitely not a hard-core bird watcher. However
column6: after being buzzed a number of times a few years back
column7: while out turkey hunting (with my kids perhaps enjoying this spectacle a bit too much at my expense)
column8: I became very interested in learning more about the birds of prey in our area

column1: After doing several weeks of research a few months back
column2: I quickly moved up the chain of less expensive p&s choices and landed on the Canon SX60HS. Nearly all of the reviews that I read picked this camera over other offerings including Nikons P610 and the P900. However
column3: a couple reviews got me to at least think about these two Nikon models. (Note: at the time the P610 was not easy to find and was scheduled to be replace by the B700.)

column1: Before making a final decision I wanted to feel and touch these cameras
column2: so I located a nearby Best Buy that had the SX60HS in stock and a few other cameras included in the reviews I read. One of the other cameras was the P900. I picked up the SX60HS first
column3: and fiddled with it for several minutes in the store. Then I picked up the P900. I was immediately impressed with its feel and ease of focusing in particular compared to the SX60HS. While the reviews had me convinced before coming into the store that I was here to purchase the SX60HS
column4: I found myself unable to deny the difference in feel and ease I was experiencing hands-on at that moment with the P900. I spent the next hour or so going back and forth with these two cameras there in the store
column5: fiddling with the controls
column6: settings
column7: focusing on things near and far
column8: as my wife and the salesperson patiently allowed me to compare these two cameras.

column1: Before purchasing the P900 I asked the Best Buy salesperson if I could bring it back if I wasnt happy with it. He reminded me of the return policy they offer saying
column2: we want you to be happy with your purchase too. Since then
column3: Ive never once thought about returning this camera. Yes
column4: it is a bigger camera than I ever thought Id buy for my desired use in the outdoors. However
column5: after trying it out first at our local zoo
column6: and using it now several times out in the field
column7: I have absolutely no regrets that I went with the P900. Im truly thrilled by its zooming capability
column8: which I can only describe as insane (unbelievable). Its feel and handling
column9: the simplicity of accessing and using its essential basic features
column10: and the ease of focusing continue to impress me every time I use it. And I look forward as well to learning about its advanced features now and growing into using this camera to more of its full potential."^5^Oct 19

column1: Overall

column1: One final remark....I hear so many people complain about it being so heavy. My thought to that is

column1: I am very happy with my purchase!

column1: SidVicious^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^2^"Wow

column1: CMCM^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^2^"This camera is a lot of fun
column2: and you will be happy with it as long as you understand its shortcomings and limitations. As I read somewhere
column3: this is a really fantastic 2000mm super zoom lens attached to a modest camera. The lens can be very good when you are shooting under the right conditions
column4: and that means you need sufficient light
column5: particularly at the longer end of the range. It's not a fast lens so it's really not that great in low light so choose your photo time accordingly. The vibration reduction is quite amazing
column6: and you can actually shoot the moon
column7: birds
column8: and animals while hand holding the camera. The reach of this 2000mm lens continues to astonish me. I read that to get a separate lens of this reach for a dSLR you would pay $10K to 20K!! Another positive is that the P900 is surprisingly light in weight and very well balanced when holding it. It is better to use a tripod or monopod when if you can
column9: especially at full zoom
column10: your photos will be better. However
column11: with practice your ability to hand hold the camera (with the great VR) will improve over time. I did much better with moon shots when using a monopod with a tilt head (it was harder with a tripod because at full zoom
column12: the moon tends to move out of the lens range quite quickly and you have to re-adjust the lens position often. But it was much easier with adjustment on one plane instead all directions with a ball head
column13: and the one leg of the monopod makes turning other directions much quicker and easier). The necessarily smaller sensor and 12 MP can lead to noise (yes
column14: this is a noisy camera)
column15: and noise is more noticeable under less than optimal lighting situations. It's what it is. But the tilt and swivel back screen is great
column16: the menus are easy
column17: it's a fairly quick and easy camera to learn. It can also do amazing macro shots of insects and other small things
column18: even more so when paired with a Raynox 150 or 250 magnifier lens (cheap). Above all
column19: just be informed and realistic and don't expect the P900 to do everything like a more expensive camera with a larger sensor and higher MP. You will get very good pictures and sometimes you'll get great photos if you learn how to use all the camera settings
column20: and this crazy long lens is an enormous amount of fun for certain things. I would not have this as my only camera
column21: but it's a great second camera. Just know what you are buying and what its capabilities are. Alexander S. White wrote a great book that explains everything and how to use this camera...it's much better than the manual."^4^Jan 5

column1: Rick^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"I am a professional photographer so this wasn't a camera I was going to use for work but I am having tons of fun with it. Very light and portable. The zoom is no joke. Amazing camera for nature shooting."^4^Jan 22

Vishnu^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^2^"A good option for people who enjoy the ease of use of a point and shoot and is looking to move a step further without compromising much on the ease of use. It has an amazing zoom threatening other DLSRs paired with tele-photo lenses. It provides a decent functionality on adjusting ISO
column2: Shutter speed and Aperture. A fast auto-focus along with a massive zoom range makes this an excellent option for bird watching and wildlife photography
column3: where taking pictures quickly is a priority. If you are planning to use this camera on its higher zoom settings
column4: it is highly recommended that you use it with a tripod."^5^Dec 12

column1: itProbe^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^2^"I got this camera simply because I enjoy long zoom and playing with telescope
column2: this camera is very easy to use and the focus is very accurate. If I need to be picky on P900
column3: I would say the the build quality is not the best
column4: the filter ring is plastic(better than nothing). Anyway
column5: it is a really fun camera to have."^5^Jun 9

column1: Rainbird^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"I am going to tell you what is not great about the P900 as what is great about this camera is being said in the many reviews. I use the P900 extensively and can speak about what is not great about this camera with some authority. I gave the camera 5 stars because for what it is
column2: which is a camera that allows those of us who can't afford $20
column3: 000++ rigs for wildlife photography
column4: it deserves five stars.

column1: Having said that
column2: it does have it's short comings. The auto focus is only middle of the road. It does not miss focus a lot
column3: but it It will miss focus enough to be irritating in certain circumstances and there is no true manual focus. A good auto focus would be best. When shooting in continuous/burst mode there is significant buffering time between bursts
column4: like 3 to 5 seconds. That buffering time is seriously annoying when shooting birds for example. There are times when you will miss the shots due to the buffering. The image quality is ok/good
column5: but 16 megapixels is disappointing. Is 20 to much to ask? How about 25
column6: 25 would be nice. The electronic view finder is just ok. Functional
column7: but not great. The overall build quality of the camera is juuust good enough. . So far it is holding up reasonably well to the extensive use I give it
column8: but I don't think it was designed for it. I had to send it to a Nikon repair facility for a new integrated circuit board because I was zooming in and out so much I wore out the switch. The new board
column9: as expected
column10: is showing signs of the same wear. I hope Nikon reads this because this camera could be much better."^5^Jan 26

column1: JudeG^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"I bought this camera right before taking a trip to Ireland/Scotland in the hopes of getting some great photos. The results far exceeded my expectations! There are so many features to this camera
column2: that you can capture macro shots
column3: as well as long distance close-ups. All in sharp clarity and amazing colors! I am an amateur
column4: but I felt like a professional using this camera."^5^Sep 2

column1: birdLady^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"For many years I've enjoyed the convenience & easy handling of Canon long zoom point & shoot cameras for birding
column2: but when my SX40 wore out
column3: I thought I wanted an SLR. I couldn't find what I needed in my price range. The Nikon Coolpix P900 is a great compromise! This convenient camera takes sharp photos both close up & far away
column4: and it actually focuses on a tiny hummingbird instead of always wanting to focus on the background. It is heavier than I am used to
column5: but certainly not as cumbersome as an SLR with 2 lenses. Be aware that you will probably want to buy a separate battery charger because the camera doesn't come with one & requires charging the batteries in the camera. The Nikon MH-67P is the only charger recommended. I had to buy mine online from an outside source because Best Buy didn't carry them."^5^Jul 12

column1: MikeSech^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"I've had the P900 for about 4 weeks and used it frequently. It's heavier and bulkier than my old compact zoom (a 30x Sony)

column1: JohnnyPhoenix^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"I do a lot of birding in the field. Occasionally I encounter a rare bird
column2: one that is out of place or out of season. The easiest way to provide documentation is a quick photo. Enter this camera. With its 83x optical zoom it make capturing a photo of a distant bird an easy task. It has a birding mode that automatically zooms the camera to an 800mm equivalent
column3: which makes less to fuss with when trying to capture a fast moving bird.

column1: Its not perfect. I does focus search when the background is busy and low light can introduce focus problems.
I like that I can transfer photos to my phone and I use the feature frequently.
Battery life seems reasonable and it can be charged with a micro usb cord in the car.
Not a replacement for a DSLR if looking for perfect bird photos
column2: but for my purposes it works great."^5^Feb 9

kanehi^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^2^"I really wanted a long zoom bridge camera and found this camera. This camera has been a hot seller and difficult to get but Best Buy finally offered it for sale and I was lucky to get it. The P900's size is akin to a small dSLR but lighter in weight. The zoom range is incredible and the images are essentially sharp. It has wi-fi
column2: NFC and GPS which you can record where the picture was taken. The articulating screen is a nice feature and the controls are easy to manipulate. I do recommend a memory card that can write fast otherwise if you shoot in rapid mode the camera will lag and will miss shots in the meantime. The sensor suffers in low light situations which hunts or ending up with a blurred focus in the end but you do have the option of manual focusing using the zoom lever in the lens barrel (option under setting). Plan to get extra battery because it only takes around 360 images and less if you do use your articulating screen a lot which does zap power. I will be using this camera while on vacation and hiking where I can take pictures of subjects far away. It's also a great camera to use looking for rock climbers in steep cliffs where you don't have a binoculars."^4^Nov 6

column1: Venice^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I bought this camera to replace a Canon SX60 that had gone everywhere with me for the last several years and had finally gotten to the point it was becoming unreliable. I was hoping that Canon would have come out with a newer model so when I found that they had not
column2: I looked to Nikon to see what they had to offer. As you can probably tell
column3: I am a Canon person so it took a bit for me to move forward in ordering this camera. But I love it! The longer lens and the smaller F-stop were definitely a plus as I use this camera not only for wildlife photography here at home but it is my go-to camera for traveling. My biggest concern was the ability to hold the camera still enough to take those distant photos as I struggled with that issue when using my SX60. But the longer lens on this Nikon allows me to hold the camera lens in my left hand while shooting photos with my right. This tends to give me more stability and less shake. The camera also has a built in stabilizer which seems to work fairly well. I continue to use my DSLR when I want something a little more professional
column4: but you can't beat this camera for the everyday
column5: carry in your car
column6: candids of the kids and grandkids at ballgames or concerts and travel - it can't be beat!"^5^Feb 16

column1: Debi^/nikon-coolpix-p900-16-0-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4961288?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"Purchased the ambitious P900 to keep in the car for bird sighting documentations when I did not have any of my DSLRs in tow.
