LowerEastSider^/canon-powershot-sx620-hs-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-red/5298700?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^57^3^"I looked at much more expensive cameras but settled on this one because it generally had good reviews and was just small enough to fit into a pocket.
I did not want to spend a lot of money on something that could get damaged
The picture quality is above average without a lot of graininess or artifacts. Even when zoomed-in to a reasonable level on a large screen monitor
column2: most photos look very detailed. And
column3: the colors are quite pleasing and natural looking.

column1: It is best at taking still photos. That being said
column2: when I set the camera in burst mode
column3: I was able to get some decent shots at a recent bike race. But there are better cameras with faster lenses if you plan on taking a lot of action shots.

column1: The 'P' mode offers some controls for things like exposure level and white balance. But this is a camera designed primarily for automatic use. There is no function dial
column2: so you must go into the menus to make changes to the settings.

column1: The camera does a better than average job of taking good photos using the auto mode. And
column3: it still operates mostly automatically.

column1: The 25X zoom range is certainly more than adequate for most users.
This is not one of those cameras that amazes you with it's shot to shot speed. But for most people it is more than adequate.
You will not feel like you have a 'brick' in your pocket or purse with this camera. It is quite lightweight and not too long or wide. The next most expensive Cannon model offers better performance
column2: but it is (in my opinion) simply too large and heavy to tuck in a pocket.

column1: I bought a small canvas case that I hook to my belt. This keeps the camera protected and it is always ready for use.
This camera is a good value for someone who is not a 'camera person' but wants pleasing
column2: lifelike photos. You could spend additional money and get more features
column3: but not necessarily better quality photos."^4^Jul 2

I would give 5 stars except the wifi connection does not work with Apple computers. Its very frustrating because now I have to go find a cable that will work with the camera and my Mac."^4^Apr 22
MarkRC^/canon-powershot-sx620-hs-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-red/5298700?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^34^5^"This was a good upgrade from my Canon Elph 300. This one is a bit bigger
column2: but is faster and takes sharper photos. The wi-fi transfer of photos works well
column3: once you figure it out. Every device you want to download to needs a different name in the program. And
column4: you have to download the App to make it work."^5^Aug 20

column1: BattyFoto^/canon-powershot-sx620-hs-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-red/5298700?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^26^8^"First let me say this. This camera is nice and good for this price range
column2: which is why it has 4 stars and I would recommend it....

column1: If you can get past the following points...
**Please note though
column2: the whole purpose of this purchase was for a higher megapixel camera that could give me crisp macro (close up) photos of my artwork.

column1: That being said
1. This camera is tiny! Think almost flip phone size
column2: which makes it very awkward and hard to grip right with average adult hands.

column1: 2. Very impressive zoom photos. I used it to take exterior detail photos for an insurance claim. When I took 2nd floor photos of the details around windows
column2: you would have thought they were first floor! So it did what I needed it to there.

column1: 3. No cords come with it. You take the battery out to charge it using a plug in adapter.
4. I ended up not being able to get it to connect to my laptop at all
column2: so I just took the memory card out each time. This was a let down.

column1: 5. Cannon menus are a bit confusing to me. My son has a T5
column2: which I tried to use a few times before and couldn't get the hang of things. Beginners be careful and really read the manual and try how to videos online.

column1: 6. There's a clicking noise it makes. It's the small metal pieces making up the lense protector. So when it's closed/off
column2: for some reason mine made noises when I moved it around. Just an annoyance.

column1: 7. Okay here's the main reason I took it back. The closer shots were not as impressive as I expected per the many reviews saying it's good for that. I'm sure it's better than average though. However
column3: I need really detailed photos of my artwork to be able to make prints of good quality. This did not deliver. Now
column4: I might have been expecting way too much for a $200 range camera
column5: but I was just going by other's opinions.

column1: So there ya go. This is just MY humble opinion also lol.
I would call myself a hobbiest photographer. Not an expert
Thank you!"^4^Aug 9

But my wife just bout an IPhone 8 and it takes a better standard picture than this camera if you don't need zoom and 20mp density photos. The other nice thing is that adding another 600 photos to my IPhone might start giving me memory issues

Howie^/canon-powershot-sx620-hs-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-red/5298700?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^28^32^"I bought this to replace an older like model. What a disappointment. If this is suppose to be an improved model
To power the camera up
column2: you have to try and push the little power button on top. I had to use my finger nail to push the recessed button down.

column1: They eliminated the auto flash like the older model had. So if you are taking pictures and the sensors decide you need a flash
column3: twist the camera sideways to find the little slide button then you raise the flash by using your fingernail to push the tiny little recessed button on the left side.to pop the flash up. Then you go back to your shot.

column1: The other buttons on the screen side are close together and recessed. You have to be right on to push them or you will push the wrong one. The dial around the Func set button is small and when you attempt to push on the outside ring
column2: there's a good chance you will also hit the func set button that you didn't want to push. There are 4 buttons around that dial that are also recessed and close together. Not easy to use.

column1: The door on the right side which you open to get to the HDMI cable hook ups is held by two little plastic strips which I have a feeling would not last that long.
Very dissatisfied with this camera and will return it to BB. I will not spend this amount of money on what appears to be a cheaply made product and without much thought in designing it."^1^May 12

iAppleNovice^/canon-powershot-sx620-hs-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-red/5298700?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^13^"I was told by the BB sales rep that all the cameras come with a USB cable to transfer photos. Well
column2: this camera does not. I ordered one on Amazon for $5. How am I suppose to transfer photos if I am at someone's home or a location when wifi or removing the memory card is not an option? You will need the cable.

column1: The free memory card is to small to be practical. The SanDisk Extreme PRO 128GB SDXC is not stocked at the BB store. Available for half the price at Amazon. That is the best card for this camera. (the micro card is to slow). BB would not give credit toward a better memory card. The free card is a wasted product.
Finally
So
column2: after you buy this camera you need a transfer cable
column3: better memory card and travel/purse case. I would not give this as a gift because it is not a complete package. More a fault of Canon than BB. What's next? Charging extra for a battery charger?

column1: I don't like the pop-up flash. That is obsolescence engineered into the camera.
It is an expensive camera and yes
column2: it does take fantastic pictures after a lot of practice. You must practice before that special event."^4^Jun 24

TYGIGI^/fujifilm-instax-mini-liplay-instant-film-camera-stone-white/6355184?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^3^"I'm not one to write reviews butI have some concerns regarding the camera. column2: I just want to say that out of the box there were no issues I was actually impressed with the build quality. But the minute I turned on the camera I was immensely disappointed..the LCD not great and when taking a picture you have to wait a couple seconds snapping it because if you move ever so slightly it will come out blurry. But that isn't the biggest issue its the screen itself and it reminds me of a old samsung phone or something from a 90's toy. I loved the Product but for 160 price point I was expecting the screen to be of higher quality. But guess you cant have everything you want in a Product. Lastly the Prints come out way darker than what its showing on the camera now this is just a preference of mine but i prefer my prints to come out more exposed because the Liplay just wasnt giving me that no matter how high you turn the exposure up. And the flash is no help either. I think if you want a Fuji product that gives you that instant photo vibe I'd opt for the mini 9 or if you just want printer with fun tools I'd opt for the mini link. Overall disappointed in this product from Fuji. Will be returning."^2^Nov 25

BenYoung^/nikon-coolpix-w300-16-0-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-orange/5891004?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^19^0^"First of all I want to say that I have been a constant user of Nikon products
column2: I had the Nikon AW130 which was with me constantly diving
column3: hiking and being exposed to the elements. Probably one of the best cameras I have ever owned.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the new W300 is not on the same level as that camera. I purchased it and set it all up in m y house before a diving trip. Full battery and new sim card
column3: it was not opened again in humidity or on the boat. The seal was properly shut. I know how to care and use this product from my use of the older version
column4: so this is not my first time with their waterproof cameras.

column1: On the second dive I got a warning message saying 'battery overheating camera turning off'. As well as this condensation was inside the screen (remember here I had not opened this camera since sealing it at home). As per the instructions (and as I had done countless times with my AW130 with condensation)
column2: I left turned off in a dry area with the seal open for 2 days. Needless to say the camera no longer turned on and I had photos from 1 dive when I was completing 24 that week. I wish I had taken my old camera with me but
column3: as I was so used to that one being indestructible
column4: I thought Nikon would have taken the same care with the new version. Obviously not.

column1: The problems do not stop here however. I have submitted multiple questions to Nikon support about my problem
column2: and I get the same response every single time 'any shock damage or water damage is not covered by the warranty'. I then respond that I am not happy with the answer to this question and
column3: without fail
column4: every time it is marked as resolved when it clearly is not. I refuse to accept this as my fault for water damage and
column5: as I have seen
column6: a number of other people have had the same problem with the new version when owning the old version before it with no problems (thus they know how to care for it).

column1: If I had messed up and caused the camera to flood I would accept the cost to repair it. As I see literally no way that this was my fault (checking seal before each use etc etc.)
column2: Nikon has been consistently wasting my time and not providing adequate answers to questions when asked.

column1: I would not be disappointed with the camera if Nikon accepted fault and had it checked out. On the other hand
column2: they are skirting questions and not being helpful at all.

column1: I would honestly recommend different underwater cameras even if there is a slight reduction in the performance. It is not worth the hassle
column2: stress and sheer disregard by Nikon to one of there customers. I would not wish the time I have spent on my worst enemy trying to sort this out.
column3: it has been horrible."^1^Oct 8

column1: TheDuke^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^51^7^"Instant print cameras have been around since the Polaroid Corporation introduced the Land Camera Model 95 back in 1948. And while it may seem like instant print photos are a gimmick that fell out of fashion with the invention of digital photography
column2: printable photos have become big business once again (as it is a way for camera & film companies to ensure consistent revenue in a similar way to how they once sold film).

column1: The Canon Ivy Cliq uses Zink paper which requires no ink. (Zink actually stands for Zero Ink.) Instead
column2: the photo paper is comprised of multiple heat sensitive layers containing dye crystals that display various colors when they melt. The camera delivers varying intensities of heat which quickly results in a colorful picture. It is important to note that while many companies (such as HP
column3: Polaroid
column4: Lifeprint
column5: Fujifilm
column6: & Canon) offer Zink cameras  all Zink paper is made by one company: Zink Holdings. They created the underlying technology  which has been licensed out to several companies. So
column7: while physical cameras or printers may vary in quality
column8: all of the photo paper is essentially the same.

column1: Just how good is Canons Ivy Cliq?
Well
column2: the Ivy Cliq is Canons least expensive Zink camera coming in at just $99.99. And while it is affordable  it is basically a toy. It is large
column3: made from bright colorful plastic
column4: weighs practically nothing
column5: has very limited features
column6: and prints 5 megapixel images onto stickers. It works just well enough to be passable.

column1: It feels as though Cannon focused too heavily on creating a flashy new device that looks fun and lost sight of actually making a good camera. Where they really fall flat is their halfhearted attempt to make the Cliq a digital camera. The device can accept a Micro SD memory card - and when one is inserted
column2: it saves the picture as a digital file. But
column3: what is absurd is that a digital picture is only saved if there is Zink paper in the camera. If you are out of Zink paper (or simply dont want to print the picture) the camera will not save the digital file. So  dont expect to use the Cliq as a digital camera. If you want a picture
column4: you have to pay Canon for Zink Paper.

column1: - Having a Micro SD card inserted also allows you to re-print the last photo that was taken  But
column2: even this has a caveat. If you power off the camera
column3: it is no longer able to re-print the last image (even though it is saved on the memory card). This is also frustrating as the device could have had the ability to work as a photo printer  if it could print pictures saved to the memory card. This could have led to more money for canon (as it would require customers to purchase more Zink paper)
column4: but it would have interfered with leading customers to purchase the Canon Ivy Mini Photo Printer (which is also $99.99).

column1: There is a workaround to using the Cliq as a digital camera:
If you would like to save a digital image to a Micro SD card
column2: but do not want to print a photo (or are out of paper)  you have two options:

column1: 1) Each package of Zink photo paper comes with a blue card that ejects before pictures are printed. You can load this blue card into the camera and take a picture. The photo will save as a digital file and the blue paper will eject as though a photo is being printed.
2) Re-use a Zink Photo Sheet. You can re-use the Zink photo sheets (although I wouldnt recommend doing this too many times with a single sheet). If you load a photo that has already been taken
column2: the camera will print a new photo right over top of the previous image
column3: but the new picture will be saved as a new digital file.

column1: NOTE: Both of these options work
column2: but it is annoying having to wait 55 seconds for each picture to print and save before you can take a new picture. It is also annoying that there is no screen on the camera.

column1: I do appreciate is that Canon has kept both the camera and the picture refills affordable. Each 2 x 3 inch photo sticker is just 50 cents  which matches the price of virtually all other Zink camera brands. Sadly
column2: buying larger quantities of refills does not save any money.

column1: Though the picture cost is reasonable
column2: it is frustrating that money is wasted on accidental pictures. The shutter button offers almost no tactile feedback and it is extremely easy to press accidentally. Almost every person who has used my Cliq has inadvertently pressed the button while holding the camera (which is frustrating as it wastes money and 10% of the cameras picture capacity).

column1: Here are some other things customers should know:
- The camera does not have any way of indicating how many pictures you have left. Luckily the Zink paper is not sensitive to light  so
column2: if you want to know how many pictures you have left  simply open the back and count the remaining sticker sheets.

column1: - There is a rechargeable battery
column2: but again  no way to determine just how much power you have left.

column1: - The Cliq does have a flash
column2: but it cannot be triggered manually and it only turns itself on in very dark conditions. The flash results in better pictures than most other lighting conditions
column3: so it may as well be on all the time.

column1: - The front features a tiny convex selfie mirror. It is laughably small
column2: but it actually works. What you can see in the reflection
column3: does end up in the photo.

column1: While the Ivy Cliq is fun
column2: I would only recommend it for kids. Instead
column3: I would recommend the Canon Ivy Mini Photo Printer. It is the same price and allows you to print better quality photos taken from your phone. And
column4: because it prints phone pictures  you can actually choose pictures you like and edit them to your liking before you print.

column1: NOTE: The Ivy Cliq+ is 8 megapixels and has a much improved flash. But
column2: it does cost $159.99. I would still recommend the Canon Ivy Mini Photo Printer over the Cliq+.

column1: Pros:
+ Takes a digital copy of the image that prints (if a Micro SD card is inserted)
+ The most recently taken picture can be reprinted with one button press  this allows you to share identical photo pictures with friends
+ Photo prints are actually stickers
+ Photos are thin and stick well
column2: but can also generally be peeled off of surfaces without causing damage

column1: + Only 50 cents per picture (as compared to classic Polaroid pictures which cost $2.00 each)
+ Zinc Photo Paper is not sensitive to light (in the same way as film). This means you can open the back of the camera without worry of ruining film.
+ No ink or development chemicals to worry about
+ Allows double exposure prints (Simply re-load a picture back into the camera and take a 2nd picture that prints over top of the first. Fun & artsy!)
+ Photos print quickly (~55 seconds) and do not require time to develop (compared to Polaroid pictures which take up to 10 minutes to develop)
+ Rechargeable battery built in
+ Built in flash
+ Selfie mirror actually works reasonably well
+ Camera is available in several vibrant and fun colors
Cons:
- Camera does not save digital images unless zinc photo paper is installed in the camera **NOTE: There is a workaround for this. See review above.
- Shutter button is far too easy to press. It offers no tactile feedback and it is very easy to accidentally take a picture (which is a waste of 50 cents).
- Camera does not have a screen
- Photo resolution is only 5 megapixels
- Camera does not have any indication of how many pictures are left (although you can take the paper out and count the sheets)
- Flash is automatic only and cannot be manually turned on or triggered
- Flash only turns on in very dark conditions
- Once the camera is powered off
column2: it can no longer re-print the last image that was taken (even when the image is saved on a memory card)

column1: - Image quality on the Zinc Photo Paper is fairly poor (this seems to be related to the 5 megapixel resolution of the camera)
- Water eats through the top layer of the photo paper destroying the image underneath. If rain touches an image
column2: or if liquid is spilled on a photo  they will be ruined. Keep in mind
column3: these are stickers  so they may end up on notebooks or other areas that kids might splash or get wet.

column1: - The back of the stickers are difficult to peel away (there should be a slit on the back of the paper  instead of needing to be peeled at the corners)
- No battery indicator
- Does not include a Micro SD memory card
- The cost of Zink photo paper is the same price regardless of the quantity you buy (50 cents per 2x3 inch sheet)"^3^Apr 30

TechEnthusiast^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^20^7^"Im not going to beat around the bush. The Canon Ivy Cliq is a truly awful camera that isnt worth the money. Do yourselves a favor and dont buy it.
Ive seldom encountered a product with no redeeming features or use cases
column2: but I can honestly say that this camera is a complete and total waste of plastic.

column1: The camera is made of light-weight plastic and feels cheap in the hand. My camera was yellow
column2: but the entire back of the camera is a glossy white plastic that will start to look dirty within a couple days of use.

column1: The camera has four buttons on it: power
column3: aspect ratio
column4: and duplicate photo. The camera has no LCD screen to it
column5: and there are no menus or options whatsoever. Once you click the shutter button
column6: the camera prints the photo (no matter how bad it is). There is no app
column7: this doesnt pair with your phone
column8: and you cant cancel the print if you know its going to turn out poorly. This was okay with the original Polaroid cameras of the late 80s and early 90s back when you were getting instant gratification instead of going through the hassle of getting film developed
column9: but this is quite frankly unacceptable in 2019.

column1: The camera does have a spot for a micro-SD card. If you should somehow blindly luck into a decent photo
column2: you can retrieve it from the SD card to share or print later. And trust me
column3: you will be blindly lucking into decent photos. The positioning of the optical view finder is awkward
column4: and its somewhat painful to use unless youre open to smashing your nose into the back of the camera.

column1: The cameras strap is a MAJOR design flaw. Its positioned in the upper left-hand corner of the camera
column2: and it dangles right in front of the printer. Theres a reason that the Polaroids of old spat the picture out through the front. With this camera
column3: you have to move your left hand out of the way
column4: and hold the strap so that it isnt in the way of the printer. Im at a loss as to why they thought this was a good idea.

column1: The instructions recommend that you be within 1.6 feet of the subject of your photo. At this distance
column2: I found that the flash washed out my subject rather badly. It should be noted that there is no way to turn off the flash with this camera.

column1: The camera holds ten sheets of instant photo paper and the blue data sheet that comes with the pack. My very first print jammed until I took the paper out and lightly fanned it before putting it back in. The paper is fairly expensive at the time of this review
column2: and youre not going to want to waste a single print.

column1: At 5 megapixels
column2: this camera has the same resolution as my first digital camera from 2003. Given the size of the print (2x3 inches)
column3: the prints look okay.

column1: If I could return this camera
I do not recommend buying this camera. Spend a little more and get something better
column3: instant printer and use your smartphone instead."^1^Apr 24

column1: DocCupCake^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"Have you ever been taking a picture and thought wow I wish I could just have an instant picture to have and share?

Well look no further Canon has made the IVY CLIQ to fill your instant picture needs! This compact lightweight camera takes a beautiful picture and prints it out in under a minute! No more uploading and going to the store!
So
column2: what are the core features of this camera you may wonder?

column1: Snap 5 MP photos to print instantly
Take great selfies with the Selfie Mirror
Print fun 2'x3' photos in 50 seconds or less
Every photo has a peel & stick back
Save all your photos with the MicroSD card slot
Simply press the reprint button right on the camera and print an additional 2x3' photo to share with friends

Unboxing the camera was straight forward and came with a 10-sheet picture pack to print on. It is recharged by small microUSB cable (included). The camera is thin and compact enough to hold in your hand or use the included strap. The camera does sport some trendy colors such as the Seaside Blue (which is the one I have)
column2: Bumble Bee Yellow or Lady Bug Red! So
column3: whatever your personality is the color is there to fit!

column1: So
column2: lets get to the details! Does it work?

column1: Oh
column2: does it! This camera sports some quick printing time and looks high quality for the 2x3 format. Once you print the photos you can choose to stick them on stuff
column3: or you can make a collage as they are a nice 2x3 size (perfect for those baby books and scrapbooking!

column1: Selfie Mode?
Yes
column2: this camera has a faux selfie mode by including a small selfie mirror on the front so you can get that perfect angle of that perfect moment. Nice thing is you can hit the reprint button and reprint that selfie again and give to your friend or loved one no need to take another photo.

column1: So how long doe sit last on one charge? 28 photos printed on one charge for me. Which isnt that bad considering you arent going to be taking hundreds of these at a time. It only takes 90 minutes to fully recharge the battery. It does have an auto off feature after approx. 5 min so need to worry if you leave on by accident.
The ZINK Photo paper Packs are inexpensive at 5 packs for $25 at the time of this review.
My Final Impressions-

This camera comes in a time where cellphones are doing the quick pictures. This camera brings back that feeling of fun memories with instant gratification of having a physical product post picture. You can save and share on the microSD card
column2: but this camera really shines with its instant print features in very bright settings some colors bleed a little but minor. I really enjoyed using this for those moments I wanted a permanent memory that could be saved physically for years to come! Canon nailed bringing fun back to taking memories in a time of all digital."^5^Apr 24

column1: RedScorpion^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^1^"The Canon IVY Cliq is an update on the old Polaroid of years ago. It produces zero ink pictures and it does a good job.
The instant ink photos feel a bit like a gimmick
column2: but they are fun. Last summer I picked up a Polaroid Onestep and I was incredibly disappointed. the pictures looked awful
column3: and the film was incredibly expensive. Thankfully
column4: the Cliq suffers from none of those problems. On a single charge
column5: I was able to take ten pictures and the pictures came out looking pretty good.

column1: I compared the IVY Cliq with the HP Sprocket instant ink printer. I took one picture with my phone and the other with the Cliq. I probably got more fine detail with the Sprocket
column2: but the colors looked better with the IVY. Also
column3: there was less banding and distracting lines with the IVY. The photos looked more like actual
column4: tiny photos.

column1: The camera itself comes with a tiny selfie mirror built in along with a slot for a micro-sd card to back-up pictures. Both worked as expected. I wish this camera had a digital view screen and a way to print photos from my phone
column2: but as an instant point and print
column3: it works well.

column1: My general attitude with reviews is 'did the item work as described and did I enjoy it?'. The IVY more than met those expectations. I wish it had Bluetooth built-in (I believe the more expensive models do)
column2: but I can't fault this model as it is good at what it does.

column1: I think the cameras are fun and look snappy
column3: the film isn't too expensive (last I checked you can get a pack of 20 shots for $10)
column4: and the device is simple and reliable. Easily recommend to friends and family.

column1: Note: With Mother's Day /graduations coming up
column2: I think these cameras will make for a good gift. Combine the camera with a photo album for small prints
column3: and really make their day."^5^Apr 23

column1: TechnicallyCorrect^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^1^"As Best Buy Insider
column2: I hate giving a bad review . However
column3: let me be clear
column4: the Canon Ivy Cliq camera is a truly awful waste of money. When you first take the camera out the box
column5: it looks good. Nice color
column6: seems to be decent craftmanship. It has some heft to it. Then you notice things that are move evident in the specs. No screen. Weak flash. Little to no memory. No app. 5MB photos. No Bluetooth. No NFC. That is correct
column7: 5MB. The lack of screen is acceptable because it is an instant camera
column8: but pictures on a digital camera that are only 5MB? So maybe the prints are okay at 5MB because they are only 2 X 3. Not even close. The colors are completely off - skin tones are reddish
column9: whites are yellow and there is an odd washing out on the edges. I tried multiple different lighting scenarios and they all came out terrible. So in thinking about
column10: the 5MB does not really matter. The reality is you can print photos 3 times the size at 5MB if the lens is good and the print media is good. Therein lies the problem. You have a tiny lens and the Zink media is very poor quality. Bad combination. The competition offers digital cameras with instant printing with 10 to 20 MB
column11: wider lenses
column12: Bluetooth
column13: screens and more. If you look at the non-digital instant cameras
column14: you find much more features and much
column15: much better image print quality. Then the competition does all that at a lower price. The reality is this is a product with no target customer. The image quality is too low for the enthusiast. The lack of screen will not get the under 30 customers. The camera is basically a toy and that will not get the teens ( which seem to be their target customer from the ads.) The price of $99 will not get parents to buy for kids. This should have been a $50 camera marketed kids who will use it a couple of times and put it in drawer.

column1: In summary  poor features
column3: poor price. This is the worst Canon product Ive ever owned. Nothing to look at here
column4: move on to the competition that just does a better job. Sorry Canon
column5: I usually like your products but - uugghhh....."^1^Apr 29

column1: psyclopps^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"This is a great entry level camera. Especially for kids and pre-teens. They can learn basic photography techniques and have a lot of fun with the built in printer.
Unboxing: The box is pretty plain but shows an accurate depiction of the device
column2: it looks to be about full size in the pictures. The contents are basic documentation
column3: the device
column4: 10 ZINK sheets
column5: a wrist strap and a micro USB cable. I wish it was USB-C but it is what it is.

column1: Product: The build quality is study plastic. It is glossy which looks great but could be an issue if you are giving the device to someone you know will abuse it
column2: it will pick up lots of scratches over time. I think this product would have been better with a matte finish or even a cheap metal body. There is a basic viewfinder
column3: mirror for selfies and flash on the front. The top has a power button
column4: shutter and shutter. The bottom has a micro USB port
column5: a micro SD card slot
column6: charge indicator and reset button. The back has the viewfinder
column7: a copy button
column8: and a button to size your prints in 2x2 or 2x3 inches.

column1: Setup: It is very straightforward. Make sure it is charged
column2: insert the paper in the device. I highly recommend a micro SD card for permanent copies.

column1: Use: Using the viewfinder you will have no issues lining up your pictures. It saves seamlessly to the memory card but keep in mind there is no internal memory so you will need to insert a card if you want copies for later. Most of the time the flash will go off and you will quickly get a print. I recommend you set it to 2x3 photos since it will fill up the paper but you will also have the option for 2x3 if you wish which will give you a small border on the bottom. I you put in a memory card you will get 5 MP photos which dont look too bad for what it is. The battery is rated at around 25 photos. I assume this is with print. It takes about a minute to print out a photo after each photo.

Print quality: It is a mixed bag. You have to remember this is not a high end camera and best used for kids or people who just want some picture stickers. The picture quality is not very detailed in the prints and is heavy on the red tint. I posted two photos to show you. Also
column2: the pictures double as stickers. You can peel the back and put them in a book or on the wall. They tend to bend easily after being stuck on a wall or a while (also seen in the pictures). The prints are cheap and you can get a 20 pack for under 10 bucks
column3: look or deals on this.

column1: Summary: Though this device is nothing to write home about
column2: it is fun. It is exciting. Kids and family who are not that into tech will love it. Professional photographers definitely won't use this for any projects
column3: but I would be they would have fun with it too as it makes a great toy.

column1: It is very much entry level and geared toward a young audience. Try one out if you get a chance."^4^Apr 24
RandallFlagg^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^2^"I have an AS in photography and for a Canon product
column2: the Cliq is fairly disappointing. I realize it's only 5 megapixels
column3: but the color quality
column4: grainy photos and the awkwardness of the camera make it a two for me. The one good thing it has going for it is that its size is nice to fit in a pocket.

column1: I tried a couple of shots indoors and they either came out dark because the flash failed to fire or they are hot with the blacks not really black and tons of reflection off of the subject. Many of the colors fail to reproduce to the actual item

column1: The camera has very basic controls. Power button
column3: print button and aspect ratio 2x2 or 2x3 depending if you shoot regular or portrait. The power button is really easy to brush and hit while you are handling it. It doesn't seem to bother the function as it takes a press and hold to power up or down the unit. It does bother me a bit when I accidentally hit it. Other than those buttons
column4: you can't control anything. There is no manual flash that I could see or read about in the manual. The manual is actually just a quick start guide in a few languages. It doesn't give you much and can quickly cause a headache as you try to decipher each step in your spoken language. It's really bunched up to save data or paper. The FAQ on this unit doesn't answer many basic questions. I imagine it's because of the newness of the item. I went to see why my photos were dark and how to turn the flash on. I'm guessing it is a German Flash and is always on Otto (auto). Sorry

column5: or on an outing where the quality of the photo isn't as important as the event. Just being able to snap some pics and share the small instant prints would be enjoyable for most if not all.

column1: I'd recommend the camera if you fall into the group that loves to snap photos and share right then and there. Otherwise
column2: I believe there are far better options for a point and shoot camera."^2^Apr 23

column1: Txstatesal^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Family and friends won't stop asking me to take their picture and if it was filled with endless film I sure would but it got to the point where I put this little winner away because I wanted to be able to choose when to snap a pic.

I love instant film cameras and cameras of all sorts because they all have great uses. For instance the Cliq came in handy recently on my way to Disney World when I realized how easy it would be to get my pictures fast and on the spot. As opposed to the person who works there and then going to find the venue that develops them.
The color of yellow is just as vibrant as the picture online
column2: the pictures are of good quality

column1: dharr18^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^7^"Canon - IVY Cliq Instant Film Camera - Bumblebee Yellow
Maybe I am missing the point...
OK. Maybe I am missing the point. I have the Canon Ivy Printer
column2: and I use it as needed when I find a picture I want to print out. It does a really nice job for a small format print. So I was intrigued when I found the IVY Cliq Camera. I was excited when the package arrived looking forward to having camera and printer in one package.

column1: After opening the package

I grew up back when instant cameras were a thing. Film cameras were the norm. Digital cameras were not a thing yet. The fun part of taking pictures back then was seeing how they turned out after waiting an hour at the local photo lab. Then you start going thru the pictures and were lucky to get 3 or 4 good shots of people in a 36 picture roll. The odds of someone not blinking or making a odd face were pretty slim.

Instant cameras were fun too as you took the picture and stood there like a fool waving it in the air trying to get it to develop quicker. The fun there was watching the photographer and seeing the disappointment as they see the picture was nowhere near as good as they had hoped as cousin Jimmy decided to stick a finger in someone's nose.
Why do I bring up this memory? At 50 cents per sheet
column2: taking a photo to be instant printed is not cheap. It would be very easy to go thru 10 pictures and not get a good one.

column1: Clearly there must be a way to take a picture and view it before it prints. Right? Maybe a app that sends the photo over Bluetooth...but then why not just use the phone to take the picture? But don't worry Canon took care of that...there is no app...there is no Bluetooth...there is no control over what prints. All pictures print
column2: even the nose picking Jimmy pictures.

column1: That is OK
column2: I thought. I just won't load the paper
column3: save the image to the micro SD and figure out how to get the right photo to print later.

column1: Nope. The camera will not take a photo without the paper.
Clearly this wasn't right. I go to Canon's support page.
Nope. You can't take a picture with no paper.
OK
column2: this can be fixed in a firmware update I am sure. I'll download the software and see what the firmware update process is like.

column1: Hmmm? No software for the camera. I am now assuming no firmware updates either.
So I have a camera with a SD slot that will not take pictures without 'film' being in this digital camera.
A 5 megapixel camera? You honestly could buy a cheap cell phone and have similar results.
I am not sure who this camera is for nor why it exists in this format. Buying just the IVY printer and using your phone will give better results and known results.
Honestly I can not recommend this camera in any sense of the word. It might be more tolerable if the paper was cheaper and affordable
column2: less than 10 cents a sheet seems about a right price point. But for the gamble of taking a good pic and no way of editing the picture before print and the hassle of having to have extra paper available if you are taking a lot of shots... I'll stick to my cell for everyday shots and break out the DSLR for special moments or projects.

column1: For the life of me
column2: I don't know who the target consumer is for this camera. The prints are so small that older people won't be able to see them. The price per shot is too high for most people sub 30 years old to find affordable. The inability to just take a digital picture is a waste.

column1: The beauty of digital photography is the ability to correct a picture before publishing or printing. This works against the grain of the advantages of digital photography.
For less than 10 cents an image
column2: I can select the photos I want printed and pick them up in an hour or have them shipped to me. Or I can wait 30 seconds to get a picture I am not sure of with cousin Jimmy and his stray finger.

column1: jpatterson34^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"The Canon IVY Cliq Instant Film camera is very easy to use. You have the option to take take 2x3 or 2x2 pictures. The Zink photo paper is a very durable sticky paper (which is why I guess it runs about $.50 a sheet before tax). The camera comes with one package of 10 sheets -which I really wish it came with more. There is no digital screen on this camera so it's really like a point and click. You can take selfies by looking in the small 'selfie mirror' (which mimics a mirror in a park bathroom). Overall
column2: it's a cool concept and the paper that the pictures are printed on is durable. I find it to be a little overpriced for the overall basic print a picture on demand camera."^4^May 7

column1: dlowen^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Polaroid cameras were very popular many years ago. WyldeBlue^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^1^"PROs:
- Actually delivers decent picture quality for an instant

column1: - Audible sound cues and status LEDs give you indications as to current status of image proportions
column3: internal printer & SD card activity
column4: etc.

column1: - As much as I thought the little selfie mirror on the front was a bit cheesy at first
column2: it actually does a GOOD job of allowing you to frame your subjects in the shot...a must for what seems like the target audience for this little gadget

column1: - Framing marks in the viewfinder also help you properly compose your subjects within the shot if you happen to be shooting from behind the camera
- Everything you need is right there in the box including a charging cable
column3: and carrying strap...my camera even came nearly fully charged

column1: - Built-in LED flash provides at least cell-phone level illumination in darker environments so you never miss that critical selfie or shot of Big Foot strutting past the front of your car on a country road
- With an SD card on board

column1: CONs:

column3: a little darker maybe...you are getting convenience and gadget-level fun factor here--this is not a camera for capturing serious/long-term memories

column3: or scrapbook embellishments

column1: - You have to completely unwrap the photo paper
column2: handle it with your bare hands
column3: and load it in the camera with the proper 'smart starter page' face down...an error-proof cartridge would have been preferable to ensure you didn't contaminate the printing surface or accidentally load the paper incorrectly

column1: - If you have paper loaded in the camera
column2: you can take pictures even without an SD card inserted
column3: but if you only have an SD card loaded
column4: you can't take any pictures at all--this ensures that even if that once-in-lifetime UFO landing is happening right outside your door
column5: you're going to miss the shot unless you have some Zink paper on board...just know up front that even though this feels like a 'regular' digital camera
column6: it is ONLY useful as such for printing out pictures as you take them

column1: - Printing speed was a bit slower than the older Polaroids that inspired it (for those of you who even remember using a Polaroid camera); you can easily spit out one image in about 30-45 seconds and be ready for the next shot
column2: but it's slow enough to take you 'out of the moment' if you have a few shots in a row you were hoping to take

column1: - The 'print again' button simply has a picture of a sun over some mountains with a small offset frame behind it to suggest a second image--it's not an obvious choice in iconography and could easily confuse someone you loaned your camera to ('Hey
column2: should I reset the focus to 'nature scene'...oh
column3: shoot--I just reprinted that photo instead
column4: sorry!)

column1: - It's not a big deal
column2: but if you use the recommended Canon Zink photo paper
column3: your first photo will take at least 2x as long to print because the camera has to spit out the cardboard starter 'smart sheet' before it moves on to printing from the first sheet of actual photo paper

column1: - The LED status light on top tries to do a bit too much for me to decipher without the instructions handy--status indicators from that single LED slit are white
column3: blue
column4: cyan
column5: magenta (seriously!)
column6: and yellow with blinking
column7: looping
column8: and combinations of those colors all trying to tell you different things. I get it--the focus is on fun so why not use a bunch of fun colors
column9: but would something like a little light next to an SD card icon be SO hard just to reduce the amount of stuff I have to remember?

column1: Summary review:
Everything about this camera screams fun and cutesy...the color choices are cute
column2: the selfie mirror is actually kind of cute (as well as being surprisingly more useful than I expected)
column3: the little Zink paper packets are cute
column4: the little sounds it makes when you take a picture are cute
column5: the changing LED colors in the status indicator are cute (if not a bit cryptic in their meaning)--the whole package is just very...cute. If that's what you're after
column6: this is a great little gift for the budding photographer/selfie-addict in you or your family. My daughter and I had a blast shooting off photos at the Endgame premier and she loves the instant gratification the in-camera printing provides for those spontaneous 'photo needs' with her friends. Sure
column7: the images are tiny once they're printed

column12: but with the added benefit of getting a printout of that moment while you're still IN the moment. I wish the camera could hold a few more sheets of Zink paper (only 10 per load) and an indicator of how many sheets are left in the hopper would be a BIG help; but for spur-of-the-moment

Loading the paper is pretty straight forward and not at all difficult. The quality of the printouts is much better than most other instant print cameras.
I only have a few issues with this camera
column2: but nothing is what i would consider a deal breaker. There is only an optical viewfinder. This is probably due to the printer elements being located on the back of the camera. This means you get no preview before it prints. You shoot a picture and it prints out. That's my only main issue with the camera so far.

column1: Overall
column2: if you were a fan of old school photo booths then you'll like this camera."^4^Apr 23

column1: TECHBEENGOOD^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Canon IVY CLIQ - This is my idea of a party camera. It could be a nice incentive for school-aged kids to get social and share instant photos of their friends and other party goers. For the rest of us
column2: its a very convenient instant camera that captures a moment or makes a permanent record
column3: with the printed result in your hand . . . now. But
column4: instant comes with a trade-off and you wont be leaving your camera/phone home..

column1: FRAME an image . . . CLICK . . . WAIT 30 seconds or so for a cute 2x2 or 3x3 PHOTO to pop out. Instant. Permanent.

SETUP and USE: The photo paper loads as 10 sheet packages (a 10 sheet pack is in the box and costs approx. $10 for 20 sheets when you re-supply). You should have charged up the camera beforehand. There is NO need for ink . . . this is a special paper using technology that never needs ink. There is a microSD slot if you want to have digital backups for your computer  Just do it; trust me. [The CLIQ PLUS version of the camera adds Bluetooth connectivity and adds around $60 to the price if easier connectivity or backups are important to you.] With either version of the camera
column2: you can also do reprints immediately after taking a picture using a top/rear button on the IVY CLIQ camera. There is a built in flash and an optical viewfinder to properly frame your pictures. I found it very easy to get an image that was always properly framed. Proper lighting was a bit trickier
column3: but improved with experience

column1: PERFORMANCE: So
column2: how did the pictures look? Nice and sharp
column3: but my first close-up picture was a bit washed out. A little practice recognizing how much light on my subjects was ideal
column4: and my pictures improved to a natural
column5: colorful print. Sure
column6: they were not as richly intense as I can accomplish with my newest Canon home printer
column7: but thats why I put a microSD card to print out those backups at home. According to Canon
column8: this version of the IVY CLIQ has a 5-megapixel resolution
column9: and at these small photo sizes
column10: the prints are pretty and natural looking. The backing of the print can be peeled away to reveal adhesive
column11: if you want to decorate stuff.

column1: RECOMMENDATIONS: I suppose you could think of this Canon Ivy CLIQ as a nostalgic throwback
column2: with some updates. It is reminiscent of those instant cameras we first saw in the 1950s-60s. I like the idea of encouraging social interactions and creating instant memories while the party is still on. I think imaginative kids
column3: especially
column4: will find ways to capture their world
column5: decorate their stuff
column6: and explore artistic projects. I can recommend this camera
column7: with the caveats Ive noted."^4^Apr 23

column1: CaneDOC^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This is one cool little camera! It prints out a 2x3 photo that has a backing on it that can peel off to be made a sticker! Setup is a breeze. It comes with everything you need to get started. I charged up the device and inserted the zink paper. This thing has no print cartridge nor requires any ink! It's all in the paper!

One thing I liked about the camera is it's simplicity. It has 2 buttons. ON/OFF and the shoot button. How simple!! I snapped a couple of photos to test it out and I was so surprised by the picture quality. It makes a great little photo that is sharp and clear! It took some work to get the sticker backing off
column2: but before long I was sticking little pics all over the house
column3: much to the chagrin of my wife. Think of all the little photos I can leave around the house for her to find!!

column1: I loved this camera! I give it 4 stars for it's fun factor
column3: and simplicity. I did not give the 5th star because I feel that the paper is a little pricey at 50 cents per sheet."^4^Apr 23

column1: jailoliv^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^2^"Loving photography like I do
column2: I would like to clarify that I look for perfect image quality
column3: which is the reason I own a Canon D70. That is not to say that I cant have fun with instant film camera such as the Canon IVY Cliq. After all
column4: instant cameras were a big thing when I was a teen. I even tried one recently and I liked it but I am sad to say that even my ten-year old did not like this one.

column1: The pictures came out either too orange or too red in every situation. In low lighting
column2: they were grainy and extremely dark. The flash made things even worse in that type of situation
column3: with spots of intense reflection. In good lighting
column4: it came out slightly better but not by much. The fact that it has no way of previewing the pictures before printing them
column5: make it a waste of money
column6: especially with the film you need to buy without the option of seeing whether it is worth it to print before you do so. If the quality was mostly good
column7: this would not be a big deal but the fact that it is not takes the fun away.

column1: You can save the pictures to an SD card but you will need a computer to see them. By then
column2: youd better off with a pocket photo printer that you can connect to your phone
column3: which probably can take much better pictures anyway.

column1: It feels cheap and seems to be designed with kids in mind but my younger daughter did not enjoy it either despite her initial enthusiasm.
The pros are few but size is one of them. It is also light
column2: easy to use and charged via USB. It has a small mirror for selfies but it did not impress me. I do like Canon but I cannot recommend this camera"^2^Apr 25

column1: Ebonovic^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"Welcome back the classic instant camera; as in physical picture in your hand.
The good: It is lightweight
column2: it is not a very heavy camera. Has fair picture quality
column3: and it does produce a physical picture that develops in under 1 minute.

column1: The not-so-good: You need basically FILM cartridges for the pictures. And they are not-in-expensive. about $10 a refill
column2: thus making each picture cost about $0.50. When learning how to use the camera
column3: we used up over half of the included cartridge.

column1: There are two settings for picture size
column2: that got a bit confusing for her to use at first... now that she knows
column3: setting it is okay.

column1: Two times in picking up the camera (that was on)
column2: we hit the easy to push shutter button
column3: which caused us to take two instant pictures of our palm.

column1: There is no digital screen
column2: as most young users are used to. So you don't get to pick and choose what picture looks best to print
column3: and no way to make duplicates of the same photo for all the friends squished into it.

column1: It is a small print
column2: about 2'x3'... not the full-sized Poloroids from 'back in the day'.

column1: Overall
column2: the quality of the camera seems nice... but if this is going to be a primary use camera
column3: be prepared for the cost on the supplies and the small print size."^3^Apr 24

column1: nhtechie^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^1^"I love Canon cameras - and I used to love the Polaroid Instant photos when I was a kid. So
column2: the combination of these two was very appealing to me. Well
column3: not to me - but to my kid.

column1: Its kind of big for kids hands
column2: so its good that there is a wrist strap. Theres an SD card slot
column3: so you can keep a digital image with the physical image. Mine was mint green - but thats just the front; the back was white and it looks like it could be a dirt magnet.

column1: The images were just not great. Well
column2: if this was a $30 camera then itd be on par - but not for one retailing around $100.

column1: Some images had lines
column2: others were fine (see attached images). We fell victim to the duplicate photo press and were stuck with a wasted dupe photo (also in included images). I got this as a product to review
column3: so I found it strange that it only came with the 10 sheets (default in the box) to write a review with. Normally
column4: we get extra accessories to ensure we get a lengthy review session
column5: but 10 photos went *poof* pretty fast.

column1: There is a Blackberry-esque selfie mirror on the front - which does the job.
When you take a photo
column2: shortly after you hear the rollers start and you want to turn the camera over. Well
column3: for both my wife and I
column4: we ended up hitting the shutter button at that time
column5: firing off another photo
column6: which in-turn kicks off another print job. Mine mis-shoot was of the ceiling
column7: my wifes was of the sky - so
column8: pretty consistent: up (yes
column9: in the attached photos too!). That really needs to be fixed - make the button more rigid
column10: or have it print out a different side. Something.

column1: I did go and buy a 20-pack of photo sheets
column2: running around $0.50 a photo - which is pretty pricey for a gimmick-type little camera. So
column3: there's $120 right out the gate - excluding memory cards.

column1: Overall
column2: this is a no-go for adults.

column1: For kids
column2: its a cute to have - but the price tag puts it out of that type of audiences budget. It also needs to include more sheets."^3^May 1

column1: MarkusMN^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^1^"I took this out of the box

column1: AcurNet^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^1^"The Canon - IVY Cliq Instant Film Camera in Ladybug Red is simply outstanding. niteryder^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^1^"Ive had a chance to run two packages of Zink paper through this camera and have been dissapointed with the results. When I first got the camera I was looking forward to shooting random grab shots to put into a small photo book. But after using the camera and going through 20 prints
column2: I have yet to find one that is acceptable enough to put into the photo book.

column2: it is what you would expect from a $60 camera. No many features but really what would be expected from a camera in this price range. The camera charged quickly and was easy to load the Zink pack. It seems fairly well built and actually feels pretty good in the hand. You can put a micro SD card to save photos

column1: NyVetteGuy^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"If you are looking for high quality prints and ability to take pics in almost any situation (lighting etc)
If you want something compact
column3: easy to operate that gives instant gratification by printing a pic in an instant then this IS for you.

column1: There is the option to save pics you have taken on an SD card but the image quality just isnt up to par with what your cell phone can do (and who doesnt have a cell phone camera now a days?) so I would just recommend using the Cliq because you can have a pic that you take in your hand to hold within seconds.
Its a little wonky sometimes as you really dont know how many pics you have left in your camera
column2: I just keep taking pics until I cant take any more then reload. Its also got a selfie mirror on the front for instant selfies.

column1: I have mirror-less SLRs that cost thousands and this obviously doesnt compare BUT for a compact camera you can take anywhere the Cliq a fun inexpensive choice.
My daughter loves it even though she has an iPhone for most of her pics and has started a collection of the instant shots from the Cliq that she has displayed on her wall in her room.
Good fun for what it is."^3^May 3
TechGuru^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"I gave the Canon Ivy Cliq to my daughter last week right before camp

column1: Christopher^/canon-ivy-cliq-instant-film-camera-ladybug-red/6344510?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"I have tested a few of these novelty self-printing cameras

column1: ENX0^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100m-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6573182?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^120^26^"I was excited when I bought the new Sony RX100M3 Camera brand new from Amazon about 3 months ago. I used it for a week on vacation and took about two thousand pictures. I have also used it for a couple day trips since then with no issue. I turned it on last week and to prepare it for my Christmas trip
column3: and set some of the presets. The camera powered on
column4: the lens extended
column5: but the rear screen would not display text or images. Also
column6: all the buttons stopped working and it seemed to be stuck in movie mode
column7: regardless of the dial settings
column8: any button I pressed turned on and off record mode.

column1: At that point
column2: I checked Amazon online to see what the service policy was and where to go for support. Amazon's site said to contact the manufacturer for questions and/or repair
column3: fair enough. So I called Sony support. The Sony tech asked me to try a couple things
column4: power off and on
column5: take the battery out
column6: and finally said it sounded like a firmware issue and told me to send the camera back. He said that Sony would fix it under warranty.

column1: I sent the camera in. A few days went by and Sony called me. They told me that the camera has some corrosion inside on the circuit boards
column2: and said it was probably due to the humidity or moisture that may have entered the camera while in my use. I explained that I take very good care of tech gadgets and know for a fact that this camera was never exposed to any water or moisture. Apparently
column3: corrosion is conveniently excluded from coverage under their warranty. Anyway
column4: they told me that the repair of my camera is going to cost $225. I could either accept the fee or they would send the broken camera back to me. What was I going to do with an $800 paperweight and I really wanted this camera for Christmas photos. After trying to negotiate a more amicable solution
column5: with no success
column6: I agreed to the repair.

column1: This was an $800
column2: 'TOP OF THE LINE' Sony camera (plus case
column3: batteries
column4: and other accessories) that I used for one trip
column5: owned it for a total of 90 days
column6: and now I have to spend another $225 to have it fixed. I checked online and found a lot of similar complaints about this corrosion issue with this camera and others are in same situation having to pay out of pocket for repair. In my opinion
column7: here are the reasons this camera failed: inferior parts; poor construction; lack of quality control; and the body is not sealed from humidity. I have gone back and forth with Sony customer support and keep hearing
column8: 'this is our policy' and 'while we would like to help
column9: there is nothing we can do'. I asked them to send me pictures of the corrosion
column10: which I have not received. I can see me being charged if this was negligence on my part or if I had dropped the camera in the pool or ocean
column11: but this camera has been dry since day 1. I don't expect every product to be perfect
column12: if Sony would just acknowledged the camera was faulty and fix it under warranty
column13: I would be happy.

column1: I have several other cameras
column3: Canon
column4: and Nikon as well and iPhone
column5: iPad
column6: etc. Most are less expensive than the RX100M3 and some more than 10 years old. They are all still in top working condition
column7: except for the Sony RX100M3.

column1: Needless to say
column2: I am very disappointed in Sony! The product quality and customer service are horrible! At one time
column3: Sony was the go to company for high quality equipment and you didn't mind paying a little extra for it. It's just not that high quality company anymore. If Sony wont stand behind the products they sell
column4: who will?

column1: There are far too many quality products on the market to waste your money on this overpriced junk. It takes great pictures and has lots of features
column2: but in my opinion the costs are not worth the risks of getting one with a corrosion issue.

column1: This will definitely be my last Sony product!"^1^Dec 8

English^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100m-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6573182?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^50^1^"I'm a very keen landscape photographer. I usually use digital SLR cameras with all the associated paraphernalia
Some time back
column2: I started looking into using smaller cameras as carrying about all the DSLR gear was getting old. For a few years
column3: I have been using a Canon G11
column4: which is a great camera
column5: but not quite up to the quality attainable from my DSLR.

column1: When the RX100M2 came out
column2: I was very interested because the reviews were so good. Sadly
column3: it had no kind of viewfinder which
column4: for me
column5: is a requirement. I really don't like holding the camera out in front of me
column6: trying to compose with a washed-out monitor in the sunlight.

column1: When the RX100M3 came out
column2: I was excited to see that they had added an electronic viewfinder
column3: so
column4: after much research
column5: decided to give it a go. I figured that I could always return it within the return period if I didn't like it. It is
column6: after all
column7: a very expensive camera for a compact.

column1: From the very first shot taken with this
column2: I was amazed at the quality
column3: and I remain amazed having taken 1
column4: 110 shots with it so far.

column1: As an example
column3: and my Nikon D7000 DSLR to the same location
column4: and shot with both side-by-side. Loading the files onto my computer when I got home
column5: I really could see no discernible difference between the quality of the shots from the Nikon
column6: and this little Sony. In fact
column7: all the shots that I ultimately used turned out to be from the Sony!

column1: Of course
column2: everybody's requirements in a camera differ
column3: but I will outline some of the facets of this camera
column4: and what makes it such an ideal camera for me:

column1: Lens: As stated before
column2: the quality of this camera is superb
column3: and the lens has to take quite a large amount of credit for this. For some
column4: they may find that it only going out to is a problem. Being a landscape photographer
column5: I was more interested in the wide end
column6: and was very pleased to see that Sony had widened it from 28mm in the previous models to 24mm in this model. This end of the range is far more important to me than telephoto. Of course
column7: 70mm at the wide end may not be enough for some people -- possibly if you are intending to shoot wildlife or sports. In that case
column8: you may be better served by one of the long-zoom bridge cameras. They will
column9: of course
column10: not have the image quality that this little Sony has.

column1: It is a fast lens
column3: although be aware that the F1.8 is only really available at the widest end. Still
column4: F2.8 at 70mm is fine for me.

column1: Handling: Make no mistake
column2: this is a very small camera. This is
column3: of course
column4: a great asset
column5: but it may seem a little 'fiddly' if you are used to bigger DSLRs. I personally don't find it too 'fiddly' to use
column6: although you will have to get used to the fact that there are limited dedicated buttons so
column7: for things like exposure compensation and other common adjustments
column8: you will have to delve into the menus. This is actually made easier because there is a user-assignable bank of twelve settings that are easily reached from the dedicated function button. This makes on-the-fly adjustments quite easy to achieve with the minimum of fuss.

column1: Viewfinder: For me
column2: this is the real high-point of this camera. It is small
column3: but bright and easy to see. I find it more than acceptable to use it to fully compose my shots. Indeed
column4: it is my preferred method of using this camera.

column1: I did
column3: find that this camera solved a real problem for me that I didn't anticipate. Being a relatively new eyeglass wearer
column4: I always struggle with how to use my glassed when shooting. Do I adjust the dioptre for clear viewing with my glasses on? The trouble with that is that it means I can't shut out enough light at the viewfinder because my glasses are in between. Also
column5: because you can't get your eye near enough to the viewfinder
column6: you have trouble seeing the whole image and have to shift around to see all parts in the viewfinder. Alternatively
column7: do I adjust the dioptre to be able to see clearly without my glasses? The trouble with that is that I can then not 'chimp'
column8: or look at the shot on the monitor without putting my glasses back on. It's a real pain. It turns out that this little Sony solves that problem for me. Because the viewfinder gives you exactly the same information that is available on the monitor
column9: I adjust the dioptre so that I can see clearly without glasses
column10: and just use the viewfinder to see the last shot
column11: check on the histogram
column12: adjust settings. In essence
column13: I don't use my glasses with this camera. This works out perfectly for me
column14: and is something that is not possible to do with a DSLR without EVF.

column1: The built-in neutral density filter is a very welcome addition that I use very frequently
column2: and I have added a filter adaptor from LensBaby which allows me to use a 52mm polarising filter.

column1: There are lots of extra gadgets and features on this camera -- most of which I don't use. Mostly in the automatic modes and HDR
column2: etc. Most of these don't interest me. I hear the video is supposed to be class-leading although video is also something that doesn't concern me.

column1: If I search for some negatives about this camera
column2: they are slight and well worth the compromise in my opinion.

column1: I find it tends to blowing out the highlights. It is quite rare for me to take a shot where I haven't dialled in -.3 to -1.5 exposure compensation. I think that's just the price you pay for a camera which has to cater to the casual user. They lean towards a more brightly exposed shot overall at the risk of blowing highlights. No big deal.
There is no facility for remote shutter release
column2: so I use the two-second timer most of the time when I have the camera on a tripod. I was quite disappointed to find that it was impossible to use the self-timer on most of the automatic modes or
column3: more crucially
column4: when using exposure bracketing. There is no point in exposure bracketing if you're going to be shaking the camera around when pressing the shutter manually! Oh well. Can't have it all.

column1: Overall
column3: I love this little camera. I really feel now that I can carry this camera around (especially as I do most of my photography travel on a motorcycle)
column4: and not feel as if I'm compromising on image quality for the sake of portability.

column1: There's an old saying in photography that the best camera is the one that you have with you. Never has this been more true. It's always with me
column2: plus it really is the best camera!"^5^Nov 5

column1: OffTrekkin^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100m-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6573182?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^28^4^"I purchased this camera for a long-term backpacking trip
column2: and loved the quality and features
column3: especially the manual features for long exposure and the timelapse app that you can buy for $9.99. However
column4: my camera died after 2 months in Central America from humidity. I took all of the precautions necessary
column5: including dessicant packs and a dry bag. However
column6: the moment you take the camera out in 90% humidity
column7: you risk damage. Now imagine trying to do a timelapse for 15 minutes on a pier on the barrier reef in Belize
column8: and imagine how much humidity the camera is being exposed to. Sony does not cover 'water damage' and will not repair or replace this camera. Many searches online find people with the same problem. So if you are going to buy this camera
column9: which is a fantastic camera
column10: make sure you get a warranty that will cover water damage and corrosion
column11: or you will be out $800 like me."^2^May 3

column1: PMRM^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100m-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6573182?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^24^0^"I had a Rx100 & RX100 II. So my review will be based on it.

#Compare to RX100 and RX100 II. The Lens on this camera is amazing. Sharpness is equal to some of the best DSLR general purpose lens'es. A comparable interchangable lens will cost around same as the camera.
#High ISO image quality
column2: Dynamic Range rivals some old DSLR's.

column1: #Video mode is the best available for a pocket camera. Only Panasonic m4/3rds rivals it. others cannot come even close.
#Viewfinder is good a addition. Though it is kind of small. eventually you will get used to it.
#for me this is the only camera i need for 90% of my shooting needs.
# I have DSLR for potraits and events."^5^Jun 19
BiGGiE^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100m-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6573182?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^14^2^"I was looking for something that would be easy to carry around
column2: especially in a pocket and take great photos. The price is steep but if you look around you will find a reasonable price for such a great camera. To preface
column3: I used to own the QX100 that is also made from Sony and I thought upgrading to the RX100 would be a minimal upgrade at best. I was wrong. The features and control over different functions blows away the QX100. This camera is great in automatic mode but has enough tools and features to play around with if you are a professional photographer as well. The speed and ease of use is quick and easy enough for me to use it over my cell phone.

column1: Funnest features

1) The camera is already great in low light but if needed it has a flash that articulates up that doesn't wash out your subject and allows just enough light to make a great photo out of something that wouldn't have shown up otherwise
2) Electronic viewfinder - Something I didn't think I would use that much but using it has helped to stabilize and frame my photos better.
3) NFC transfer - One of the things i loved about my previous camera was the pictures could be stored directly onto my phone to instantly share. While this feature isn't evident in the RX100
column2: it does provide quick NFC file transfer to phones that support it (android mostly) allowing you to quickly share the file via the internet.

column1: 4) Smart remote - One thing I enjoyed from my QX100 is that i could use the phone as a remote to the camera. That is not lost on the RX100 either as the smart remote feature is built in and allows you to use your phone (via the playmemories app) to remotely snap your photo while viewing what the camera can see.
Cons
1) coming from a cell phone might take some time to get used to the RX100 as there is no touch to focus feature. Facial recognition and positioning your focus take precedence here.
2) Tad bulkier than the previous generations but fits nicely into large pockets and jacket pockets. A little tight for your straight fit jeans but still somewhat comfortable."^5^Feb 4

Samath^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100m-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6573182?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^13^1^"I have a RX100 (original version) but decided to get the new RX100M3. The picture and video quality is much better than the original RX100. The new lens is amazing and the prime reason for the quality. In addition to the picture quality I like the titled screen and the new flash configuration. Unlike the previous version of RX100 you can pop-up the flash using a dedicated button when you need the flash. Since BestBuy didn't have the camera in store and didn't want to order online and wait for it I bought it from a Sony store. I really like the camera."^5^Jul 13

column1: Turbo^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100m-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6573182?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"Being a long time DSLR user this is my first small pocket-able camera with the features I am used to and I will use it to compliment my DSLR. Techmaster^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100m-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6573182?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^5^"The reviews on this camera are excellent. The actual use of this camera did not live up to the hype....for me. One big complaint I have is when trying to do a selfie and the screen is in position so you can see yourself..you have to hit the shutter and then a countdown ...3 -2-1 and the shutter fires. I don't want this. I want to hit the shutter to take the photo. When I take a selfie with my young grandson I need to be in control. Maybe you can change this. I don't know.

Another downside is the blown out highlights. For a camera in this price category and caliber that is not acceptable to me. The overall image was not as sharp as I anticipated. The exposure was not what it should been too. On playback on my computer
column2: as you started to zoom in the image became overly pixelated. The camera had many manual controls but I feel I should get acceptable results without having to tweak every shot. Then I used my friends Canon g 7x Mark 2 and the images were spectacular on the Canon. The exposure
column3: color
column4: saturation
column5: highlights
column6: etc on the Sony was lacking compared to the Canon. Yes

column1: The Canon also has a bigger zoom ratio. The bottom line for me is IMAGE QUALITY. I think the Canon is much superior to the Sony.
I guess with somethings maybe you will sacrifice quality for other features

column6: first steps
column7: birthdays
column8: once in a lifetime vacations
column9: etc I will choose the best image quality anytime. My choice is Canon."^1^Aug 30
