column1: Missy^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100m-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6573182?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This camera takes very good low light pictures. The pop-up viewing eye piece is nice in very bright outdoor light. I wanted a new camera with Wi-Fi capability but it turned out to be very complicated to use. I thought it would be like using my phone to share pictures. I took the camera back in to Best Buy but they would not help me. 'Just Google it.' I just have not found the time to figure it out. I have not been happy with Best Buy customer service and their rewards points. I wish I had purchased it from another store.
I like the playback feature that remembers what picture I was on when I turned off the camera. My husband's Nikon does not and he has to start again after turning off the camera."^5^Jun 25

Diverbrian^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100m-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6573182?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I will be completely honest here. I bought this thinking I would try it out and return it after my trip. I went to France for two weeks with this camera and my Nikon D750. I wound up using my Nikon 3 times for astrophotography and every other time I used the Sony. I decided to keep the camera and sell my A6000 which is what I was previously using as a travel camera. When using the kit lens on the A6000 I couldn't tell the difference in the quality between the A6000 and the RX100 III. Sony has yet to make any good lenses for that camera without going to the full-frame E mount lenses. The only improvements for my photography for this camera would be to add more magnification to the viewfinder and to not have the camera shut off when closing the viewfinder. (The latter has been corrected with the Mark V version for 500$ more.) I did add the handgrip which really made the camera handling so much better than the smooth front. I think the M5 version also has this built in now. I picked up two extra Sony batteries a charger and a screen cover and this is now my go to camera for holidays and day to day shooting. A fantastic addition to a DSLR or the perfect camera for someone who just wants to take really nice travel pictures.

PS. Since I said I was going to be completely honest I will admit to you that after the first day of shooting in full manual in constantly changing light as I went in and out of chateaus I wound up switching to full auto and with VERY few exception of tough lighting all the pictures came out amazing."^5^Apr 19
mike^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100m-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6573182?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Love this camera! Dslr quality in a pocketable camera"^5^Nov 16
point^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100m-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6573182?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Pros: Smart controls in a compact body
Excellent implementation of Program Shift with front ring
Exposure preview as you make adjustments
Very high resolution
Bright f/1.8 maximum aperture for shallow depth of field and good night shooting
Very fast AF performance
Very good low-light AF capability (down to less than 1/16 foot-candle)
Excellent high-ISO performance for such a compact model
Surprisingly good dynamic range
Crazy-fast shutter response when pre-focused
Very good buffer depth
Fast buffer clearing
Blazing-fast buffer clearing for RAW files (with high-speed SD card)
Excellent 'WhiteMagic' LCD
In-camera correction means virtually no distortion or chromatic aberration in JPEGs
Very fast continuous shooting in Speed Priority mode (focus and exposure lock after first shot)
Great flash range at wide angle
Excellent Sony 'Handheld Twilight' mode for handheld exposures after dark
Sweep panorama mode (one of our favorite camera features)
AVCHD 2.0 Full HD video with stereo sound
Focus peaking
USB charging; charge from your laptop or iPhone charger
Good battery life (330 shots/charge) for its siz"^5^Nov 11

column3: it would have been better if it had touchscreen (comparable camera from Canon has touchscreen at a much lower price range). Also

column1: 1) the BEST camera is the one you have with you
column2: and while I would stop short of calling it 'pocketable'
column3: it is small enough to take with you nearly everywhere without a big hassle.

column1: 2) Image quality is SUPURB! At 24 megapixels
column2: there is more than enough room to crop photos to your hearts content and still have plenty of detail left to print nice 8 x 10's or larger with no worries.

column1: 3) Beginning photographers will appreciate the well-laid out and detailed menu system. Not only can the camera 'walk you through' the different shooting modes
column2: it explains when you should use them and why. There is a shooting modes for nearly ANY possible situation
column3: yet more advanced shooters can still take manual control over all camera functions.

column1: 4) This. Lens. Is. SPECTACULAR!!! The low light performance of this camera has to been seen to believe it!! This Zeiss 1.8 glass delivers amazingly crisp pictures WITHOUT a flash when most other cameras (including some DSLR's) would be hard pressed to capture a respectable image with one! I know that sounds like an exaggeration
column2: but it's TRUE! Simply second to none in my opinion and I've been behind a camera since LONG before 'digital' was even a thought.

column1: Yes....it's a little more expensive in the opinion of some people. But if you want to capture great images
column2: instead of coming up with excuses and explaining the pictures you SHOULD have snapped
column3: THS IS THE CAMERA TO BUY! PERIOD."^2^Oct 22

column1: ZeroStarsIfICould^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-stone/6367050?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^34^9^"In no scenario does this camera take a single clear photo without SIGNIFICANT grain and slight blur. The shake in videos is jarring. This camera is comparable to something that would have been released in the very early 2000's. I purchased this for the carefree simplicity for on the go fun however it's literally unusable if you have any desire to enjoy your memories. I'd recommend purchasing the HTC re from 2014 even though it's five years old and most likely difficult to find. Do some research and you'll see that the re far surpasses the IVY REC which is mind-blowingly shocking as it's 2019 and we're talking about a camera from Canon. Do your research
column2: this is a 100% unbiased review (I've never previously reviewed a product) but I've been so burned by this I just had to air my disbelief. I guarantee this will be pulled from shelves or never to be seen again after these initial units are severely discounted and sold."^1^Oct 21

KLC7^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-stone/6367050?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^3^"I received this free IVY REC Outdoor Camera (Riptide) to review. I found it to be a great little camera
column2: unbelievably small for all that it can do! I was able to take clear crisp photos as good if not better than my smartphone camera.

column1: What I also found surprising was even though it is advertised as an outdoor camera
column2: it takes great pictures indoors too. There is no flash feature for indoors
column3: but as long as there is light in the room
column4: pictures come out great.

column1: The video option is doable. Not necessarily the best but it does what it says and for those moments when a short video is needed
column2: it is fine. I like the fact that it can all be downloaded to your phone or computer later.

column1: I think this little camera is marketed for younger people for it's usability to travel and rugged exterior. I took photos in the rain without worry. If dropped
column2: it can withstand the pressure. The camera itself has an attachable clip which makes it easy to carry; I clipped mine on my purse strap.

column1: The only drawback I personally had with the camera is trying to open the little door for inserting the  MicroSD card and the cord for the USB port to download and charge. My husband had no problem opening it but I simply couldn't manage it. Perhaps not the best feature if you are older
column2: have arthritis or other issues with strength.

column1: I would recommend this product especially for children when they want a camera of their own but might drop an expensive smartphone when taking a picture."^4^Dec 3

column3: or to really see the picture before you take it

column5: and allows the camera to easily be attached to a belt loop for easy access. The accompanying app requires little set up
column6: but after that is pretty easy to use. The app let's you see the photos or videos you've taken and then download them to use elsewhere. I don't appreciate that the app is mandatory in order to have full use of the camera
column7: but I understand that it is part of streamlining the experience so I accept it. Overall it is a nice simple camera for on the go
column8: and it would be nice for people who just want to be able to take quick pictures but aren't worried about professional quality."^4^Dec 3

column1: satisfied1^/sony-dsc-h300-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4076008?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^96^11^"Respectfully disagree with the negativity of the previous reviewers. column1: jhoner^/sony-dsc-h300-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4076008?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^58^9^"I have owned Sony camera's for many years. column1: MDAC^/sony-dsc-h300-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4076008?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^28^0^"Recently got this camera in store. I will admit that I was a little skeptical about buying it based on some of the other reviewers comments

column1: Swipesy^/sony-dsc-h300-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4076008?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^36^10^"I bought the Sony DSC-H300 at Best Buy while on vacation in Washington D.C. I don't have a smart phone (just a little flip phone for emergencies)

column3: but my initial impression
column4: after 200+ photos
column5: is that it's a huge step up from my previous camera (Sony DSC-P72)
column6: or any other camera I've ever had.

column1: I went from 3.2 to 20.1 megapixels and the difference is astounding. So is going from 3x optical zoom to 35x! Photos are clear
column2: image stabilization (not available on my old camera) is an extremely nice feature to have
column3: and this new camera is almost as easy to use as my old one. I haven't tried the video recording feature yet
column4: but I didn't buy it for that anyway. I bought it because I wanted something that could take very good photos
column5: have more zoom that I had before
column6: and didn't cost more than $250. I was looking for something with at least 10x zoom
column7: then I saw this one with its 35x zoom. Needless to say
column8: it caught my attention.

column1: I read the reviews posted here and elsewhere before buying. There are good and bad reviews on just about everything out there
column2: and I've learned to look at the overall picture (no pun intended) rather than place too much importance on bad reviews
column3: though that's not so say I ignore them completely. Quite the contrary.

column1: It's not perfect
column3: but for the price I paid I think it's a great bargain and has everything I want in a camera. It came with a set of four AA batteries
column4: and those batteries lasted through all 200 photos and the time it took to download them to my computer. By comparison
column5: my old camera ate batteries for breakfast.

column1: I'm a happy camper with this camera. As an example
column2: I've attached one of the photos I took with the camera. Due to the file limitations on this review
column3: I did crop the photo and reduce the colors to reduce the file size
column4: but the full-size photo look the same to me
column5: and I have good eyes. The photo was taken from the Washington Monument
column6: which is about 0.57 miles away line of sight. It was not taken at full zoom either.

column1: Downloading photos is a breeze with the included USB cable. There's no WiFi
column2: but that doesn't matter to me. I might try getting some rechargable batteries for it
column3: but I haven't had much luck with rechargables in the past. Maybe they're better now?

column1: I'm looking forward to taking more trips now
column2: since I now have a camera that can take much better photos than I was able to before.

column1: I don't normally give five stars on anything
column2: but four seems a bit low too. I'd rate this camera at 4.5 stars.

column1: Did I mention I'm a happy camper? :)"^5^Sep 23

column1: Parkersspace^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-sky-blue/6333186?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"Previously on vacation I would buy those waterproof throw away fuji film cameras
column3: pay to develop the photos and get what came out.  It is very difficult to view anything underwater on any small camera
column4: so you kind of point it and hope.  I did get used to viewing the screen through my goggles and could at least make out a large rocks or a shell I would aim for with lots of fish or coral near it.  I could then zoom
column5: focus and shoot.  I am a semi professional photographer but not underwater.  The quality of the photo when taken in highest quality and largest size
column6: though the camera over processes like all point and shoots
column7: when edited to clear haze and shrunk to a 2500px longest side was great and hid most over processing artifacts created by the camera. It did a colour reproduction in and out of water but it is not my professional DSLR.  For the money it was awesome.  Fun and easy to use.  I quickly learned the set up and appreciated being able to adjust the white balance and have jpg's with a high enough quality and size to edit. I snorkeled two days for 4 hours each day
column8: had the camera under water the full time and 0 issues
column9: it worked flawlessly and much better than the throw away i would normally use.  It will pay for itself in 4 snorkeling days.  Attaching photos
column10: they have been edited to remove haze and to my liking.  The wonderful thing about the camera is i can take photos
column11: throw away those that don't work without paying to develop them and keep what i want
column12: and edit them to my liking
column13: unlike the film throw aways."^4^Nov 4

It always ranked in the top 5 of underwater cameras. I used if for snorkeling and ran into several big issues
column2: the main problem was the camera would take a long time to focus or not focus at all. When you would zoom the problem got worse. The other problem was 'bubbles' on all video or photos. Not sure if water got in between the lens and waterproof glass or condensation. The final issue was the glare on the screen while snorkeling
column3: it made it almost impossible to see what you were shooting. Oh
column4: one more thing. While taking a video when you would zoom you could here the motor noise in your playback. No good. I bet I deleted 80 - 90% of photos and videos. Lucky we brought our GoPro Hero 7 black on the trip. I am returning the camera."^2^Oct 11

column1: kevinS^/fujifilm-finepix-xp140-16-4-megapixel-waterproof-digital-camera-sky-blue/6333186?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I went on a week long river rafting trip. - Pictures were good. (not great...)
- The multi-shot mode was great for action shots
- Easy to use
Cons:
- The screen is not visible when wearing polarized sunglasses
- I wish it had an exposure bracketing setting . (can be done manually)
spare battery (s) can be helpful...
Overall I'm happy with this purchase."^4^Jul 27

column1: Photogenie7^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-vii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6364719?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"I am totally amazed at this camera. The picture quality is excellent as is the quick and accurate focusing. The low light performance is excellent too. I was skeptical to buy this camera and considered the Sony RX100 VA as it has a faster lens but I wanted the longer zoom and touch focus. The V7 has performed wonderfully in all lighting conditions. The lens is still fast  enough for me as I got great night shots
column3: clear
column4: sharp. I did a few selfies and the photo was sharp as could be with excellent color. The features rival the Sony DSLR. Best Buy did price match so I saved a considerable amount of money which was one reason I bought the camera as I did not want to spend 1200 Dollars on a camera. After using this camera I can tell you it is worth  the price. Best camera out there. Since I saved so much money on the camera I bought an extended warranty
column5: fitted case and extra batteries. Great accessories if you buy the camera. I know that Best Buy will fix or replace the camera if anything goes wrong for 3 years. Extra batteries are a necessity. The case protects the camera. There are two different styles of cases but I am not sure if Best Buy carries both. You can get it at a well known photo retailer in New York City. However
column6: Best Buy carries a very popular fitted case and excellent Sony case.

column1: I took photos in total darkness with the flash and the the photo quality was excellent. The camera focused accurate with correct exposure. Most camera would have a difficult time focusing in total darkness without a light assist. Not this camera. Read all about the features of this camera and you will see it is in a class of its own. I highly recommended this camera. You will not regret buying it."^5^Feb 20

OurMicroFamily^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-vii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6364719?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"This camera is the absolute best camera in the point and shoot camera and easily puts the G7 X Mark III to shame on what that could have been. Granted both are premium but different price categories still the auto focus on this is well worth the price difference and the quality of the menus feels like a pro would easily enjoy with so much customization its nonstop of potential. When I invested in this for Our Micro Family vlog I thought noway would this be amazing but it really grabbed me and proved me wrong. The thing that I love most is that I have power of a 24 mm lens and all way out to a 200 mm zoom which is great. The 4k recording does not overheat after five minutes but instead around 30 minutes which is nice.
Now onto the bad side
column2: there is no wall charger in the box and that is a 49 dollar optional addon.

column1: DrMAS^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-vii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6364719?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Camera work really nicely. You can focus the camera really fast. This camera produces amazing pictures and videos. Very easy to use either automatically or with different camera settings. I added a Lensmate system to add a polarizing filter or a ND filter. It works really well with this camera and is not affected by the zoom lens. This is a great travel camera"^5^Oct 11

Traveler^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-vii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6364719?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I switched to a compact camera because it was getting increasingly difficult to carry my SLR camera and lens and enjoy traveling.
The pictures are amazingly sharp and I used the 200mm zoom quite a bit.  The Sony was able to focus and take a clear picture even though our tour bus was in motion.  When we visited a National Park
column2: we were extremely lucky and saw a tiger appear briefly from the bushes
column3: I was the only one on my vehicle that captured the whole body of the tiger.  The other people with smart phones and slower cameras got only half the body or tail before the tiger disappeared in the bushes.  For me
column4: it was worth the cost of the Sony to capture a once in a lifetime picture."^5^Dec 14

column1: Larry^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-vii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6364719?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"There are times you just don't want to carry your 'big camera' - in my case if I'm gonna be in a theme park all day or other such location or when it's important to be a little discrete.  This little fella with its small size
column2: 200 mm zoom and 2.8 lens is perfect!  You can put it in your pocket or hang it off your belt in a small case.  Pop in a couple of extra batteries and you're set for the day.  It makes great pictures and video to document your activities.  It is pricey but as I've found over the years you get what you pay for.  This is my 2nd in the RX100 line and it is an excellent alternative to carrying your dslr gear."^5^Dec 7

column1: GEO1^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-vii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/6364719?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^6^"This is an expensive point-and-shoot.  It was much anticipated.  There will likey be an rx 100 viii next summer.  I'm sure the new iphone 11 pro can take similar quality photos.  This camera is likely best for vloggers.  The tilt screen works great for this and selfies.  The video quality is great
column2: very little shake.  The sound is also good.  You can record in slow motion and time lapse directly in the camera.  These feature are fairly easy to use but you won't likely use them much.  Stills had good resolution and the autofocus was on spot most of the time.  Eye detect AF doesn't always stick to the eyes.  There is also eye AF for video.  It shoots a high amount of frames per second (90 fps?).  The focus on the subject is not as sharp as I expected at high frame rates.   The optical zoom is 8x and gets you close enough for shooting sports action from the stands.  The Sony app this camera connects to works great to send pictures and videos directly to the cellphone and television.  This camera is a good fit for someone who wants a versatile camera on the go without having to carry a mirrorless
column3: lenses or flash.  I couldn't find a dedicated travel case for this camera.  It is quite small and definitely does not belong in your pockets.  If you want higher resolution pictures you'll need a bigger sensor and camera!  So if you're fine with above average quality pictures and video from a point-and-shoot
column4: use this camera in Auto mode and it will work great.  Sony has the best autofocus on the market hands down.  I did not keep this camera
column5: I found the a7riii was a better fit for me."^4^Oct 9

column1: sumofan^/sony-cyber-shot-rx10-iv-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera/6111512?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^16^0^"This is my fourth camera in the SONY RX line. I started with the initial RX10. As SONY introduced the next iterations
column2: there were notable improvements. The RX-10iii was an excellent camera in particular: fast lens
column3: great range. But
column4: with the introduction of the RX-10iv
column5: SONY made it impossible for me to not move on. Same superb 24x600 mm ZEISS lens
column6: 20 megapixel 1' sensor
column7: recent modification removed the slight delay when shooting moving objects such as birds or planes. This is a Point and Shoot camera (meaning the lens is permanently fixed to the body ... unlike DSLRs
column8: which have removable lenses. It has a wealth of controls
column9: but also takes absolutely superb pictures in AUTO mode - for those wanting to get right down to just plain getting great shots without wrangling with manual settings. The camera itself has the heft and feel of a DSLR and
column10: with that 600 mm range and low light capability of that very impressive Carl Zeiss lens
column11: I offer the suggestion that this camera would fit the needs and desires of very many budding photographers. Additionally
column12: this one camera replaces a bag full of heavy/expensive lenses. You'd have to have had to lug heavy camera bags housing a DSLR and an array of lenses to appreciate this previous sentence! :-) I have tried many cameras (including DSLRs and expensive lenses)
column13: but have always returned to the SONY RX-10 line. The pictures I've taken
column14: per my subjective viewpoint
column15: are excellent. What else is there? Go into Best Buy
column16: the folks at the Camera section will be more than happy to let you try one in the store (no
column17: not getting any AttaBoys for this!)."^5^Feb 23

column1: MandarinDuck^/sony-cyber-shot-rx10-iv-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera/6111512?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^0^"I had the original APS-C sensor 2005 Sony bridge camera
column3: as my first digital camera which was extraordinary for its time. I then upgraded to Sony's 1' sensor bridge camera DSC-RX10 (mark I) which was lighter in weight and extended the zoom to a 24-200 mm equivalent. I loved this camera but its limitation in telephoto range prevented great wildlife and bird photography as well as its slow focus in certain situations had me eagerly awaiting this Mark IV. This camera extends the zoom to 600 mm telephoto for wildlife and birds.while the phase detection focusing solves the slow focusing problems with the preceding Mark I
column4: II and II versions of the RX10. It is hard to imagine a version which would lead me to upgrade again. The only way to replace this camera with a DSLR or mirrorless would require a large camera bag full of lenses. For active travel
column5: the RX10 Mark IV is perfect and solves the shortcomings of other bridge cameras."^5^Nov 11

column1: jjsereday^/sony-cyber-shot-rx10-iv-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera/6111512?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^0^"Sony's RX10 is an incredibly capable camera. As a professional I never thought I would purchase a bridge camera but the ability to capture 4K video on a 24-600mm F4 lens is something that I couldn't pass up.
I use this camera as a 3rd camera next to the Sony a7Sii or a7Rii. It has Slog which can be graded to match color nicely and just able all of the camera settings and capabilities as the a7 series.
For photos the IV added higher and longer FPS which is great for sports or any fast passed action that needs speed and great autofocus.And doing so at 600mm is unreal.
Definitely check it out. It is one of the most versatile camera on the market and for under $2k it's definitely worth it."^5^Nov 22

Doc100^/sony-cyber-shot-rx10-iv-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera/6111512?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"This is a professional quality camera with two major benefits not seen in any of its competitor products: 1) it has Sony's best autofocus system and 2) it has the longest zoom range of any camera of this type except for one model from Nikon which is inferior in every respect.

1. Autofocus. You will want to use the 'center lock-on AF' option whenever you have a moving subject. This causes the camera to dynamically focus on your intended object even if it moves in the frame and even if it temporarily moves OUT of the frame and then back in. If you are trying to photograph moving objects (children
column2: animals) this feature is a game-changer. It even works BOTH for movies and still shots. No camera manufacturer has autofocus as good as Sony. This camera can focus in 0.03 seconds without the 'hunting' seen in contrast-detection autofocus systems.

column1: 2. The lens. This lens is nothing short of spectacular. You can get reasonable wide angle shots and stunning telephoto shots without changing lenses. The goal of all photography is to 'get the shot' which is more difficult if you have to fumble to change the lens when you need either a wider or more telephoto shot. You don't need to do that with this camera due to the incredible lens range. This lens is also tack sharp at all focal lengths. To get comparable-quality lenses for an interchangeable lens camera you would have to spend at least $2000 for each of at least 2 lenses!
Some have suggested that the sensor on this camera is too small for low light work. I can tell you I sold a micro 4/3 camera which a sensor about twice as large as the 1 inch sensor in this camera
column2: and this camera takes better pictures
column3: including in low light.

column1: The price is high on this camera; no other camera manufacturer makes a 'point and shoot' camera this expensive
column2: but as in all other areas in life
column3: you get what you pay for. This is the kind of camera one would want to buy and use for literally everything for years.

column1: I couldn't be happier with it."^5^Sep 23

column2: this camera simply puts my old cameras to shame. The light sensor of double that if the Panasonic. I recommend the camera in spite of its flaws

column1: 4REEE^/sony-cyber-shot-rx10-iv-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera/6111512?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"Earlier this year I bought a Sony a6500 camera at Best Buy and it is awesome!!! The one BIG thing that I don't really like about it is having to switch lenses constantly.

ENTER the RX10 IV: I no longer have to switch lenses. The built in zoom lens is *sharp* even at the 600mm end! The phase detection auto focus is fast and accurate just like the advertisement says. And the built in image stabilization works great too.
In regards to recording in 4K
column2: I've had NO problems with overheating
column3: which unfortunately happens with the a6500 every now and then.

column1: The only things that I'd like to see improvement in a future RX10 V would be:
(1) No 4K video at 60fps
(2) I wish it had at least 24MP of resolution
(3) No built in neutral density filters
(4) No way to reprogram the zoom ring to simply do nothing. (I sometimes bump the darn thing every now and then when I'm using the manual focus ring)
(5) Dual memory card slots. Let's face it
column2: some of us will be using this camera in semi critical/critical applications. Having backup memory is important.

column1: grsa^/sony-cyber-shot-rx10-iv-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera/6111512?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I have read a number of reviews and mulled over the decision to get this camera and have not been disappointed(with one exception).  First the good.

My only complaint would be that in HFR mode(slo mo) i can not zoom in and the amount of time it can record is limited.
Good bokeh also.
Overall i am very happy with the purchase."^5^Aug 24

column1: Santosh^/panasonic-lumix-zs100-1-inch-20-1-megapixel-sensor-point-and-shoot-digital-camera-with-leica-dc-10x-lens-black/5001400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^0^"I had researched over a month to find a camera that fits my purpose.

A bit too costly for a point and shoot - more than some of the DSLRs in market. Its auto-focus is nice but slower than competitors (My friend has an RX100 Mark IV). Its packing is cheap for a 650$ product
column2: it doesn't matter since you are not going to use that box anyway. But
column3: you might feel that you got a duplicate product looking at its packaging.

column1: Its 10 X Zoom is stable and thanks to its 1 inch sensor
column2: night shots are very good (nearly the best - but you can use the built in night modes to get a great night picture). The picture quality is standard (do not expect it to be like a DSLR
column3: they have a more controlled focus and bokeh effect). The most important and the the main function is its 4K modes (video
column4: burst shoot) - this is fantastic
column5: especially with the 5-axis image stabilization. The Post Focus is not really what is expected to be. The battery has a fair performance
column6: depending on what is used more - video/still-photos/4k Burst etc.
column7: I did not like the view finder
column8: reason for it being an electronic - but I knew this before I bought it. There is no screen articulation
column9: which I do not need - I am not using it for v-logging or a fan of selfies. I mostly use it for landscape or random still life photography. The camera has a WiFi to mobile communication via app - This is amazing for this generation making your life easier
column10: you can just transfer the pics and even take pictures remotely without touching the camera. If you are looking for a nice travel camera that fits in your palm and which can quickly capture good images
column11: this is best in the line (only rival being Sony Rx series
column12: other do not even match). It has several other features
column13: which I tested and can go on writing about them - that is for you when you buy one. Happy clicking."^5^Nov 20

column1: SriC^/panasonic-lumix-zs100-1-inch-20-1-megapixel-sensor-point-and-shoot-digital-camera-with-leica-dc-10x-lens-black/5001400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^13^0^"large sensor
column2: very good with low light shooting. Note: The RAW files are hard to edit because they are not supported in the standalone version of Lightroom and other installed apps. You need to use Adobe online (9.99 a month).

column1: That said
column2: the JPEG output is sufficient for almost all of the scenarios. It has all the 'advanced' features like HDR shooting
column3: 4K video
column4: etc. See detailed review at dpreview.

column1: About the only con I can think and it has nothing to do with the camera - there is no standard camera case. I had to buy a synergy digital case."^5^Jun 17

Redwing^/panasonic-lumix-zs100-1-inch-20-1-megapixel-sensor-point-and-shoot-digital-camera-with-leica-dc-10x-lens-black/5001400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^13^3^"Overall this is a very impressive camera. It has a nice 10x zoom
column2: and a relatively fast lens at the wide end. There is complete manual control
column3: and more features that even an enthusiast is likely to use. The image quality ranges from acceptable at the telephoto end wide open
column4: to very good at the mid to shorter focal lengths with the lens stopped down a little bit. But the convenience of having a decent length of zoom lens makes it worth the slight trade off in image quality at the longer focal lengths
column5: especially considering the small size of the camera.

column1: But what I am really impressed with is the 4K video quality
column2: both at 24 and 30 frames per second. There are also a number of features and controls you can use while shooting video. And the video quality doesn't seem to suffer at the longer focal lengths like the photo image quality does. Overall
column3: I think a novice to intermediate level photographer will be very satisfied with this camera. Throw in the excellent video
column4: and compact form factor
column5: and this is a definite winner.

column1: I had considered the newer version of this camera
column2: which has an even longer zoom range
column3: but the lens was a little bit slower and I didn't think that would be as useful for the kind of photography I do. Plus I shoot a number of micro four-thirds cameras when I really need top notch stills and or 4k video quality.

column1: From an overall enthusiasts perspective it earns four stars
column2: but for an overall camera for a beginner or intermediate level photographer this is definitely a five-star camera."^4^Jul 8

column1: DhLBBY^/panasonic-lumix-zs100-1-inch-20-1-megapixel-sensor-point-and-shoot-digital-camera-with-leica-dc-10x-lens-black/5001400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^0^"Almost perfect specifically for my use / needs - which is that I wanted a camera that is small
column3: touchscreen
column4: and as a large a sensor size as possible. Note that having a long zoom in this size sacrifices possible aperture for the lens
column5: but I knew this going in. If you need large aperfure (f1.8-f2.8
column6: etc.) then cameras such as RX100 III or IV are available but with significant less zoom."^5^Jul 20

column1: memb^/panasonic-lumix-zs100-1-inch-20-1-megapixel-sensor-point-and-shoot-digital-camera-with-leica-dc-10x-lens-black/5001400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"Dust showed up on sensor quickly without a dusty environment. Returned."^3^Jul 19

TravelPictureTaker^/panasonic-lumix-zs100-1-inch-20-1-megapixel-sensor-point-and-shoot-digital-camera-with-leica-dc-10x-lens-black/5001400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^4^"Just before leaving on a trip
column2: I wanted a camera that was a step up from the inexpensive point and shoot cameras I'd purchased in the past
column3: which frankly
column4: didn't offer much more than a good cell phone camera in terms of quality and features.

column1: This hit the spot. The 20x zoom was used a lot more than I thought
column2: and the larger sensor delivered better low light photos and other benefits. The size was very reasonable considering the zoom capabilities of the camera.

column1: There are an incredible number of features built into this camera. Many more than I could master prior to the trip
column3: One that did come in handy was the 4K snapshot mode
column4: which was perfect for capturing the perfectly timed shot for sporting events.

column1: Pros- large sensor
column3: good zoom range
column4: extensive features. Decent battery life.

column1: Minuses- no built in geo-tagging. No manual focusing
column2: and auto-focusing seemed slow at times- or else I didn't choose the right mode.

column1: Overall
column2: this has exceeded my expectations for a quality travel camera."^4^Jul 2

column1: Redwing^/panasonic-lumix-zs100-1-inch-20-1-megapixel-sensor-point-and-shoot-digital-camera-with-leica-dc-10x-lens-black/5001400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I'll start out with the one bad characteristic
column2: the lens is a little bit soft at certain apertures and focal lengths. However
column3: unless you're pixel peeping
column4: you probably won't notice it. The lens is also a little bit slower than a lot of other 1' cameras
column5: because it has such a long zoom range. Overall I think it is worth the trade-off. It has great manual controls
column6: is fairly straightforward to work with
column7: and the touchscreen is fantastic. This is a great all-in-one camera to take on a trip
column8: if you don't want to bring your larger interchangeable lens camera with you.

column1: Any recent overseas trip
column2: I took an Olympus e-m1 Mark II with several lenses
column3: the Canon g7x enthusiast camera
column4: and this. I took the overwhelming majority of pictures with this camera. In camera raw processing is very nice also.

column1: The overall video features and quality are outstanding on the camera
column2: lots of customization available on the video.

column1: I would actually recommend this camera over the newer version
column2: because although the zoom range is longer on the new version
column3: the lens is a little bit better quality on this one
column4: and the apertures are faster. Plus being an older model it's less expensive.

column1: If you are looking for the ultimate in image quality in a pocketable camera
column2: get the Sony RX100 mk 6. But you'll pay three times more for it."^5^Apr 13

column1: NeighborDave^/panasonic-lumix-zs100-1-inch-20-1-megapixel-sensor-point-and-shoot-digital-camera-with-leica-dc-10x-lens-black/5001400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"The ergonomics of this camera are frustrating...you'll be hitting random buttons prompting messages and questions and different modes when you're just trying to take a picture. column2: you'll think you have everything you want in the pic then the camera arbitrarily cuts off a third of what you took...you'll never know when to stop the picture to get what you want. column3: the camera takes nice quality photos."^3^Oct 21

column1: Drr50^/panasonic-lumix-zs100-1-inch-20-1-megapixel-sensor-point-and-shoot-digital-camera-with-leica-dc-10x-lens-black/5001400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Purchased this LUMIX camera after reviewing other similar cameras. column3: but too heavy to carry around on a daily basis. Finally got tired of inferior mobile phone photos so decided to pick up a bridge camera that can fit in my pocket and produces decent quality images. Researched the current line of advanced point & shoots and settled on the ZS100 because image quality appears comparable to the others and it has a 10x zoom
column4: which makes it more versatile.

column1: Obviously image quality of a 1' sensor is not up to full frame standards
column2: but I've found it much better than my mobile phone and unless I pixel peep
column3: can produce images that are very acceptable.

column1: The biggest benefit I've found is that it has expanded my ability to be creative and capture images that I wouldn't have taken before. Generally I use a tripod with my DSLR
column2: which takes time to set up. The ZS100 allows me to shoot quickly and hand-hold shots from various angles with surprisingly good results.

column1: The only negative I feel is the difficulty in controlling ISO
column2: aperture and shutter speed. Maybe its just a matter of getting used to the controls
column3: but I would have preferred separate controls like what's offered with the LX100. I was very tempted to get the LX100 except for the slightly larger size and limited zoom range.

column1: All in all
column2: I'm pleased with the ZS100 and look forward to using it as my casual go-to camera."^4^May 5

I also have a Sony 100 and this camera does not have as good low light than that

column1: If you can afford both cameras you are set. For a quality camera with solid results in most conditions and a good zoom lenses it's worth the price.

column1: TIGER7388^/panasonic-lumix-zs100-1-inch-20-1-megapixel-sensor-point-and-shoot-digital-camera-with-leica-dc-10x-lens-black/5001400?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^20^"A compact camera that takes pictures. I still can not figure out how to send my pictures taken so I can send by email to friends pictures taken by the ZS100! column1: LowerEastSider^/canon-powershot-sx620-hs-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/5298501?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^57^3^"I looked at much more expensive cameras but settled on this one because it generally had good reviews and was just small enough to fit into a pocket.
I did not want to spend a lot of money on something that could get damaged
The picture quality is above average without a lot of graininess or artifacts. Even when zoomed-in to a reasonable level on a large screen monitor
column2: most photos look very detailed. And
column3: the colors are quite pleasing and natural looking.

column1: It is best at taking still photos. That being said
column2: when I set the camera in burst mode
column3: I was able to get some decent shots at a recent bike race. But there are better cameras with faster lenses if you plan on taking a lot of action shots.

column1: The 'P' mode offers some controls for things like exposure level and white balance. But this is a camera designed primarily for automatic use. There is no function dial
column2: so you must go into the menus to make changes to the settings.

column1: The camera does a better than average job of taking good photos using the auto mode. And
column3: it still operates mostly automatically.

column1: The 25X zoom range is certainly more than adequate for most users.
This is not one of those cameras that amazes you with it's shot to shot speed. But for most people it is more than adequate.
You will not feel like you have a 'brick' in your pocket or purse with this camera. It is quite lightweight and not too long or wide. The next most expensive Cannon model offers better performance
column2: but it is (in my opinion) simply too large and heavy to tuck in a pocket.

column1: I bought a small canvas case that I hook to my belt. This keeps the camera protected and it is always ready for use.
This camera is a good value for someone who is not a 'camera person' but wants pleasing
column2: lifelike photos. You could spend additional money and get more features
column3: but not necessarily better quality photos."^4^Jul 2

I would give 5 stars except the wifi connection does not work with Apple computers. Its very frustrating because now I have to go find a cable that will work with the camera and my Mac."^4^Apr 22
MarkRC^/canon-powershot-sx620-hs-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/5298501?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^34^5^"This was a good upgrade from my Canon Elph 300. This one is a bit bigger

column4: you have to download the App to make it work."^5^Aug 20

column1: BattyFoto^/canon-powershot-sx620-hs-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/5298501?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^26^8^"First let me say this. This camera is nice and good for this price range
column2: which is why it has 4 stars and I would recommend it....

column1: If you can get past the following points...
**Please note though
column2: the whole purpose of this purchase was for a higher megapixel camera that could give me crisp macro (close up) photos of my artwork.

column1: That being said
1. This camera is tiny! Think almost flip phone size
column2: which makes it very awkward and hard to grip right with average adult hands.

column1: 2. Very impressive zoom photos. I used it to take exterior detail photos for an insurance claim. When I took 2nd floor photos of the details around windows
column2: you would have thought they were first floor! So it did what I needed it to there.

column1: 3. No cords come with it. You take the battery out to charge it using a plug in adapter.
4. I ended up not being able to get it to connect to my laptop at all
column2: so I just took the memory card out each time. This was a let down.

column1: 5. Cannon menus are a bit confusing to me. My son has a T5
column2: which I tried to use a few times before and couldn't get the hang of things. Beginners be careful and really read the manual and try how to videos online.

column1: 6. There's a clicking noise it makes. It's the small metal pieces making up the lense protector. So when it's closed/off
column2: for some reason mine made noises when I moved it around. Just an annoyance.

column1: 7. Okay here's the main reason I took it back. The closer shots were not as impressive as I expected per the many reviews saying it's good for that. I'm sure it's better than average though. However
column3: I need really detailed photos of my artwork to be able to make prints of good quality. This did not deliver. Now
column4: I might have been expecting way too much for a $200 range camera
column5: but I was just going by other's opinions.

column1: So there ya go. This is just MY humble opinion also lol.
I would call myself a hobbiest photographer. Not an expert
Thank you!"^4^Aug 9

column1: One difference is my old one had view finder to look through and a screen - this one only has a screen. I keep forgetting - annoying! Another difference is the pop-up flash. column1: Barb^/canon-powershot-sx620-hs-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/5298501?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^3^"I still have not been able to connect the camera to my Mac. The directions are extremely difficult to understand. Very frustrating!!

Howie^/canon-powershot-sx620-hs-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/5298501?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^28^32^"I bought this to replace an older like model. What a disappointment. If this is suppose to be an improved model
To power the camera up
column2: you have to try and push the little power button on top. I had to use my finger nail to push the recessed button down.

column1: They eliminated the auto flash like the older model had. So if you are taking pictures and the sensors decide you need a flash
column3: twist the camera sideways to find the little slide button then you raise the flash by using your fingernail to push the tiny little recessed button on the left side.to pop the flash up. Then you go back to your shot.

column1: The other buttons on the screen side are close together and recessed. You have to be right on to push them or you will push the wrong one. The dial around the Func set button is small and when you attempt to push on the outside ring
column2: there's a good chance you will also hit the func set button that you didn't want to push. There are 4 buttons around that dial that are also recessed and close together. Not easy to use.

column1: The door on the right side which you open to get to the HDMI cable hook ups is held by two little plastic strips which I have a feeling would not last that long.
Very dissatisfied with this camera and will return it to BB. I will not spend this amount of money on what appears to be a cheaply made product and without much thought in designing it."^1^May 12

iAppleNovice^/canon-powershot-sx620-hs-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/5298501?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^13^"I was told by the BB sales rep that all the cameras come with a USB cable to transfer photos. Well
column2: this camera does not. I ordered one on Amazon for $5. How am I suppose to transfer photos if I am at someone's home or a location when wifi or removing the memory card is not an option? You will need the cable.

column1: The free memory card is to small to be practical. The SanDisk Extreme PRO 128GB SDXC is not stocked at the BB store. Available for half the price at Amazon. That is the best card for this camera. (the micro card is to slow). BB would not give credit toward a better memory card. The free card is a wasted product.
Finally
So
column2: after you buy this camera you need a transfer cable
column3: better memory card and travel/purse case. I would not give this as a gift because it is not a complete package. More a fault of Canon than BB. What's next? Charging extra for a battery charger?

column1: I don't like the pop-up flash. That is obsolescence engineered into the camera.
It is an expensive camera and yes
column2: it does take fantastic pictures after a lot of practice. You must practice before that special event."^4^Jun 24

column1: SammieJo^/canon-powershot-g9-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5715504?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^1^"Finally! A point and shoot camera that is halfway comparable to a DSLR. column1: joshuaafterdark^/canon-powershot-g9-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5715504?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^4^"I picked this camera up about a month ago as a complement to my main camera
column2: the EOS M6. I wanted a genuinely pocket-sized camera that could pack a punch
column3: and boy does this little thing rise to occasion.

column1: I knew it would have stellar photo quality because it uses
column3: the same sensor as the G7x and G5x series
column4: which are incredible advanced compacts. What I didn't expect was just how small the G9x Mk II was going to be when I took it out of the box... This thing is TINY. And for the past month the photos and videos I've taken with it have pretty evenly matched those from the G7x and G5x I've used in the past.

column1: There are 2 (minor) downsides to the G9x though. The first being the lack of a flip or articulating display. And the second is the fact that you cannot record in 60fps when in auto mode
column2: you actually have to switch the dial to movie mode and set 60p as your desired recording frame rate.

column1: At full price ($529) the camera is a bit overreaching. But at it's now pretty common $429 price it's a no-brainer to add to your camera arsenal."^5^Jun 2

Priusguy^/canon-powershot-g9-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5715504?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"I'm impressed by the image quality of this pocketable little camera. I bought this as a present for my wife
column2: who uses it in AUTO for the most part. She is very happy with it
column3: her only complaint is that the lcd screen can be hard to see in bright sunlight. She didn't try to increase the screen brightness to the max
column4: so that may help on her next outing. If you are an enthusiast
column5: you will have no trouble figuring out all the options and settings. If you just want to point and shoot
column6: that will be fine too."^4^Jun 2

column1: InlandPNWShooter^/canon-powershot-g9-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5715504?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"This camera is currently available for $399 USD
column2: which makes it hands down the best value in compact cameras right now. Sometimes I don't want to pack along my bigger Fuji system with multiple lenses
column3: so I just bring this along instead. It doesn't disappoint. JPEG images look great straight out of the camera. Or
column4: if you don't mind getting your hands dirty and messing with a RAW file
column5: you've got that option as well. Take some time to dig through the menus to see what options are available to you. The in-camera HDR processor is surprisingly effective. I also use the time lapse video feature as well. Images are reasonably sharp
column6: probably more than I would expect in a camera like this. And certainly more than sharp enough for web use.

column1: Physically
column2: it's small and somewhat weighty due to its metal construction. It just feels sturdy.  Power up is quick; just the amount of time it takes for the lens to extend out of its housing. I've used the Canon phone app to transfer photos to my Android device
column3: and it works like a champ.

column1: Just know what this camera is good for. You'll get nice shots of your kids indoor birthday party
column2: but probably not of their indoor sports. You don't get much reach with the lens
column3: so you might want to move up to the G7XmkII if you need longer zoom. I'm finding that it's great for travel/nature/landscape work
column4: and an occasional street scene that I might come across.

column1: If you just choose this as your only stand-alone camera
column2: I think you're making a good choice. Take some time to learn it and to understand what it can and can't do
column3: and you should get years of great images."^5^Jun 26

ZeroStarsIfICould^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-dragonfruit/6367051?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^34^9^"In no scenario does this camera take a single clear photo without SIGNIFICANT grain and slight blur. The shake in videos is jarring. This camera is comparable to something that would have been released in the very early 2000's. I purchased this for the carefree simplicity for on the go fun however it's literally unusable if you have any desire to enjoy your memories. I'd recommend purchasing the HTC re from 2014 even though it's five years old and most likely difficult to find. Do some research and you'll see that the re far surpasses the IVY REC which is mind-blowingly shocking as it's 2019 and we're talking about a camera from Canon. Do your research
column2: this is a 100% unbiased review (I've never previously reviewed a product) but I've been so burned by this I just had to air my disbelief. I guarantee this will be pulled from shelves or never to be seen again after these initial units are severely discounted and sold."^1^Oct 21

column3: I found it difficult to use. I am in my 50s....I am sort-of tech savvy
column4: but really have a hard time turning the dials to select what I want to do on the camera (my son..did not have this problem) Additionally

column8: but

column10: in exchange for receiving the product for free."^3^Dec 14

JosieN101^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-dragonfruit/6367051?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^2^"I received a free sample in exchange for agreeing to write a review. The IVY REC Outdoor Camera (Riptide) is so cute and can easily clip on your backpack
column2: purse or even your belt buckle. The only thing I didnt like Is trying to set up the camera it wasnt an easy process but once I figured it out and set up it works so well! The videos and photos come out so clear and crisp which easily saves on my phone. Overall
column3: I loved the camera and would recommend it to anyone looking for an outdoor camera with many features including being waterproof that wont break the bank and small enough to take anywhere!"^4^Dec 6

column1: Lars^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-dragonfruit/6367051?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^3^"Great item - was unable to try or test it out because it was damaged upon arrival."^1^Dec 6

KLC7^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-dragonfruit/6367051?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^3^"I received this free IVY REC Outdoor Camera (Riptide) to review. I found it to be a great little camera
column2: unbelievably small for all that it can do! I was able to take clear crisp photos as good if not better than my smartphone camera.

column1: What I also found surprising was even though it is advertised as an outdoor camera
column2: it takes great pictures indoors too. There is no flash feature for indoors
column3: but as long as there is light in the room
column4: pictures come out great.

column1: The video option is doable. Not necessarily the best but it does what it says and for those moments when a short video is needed
column2: it is fine. I like the fact that it can all be downloaded to your phone or computer later.

column1: I think this little camera is marketed for younger people for it's usability to travel and rugged exterior. I took photos in the rain without worry. If dropped
column2: it can withstand the pressure. The camera itself has an attachable clip which makes it easy to carry; I clipped mine on my purse strap.

column1: The only drawback I personally had with the camera is trying to open the little door for inserting the  MicroSD card and the cord for the USB port to download and charge. My husband had no problem opening it but I simply couldn't manage it. Perhaps not the best feature if you are older
column2: have arthritis or other issues with strength.

column1: I would recommend this product especially for children when they want a camera of their own but might drop an expensive smartphone when taking a picture."^4^Dec 3

Bev31^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-dragonfruit/6367051?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^3^"I received this camera fot free in exchange for a review. I like the simplicity of the design overall to make it more 'point and shoot.' The wheel on the back to choose the shooting mode is very easy to use
column2: but does require using a fingernail or something similar so I don't believe it could be turned on by accident. There is no option to review pictures
column3: or to really see the picture before you take it
column4: so how good the picture turns out is based either on luck or by practice. The clip is very nice
column5: and allows the camera to easily be attached to a belt loop for easy access. The accompanying app requires little set up
column6: but after that is pretty easy to use. The app let's you see the photos or videos you've taken and then download them to use elsewhere. I don't appreciate that the app is mandatory in order to have full use of the camera
column7: but I understand that it is part of streamlining the experience so I accept it. Overall it is a nice simple camera for on the go
column8: and it would be nice for people who just want to be able to take quick pictures but aren't worried about professional quality."^4^Dec 3

column1: dranreb^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/4866811?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^28^2^"This camera is small and lightweight. It easily fits in a pants pocket or purse (even a very small purse). I was very happy with how easy it was to carry around and use when traveling. I wish it came with a case though. The large
column2: bright screen makes it easy to compose pictures. Anyone familiar with the Canon Rebel series would find the menus on this camera similar and easy to use. The camera gives you a lot of control in manual settings
column3: but I also found the AUTO mode to be quite effective for most of my needs. I am very impressed with the photo quality
column4: especially the accuracy of colors
column5: like a blue sky. (I have seen other cameras 'wash out' a blue sky but not this camera.) The camera also does an excellent job in scenes with high contrast. The photos come out great and require little or no editing. Battery life is excellent and I like that the charger does not have a cord. One less cord to drag around. The charger's prongs fold up
column6: too
column7: so it is very portable.

column1: One minor complaint is that I wish the lens had a wider angle in order to take more impressive landscape photos. Another complaint
column2: which causes me to knock one star off the rating
column3: is that the wifi is very clunky. It requires you to download an app onto your computer and sign up for a Canon image service. I would have expected to only need to download an app. Not create some kind of account. The wifi is a useless feature to me and I am happy to continue putting the SD card into my computer or printer slot.

column1: Overall this was a great purchase and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a very portable little camera that has a good zoom and takes great pictures. It is good for travel because it does a great job in a variety of shots
column2: whether you are taking landscape photos
column3: close-ups
column4: or photos of people. I brought this camera along on a trip where I also used my iPhone 6s for some pictures. The Canon ELPH 360 took better pictures
column5: hands-down."^4^Feb 28

column1: AntiAR^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/4866811?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^22^2^"Nice camera. I have a big Nikon
column2: and a waterproof Nikon. Was not at all happy with the waterproof Nikon as the photos were never crystal clear. I like to take a small camera with me on walks as you never know when a photo opp might arise. This camera fits my needs and I had Best Buy gift certificates to use. Used the movie function once
column3: in an auditorium and it turned out good. Negatives - doesn't come with a usb cable for downloads and the battery doesn't last as long as the ones with my Nikons."^4^May 27

column1: Geekmaster92^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/4866811?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^16^1^"Great product! Smartphone cameras are catching up in quality BUT Point-and-Shoot cameras are still better because they have a physical zoom lens.
This camera has great photo quality
column2: burst mode at about 7 shots a second
column3: good low-light images
column4: decent battery life(Make sure you have at least 2 spare batteries if you're going to be taking photos all day. And it's small and slim which it will easily fit in a pocket or in a small case with spare batteries attached to a belt loop.

column1: Overall
column2: a great compact camera. I definitely recommend the ELPH 360 HS over the ELPH 180 or 190 BECAUSE of the HS system
column3: image stabilization(Especially when recording video) It's definitely worth the extra $40 or so. Canon has definitely dominated this market for years and will likely continue to do so for years to come."^5^Nov 22

TallBill^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/4866811?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^2^"I previously had a PowerShot SX120
column2: and this camera (PowerShot ELPH 360 HS) has all of the same features and much more. It does lack a true manual mode
column3: however (allowing the user to set shutter speed and aperture manually). The control buttons on the back are flush with the case
column4: making the camera somewhat difficult to use in very dim light conditions. As with all point-and-shoot cameras that have no viewfinder
column5: the display will be hard to see in direct sunlight. It has a lens cover that opens and closes automatically
column6: which prevents losing a separate lens cap. The camera has connectors on the right side for USB AV out and HDMI interfaces
column7: but they are covered by a cheap plastic cover that is difficult to get open until you file off the catches a little bit. The Li-Ion battery is small (only 800 mAh)
column8: and I have not yet determined exactly how long it will last (the manual claims 180 pix). I have only used the USB port to transfer pictures directly to my computer without going through an online service. I have not tried setting up the Wi-Fi interface yet to see if it would be easier to use. This camera has both High Speed Burst mode (about 7.2 pix per second) that will group the pictures and Continuous Shooting Drive Mode
column9: which allows pictures to be taken continuously while the shutter button is held depressed (about 2.5 pix per second; pictures are NOT grouped)."^5^Jul 31

column1: LoneBiker^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/4866811?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I have several PowerShot SX's and I like them. But I've been cycling a lot lately and I wanted something smaller and lighter. I didn't expect to find it to have almost twice the Megapixels as my last SX so that was a pleasant surprise. If you're use to using PowerShot then the User Interface is about the same thing. Design choices come down to compromises. I would have preferred a screen that tilts up but I like getting so much picture taking power in something smaller than my hand with a good image stabilizer capability. I really like being able to carry this little guy around my neck or tucked into a little gadget bag on the bike. I haven't considered mounting it on the bike because I think that the vibrations may be a little harsh for it. I like to stop to take a drink and shoot a few pictures and then attach the images to my ride maps on MyMaps."^5^Nov 13
DeeDee^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/4866811?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I love taking pictures and had a Canon 300 for my point and shoot camera

column1: And really liked the Canon 300 better. It was much easier to use and when you would take pictures on the VIVID they didn't look FAKE. Today I went taking pictures of the changing of the leaves and Used the vivid and also the regular. The Vivid looks so fake. I was disappointed because I had to delete over 1/2 my pictures. However
This camera dose take good CLEAR pictures. I am sharing 2 pictures. One of the regular setting and one on Vivid."^3^Oct 19
Harry^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/4866811?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^14^"I purchased this wonderful camera on February 15
column2: 2019. I downloaded the required software and then spent about 3 hours trying to get the Camera connected to my computer. I then went on-line and downloaded the 157 page used guide but the chapter for connecting to a computer was for Windows 7 users. Canon customer service told me that the Camera worked perfectly on windows 7 but there are problems with windows 10. They blamed the problem on windows 10 but their camera was 'perfect'. The person asked me to make a number of changes (adjustments) to my computer so that the camera could upload pictures. I had no idea what I was doing but I was told that my adjustments would not hurt my computer or prevent any other software from operating correctly. The Camera still didn't work after about an hour of discussions and making computer changes. I was told that I could use a USB cable but I could still use Wi-Fi. I was told that sometimes it takes about 50 or more tries to connect the camera to a computer that uses windows 10. Each try takes about 5 minutes. Forget it. I returned the Camera on February 18th.

column1: I question Canon's comment that the Camera works perfectly on windows 7 - you can't even purchase a computer that uses windows 7. Why does Cannon continue to sell this? Why don't they pull it from the shelves. And why doesn't Best Buy
column3: and other vendors inform their customers that Wi-Fi only works on Windows 7. What a colossal waste of time."^1^Feb 19

column1: Silver^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/4866811?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"The Canon ELPH 360 digital camera is convenient to carry

gira^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/4866811?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^32^"This camera has nowhere to plug in a USB cable. So you can't move the photos onto your computer with a USB cord. You have to use wifi to do it wirelessly with the faulty
column2: unreliable Canon software to get your photos off of this camera. And you need to register with Canon and fumble through a clumsy installation process before you can do that. That also requires that you have wifi available to you when you want to do the transfer - not just to install the software but also every time you move photos from your camera to a computer. I guess many people don't care
column3: but that can be problematic depending on where you're traveling
column4: and at home I'm wondering if it adds to data consumption. And the software for transferring the photos doesn't even work right
column5: so I'll probably end up pulling out the SD card and using a card reader instead to transfer the photos. This is frustrating because the camera otherwise is pretty good. It's friendly to use
column6: with the necessary features. It's a decent cheap point-and-shoot. I just really don't like this nonsense about not having a port to plug a cable into. That's a deal breaker
column7: the way I see it. I can't imagine how many pennies they shaved off the price by leaving off such a basic component."^2^Jan 8

column6: feeling free

column10: will depend on when to change from Manual to Superior Auto. I used this camera on a religious event and I was able to catch from one side of the coliseum to the other side of the coliseum (about a 100 feets) with good quality

column20: Internet
column22: also print to a big 8 x 11 without loosing quality. Great camera!"^5^Dec 16

column1: burque5^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^1^"This is my second point and shoot from Sony in the past 8 years. The ease of use in automatic mode is matched with the great results in quality and sharpness. The camera performed great
column2: especially capturing my kids that never seem to stand still. The only flaw is the lens cover does not come with a lanyard
column3: so keeping track of it was a constant concern. The battery lasted for three days of picture taking. You need to purchase an extra battery and standalone charger. The camera only comes with one battery and must be plugged into the wall to charge via USB. If not for the battery issue I would have gave it 5 stars."^4^May 14

column1: DHPatrick^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^6^"This camera is capable of pulling long distance photos up close. Other reviews have said it is not a night camera - they are incorrect. It takes great low level shot. After it takes a low light shot
column2: you can watch it adjust the shot to a clearer photo. It is not a pocket camera
column3: but with hand strap it is easily carried without fear of dropping it. It has the best lens stabilizer I've seen
column4: but the longer the shot
column5: the greater care you have to use to get a clearer shot. I haven't tried a 256 GB SD card
column6: but it easily addresses a 128 GB card. There is not normally a big delay between the press of the shutter button and the camera being ready for the next shot. Best yet it has a Carl Zeiss lens. It is not an all weather camera - take care in inclement weather and in dusty environments. Love this camera."^5^Dec 11

column1: wrs33^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"I purchased this camera in August of 2015. I have taken lots of pics and vids and everything worked as expected. pic quality not the best
column2: but decent considering the sensor size. light is your friend. setting the pixels to 5M also helps the sensor. Within the past 6 weeks an error code (e:62:10) started to display. I tired the work arounds found on the internet and that worked for about 1 month. Now I am finding that I will have to spend ~200$ to replace the lens
column3: which is ~1/2 the price of the camera after 3 years and 1 month of use. I really like this camera and I imagine that when I look for a replacement the best option will still be this model. Hopefully this issue has been resolved. I want to stress that this camera has never been handled poorly. When I cannot clear the code you can see the lack of image stabilization in the view finder and in the pic. If I had written this review before this error occurred it would have been 5 stars. I am really disappointed that this happened after 3 years. Maybe Sony will help me out."^1^Oct 23

column1: Dillman^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^13^5^"The camera takes superior pictures in daylight/bright light but the low light is extremely poor. I have a DHC-HX200 and it is superior in low light using the same settings. The DHC-HX200v can capture a illuminated museum display with great accuracy. Nice black background and crystal clear foreground. The HCX400 has a gray background with a huge blob of out of focus light for the foreground. Absolute terrible in side by side photographs between the HX200v and the HX400v. The worse thing about the HX400 is the memory card slot. When I change batteries
column2: opening the batter cover partially ejects the SD card. I took over 100 irreplaceable pictures with the HX 400 with no error showing. After the last it shows a ' No card' error came up. Upon investigation it seems when you press down to close the battery compartment it ejects the card. There is no warning but the pictures are not saved. I could see the pictures when I shot them and after 'Processing' it went to the next picture but the pictures were not there at the end. I reseated the card and carefully closed the door. The next picture I took was saved with the next sequence number meaning the 100+ shots I took were gone with no trace of the files. I ran a card recovery software and there was no data on the card for the missing pictures. I lost a lot of memories with no way to recover and no error indication. My memory card works great in my HX200v. The 400v has incredible issues."^3^Sep 26

column1: usmmaka^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"I had been researching cameras for over a year and finally decided to purchase the SONY DSC HX400. column1: aarondr^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"Coming from a DSLR

column5: this camera delivers. Zooming to the maximum optical zoom - it's quite easy to take a steady shot. The stabilization technology is amazing. The sensor that turns on the view finder and turns off the screen is handy. That's another important point of this camera: It has a view finder. This may seem antiquated
column6: but if you're making a decision to move away from a DSLR
column7: it's a must - as it allows you to effectively frame your shot while steadying the camera (IS can only do so much) and is a must outside in the bright sunlight (as it's hard to see even the brightest LCDs). This is a great camera!!"^5^Oct 5

column1: SonyE6210^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"The DSC-HX400V is a bridge unit very versatile

column5: making it impossible to take sharp pictures. Thousands of users on the Internet have the same problem
column6: see for example http://sony-e-62-10.tk/ or look for E:62:10 on the Internet. If I had known I would never have bought this model. For me it is a hidden defect or a problem of obsolescence programmed which Sony refuses to follow up despite the many complaints."^1^Nov 24

column1: NCTS95^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"After having a DSLR for the last 9 years

I've even been 25 or 30 feet from the camera and remained connected. It will be great for taking family pictures. Still learning features and what all I can do with it but that's going to be half the fun."^5^Jan 30

column1: Seagull5^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"I have come to the decision that for the money a bridge camera will give you the best all around camera for the money you invest. I own three now and each one has its advantages. The HX400 is a solid feature laden camera. The glass used in the lens is top notch. The focus is quick so any sports or Birding shots are not lost. As far as low light photos go being it has a small sensor it can struggle to find focus.

My other cameras are a Fuji S1. Another bridge with one big plus. A Weather resistant 24 to 1200 mm which is great for Florida. Also has a hard time in low light. The last and a great all around piece of equiptment is the Lumix FZ200...very bright F28 lens which will keep the F28 up to 600mm.
The HX400 is a very good camera....I had to buy a second one as I sold the first one and missed having a really good fun camera. Enjoy"^4^Dec 29
milo^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"This is a phenomenal camera for the price.

I bought this as a second camera for my wife to use while on safari. She's kryptonite to anything technology if it can break or stop working she will find a way to make it happen. With this camera however
column2: she ended up taking some amazing photos on our trip of fast moving animals at distances I couldn't believe. The videos turned out even better.

column1: Reasons to buy:
-This a great does-it-all camera: Enough megapixels to take photos for large print
column2: good enough glass to make them clear and more

column1: -The 50x (1600mm equivalent) zoom takes great photos at long distances with the right lighting - my wife got photos of monkeys at 500 yards that my 200mm/F2.8 would never be able to. The clarity was phenomenal and some will be on our wall
-The video quality is outstanding and the slow zoom makes for great landscape shots that zoom in on objects far away
-GPS- We were deep in the African bush and when I synced our photos all of them were geotagged
-Wifi - Using the playmemories app on Android or iPhone
column2: you can control the camera and take photos or send your best ones to your phone from the camera for sharing online

column1: -If you are already bought into Sony's camera line: this takes the same batteries and has the same menus as many others
-Viewfinder is good enough
column2: it gets the job done. For better long distance shots
column3: this is a must and is why the cheaper long zoom cameras without an EVF are just about useless

column1: -Build quality is really good. The camera is also super light"^5^Sep 4
deGenius^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^1^"I cannot take good pictures but this camera helps me to be a better photographer.

The 50x zoon is great. I took a picture of the moon FREE HAND. it turns out pretty good. The camera took several pictures of the moon and re-compose them into one which I call it cheating. The craters are visible without magnifying much on my laptop. The other pictures are sharp and exposed just right.

The Firework program is not that great. Maybe I don't know the camera well enough. I did not have any pictures to bragg about. The night portrait program works well. it cuts down the blue tint from the sky to virtually nothing. The colors are true.
The battery ran out on me once. I am considering to buy a spare.
It will be great if Sony or Best Buy can make some small pouches which can be attached to the strap to carry small items like spare lenses and USB cables."^5^Aug 21

Elaine^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"I have been using Canon products for more than 10 years. My most recent Canon was a 7D MarkII with a Sigma zoom lens. My favorite subjects besides my grandchildren are birds
