Long story short...I had invested A LOT of money and my shots were mediocre. First day out with this Sony point and shoot I captured pin-sharp photos of birds like I never had with the Canon products. Without a doubt this Sony point and shoot is a dream to handle. FYI...recovery between shots is slower than the Canon
column3: and low-light is an issue. However
column4: the Sony brings a more consistent and pleasant result with each photo shoot!"^5^Mar 10

column1: Xenardr^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"I needed a camera that took still and photos in motion with high clarity. The 50X zoom is the greatest thing ever. I'm still learning everything it does and each time I find something else it just amazes me. This camera gives you all the fantastic features of a DSLR camera without having to buy extra lenses....although I recently found out that you can get other lenses for this camera. It's simple to use
column2: and with a point and zoom and shoot you can get those amazing photos that you see everyone with a high tech camera get without major cost and without trying to change lenses. I bought an extra battery and a 64 Gig card and went on vacation.....using it several days taking video and photos and never used all the space on the card. The only thing I wasn't happy with was it could have used a better How To guide. I would have loved to have a guide that showed every single thing that the camera could do on different settings. Would have made learning all of it a bit easier but overall....this camera is fantastic and I recommend it if you want fantastic photos without a DSLR cost."^5^Aug 26

column1: Brillo^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I dislike the poor photo quality and limited feature set of smart-phone and point-and-shoot cameras and constantly feel that I am giving up too much for the pleasure of easy portability. column1: Raymond^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I am upgrading from the DSC-H5 to the DSC-HX400.
I will start by pointing out that the camera does everything Sony says it will do. Specifically useful to me are
- image stabilization (clear pictures at full zoom)
- good clarity in low light
- good automatic composition (auto mode and super auto mode)
- battery life is much better than the H5
The HX400 behaves like a higher end DSLR.
A couple of things I don't like:
- the HX400 is bigger and heavier than the H5
- pop-up flash is not auto-pop-up even on force flash setting.

The biggest beef with this camera compared to the H5 is the fish-eye starting point of the zoom lens. The H5 started out at 36mm equivalent which was fine for taking group photos - low distortion if any on the edges. The HX400 starts at 28mm equivalent which really stretches the faces of anyone outside the central ~2/3 of the composition. Zooming in to 1.5X fixes the issue but kills the spontaneity.
Hey Sony
column2: can we get a setting to wake the camera up to a certain zoom level (but everything else stays automatic)?

column1: In general a great camera that takes some getting used to."^4^Aug 31

PebblesCO^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I have been using a friends camera (the 300 model) for a few years and loved it. While at tournaments (only time I've used it so far)
column2: my friend noticed that it was slow to take pictures. There seemed to be an unusually long lag time between taking one picture and the camera being ready to snap the next photo. This is using the automatic feature. When I took it for USA Games tournament
column3: I got to use it for the first time. I noticed that when taking distance photos
column4: it struggled to focus (the 300 model did an OUTSTANDING job with focus). Then
column5: when I got where it would take the telephoto shot
column6: it wouldn't focus for the next shots
column7: etc. I found the only way to get it to focus again was to power off the camera and turn it back on. I missed a number of precious photos of my athletes receiving their awards or performing in their events because of this focus problem. Taking camera back in case it is a lemon. Since the 300 model didn't have any issues
column8: it is surprising that the 400 and newer model would have these difficulties.

column1: Love the adjustable back viewing screen -- one of the major selling points for this camera. I had been also looking at the Canon T5i or Nikon 5300
column3: but neither got near by budget of $500 -- even for Black Friday sales (only the T6 model hit $500
column4: but doesn't have adjustable screen). I recommend getting a camera with the adjustable back viewer. It is so handy when you need to take pictures over other peoples's heads or down low -- like when taking pics of little kids.

column1: I'm hoping the focus issue can be corrected. I loved the quality of photos from the 300 model and was hoping for similar performance with the newer model. The 300 model took excellent distance photos
column2: that when you zoomed in on the computer
column3: didn't become pixelated and made it seem like you were a lot closer. I take sporting photos and often take photos from across football fields. The quality of zoom made that 100+ yard distance look like the photo was taken less than 10 yards away."^4^Aug 12

column1: wannabephotographer^/sony-dsc-hx400-20-4-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4384007?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^4^"Sony Cybershot DSC-HX400V REVIEW
I just purchased this Sony 7-16-2018. I had read about the great zooming
column2: It Is truly amazing! I mean amazing! But no one really talked about macro much. I have a little Canon Power shot SX710HS that takes the best macro pics and 30x zoom but I wanted more
column3: so I bought a friends used Nikon P600
column4: the zoom is great
column5: and I got good photos on sunny days but the barrel started to stick
column6: plus macro wasn't as good as my Canon. So I got this Sony 400
column7: I took this Sony out of the box and used Auto for all the flower pics in bright sun on the river bend and for the most part they were all great
column8: but I couldn't get focused up close on some of them. I don't know what ISO 200
column10: Aperture etc means
column11: when do I use those settings? I need to learn that stuff
column12: So I used auto. One problem I had with this Sony
column13: as soon as you turn the camera on
column14: it wants you to set the date
column15: I'm not sure if it's just me but it won't set and stay so I have to hit cancel everytime I turn the camera on. When I press cancel
column16: it goes to a screen 'go to www.sony.net/pm for playmemories software'. So I have to press two things before I can even begin to photograph. So let's get to MACRO
column17: my Canon I can zoom to a bee on a flower and see pollen on it's legs and it is in focus. I can take a photo of just the bee
column18: I've tried and tried to get that close on this camera but it loses focus each time. I got ants on a leaf (see photo) but it won't let me zoom into the ant. I turned the ring on the camera and it would show me the ants up close on the monitor but then it didn't capture the photo that way. Today was partly cloudy
column19: I got great photos of a squirrel in the tree but not of birds on a feeder. I took from across the yard to behind a tree 4 feet away from the feeders. Being in the correct setting would've helped I'm sure. Not having a portable charger I thought would be no big deal
column20: well it is! Having to plug the entire camera into the wall outlet especially with such a short charger cord is ridiculous and takes a lot longer than a portable charger. I will have to see if there's a charger I can buy and get an extra battery. If there is I suggest you buy one also. The Nikon 600 you can edit photos right on the camera
column21: I haven't found that on this Sony yet. Oh the volume for the shutter
column22: The Sony 400 kept showing function is disabled when trying to turn the shutter sound down. I did an online chat with Sony and he kept saying to record a video and I could then change the volume
column23: it took 20 min for him to understand I just wanted to change the shutter volume
column24: he finally said there's not a volume
column25: it's either on or off. Ok so ISweep Panorama onscreen instructions say move the camera left or right or up/down. I kept trying the up and and it didn't work. First you have to go to menu
column26: to the camera icon and scroll down to Panorama direction and set the way you want . Now on to Handheld Twilight setting
column27: it's better than what I expected from reviews. I wish I could post more than 2 photos here to show you. Haven't tried night photos yet. And lastly
column28: don't do what I did by just going to auto and start taking photos because there is actually a wonderful camera guide in the camera (that I just now found) that tells you tips and what setting to use for different lighting and where to find the setting in the controls. So turn the camera on
column30: press the ? button on the bottom right side and then menu and the onscreen help comes up. There's apparently a lot packed in this camera but it will take a beginner like me awhile to learn it. But my suggestion is go for it! 4 stars only because it's my 2nd day to use it and had problems with not getting the up close like I wanted. Maybe the instructions will help me with that now that I know they are there in the camera"^4^Jul 17

RBNO^/fujifilm-x-series-x100f-24-3-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/5760801?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^12^25^"This is an interesting camera for street photography and portrait photography
column2: especially when the lighting is low. It provides excellent color.

column1: However
column2: it is not a camera for nature photography as the colors need to be adjusted all the time
column3: most likely because they are optimized for portrait.

column1: A major annoyance is the number of buttons. There are too many. They all can be customized
column3: but you need to remember what is doing what
column4: and then you discover that if you use some options
column5: your initial choice you made no longer works. For example
column6: if you choose Raw
column7: the option to use the focusing ring to zoom digitally (which is an interesting option) does not work. But it takes time to find that this is why the digital zoom does not work!

column1: Another major shortcoming is that it is too easy to hit a button
column3: which then had to be cancelled. This is especially the case of the quick menu button which one hits all the time. I guess that overtime one would get used to it. Overall
column4: I am a bit disappointed by this camera. It is overpriced for what it offers. I have used in the past film rangefinders
column5: which are so much easier to use and DSLR
column6: which works much consistently the way you intend them to work. With this camera
column7: the settings change too easily. Too bad
column8: particularly in view of price of this camera."^3^Jun 18

column1: BeezNutz^/canon-powershot-sx740-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6287925?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^43^18^"We upgraded from our Canon PowerShot SX720 HS 20.3 MP Compact Digital Camera - 1080p a camera our whole family truly loved. Great photos
column3: and very easy to operate. We still have this camera and love it. One of the reasons I upgraded was I could use the same batteries I already had with the new camera.

column1: The good is this camera looks and feels great. Comes with an upgraded processor
column2: 4k video and timelapse and a ton of bells and whistles. That is about where the good stops and the bad starts.

column1: With the upgraded processor it seems to have some lag from when the shutter is pressed and when the image is taken. Big problem
column2: I am trying to capture action and you really have to adjust your timing
column3: but that is just the start.

column1: The 4k video in a bright room was grainy and almost unwatchable - i didn't even share any of the dozen or so videos I took because they are so far from the quality I am used to. The focus on the video is another huge problem. It had trouble and would keep adjusting the focus during recording also adding to make these unwatchable.
The photos also leave a lot to be desired. I tried every mode and auto and the same result. Grainy
column3: even in good light. Low light forget it. The 4k timelapse was okay
column4: it takes 24 minutes to make a 24 second clip and that was okay. The photos/video just did not cut it for the pricetag. I took this back. I may buy another of the camera I bought this one to replace.

column1: I returned this unit for the video/photo quality - out of focus
column3: even in good light. Check other reviews and judge for yourself - better yet go try one in person before buying to help avoid yourself the trouble of a return."^1^Oct 3

rhettw^/canon-powershot-sx740-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6287925?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I am normally a DSLR user and have had several including my current a 7D mk 2.  That being said
column2: I bring it for photos of my daughter and her friends at the Friday night football games.  She wants me to video the entire show and not her zoomed in so I wanted something with a wide zoom and 4k for the video.  The video in this camera looks amazing.  Under the dim high school lights you can see the difference between this camera and my 7D but it still looks good.  The zoom on this camera is CRAZY!  I do not use the digital zoom.   This was my first game to use the camera tonight and what I did not like was where the record button is and how it feels.  My other cameras have the button on the back where I can see it and it is easy to press.  The record button is small and level with the camera.  I had a hard time finding it without shaking the camera.  I am attaching two images to show what the optical zoom can really do.  I had to reduce the quality slightly so I could attach the images.   The game clock in the 2nd image is at max optical zoom.  That same game clock is in the middle of the zoomed out picture.

column1: I would not replace my DSLR for taking pictures on a regular basis but so far I am enjoying using the camera."^4^Oct 5

Kittie^/canon-powershot-sx740-hs-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6287925?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I have been using this camera about a month now. I have had no issues. It does have a neat function where you can bluetooth sync your phone and camera to use your phone as a remote. Just be warned it does seem to change the formatting on the card to do this. Once this is set up the card will no longer be able to read by pc. You will either have to use a cable to transfer from the camera to the pc or use the sync function to move the pictures to your phone then to a pc if desired. There is stuff that says you can sync it with your pc wirelessly though I have not found a working version of this I trusted.

I added a picture taken with the camera. I had to cut the image size down due to file size limitations. At full resolution files are about 10-12MB each. This has been resized to 65% to meet file size requirements"^5^Jan 20

column1: ZeroStarsIfICould^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-riptide/6367054?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^34^9^"In no scenario does this camera take a single clear photo without SIGNIFICANT grain and slight blur. I'd recommend purchasing the HTC re from 2014 even though it's five years old and most likely difficult to find. Do some research and you'll see that the re far surpasses the IVY REC which is mind-blowingly shocking as it's 2019 and we're talking about a camera from Canon. Do your research
column2: this is a 100% unbiased review (I've never previously reviewed a product) but I've been so burned by this I just had to air my disbelief. I guarantee this will be pulled from shelves or never to be seen again after these initial units are severely discounted and sold."^1^Oct 21

column2: unbelievably small for all that it can do! I was able to take clear crisp photos as good if not better than my smartphone camera.

column1: What I also found surprising was even though it is advertised as an outdoor camera
column2: it takes great pictures indoors too. There is no flash feature for indoors
column3: but as long as there is light in the room
column4: pictures come out great.

column1: The video option is doable. Not necessarily the best but it does what it says and for those moments when a short video is needed
column2: it is fine. I like the fact that it can all be downloaded to your phone or computer later.

column1: I think this little camera is marketed for younger people for it's usability to travel and rugged exterior. I took photos in the rain without worry. If dropped
column2: it can withstand the pressure. The camera itself has an attachable clip which makes it easy to carry; I clipped mine on my purse strap.

column1: The only drawback I personally had with the camera is trying to open the little door for inserting the  MicroSD card and the cord for the USB port to download and charge. My husband had no problem opening it but I simply couldn't manage it. Perhaps not the best feature if you are older
column2: have arthritis or other issues with strength.

column1: I would recommend this product especially for children when they want a camera of their own but might drop an expensive smartphone when taking a picture."^4^Dec 3

Bev31^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-riptide/6367054?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^3^"I received this camera fot free in exchange for a review. I like the simplicity of the design overall to make it more 'point and shoot.' The wheel on the back to choose the shooting mode is very easy to use
column2: but does require using a fingernail or something similar so I don't believe it could be turned on by accident. There is no option to review pictures
column3: or to really see the picture before you take it
column4: so how good the picture turns out is based either on luck or by practice. The clip is very nice
column5: and allows the camera to easily be attached to a belt loop for easy access. The accompanying app requires little set up
column6: but after that is pretty easy to use. The app let's you see the photos or videos you've taken and then download them to use elsewhere. I don't appreciate that the app is mandatory in order to have full use of the camera
column7: but I understand that it is part of streamlining the experience so I accept it. Overall it is a nice simple camera for on the go
column8: and it would be nice for people who just want to be able to take quick pictures but aren't worried about professional quality."^4^Dec 3

column1: SammieJo^/canon-powershot-g9-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/5715505?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^1^"Finally! A point and shoot camera that is halfway comparable to a DSLR. column1: joshuaafterdark^/canon-powershot-g9-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/5715505?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^4^"I picked this camera up about a month ago as a complement to my main camera
column2: the EOS M6. I wanted a genuinely pocket-sized camera that could pack a punch
column3: and boy does this little thing rise to occasion.

column1: I knew it would have stellar photo quality because it uses
column3: the same sensor as the G7x and G5x series
column4: which are incredible advanced compacts. What I didn't expect was just how small the G9x Mk II was going to be when I took it out of the box... This thing is TINY. And for the past month the photos and videos I've taken with it have pretty evenly matched those from the G7x and G5x I've used in the past.

column1: There are 2 (minor) downsides to the G9x though. The first being the lack of a flip or articulating display. And the second is the fact that you cannot record in 60fps when in auto mode
column2: you actually have to switch the dial to movie mode and set 60p as your desired recording frame rate.

column1: At full price ($529) the camera is a bit overreaching. But at it's now pretty common $429 price it's a no-brainer to add to your camera arsenal."^5^Jun 2

Priusguy^/canon-powershot-g9-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/5715505?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"I'm impressed by the image quality of this pocketable little camera. I bought this as a present for my wife
column2: who uses it in AUTO for the most part. She is very happy with it
column3: her only complaint is that the lcd screen can be hard to see in bright sunlight. She didn't try to increase the screen brightness to the max
column4: so that may help on her next outing. If you are an enthusiast
column5: you will have no trouble figuring out all the options and settings. If you just want to point and shoot
column6: that will be fine too."^4^Jun 2

column1: InlandPNWShooter^/canon-powershot-g9-x-mark-ii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/5715505?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"This camera is currently available for $399 USD
column2: which makes it hands down the best value in compact cameras right now. Sometimes I don't want to pack along my bigger Fuji system with multiple lenses
column3: so I just bring this along instead. It doesn't disappoint. JPEG images look great straight out of the camera. Or
column4: if you don't mind getting your hands dirty and messing with a RAW file
column5: you've got that option as well. Take some time to dig through the menus to see what options are available to you. The in-camera HDR processor is surprisingly effective. I also use the time lapse video feature as well. Images are reasonably sharp
column6: probably more than I would expect in a camera like this. And certainly more than sharp enough for web use.

column1: Physically
column2: it's small and somewhat weighty due to its metal construction. It just feels sturdy.  Power up is quick; just the amount of time it takes for the lens to extend out of its housing. I've used the Canon phone app to transfer photos to my Android device
column3: and it works like a champ.

column1: Just know what this camera is good for. You'll get nice shots of your kids indoor birthday party
column2: but probably not of their indoor sports. You don't get much reach with the lens
column3: so you might want to move up to the G7XmkII if you need longer zoom. I'm finding that it's great for travel/nature/landscape work
column4: and an occasional street scene that I might come across.

column1: If you just choose this as your only stand-alone camera
column2: I think you're making a good choice. Take some time to learn it and to understand what it can and can't do
column3: and you should get years of great images."^5^Jun 26

column1: OutofStock^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^20^2^"No amount of fresh new features can hide the fact that the focus system is absolutely broken.

Im not even going to get into the cool new features. Canon has a lot of sponsored YouTubers that can show that stuff off. My opinion is based on the reality of actually using the camera. And it hasnt been good. That focus complaint is real. The touchscreen focus is hit or miss. But the face detect focus is broken. Sometimes the white box does seem to identify faces but it just wont focus. I know the common complaint is that a 2020 camera should have Dual Pixel autofocus built in
column2: but the bigger problem to me is that this seems like a focus downgrade from the previous model.

column1: I really like this camera so Im tempted to stick with it and hope that a firmware upgrade is on its way. But then again
column2: this is Canon and Im just not sure when/if theyll actually address the problem."^1^Aug 8

column1: DavidsAlterEgo^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^0^"I too was really looking forward to this release. A pocketable camera with great form factor that has a fast lens
column3: microphone input
column4: touch screen menu system
column5: USB-C charging
column6: an easy system to transfer media wirelessly to my phone and a tiny flash that is surprisingly useful.

column1: I pre-ordered it and was excited to add this to my photography arsenal alongside my other Canon cameras. The small size is perfect to carry along every day when the DSLRs stay at home. And the image quality is fantastic IMHO
column2: provided youre shooting static subjects and are able to lock focus.

column1: But.. and its a big but
column3: my old Canon S90 has a better autofocus and thats a 9 year old camera.

column1: Additionally
column2: if I even think about taking 4K video in anything but ta walk-in freezer it overheats in no time and locks up on you rendering the camera completely useless until its cooled back off.

column1: I could go on and on about how awful it is
column2: but see for yourself on the various (non-sponsored) reviews on YouTube. Its so bad
column3: Im embarrassed for Canon and this is coming from a Canon fan with storm cases full of their products and former employee..

column1: I honestly dont think Ive ever been so disappointed in a camera which is a shame because this one had so much potential."^1^Aug 12

MadMensch^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^20^6^"I pre-ordered this camera the day it was announced as a replacement to our G7X Mark 2. The main feature I really needed was the Mic input
column2: and the 4K option was nice as well.

column1: Thus far weve recorded a couple videos for our YouTube channel (The Montes Family) and if you watch the video titled How well do we know each other? youll notice the camera goes out of focus at certain points in the video and seems slow to correct. All previous videos on our channel were shot on the G7X Mark 2 and we didnt have that issue with the Mark 2. So it seems the concerns about autofocus on the Mark 3 are legit. My only hope is that the issue is fixed in a future firmware update because its unacceptable for a camera at this price point.

The only reason Im keeping the camera is because I do like the fact that I can now connect my Rode mic directly and I no longer have to sync audio. Other similar compact cameras such as the Sony RX100 do NOT have a mic input so alternative options are limited.

Other things to keep in mind; 4K video is limited to 9 mins per shot and the camera now requires a USB-C cable to connect to your computer (not included). I did have issues accessing my media directly from my MacBooks finder app
column2: but was able to finally retrieve the media once in Final Cut Pro. Overall
column3: I really wanted to love this camera but the autofocus issue has tempered my enthusiasm for now. Ill have to hold off on recommending this 100% until its addressed."^3^Aug 10

column1: joshuaafterdark^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^14^3^"So I preordered a G7X Mark III after LOVING the G1X Mark III and G7X Mark II
column2: due to the fact that it had an external mic input and uncropped 4K (the first of any Canon camera to as well I think). So the camera comes in
column3: I pop in the battery and my SD card
column4: go into video mode and turn on 4K at 30 fps to do a sample test in excellent lighting and the entire camera falls apart. There box is around my face making it seem like I'm in focus
column5: but nope it's drifting everywhere and once it does lock on focus it loses the moment there's any slight movement.

column1: TLDR: On paper an excellent little compact camera at a great price compared to the RX100 VII
column2: but the autofocus make it completely useless for video which is who this camera is targeted at."^2^Aug 10

column1: OurMicroFamily^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^22^15^"This camera has been long waited for and honestly has let me down alot. The audio on this camera was ok
column2: so I used a small microphone on side and worked amazing. This issue I could overcome
column3: what I cant get past is the horrible focus system. I know it doesn't have the dual pixel system like m50 but for the price the auto focus could have a better computer system for it. Vlogging with the camera for Our Micro Family we need a good camera
column4: and this one did not work.  I would be interested in canon releasing a firmware update to improve the camera but the other issue is adobe does not support cr3 the new raw file format from canon so i had raw files I could not edit either.

column1: Long story short
column2: canon is amazing brand but did not deliver enough to impress this vlogger."^2^Aug 2

column1: SlowMN^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"The Canon PowerShot G7 X Mark III is a high quality camera with many great features. It gives the user extreme portability while allowing for professional level photos and videos.
The camera was paired with the SanDisk Extreme Plus 128 GB UHS-I microSD card
column2: which is ideal for 4k video due to its fast read and write speeds and for storing a large number of high resolution photos.

column1: Features to note:

* 3' multi angle touchscreen LCD: The touchscreen is responsive and is easy to view from any angle. I did not have any issues with hitting a wrong button. When it is flipped up or down it is firmly attached and doesn't feel like it is going to snap off. The versatility of this screen allows the user to position the camera at angles other cameras could not while maintaining the ability to see what the camera is seeing. I think this is great because nothing is worse than recording something and finding out you or the intended object are not even in the frame! Overall
column2: this screen is well implemented and a great feature.

column1: * 4K video: The camera has the ability to record 4K video at 30 fps and HD video at 120 fps. It can be recorded in both horizontal (landscape) and vertical (portrait) positions. It has a multi angle touchscreen that can be flipped up 180 degrees so the user can see themselves while recording in both the horizontal or vertical orientation. Streaming is only available on YouTube and there are some additional requirements/limitations. There is the option to add an external mic to the camera in addition to the standard stereo quality mic that is included; however
column2: the standard microphone delivers clear sound. Lastly
column3: there is a HDMI output so videos can be played back on a large TV. These features allow the user to create high quality videos without needing to purchase a stand alone video camera. The quality of the videos are excellent
column4: especially when recording in 4K. 4K is very power intensive/heat producing and I found recording shorter segments (a few minutes at a time) was the most efficient so the camera wouldn't get too hot. When recording in lower resolution
column5: the camera did not experience any overheating issues. If you are thinking about vlogging/streaming or creating home/casual videos
column6: this camera hits the mark.

column1: * WiFi/Bluetooth technology to transfer photos/videos: Using WiFi technology
column2: it was straight forward to transfer files from the camera to a smart phone. I used an iPhone 11 Pro Max running IOS 13.3. You download the CameraConnect App from the Appstore and follow the onscreen instructions. It gives you the option to connect via Bluetooth or WiFi. The directions are clear and even the most novice user should be able to successfully pair the camera and phone. ***A note for connecting via WiFi - If you have an installed VPN that connects on demand
column3: you will be unable to connect to the camera until you turn off this option in the VPN settings on.*** Within the App you can turn on/off geotagging on photos if you do not want that information available.

column1: Please note there was a known issue with auto focus but this has been addressed by Canon with a firmware update on 12/12/2019.
Overall
column2: this camera is excellent. It is compact in size but packed full of amazing features. It allows you to take beautiful high resolution photos with its 1 inch 20.1 MP sensor and up to 4k 30 fps videos. I believe it out-competes all smart phone cameras in both photo and video quality. It is highly competitive in its camera class. I highly recommend this camera."^5^Dec 27

column1: drumanji^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"I've shot a lot and have had this since day one/launch and with patience I've been getting some decent shots out of this thing. (Lifestyle
column3: at the beach
column4: indoors.) I was waiting until I could view the RAWs. However
column5: I have to make an effort to make sure what I wanted in focus is in focus. It likes to focus on the background leaving subjects out of focus. Once its locked on though the shots are great. So the AF on stills isn't as bad as with video. But it's so bad for video I don't even consider using it... especially if i wanted to VLOG and can't 'man the camera.' The focus box shows you're the object
column6: but focuses the opposite. It takes ages to finally lock onto focus
column7: but its fickle to lose it again. That and the overheating while using FHD 120p or 4k. I'm also stuck with 30fps as the lowest framerate it can go. If I switch to PAL I can get 25fps at least. That being said I bought this for my wife who never really used cameras other than a cell phone. I wanted something for her that she can literally point and shoot and maybe she'll gain interest in some gear
column8: but I'm having trouble justifying why things don't work or are out of focus for her. Back to video: I've resorted to finding focus on me
column9: for example
column10: and switching to MF to be able to have peace of mind that it wont jump to the background. Of course
column11: I have to make sure I stay the same distance the whole time though. I still have a few weeks before I am out of my return window and I'm hoping they release a firmware fix. If not
column12: then I know what is going to replace this. (Hint: it has 24fps
column13: doesnt overheat
column14: Eye AF etc)

column1: Pros:
-Size:Feature Ratio
-Ergonomics
-1.8 aperture (W) | 2.8 (T)
-FAST high speed capture
-Touch Screen Menus
-ND filter
-MIC input
-Flip screen
-Wifi/Bluetooth
-Image Stablization in Video is decent enough (no complaints)
-FHD 120/60 fps
-No crop 4k (take a hint EOS R lol)
What I don't Like:
-no viewfinder
-AUTOFOCUS
-FHD is a little soft
-lack of dual pixel AF
-overheating in 4k and FHD 120p
-no shoe for the mic (not a big deal)
-no 24fps
-contrast focus
-no LOG profile
-constrained ISO in 4k
-battery life could be better
All that being said
column2: I can get decent results out of the camera
column3: but that is not without putting in some solid effort and patience. Using this thing is tedious. I've never googled or looked up a camera (almost daily) AFTER I bought it to find fixes or to see if others share the same problem. What good is a camera if the pictures you care about aren't in focus? What good is a camera with video if the video isn't in focus and you have to throw out footage? What good is a camera that doesn't let you use it because it overheated?"^1^Aug 20

column1: Bren^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"If I can sum up my review in a short manner
column2: it is only that you NEED to ignore these reviews that are outdated and/or ignorant of the fact that Canon has released a firmware update to address the problems this camera was having with autofocus etc. Before I did anything shooting or filming
column3: I made sure to update the firmware first.

column1: The steps to do this are fairly simple
column2: but there are only a couple of poorly shot videos on the internet that outline how to do it in simple terms. I will give a crack at it in this written review.

column1: The equipment required is an SD card
column2: a computer with internet access for downloading the firmware update (version 1.2.0 as of December 12th
column4: and a bit of time. I formatted the card in the settings on the Camera (this wipes it completely clean
column5: so be careful) and then plugged it into the SD card reader for my computer. On Canon's website
column6: I looked up the firmware on the support page where I was able to download the Zipped folder containing the update file and PDFs in different languages on how to perform the upgrade. There are both Windows and Mac OS X versions available. I unzipped this folder and dragged the file PSG7X3_120.FIR onto the SD card (not inside a folder
column7: just the main page). I then flipped the setting wheel to 'P' and pressed the view button to turn it on. On the settings page
column8: go to number 5 and scroll down to firmware. It will show you the current firmware version (1.0.1. is what mine displayed) and it will ask you if you want to update the firmware. Select OK. It will then go through the process and shut off. When you boot it back up to check
column9: it is updated! It then gives you the option of two autofocus modes; Mode 1 is what you want for a quicker
column10: more adaptable autofocus while filming.

column1: The process is simple enough
column3: and is worth taking the time to do for a camera whose predecessor is so esteemed and loved by many.

column1: I hope this review and like I said
column2: ignore the negative reviews that make no mention of updating their camera first with the latest firmware! Thanks for reading this and have a good day!"^5^Dec 23

column1: SirGalahad^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"So
column2: I got this to try and increase my quality for my YouTube tech reviews and to possibly use on my Twitch stream for a face cam. For the most part it is a good choice
column3: as it does a lot of things right
column4: but as many other reviews have mentioned
column5: there are some glaring negatives that will make a lot look elsewhere. Im not an expert at cameras. Im almost as run of the mill as you can get. Ive been using my cell phone (iPhone X) to do any of my picture and video recording needs but wanted to upgrade.

column1: The first thing youll want to do when you receive the camera is install the two firmware updates that have been released since the camera first came out. The first includes an improved autofocus that is substantially better but still doesnt fully rectify the issue. The second adds a 24-fps option to video recordings. Two things that were desperately needed and should have been available at launch. The update process is relatively simple. Its strange to me that this camera has Wi-Fi and Bluetooth
column2: but you cant download a firmware update through that.

column1: BUILD QUALITY/USE:
The materials on this camera are a mix of plastic and metal. Overall
column2: it feels well built. It has a small spot for your thumb on the back right and a small hump on the front right with a matte material to help with grip but because its so small and light its not the most comfortable. Most of the time I tried to use two hands just to insure I didnt drop it. When vlogging there is a nice area to grab even when the screen is flipped up so there shouldnt be any problem there.

column1: On the front of the camera you have a 20.1 MP
column3: 24-100 mm f/1.8-2.8 zoom lens with a control ring around the lens
column4: which can be used to perform multiple functions such as shutter/aperture control
column5: zoom
column6: EV compensation
column7: and ISO adjustment. On the front right is the small handgrip I previously mentioned. In single shot mode you can track subjects and take advantage of face detection. This works well but as you can see from other reviews
column8: it isnt flawless
column9: and can leave a lot to be desired. These options dont work with burst capture. It supports 4k 30 fps but only for 10 minutes at a time or else it will overheat. You can also do 1080p 120fps slow motion capture
column10: but it is not as sharp as the other modes. Stabilization is good. I didnt have any problems and it was better than my phones. When in focus
column11: image/video quality is very good with low image noise
column12: nice colors
column13: and good detail. There is softness at the edges of the lens and tends to overexpose itself. Image quality and overexposure is better on this camera than on my phone.

column1: On the top of the camera going left to right you have a power on/off button
column3: below the shutter release is the zoom
column4: then a mode dial
column5: and under the mode dial you have an EV compensation control which goes from -3 to +3. All these buttons feel solid without wobble. Some may say they are a bit tight as it can be hard to switch the modes with just your thumb.

column1: On the rear of the camera
column3: top to bottom
column4: you have a high quality (but not quite as high quality as some smart phones) LCD touch screen with an adjustable tilt that goes up
column5: down
column6: and forward for vlogging/selfies. A lock exposure (*)
column7: record video button (usually 1080p 30/60fps)
column8: a command dial that has four direction presses. On the outside of the command dial is a rotational dial that does the same thing as clicking in a direction. Up is for drive/delete
column9: right for flash on/off/auto
column10: down for info
column11: and left for macro/manual focus. In the center is a q/set button. Under that you have a play button to review previously taken photos/videos on the memory card
column12: and a menu button to adjust settings. By pressing the q-button it gives you a lot of other options to select either through touch or through using the direction buttons to further adjust your picture depending on the setting you are on.

column1: On the right-hand side
column3: USB-C port
column4: and Wi-Fi button. The camera has both Wi-Fi and Bluetooth. Setup is straight forward and easy. Via Bluetooth you can connect to your phone and send pictures and then upload to social media that way. You can also control the camera with that as well. Wi-Fi allows you to upload your photos to certain cloud platforms and certain social media sites. You can live stream directly to YouTube but during a live stream it does not capture the footage to your memory card. In camera charging is supported but it also comes with an external charger.

column1: On the left you have your flash slider which pops the flash up and a 3.5 mm microphone connector.
On the bottom right
column2: you have a battery port with the memory card holder. It supports SD
column3: SDHC
column4: and SDXC memory cards. Battery life for my use was great. However
column5: it wont last you all day shooting with a CIPA rating of 235 images.

column1: PROS:
Ease of use
Everything except the auto focus just works and works well.
Picture/video quality (at this price point and when in focus)
Ability to manually control a lot of features.
Wi-Fi/Bluetooth.
Zoom
Touch screen
Excellent pocket camera for vlogging.
Works well on streams (twitch) as you can passthrough without anything on the screen.
Literally pretty much everything about the product except for price and autofocus.
Has better quality photos/video than my iPhone when setup correctly.
CONS:
No EVF
Auto focus is much improved with new firmware update
column2: but it still leaves a lot to be desired. My phones focus is so much better.

column1: Battery wont last all day for shooting.
CONCLUSION:
This camera is packed full of features and the spec list for this price point is great. Build quality
column3: and ease of use works great except for the focus. It is a good pocket camera that is made as a point and shoot camera for noobies like me. It was easy to setup and learn. Picture/Video quality is good when it is in focus. I have very little negatives. However
column4: the focus leaves a lot to be desired and makes me not want to use the product. As I feel like I spend more time trying to get the stupid thing to focus on what I want than I do making content. It also takes me more time because I must go back and record or take a photo of something if it is out of focus. Or skip forward when editing video to wait for it to focus. You can also miss moments waiting for the camera to focus. Yes
column5: the picture/video quality is better than my iPhone X in all regards. I can also take photos in dark or bright environments better because the lens is better. Though not dramatically and at this price point it is a very hefty tax to pay for it. I reverted to just doing manual mode for almost everything (including focus) and my experience with that is great and has made me enjoy the camera a lot more. But doing so made me learn a lot more about cameras than I was at first expecting.

column1: With all that said. I just dont know if I can recommend this camera strictly due to the focus. As I think the target demographic for this camera is for individuals like me who have very limited knowledge of cameras and just want it to work. But you must fiddle with settings to get the best quality out of it which requires a learning curve. Most reviews from people who know what they are doing dont seem too put off about the focus. Likely because they are doing manual mode in which the camera is great. For those who are more casual users and arent as serious about picture quality and learning new things
column2: then I just dont see why the camera on your cellphone wouldnt be adequate enough and allow you to save $750."^4^Dec 30

column1: doop22^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"My knowledge of cameras and photography boils down to can I trust my cellphone to capture my subject quickly
column2: accurately and look good enough on Auto settings to share. But since I received the Canon PowerShot G7 Mark III
column3: I've been trying to branch out and fiddle with White Balance
column4: ISO
column5: Focal Length
column6: RAW and the likes that comes with working with a real camera. I've learned a little bit to get better shots but Auto mode works just fine for me.

column1: Overall
column2: I definitely see the benefits of owning and using a Real camera but just whipping out my phone and snapping my subject such as my cats is just so much easier.

column1: Back to the camera. It's packed full of features that make it a compelling option for a beginner like myself. Has WiFi
column2: and Bluetooth to connect to my phone
column3: laptop or email to get my images to things I use everyday from the app. The charging/transfer over USB-C is a great touch for future proofing. The flippable view finder is great for vlogging if you're into that. 16x zoom helps you get in

column1: On the downside
column2: the camera has issues with my SD card saying it can't be found or requiring a reformat only to end up working again through a power cycle.

column1: In the end
column2: I do enjoy using the Canon
column3: when I remember I have it around and wish to use it. A great beginner option in features and price until you can get into DSLR and Mirrorless options."^4^Dec 19

column1: Njuice^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Although smartphones have made it easier for anyone to be a 'photographer'
column2: there is still a need for high quality standalone cameras. The Canon PowerShot G7 X Mark III continues to prove the need for cameras by offering high end specs but while also conforming to the smartphone era.

column1: PROS:
- Once unpackaged
column2: you notice how small the camera feels and overall how elegant it feels. Its a nice mix of having so weight and form to it so that it feels high end - but not too much to make it feel clunky. I am a big fan of the black design and I think overall its very pleasant to have and hold.

column1: - Set-Up is mainly a breeze! There are a few options you set up on the front end and then its ready to go. Of course you can do a deep dive into the options menu to change preferences etcbut if you want to you could start using this camera almost right out of the box which is great.

- I would highly recommend you utilize the Canon Camera Connect App and I think most users will. This app is overall what you will use to communicate from your smart phone to your camera. It offers tons of great features including taking a pic
column2: quickly transferring that picture to your phone
column3: and then you can edit/post/send that to whatever you need to. Very easy to use and great idea for many people as they want content instantly.

column1: - The 3 inch touchscreen is one of the best feature of this camera. It really provides clarity for the images/videos as well as offers incredible ease of use. The multi-angle view is fantastic when taking different angles but also for the selfie view
column2: its a way where you can take a picture or take video and see exactly what is being taken. It really helps makes your content better overall.

column1: - I was very impressed with how great the 4K video looks on this Camera. It just adds to much depth to whatever you are recording and playback looks wonderful on it. Very pleased that Canon did so well on the 4K!
- Finally
column2: most importantly this Camera takes pictures so well! The lighting is always great
column3: there is great definition in the picture
column4: and the auto-focus is great. I know some people had issues with the focus at first but Canon has a Firmware update out and its essential to download as you should update firmware on anything you use.

column1: CONS:
- The box does not come with a few items I wish it had which is a USB-C Cable
column3: and a memory card. All of those you will have to provide on your own.

column1: - Updating the Firmware requires you to plug your Camera into your computer via a USB-C cable and downloading the firmware from the website. You would think a camera like this could do it all via WiFi with no cables but it doesn't and I think its a step back for the ease of use for the camera user.
BOTTOM LINE:
- The Canon G7 X Mark III will make so many people happy: travelers
column3: social media users
column4: and those who just want to just capture family memories. It has enough ease of use to just grab it and go
column5: but enough deep features for people who really want to dive into making the best content possible. I used to think my Smartphone took pictures that were just as good as professional cameras
column6: but after using this I know how far off I am!"^5^Dec 18

column1: 1ShadowFox1^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"We live in a generation of cell phone photographs. And why not? The cameras incorporated in modern cell phones are ridiculous The clarity
column3: and convenience because its always there. But can cell phones really compete with a modern quality purpose built digital camera?

column1: My first impression of the Canon Powershot Mark III was that feels SOLID. This camera is heavier than you would think and you can usually tell the quality of a device my how solid it feels. And to dive further
column3: button
column4: and switch on this camera feels VERY well made. I have no doubt that this camera will survive travel and usage for some time.

column1: When its comes down to using this camera
column2: my experience has been that there is a STEEP learning curve to it. I am not the most experienced in sophisticated camera usage. I have used my Samsung phone a lot
column3: I LOVE using my variety of GoPros
column4: but I wanted to graduate to a true 'skilled' camera. There are LOTS of settings
column5: the camera will integrate into your phone
column6: it might even fold laundry for you. I have used this camera very heavily throughout the holidays and I am pretty sure I havent even scratched the surface on what this camera is capable of.

column1: What this camera does not do...FOCUS! I have read reviews prior about this camera and seen the complaints regarding the focus speed of this camera
column2: but Canon came out and said this issue was resolved with a software update. It has not. This camera takes a LONG time to auto focus. I took my daughter to see Santa before Christmas and thought this would be a GREAT opportunity to get acquainted with this camera. Static shot in a controlled environment. Easy
column3: right? NOPE. This camera would NOT focus. After 2-3 minutes of my toddler sitting quietly on Santa's lap and behaving extremely well
column4: this camera would not focus at all and I could not get a picture of my little one with Santa at all. Luckily the retail store Santa was at was supplying free pictures. This is unacceptable to me. There was nothing complex to this photo at all. I was able to catch other family photos in different environments
column5: but none more important than the picture I missed out on.

column1: Also
column2: going from very cold outside to temperature controlled indoors I have had issues with the lens fogging over and taking a long time to become usable again.

column1: With practice
column2: I believe I will get better with this camera. I have a vacation in May in which I am heading out of country and will be taking this camera with me and video blogging. I am hoping by then I can get more familiar and take all of the great pictures and videos in the world. But I still feel that this camera and its auto focus needs an overhaul. Until then
column3: I really can't recommend this camera.

column1: Long story short...at present time I can not see a reason to bring this camera with you as its difficulty of use and the auto focus is terrible. Your cell phone will do everything you need and them some. This camera will leave you frustrated. Unless you want to video blog exclusively
column2: there are most likely better options for you out there."^3^Jan 9

column1: AndiInOKC^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I was hesitant about purchasing this camera due to the previous reviews

Auslaw^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^2^"We purchased this camera primarily for video blogging and we are very pleased with its performance on that front.  However
column2: we quickly learned that this camera is far more than a 'one-trick pony.'  It packs a ton a features into a small

column1: Grayson^/canon-powershot-g7-x-mark-iii-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/6359937?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^2^"My fiance and I got this camera as a replacement for our vlogging channel (Grayson and Jeff) and have loved it!! While it does sometimes struggle to autofocus
column2: it's an issue that resolves itself pretty quickly once you touch your face on the touchscreen viewfinder. Once you do that
column3: the rest of the video normally stays in focus.

column1: One thing we have loved about this camera is that on the touchscreen
column2: there's a button to start/stop the video. In addition
column3: this camera is AMAZING in low light conditions which has been a huge plus since our house only gets good natural lighting for a few hours every day.

column1: The Canon G7X mark III also gives a wider picture on video mode which has been nice for vlogging because we're able to fit more in one frame. While we don't normally use a microphone
column2: it's nice that this model can actually have one.

column1: Overall
column2: we've loved this camera and personally think it's a huge step up from the mark II. The only reason that I'm not giving it 5 stars is because the autofocus isn't 100% perfect every time you use it."^4^Aug 27

column1: radarvector^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^66^0^"First off
column2: I'm a 40+ year Nikon System shooter
column3: from film SLR's to DSLR's. I've been searching in vain
column4: quite some time
column5: for a first class compact prosumer type camera. Something that I can carry with me at all times and not sacrifice high image quality.

column1: This is it
column2: for me. This camera is phenomenal on every level.

column1: Hiking around with 5 DSLR bodies
column3: and invariably I'll leave out the lens that I wish I had brought with me.

column1: No more. This is the perfect 'walkabout' camera
column2: and Nikon has nothing in this category that even approaches the image quality of this little gem.

column1: The Zeiss optics are clear and bright
column2: the autofocus system is fast and accurate
column3: the creative options are extensive. Pricey? Yes
column4: somewhat
column5: but the old adage that you get what you pay for applies here.

column1: I recommend this to all enthusiasts and serious photographers out there. You will not be disappointed!"^5^Nov 2

TBCass^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^64^12^"I have been an enthusiast photographer since the 60's. My primary cameras have been mostly SLT types. I have on occasion tried more compact type cameras as something more convenient to carry around but they have been
column3: unacceptable to me due to mediocre image quality
column4: manual capabilities and overall speed and responsiveness
column5: auto focus and shot to shot times in particular. When this camera first came out I was impressed by the universal praise it received from professional reviewers so I decided to give it a try as a take everywhere addition to my camera kit.

column1: I have had the camera for over a month now and have taken over well 1000 photos with it and am happy to say it
column3: exceeds my expectations. The speed is DSLR like including fast auto focus. Due to the ability to customize the functions of the wheels and buttons I have it set up just the way I want it making it extremely easy to use whether for manual or automatic use.

column1: As far as handling
column2: at first the small size put me off but after a few days I got used to it and now I have no problems. Some people complain about the lack of a hand grip but for me it isn't needed on a camera this small and light. It may make one handed shooting a touch more difficult for some but it hasn't caused me a problem. I usually shoot 2 handed anyway. I was even able to use it simultaneously with my A65 holding the RX100 in my right hand
column3: the A65 in my left
column4: shooting video with the RX100 and stills with the A65 pushing the A65 shutter button with the little finger of my right hand.

column1: The only thing lacking with this camera is an eye level viewfinder but I can forgive that omission because with a camera this small a decent one would be impossible to include without increasing the size of the camera significantly. The LCD is usable in bright sun when you set it to the brightest setting.
Last but not least the image quality. In this area I have no complaints at all. Up to iso 800 it can compete with any DSLR
column3: it is a small step behind. At iso6400 I find it unacceptable but few cameras of any kind are acceptable at 6400 as far as I'm concerned.

column1: All things considered
column3: speed
column4: handling and image quality make this camera worth every bit of it's $650. In face I call it a bargain. If I could give it 6 stars out of 5 I would.

column1: A final comment about video. I am not as serious about video as I am about stills but
column2: other than the lack of a separate microphone jack
column3: the camera is very good with results competitive with Blue Ray quality. The built in stereo mic is adequate for general use.

column1: A final comment about the flash. Some complain about it's location but I have no problem and it can be bounced
column2: a first for a built in flash. Besides
column3: there's no else you could put it."^5^Sep 23

column1: dpoplin^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^47^1^"After researching cameras for over 6 months
column2: Sony released the RX100 and it was a perfect fit for me. I am traveling to Argentina to do mission work for over a year and I wanted DSLR quality pictures and full HD 1080p video that could fit in my pocket. I have exactly what I want in this camera. I didn't want to be carrying a huge DSLR or a micro 4/3 around in my hand and get robbed in a foreign country. This camera is perfect to whip out of your pocket
column3: take a picture with less than a second power on time and snap that picture with almost no focus time. When people see my photos they ask if they came from a DSLR because they are so sharp
column4: bright
column5: crisp and clear. I love the ring around the lens that spins
column6: you can have it adjust the zoom
column7: the exposure
column8: the filter
column9: anything you want
column10: and the Function buttons and menus are completely customizable. The shooting filters are so much fun to play with
column11: it has in camera HDR
column12: color selection with blue
column13: green
column14: yellow
column15: and red
column16: miniature focusing
column17: watercolor
column18: color pop
column19: B&W and so much more. Photos at night time are amazing. You get what you pay for and I would pay even more for this camera with the quality you get that actually slides into your pocket. When I opened the box
column20: I was actually surprised to see that the camera was smaller than I thought. I bought a waterproof/dustproof Pelican 1010 case that it fits perfectly in and a lcd scratch protector from Sony. I am thoroughly pleased with the camera

column1: The only con that I can find is that the black paint on the exterior stratches easily
column2: but can be fixed if kept in a case.

column1: And with the review above
column3: but once you start using the camera it is extremely easy to catch on."^5^Aug 23

column1: NewRX100^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^29^0^"I'm someone that has really gotten used to my phones camera as my primary PnS. I've been thinking about getting a DSLR but didn't want to lug around a bag or have a strap around my neck. I did extensive research on this camera and decided to take the plunge. Its incredible! I love taking pictures with it
column3: the different modes are impressive with the amount of settings you can manipulate and change and having it in my pocket or in my girlfriends purse is the MAIN reason I bought this camera. Yes
column4: a DSLR offers great versatility but in the end I wanted DSLR like quality in a PnS frame and this little guy delivers. I also bought the eye-fi for $40 bucks which basically transfers pics form the RX100 to my iPhone/iPad wirelessly. It does it anywhere; it does not need a wifi network to make it happen. Imagine taking a sick pic with the RX100 and then automagically it goes to your iPhone where you then upload instantly to Instagram. Its sick!!"^5^Sep 19

column1: Happycameraman^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^29^3^"I have read hundreds of reviews on this camera before purchasing. I can literally find nothing wrong with the Sony RX100! Picture quality is amazing. Auto focus is instant with absolutely no shutter delay. Battery life if very good. Some say the camera is to small others say it's to large. I think it's perfect. I am a semi-pro photographer so I know cameras pretty well. This camera will do everything I would expect from a camera of this price range. Some say it's expensive. You get what you pay for. If you want a quality camera that will literally shoot in the dark and get the image others will miss
column2: This is the camera for you! The images blow me away even at high iso. Video is crystal clear and image stabilization is great. I love the way the camera charges by simply plugging in. Keeps things very simple and works with any car or home usb charger. Seriously
column3: there is nothing not to like. I used to carry a bag of gear everywhere I went. Now I carry my Sony in my pocket all the time. My last point and shoot was a Canon G11 with a 2.8 lens. This will knock its socks off especially in low light. I tried like crazy to like the G11 but always felt it was a compromise. Not with this. I'm now getting exactly what I want. I always thought you needed a DSLR to capture great photos. This proved me wrong. Don't get me wrong
column4: I would never give up my DSLR and that will do many things this camera will not. But like they say
column5: the best camera is the one that's with you!"^5^Dec 14

column1: 2wheeltraveler^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^20^0^"I appreciate well-framed
column2: accurate and technically challenging pictures... however i'm a far cry from being able to take them myself. I have too many hobbies to take on photography too but I wanted to get 'good enough' to stop having rookie mistakes in what would otherwise be great shots.

column1: Although I firmly believe that 'knowing the technique' is the key to a better shot and that hardware cannot fix the eye of a bad shooter
column2: this camera re-defines that to some extent. Out of the box it eliminated many of my 'quick-shot' mistakes and it takes amazingly clear
column3: well-focused photos. In full auto mode it does an outstanding job of picking the right settings.

column1: Can my shot's be better if I learned more about photography technique and control
column2: absolutely! I bought this expecting to do just that... however what I have found is that I use it more as an excellent point-and-shoot and still only use 10-20% of it's full capability as a full-featured camera.

column1: It's quite a bit larger than my previous point and shoot but small enough to have with you most of the time. Jumping to a full-body SLR meant I would only have it 10% of the time I need it and with the RX-100
Things to consider...
If you buy the form-fitted leather case for it (which is excellent BTW)
column2: it does add enough bulk that it's no longer pocketable with the exception of jackets and cargo pockets.

column1: The flash is in an awkward location. i've almost dropped the camera twice when it popped up under my finger and startled me.
When zooming into a picture in playback mode
column2: the default is to jump waaaaaay too far into the picture and you have to zoom back out. I wish this was configurable (or that I could find where if it is...). 1/2 as far would be ideal for me.

column1: It's almost as much as an entry-level full body SLR
column2: but don't let that scare you away. It's well worth it and VERY unlikely you will get camera envy any time soon."^5^Sep 12

column1: camerabug^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^25^6^"Great camera to start with
column2: lasted just over one year. Camera would shut down way before the power saving limit was reached
column3: followed by complete failure with the lens extended. Camera is now a paperweight that needs another $211 to repair. Had I searched some of the blogs for RX-100
column4: I would have never purchased this camera. Funny thing
column5: Sony did not list any known issues but I found blogs over 8 pages long about problems with this camera."^2^Jun 26

column1: Saleenguy^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^0^"This Camera takes Awsome Pics and is very easy to use by anyone. The only complaint is the pop up flash because your finger gets in the way when it pops up because the finger is trying to hold the camera the normal way. All around the Camera is Great and with the Pop up Flash it just takes time to get used to."^5^Oct 14

iowapipe^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^4^"An inexperienced photographer who will only use the Program mode will get great results from this camera. You will need to adjust the autofocus choice I think
column2: but otherwise you won't have problems. The camera makes good choices.

column1: The experienced photographer will be getting this camera because they want something more DSLR like
column2: but can fit in a pocket and/or be inconspicuous when used. How this beats all other pocketable cameras: 1. (most importantly to me) it is low-light capable and leaves plenty of pixels for cropping a wide shot where the aperture is 1.8
column3: 2. the 1' sensor gives great DOF as expected
column4: 3. the control ring is useful (I would prefer it to be stepped
column5: and not have to be turned quite as far for use) 4. very quick to take pictures even in low light with the assist beam turned off.

column1: Trumps the Panasonic LX7 in IQ
column2: as well as pocketability. Quite similar in size to the Canon S110
column3: but better IQ due to the larger sensor. These are the only 2 that are cheaper that would offer similar low-light capability if you need to save $150 or so.

column1: I think this camera would be better priced at $525ish. Having said that
column2: I would not willingly give it up for any other pocket camera no matter how much cheaper. I have been waiting for an upgrade from my Canon SD4000 (2 years ago it was the only pocketable camera with low-light capability). But nobody has provided one that did anything better at the same size. The Canon S95
column3: 100 had RAW capability
column4: but there wasn't much to be gained from such a small sensor. So their purchase wasn't justified.

column1: Bottom line - if you want a small camera with good IQ
column2: THIS is the camera to get. All other camera's in this size fall short."^5^Dec 7

column1: Macrolover^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^13^0^"Had you previously told me that a point-and-shoot could be worth $650

column3: review them for my website
column4: and flip them on Ebay. My last two were the Panasonic LX-5 and Canon S100. This Sony totally smokes not only them
column5: but everything else in the point-and-shoot category. It's in a class of its' own; nothing I've ever owned comes close except a dSLR with a fast lens. I could find no fault with this camera; it's a dSLR that fits into your pocket.One simple feature really stood out for me: the flash tilts
column6: so you can bounce-flash indoor shots. That one silly thing is transformative
column7: and discovering it convinced me that it's possible for a point-and-shoot to be worth this much."^5^Apr 5

column1: okiemomma^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^0^"I love this camera. I bought it because the reviews were great. I am a photographer and I needed a good

column1: jimylegg1^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^0^"Having had my older point and shoot stolen

column1: SpartySAM^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^0^"I travel a fair bit and I always carry a camera with me. Sometimes
column2: I carry my main system cameras (either the Nikon D600/D3s or a Leica M9). Yet
column3: these systems are heavy. When I want to travel light
column4: I want a high quality camera that can give me pictures that are equivalent to what I would have gotten from either a Nikon or a Leica but that do not take up a great deal of space.

column1: In the past
column3: Olympus (XZ-1)
column4: and Fujifilm (x10). Based on reviews from places like DPREVIEW and photographyBlog
column5: I decided to look at the Sony RX100. Simply put
column6: this is a great camera. What did Sony do right: large sensor - check; good sets of control - check; high quality images - check; a decent Automatic white balance - check; a really compact decision where the lens is protected when not in use - check; programmable lens control ring - check; 10 fps full-resolution burst shooting - check (great for kids and sports); shallow depth of field - check; superb Zeiss lens - check.

column1: This is not to say that this is a perfect camera. In its current form
column2: it lacks an electronic view finder (i.e.
column3: a viewfinder that replaces the rear viewing screen -- something nice for those like me who grew up with film cameras with their optical view finders); its rear control wheel is not customizable; there is no built-in memory and lack of 'no card' warning.

column1: Yet
column2: in spite of these minor quibbles
column3: this is a great camera. Buy it - you will not regret the decision. This camera currently beats the best of Nikon (P7700 or P330) and Canon (S110/G1x/G15). This camera has been universally highly recommended in most of the reviews. If you use it
column4: you will see why."^5^May 9

column1: RichInCollegeStation^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^0^"There are lots of reviews of this camera online and I I won't attempt to one-up the pros. Suffice it to say that this camera is outstanding. It's pricey
