column1: WGAEddie^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^0^"This camera is a great option for those who want near professional quality photos. It takes great macro shots as well as portrait and landscape photos.
The automatic settings do great for everyday shots without having to tinker with settings. When I have a complex shot
column2: the manual controls allow me to take great photos in low light conditions or when focus needs to be honed in to capture the picture.

column1: The photo quality is amazing. The 20 MP image allows me to enlarge and crop the photo without pixelating.
This is a great camera for the learning photographer who wants professional quality control without having to pay for a DSLR and high-end equipment.
The battery life is incredible. I can take 200-300 photos before having to recharge."^5^Oct 16

Inee^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^0^"Lots of options for taking all kinds of pics/ scenes. Nice low light pics. Takes awesome landscape pics. Price is a bit high but worth it if you want DSLR quality pics without the bulk."^5^May 11

darthpnoy^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^0^"I was looking to replace my old faithful Nikon D40 DSLR which has served me well but unfortunately I wanted something that I could take everywhere but yet still have the quality that I yearned in the DSLR. I shopped around and played with Canon S110
column3: Canon G15
column4: Panasonic LX7
column5: Canon GX1 but I chose the RX100 simply because it not only had the superior image quality but also the compact size I needed. Yes
column6: it's expensive at $649 but well worth it because of the features it provides. Even go to Flickr and look at the results that many folks have taken with this camera. Highly recommend this camera for folks that want both image quality and portability."^5^Feb 19

column1: HOUTx^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^0^"I highly recommend this camera for those who need a backup camera or those just looking to use this as a primary system."^5^Nov 10
digiman1946^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^1^"The Sony RX100
column3: is an excellent photographic tool whether the user is a beginner willing to learn
column4: or a more experienced photographer needing/wanting a DSLR backup.

column1: The camera has great image quality and the shorter zoom is partially offset by the ability to crop and still have a fine looking image worthy of either web posting or print of discernible size."^5^Sep 12

Byxarik^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^1^"The sensor in the RX100 is the same 1' format that Nikon uses in its 1-System. It is considerably smaller than those used in most interchangeable lens cameras but it significantly larger than those used in most enthusiast compacts.
Conclusion - Pros
Excellent image quality and solid ISO performance
Class-leading movie features and quality
A good degree of customization puts your favorite settings at your fingertips
Fast operation
Flexible lens range (though a brighter zoom would have been nice)
Excellent range of additional features (sweep panorama and auto HDR in particular)
Good battery life for this class of camera
USB-charging (with fast charger) makes it easy to travel light
Conclusion - Cons
Clickless control dial contributes to vague and unengaging shooting experience
Flash metering is unpredictable
Lack of ND filter can limit the ability to use wide apertures
Screen hard to see in direct sunshine
No official option to fit filters onto the lens (third-party glue-on adapters are available)
In-camera raw conversion would add flexibility
Playback confusingly separated into stills
Lag when trying to zoom in playback mode is irksome
USB-only charging makes it awkward to use a spare battery"^4^Dec 15
Nikki^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"It outclasses other cameras that are of similar size to it
column2: but larger cameras at its price point can match or outperform it. So
column3: you need to be interested in a small but high-quality camera to consider this one.

column1: If you use this camera as a point and shoot for vacations and other events
column2: then you can leave it in the Auto+ mode and once you get the hang of letting it automatically take exposure brackets or just multiple shots to composite in low light then you will have very high quality images ready to go on the camera immediately.

column1: If you are using this camera as a small and easy to carry enthusiast or companion to a pro camera
column2: then you can set it up to save the RAW data or take the exposure bracket and let you do the HDR and other processing later. Or often you can just let the Auto+ mode do its thing and go back to manual settings only if the results weren't satisfactory.

column1: Startup time is great and it takes pictures pretty quickly. The Auto+ mode slows things down since it does the processing right after taking the images
column2: but it has enough internal buffer storage to hold 5-7 shots before having to pause to write to the card.

column1: The 1' sensor is large for this class of camera
column2: but it still isn't all that big. Other optics and sensor features push it to a higher performance than the larger sensor would alone. Low light capability is impressive for its size and this camera takes better backlit photos than any I've had before. Supposedly the second and third versions of this camera are even better in backlit scenes than this one.

column1: There isn't much in the way of a zoom on this camera. And image quality degrades a bit the further you zoom in. At 20 megapixels though you can get away with some digital-zoom-style cropping after the fact.
You will get some barrel lens distortion with this camera
column2: more than I've seen on other compacts. But
column3: as a tradeoff you get a wider angle lens
column4: so hard to call this a pro or a con."^5^Aug 11

column1: johnnyb817^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"'Set and forget' will be my approach for a while
column2: as the controls and settings are a bit overwhelming for a novice like me. However
column3: that's the beauty of this camera. It has options galore but setting it to auto mode still provides fantastic pics in a full range of locations and circumstances...indoors
column4: outdoors
column5: portraits
column6: landscapes
column7: close-ups
column8: etc. Great camera for me to grow with."^5^Apr 18

column1: zetpoli^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^1^"if you want a small and dslr kind of camera you must have this the picture quality is really nice i always got compliment on my shots. we have a canon 7d but my husband use it most if the time i buy this for me to carry anytime without hassle of heavy dslr. must have camera!"^5^Jan 19
DDalal^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^3^"As a long-time Sony/Zeiss user (Back in the DSC-S50 days of 1999)

column1: The overall quality
column2: fit and finish is excellent and expected of a made in Japan Sony product. The menu is easy to use and follow and setup is easy.

Lori^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"This is a great camera. column1: orijin^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^4^"Please understand they do not really compete with one another although they could one uses a aps c sensor while one uses a 1' sensor.

There is no argument at ~$1000 the coolpix A does in fact have a larger image sensor than the ~$600 rx100. Using the Coolpix A what really bugs me is the lack of actual zoom on this thing and the slow autofocus on this thing as well. Lastly there is an annoying thing where there is a little switch on the side to switch to between: macro
column2: auto focus and manual focus. The lack of image stabilization is another bad thing

column1: *** the RX100 lens does have image stabilization.
RX100 advantages does have faster auto focus
column2: in superior auto you do not need to physically hit a switch to go in between macro and auto focus. (it does what it suppose to do auto detect that its a macro picture or other scene options)

column1: *** The Macro on the RX100 is also significantly better as well
column2: I prefer the macro on the RX100 as I can get a closer shot to the object before the focus does not work anymore.

column1: But do realize in real world situations a faster auto focus
column2: image stabilization will generally snap you a better picture than a camera with slower auto focus especially when you are using auto mode on these two cameras.

column1: *** Where the RX100 shines is the faster auto focus being able to snap multiple pictures at once and choosing the best picture of the bunch it snaps. To me if you want an all around camera the RX100 would be the definite choice but if you are maybe just taking pictures of landscapes or non moving pictures on a tripod the Coolpix A might be a better choice.

If you google rx100 vs coolpix a you'll find spec comparisons and reasons why you might wind up falling in love the RX100 over the coolpix A. I also recommend trying them both in person I bought the rx100 first and
*** then bought the coolpix A seeing if I would replace the RX100 but winded up returning the coolpix A."^5^Apr 24

column1: Clicker10^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/5755149?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"This camera has everything I need in a pocket point and shoot. The video and sound are excellent also from what I have used so far. The focus is lightening fast and I love the face recognition selfie features.....I preferred this over the Mark II because I did not like the flimsy pull out screen...I did not need WIFI and the hot shoe had little to offer.
This is a great camera for a DSLR user looking for a point and shoot.....a novice may find it a little complicated."^4^Mar 8

I have been taken 35mm since the 1960's and have had many cameras. I now have a Sony a200 . however with 15 grand kids i needed something i could carry around in my pocket. Have used other point and shoot cameras but nothing could freeze kids fast enough or could take one picture after another fast
column2: until i purchased the Sony Cyber-shot DSC-RX100.

column1: I must admit it took me about 3 months to decided because of the price and not knowing if it would do what i expected of the camera. When I seen on Best-buy wed site and open-box in excellent condition for a price i could live with i decided to purchased(and with a return policy that was 15 days) i would see if the camera could do what i wanted it to and it did...
Cons
Price .. A bit weighty for a point an shot
Flash does get in the way of holding camera when it pops up(But does give good coverage) No view finder Screen a bit hard to view in bright light .
Overall an excellent point an shot for fast kids and fast movement.
i Purchased the extra metal hand grip and screen saver overlay.
from Amazon ..you will not be disappointed. The hand grip will make holding the camera a lot easier and safer. Also your fingers will not get in the way of the flash coming up."^4^Apr 20

column1: Jerry^/panasonic-lumix-dc-zs70-20-3-megapixel-digital-camera-silver/5866713?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"This is the 4th or 5th Panasonic ZS series camera I've bought. Although the ZS70 is not the latest one

column4: I think
column5: but I wanted the long zoom and realize I've sacrificed some of the picture quality to be had in the newest ZS100. That said
column6: ZS70 still has a lot of features and all of my Panasonics have given me good quality photos. The LCD on this one has a lot more capabilities than my last ZS50. Although the LCD screen swings up (to facilitate selfies)
column7: I wish it would swing down. I'm not likely to take very many selfies
column8: but it would have been great to be able to tilt the screen down and hold the camera over my head. That is a missed opportunity for Panasonic
column9: in my book.

column1: If you want amazing zoom in a pretty-close-to-pocket-sized camera
column2: this is the one for you. If you want amazing picture quality
column3: you might want to look to the ZS100
column4: which has a 1 sensor (compared to the ZS70's 1/2.3 sensor) even though both cameras are rated at 20 megapixels."^4^May 17

dranreb^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-purple/4866802?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^28^2^"This camera is small and lightweight. It easily fits in a pants pocket or purse (even a very small purse). I was very happy with how easy it was to carry around and use when traveling. I wish it came with a case though. The large
column2: bright screen makes it easy to compose pictures. Anyone familiar with the Canon Rebel series would find the menus on this camera similar and easy to use. The camera gives you a lot of control in manual settings
column3: but I also found the AUTO mode to be quite effective for most of my needs. I am very impressed with the photo quality
column4: especially the accuracy of colors
column5: like a blue sky. (I have seen other cameras 'wash out' a blue sky but not this camera.) The camera also does an excellent job in scenes with high contrast. The photos come out great and require little or no editing. Battery life is excellent and I like that the charger does not have a cord. One less cord to drag around. The charger's prongs fold up
column6: too
column7: so it is very portable.

column1: One minor complaint is that I wish the lens had a wider angle in order to take more impressive landscape photos. Another complaint
column2: which causes me to knock one star off the rating
column3: is that the wifi is very clunky. It requires you to download an app onto your computer and sign up for a Canon image service. I would have expected to only need to download an app. Not create some kind of account. The wifi is a useless feature to me and I am happy to continue putting the SD card into my computer or printer slot.

column1: Overall this was a great purchase and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a very portable little camera that has a good zoom and takes great pictures. It is good for travel because it does a great job in a variety of shots
column2: whether you are taking landscape photos
column3: close-ups
column4: or photos of people. I brought this camera along on a trip where I also used my iPhone 6s for some pictures. The Canon ELPH 360 took better pictures
column5: hands-down."^4^Feb 28

TallBill^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-purple/4866802?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^2^"I previously had a PowerShot SX120
column2: and this camera (PowerShot ELPH 360 HS) has all of the same features and much more. It does lack a true manual mode
column3: however (allowing the user to set shutter speed and aperture manually). The control buttons on the back are flush with the case
column4: making the camera somewhat difficult to use in very dim light conditions. As with all point-and-shoot cameras that have no viewfinder
column5: the display will be hard to see in direct sunlight. It has a lens cover that opens and closes automatically
column6: which prevents losing a separate lens cap. The camera has connectors on the right side for USB AV out and HDMI interfaces
column7: but they are covered by a cheap plastic cover that is difficult to get open until you file off the catches a little bit. The Li-Ion battery is small (only 800 mAh)
column8: and I have not yet determined exactly how long it will last (the manual claims 180 pix). I have only used the USB port to transfer pictures directly to my computer without going through an online service. I have not tried setting up the Wi-Fi interface yet to see if it would be easier to use. This camera has both High Speed Burst mode (about 7.2 pix per second) that will group the pictures and Continuous Shooting Drive Mode
column9: which allows pictures to be taken continuously while the shutter button is held depressed (about 2.5 pix per second; pictures are NOT grouped)."^5^Jul 31

column1: LoneBiker^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-purple/4866802?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I have several PowerShot SX's and I like them. But I've been cycling a lot lately and I wanted something smaller and lighter. I didn't expect to find it to have almost twice the Megapixels as my last SX so that was a pleasant surprise. If you're use to using PowerShot then the User Interface is about the same thing. Design choices come down to compromises. I would have preferred a screen that tilts up but I like getting so much picture taking power in something smaller than my hand with a good image stabilizer capability. I really like being able to carry this little guy around my neck or tucked into a little gadget bag on the bike. I haven't considered mounting it on the bike because I think that the vibrations may be a little harsh for it. I like to stop to take a drink and shoot a few pictures and then attach the images to my ride maps on MyMaps."^5^Nov 13
DeeDee^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-purple/4866802?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I love taking pictures and had a Canon 300 for my point and shoot camera

column1: And really liked the Canon 300 better. It was much easier to use and when you would take pictures on the VIVID they didn't look FAKE. Today I went taking pictures of the changing of the leaves and Used the vivid and also the regular. The Vivid looks so fake. I was disappointed because I had to delete over 1/2 my pictures. However
This camera dose take good CLEAR pictures. I am sharing 2 pictures. One of the regular setting and one on Vivid."^3^Oct 19
Harry^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-purple/4866802?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^14^"I purchased this wonderful camera on February 15
column2: 2019. I downloaded the required software and then spent about 3 hours trying to get the Camera connected to my computer. I then went on-line and downloaded the 157 page used guide but the chapter for connecting to a computer was for Windows 7 users. Canon customer service told me that the Camera worked perfectly on windows 7 but there are problems with windows 10. They blamed the problem on windows 10 but their camera was 'perfect'. The person asked me to make a number of changes (adjustments) to my computer so that the camera could upload pictures. I had no idea what I was doing but I was told that my adjustments would not hurt my computer or prevent any other software from operating correctly. The Camera still didn't work after about an hour of discussions and making computer changes. I was told that I could use a USB cable but I could still use Wi-Fi. I was told that sometimes it takes about 50 or more tries to connect the camera to a computer that uses windows 10. Each try takes about 5 minutes. Forget it. I returned the Camera on February 18th.

column1: I question Canon's comment that the Camera works perfectly on windows 7 - you can't even purchase a computer that uses windows 7. Why does Cannon continue to sell this? Why don't they pull it from the shelves. And why doesn't Best Buy
column3: and other vendors inform their customers that Wi-Fi only works on Windows 7. What a colossal waste of time."^1^Feb 19

column1: Silver^/canon-powershot-elph360-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-purple/4866802?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"The Canon ELPH 360 digital camera is convenient to carry

This is not a camera for sports events but an excellent choice for travelers and family events."^3^Dec 1

I went ahead and ordered a wall charger and two extra batteries to make life easier. Other than that

column15: great features

ZeroStarsIfICould^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-avocado/6367458?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^34^9^"In no scenario does this camera take a single clear photo without SIGNIFICANT grain and slight blur. The shake in videos is jarring. This camera is comparable to something that would have been released in the very early 2000's. I purchased this for the carefree simplicity for on the go fun however it's literally unusable if you have any desire to enjoy your memories. I'd recommend purchasing the HTC re from 2014 even though it's five years old and most likely difficult to find. Do some research and you'll see that the re far surpasses the IVY REC which is mind-blowingly shocking as it's 2019 and we're talking about a camera from Canon. Do your research
column2: this is a 100% unbiased review (I've never previously reviewed a product) but I've been so burned by this I just had to air my disbelief. I guarantee this will be pulled from shelves or never to be seen again after these initial units are severely discounted and sold."^1^Oct 21

column1: Lars^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-avocado/6367458?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^3^"Great item - was unable to try or test it out because it was damaged upon arrival."^1^Dec 6

KLC7^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-avocado/6367458?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^3^"I received this free IVY REC Outdoor Camera (Riptide) to review. I found it to be a great little camera
column2: unbelievably small for all that it can do! I was able to take clear crisp photos as good if not better than my smartphone camera.

column1: What I also found surprising was even though it is advertised as an outdoor camera
column2: it takes great pictures indoors too. There is no flash feature for indoors
column3: but as long as there is light in the room
column4: pictures come out great.

column1: The video option is doable. Not necessarily the best but it does what it says and for those moments when a short video is needed
column2: it is fine. I like the fact that it can all be downloaded to your phone or computer later.

column1: I think this little camera is marketed for younger people for it's usability to travel and rugged exterior. I took photos in the rain without worry. If dropped
column2: it can withstand the pressure. The camera itself has an attachable clip which makes it easy to carry; I clipped mine on my purse strap.

column1: The only drawback I personally had with the camera is trying to open the little door for inserting the  MicroSD card and the cord for the USB port to download and charge. My husband had no problem opening it but I simply couldn't manage it. Perhaps not the best feature if you are older
column2: have arthritis or other issues with strength.

column1: I would recommend this product especially for children when they want a camera of their own but might drop an expensive smartphone when taking a picture."^4^Dec 3

Bev31^/canon-ivy-rec-waterproof-outdoor-digital-camera-avocado/6367458?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^3^"I received this camera fot free in exchange for a review. I like the simplicity of the design overall to make it more 'point and shoot.' The wheel on the back to choose the shooting mode is very easy to use
column2: but does require using a fingernail or something similar so I don't believe it could be turned on by accident. There is no option to review pictures
column3: or to really see the picture before you take it
column4: so how good the picture turns out is based either on luck or by practice. The clip is very nice
column5: and allows the camera to easily be attached to a belt loop for easy access. The accompanying app requires little set up
column6: but after that is pretty easy to use. The app let's you see the photos or videos you've taken and then download them to use elsewhere. I don't appreciate that the app is mandatory in order to have full use of the camera
column7: but I understand that it is part of streamlining the experience so I accept it. Overall it is a nice simple camera for on the go
column8: and it would be nice for people who just want to be able to take quick pictures but aren't worried about professional quality."^4^Dec 3

column1: BlueRidgeGal^/canon-powershot-g5-x-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4608900?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^19^0^"I've tried the Sony RX-100 M2 & Sony RX-100 M3 and loved the image quality in both

column1: 0117^/canon-powershot-g5-x-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4608900?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^14^2^"The Canon G5 X is a great portable alternative to a DSLR. column1: TechMom^/canon-powershot-g5-x-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4608900?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^1^"This is a great camera - it feels and handles a lot like my old Canon G12 that served me well for many years (and which I was seeking to replace). column4: but I felt the G7X was superior for my needs and preferences
column5: particularly low light indoor action shots (basketball). I also think the G7X produces richer tones and colors - more of the Canon 'pop' with high saturation that I prefer. These differences were very subtle
column6: but those were the deciding factors for me personally. Both cameras are great though
column7: and it really just comes down to preference. If you prefer an actual viewfinder

column1: ayleen^/canon-powershot-g5-x-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4608900?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I recently started a blog and a vlog so I decided to downsize from my Canon T6i to a point and shoot camera

column1: 1koa^/canon-powershot-g5-x-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4608900?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I bought this for travel use mainly. I found that a much higher percentage of my shots were keepers compared to my point and shoots
column6: almost on par with my dslr. Fit and finish of this all metal beauty makes it look and feel like it should cost a great deal more than it does. Better than some of the DSLR's out there. It feels good in my hand

column1: lyndsie^/polaroid-pop-20-0-megapixel-digital-camera-green/6090004?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^1^"saying that it is easy to turn the polaroid pop into a printer for your phone is literally the most wrong description of this product. Even loading the paper took me so long because I thought you had to push the paper in all the way and for the longest time the camera kept reading that it was out of paper. LUCKILY I stumbled upon a discussion that states you have to put the paper ALMOST all the way in for it to be sensed by the camera. There is not one thing in the 'user manual' that even talks about that. who would've known that automatically? The camera comes with something they call a 'user manual' in reality all it is
column2: is a quick start up guide that is very
column3: very vague. It gives you no information on connecting the camera to your phone through wifi and the app which is probably the most complicated aspect of this camera. I tried calling their 1800 technical support number and it is closed until January 2
column4: what type of 1800 isn't 24/7/365? especially when Im sure they would be the busiest since so many people probably bought this product for Christmas. For the $200 it would probably be in your best interest to just buy a portable printer and a cheap grade instant camera. Also if you're someone who googles for answers
column5: good luck trying to find any answer on how to set this thing up. They're non existant. I did get ahold of the geek squad but the had to apologize because there was not one suggestion they could give me to help except wait until the polaroid tech support opens on jan 2. I really hope this saves atleast one person from the utter frustration that this instant camera is."^2^Dec 30

column1: Samuel^/polaroid-pop-20-0-megapixel-digital-camera-green/6090004?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^19^15^"I was so excited to get this camera. Software-adjusted photos look good on a large screen TV

column1: Setting the metering mode to SPOT and setting i-resolution to HIGH sometimes helps image quality. Shooting photos in Aperture Mode #as opposed to Auto# typically didn't improve Image Quality

column1: barry^/panasonic-dmc-fz1000-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/1206401?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Like it. mesess^/panasonic-dmc-fz1000-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/1206401?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Bought this camera shortly before taking a trip to the DC/Maryland/New York area so there wasn't much time to get comfortable with it but I have to say it was easy to get accustomed to the controls and ergonomics. At first it seems like a pretty large camera but it is actually really light and easy to carry when walking around. The convenience of not having to carry extra lenses also helped a great deal in that regard. My girlfriend is pretty small and has small hands and she was comfortable using it for long periods of time while walking around the city. She's also more of a beginner photographer so she spent most of her time on the auto modes but the photos came out great none the less. The 25-400mm reach is sufficiently wide angled while also giving you the zoom you need to capture details you might not have otherwise been able to. The image stabilization worked great and allowed for sharp pictures even when fully extended. One major concern with fixed lens long zoom cameras is the low-light performance but I was pleasantly surprised by the performance of this camera. I was able to walk around New York at night and photograph camera buildings
column3: and even managed to take some pictures inside a nice restaurant thanks to the silent shutter feature. Performed really well at higher ISO for fixed lens without a fixed aperture. I'm still working on mastering the camera but from what I've seen this camera is a great buy especially in this price range. It's a great camera for travel due to its convenience and also accommodates both beginners and avid photographers alike. I would highly recommend this over other super zoom cameras in this price range and even some more expensive cameras."^5^Apr 9

column1: DomC^/panasonic-dmc-fz1000-20-1-megapixel-digital-camera-black/1206401?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"The FZ1000 is a great camera for taking good photos. column2: I found that this is a common complaint with this camera. The sound is due to the 5 axis vibration stabilization system that is used. This can be an annoyance when taking videos in a quiet environment because it is picked up by the built-in mic. An external mic may solve the problem. For the features it provides
column3: it is well worth the price when compared with similar bridge cameras offering features like a 1 inch 20 meg sensor but lacking some of its other features like 4K video. I gave it only 4 stars due to the whirring sound."^4^Apr 29

Techmaster^/canon-powershot-g9-x-20-2-megapixel-digital-camera-black/4608700?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^48^2^"My objective was a small camera that would deliver high quality photos at a reasonable price. I was able to get a super deal
column3: so I bought the camera but even at the $449 price
column4: it is still reasonable for a 1 inch sensor camera. With the great deal
column5: I bought a 3 year extended warranty with accident protection and an extra battery. I also picked up a Lowerpro case which is just slightly bigger than the camera so it is still pockeable. I am an active amateur photographer but can't always bring my Canon SLR. I always like to have a camera with me besides my cell phone. My iPhone does a great job but there are times when you want or need a regular camera. This is the niche of the Canon 9GX. I was hesitant at first because many functions are accessible by touchscreen exclusively but it has not been a problem and in some ways it is easier to access the controls.

column1: The low light performance is excellent and is a rather bright lens at f2.8 but as you zoom in that does change. The photos are very sharp
column3: and vibrant. The videos are also excellent. I use mainly the P mode but I do use Shutter Priority and Aperture Priority every so often to achieve certain effects
column4: For example
column5: when photographing water such as a fountain
column6: or stream and want to emphasis slow motion or stop motion I will set the shutter speed. I will use Aperture Priority to control depth of field. However
column7: the camera does a good job of depth of field.

column1: This camera in a small form factor gives you full manual control. The camera does not have a viewfinder or articulating screen which would have been an asset. I have had no trouble seeing the screen in bright sunlight and have also taken selfies as well.
I highly recommend this camera. It delivers. If i had bought a bigger or heavier camera or more expensive that was not pocketable....it would be sitting home a lot.
I trusted this camera for my daughter' s wedding and small grandkids and I have gotten superior results. The upgrade to this is the Canon G7X Mark ii which is excellent
column2: but still no viewfinder but it will set you back a few hundred dollars more and is bigger and heavier. I have used the camera too and I love it. It does edge out the Canon G9X but the G9X is excellent too. I also wanted an everyday camera that i could throw in my bag and by the time I added extended warranty and accessories to the G 7X Mark ii it would cost 1000 dollars and i could not justify that for an everyday camera. That is when I decided on the G9X which takes excellent photos and is smaller and lighter.The camera has a 3X zoom ratio which is adequate for everyday photography. I have used the digital zoom and was very surprised at the great results. I have other cameras with great zoom capabilty so it was not an issue for me.

column1: AlaskaJaxx^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-v-21-0-megapixel-digital-camera/5655631?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^25^6^"...either your DSLR ...or your iPhone/S7 or smartphone
column3: of choice!

column1: I owned the first and second version of the RX100 and they're still working well and never an issue or repairs needed. It's a special camera to be sure. I'm fine with the menu system and the way Sony has laid their options out for many years. That said
column2: a camera like this and with the 'power' and potential available... I'd happily take a 30-50% increase in mass to allow a more functional 'rear end' - with the addition of another control wheel or joystick and possibly another option for quick access to common settings to change while shooting.

column1: I've missed a few shots because of this but I blame me. I'm aware of the 'cons' (the extremely few that exist) and I should've anticipated
column2: set up and would've been able to get the shot. I own a 5d mk4 as well
column3: the original 5D before that as well as the first Canon 7D and recent upgrade to the mkII

column1: My wife
column2: son and I love the outdoors and photography/videography is the perfect compliment to a day or a week in the woods of Alaska!

column1: We all enjoy photography and video capture as hobbies and have recently learned to fly drones for a ver y cool perspective.

As owners of smartphones (we're an Apple family and prefer iPhones) we often shoot with them and using or carrying the RX is nearly as convenient as throwing a smartphone in the pocket - but it's shots and it's abilities with both still and motion capture are as extensive as any DSLR. They're just tough to access at the right time sometimes.

I've owned the model long enough to realize those special shots are best 'grabbed' using 'auto' or program as the intelligence of the ISP is phenomenal!! Awesome captures from auto mode and easily one of
column3: THE fastest camera I've ever shot!

column1: In some of the fastest modes - you'll sacrifice resolution but not at the silly speeds advertised. They're REAL!! I'm floored sometimes with the speeds and tend to shoot with a lower setting as just a  second click'll net ya a dozen shots!

Lastly the video capture is unbelievable quality for this small a package. The one inch sensor is massive in comparison to the current smartphone offerings and most small point and shoot cameras. Hence the expense. It's not cheap and if it's great photos you're after the V2-v4 models are still exceptional. And available at a LOT less cash. But I'm seriously impressed with the upgrades and continued bright lens and ability awesome files I'm continually getting from the camera and wouldn't hesitate to recommend to a beginner or professional alike as it's a lot lighter than the 5d4 w/70-200 and associated gear - yet the right conditions allow for 90-95% of the quality of the $5
column2: 000 DSLR -- and it fits in any pocket!"^5^Feb 1

column1: Drumdestroyer^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-v-21-0-megapixel-digital-camera/5655631?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^14^1^"I bought this camera to be able to carry it around in my pocket and record 4k video. It records great 4k video but overheats after 5+ min and runs out of battery in 10-15 min. Plan to get multiple extra batteries and to take breaks between. Recording 5 min 4k video clips. Great vlogging camera. Low light pics and video are amazing. Time lapsees are amazing but you have to buy a separate $10 app to use timelapse. Which seems like nickle and diming after paying $1000 for the camera"^4^Jan 16

column1: RonRon^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-v-21-0-megapixel-digital-camera/5655631?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"I thought I wanted a DSLR camera. However

column1: Pinkpearls^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-v-21-0-megapixel-digital-camera/5655631?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"It's pocket sized. Love it more than my Sony A6000. I just leave it in the car and keep it in the side pocket. Bought extra batteries as shooting videos in 4K takes up a lot of juice."^5^Feb 3

Mangino^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-v-21-0-megapixel-digital-camera/5655631?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^2^"I wanted something less bulky than my current DSLR but yet is very capable. So I decided on a compact. Compacts have come a long way over the last few years and the Mark V is a great example of an extremely capable compact camera. The picture quality is superb and has a plethora of features you normally only find on high end DSLR cameras. What really distinquishes the Mark V from all other current compacts is the 1' sensor with phase detection autofocus. It's currently the fastest and most accurate autofocus on the market for a compact (as of this review) and competes with high end DSLR cameras.

If you're a pro currently using a DSLR and looking for an excellent compact to supplement or even replace your DSLR you should definitely give this camera a good hard look. And for the novice or experienced photographer that wants a camera that's less bulky yet easy to handle and operate but are not willing to sacrifice picture quality (like me) then this just might be the camera for you if it fits into your budget.
I'm very happy with my purchase and look forward to many years of enjoyment with my Mark V."^5^Dec 15

tyxiao^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-v-21-0-megapixel-digital-camera/5655631?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"The image quality is excellent considering it's small size. I can not distinguish the photograph between this and my 5D Mark III when shoot in daylight. When in dark
column2: it can capture beautiful stars and even milky way

column1: JustMyView^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-v-21-0-megapixel-digital-camera/5655631?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Overall
column2: I am very pleased with the camera. Pictures are clear and it is so small it really does fit in my pocket. I take it out on walks or when heading some place with the kids. It works great for landscapes
column3: flowers
column4: sunsets etc. The focus system is great and it has lots of options
column5: so the little bit of portrait and street shooting I have done has been easy. Using it for kids sports
column6: the very fast frame rates makes it easy to 'spray and pray' and end up with decent shots. And I am only using the medium setting.

column1: Of course
column2: with a camera this size there are limitations. I have used it for photos of soccer and fencing
column3: but the short reach on the lens is limiting. Same with wildlife - good pictures of deer in back yard or birds sitting still
column4: but you can't get birds in flight or a rabbit at distance. The small size also means the controls are close together. Finally
column5: it is not great in darker settings due to the one inch sensor. ISO pushes up high in those settings. The pictures you get in those darker situations are OK for a social media post or Christmas card small pic
column6: but not outstanding. Shooting in RAW and post processing helps some
column7: but it won't replace a much bigger
column8: more expensive multi-lens camera.

column1: Despite the limitations
column2: it is way easier to take along and I end up getting a lot more pics from it then from a bigger set up. And as my wife has said
column3: the pictures blow away what we were getting from our Iphones."^5^Jun 4

column1: ZEUStheDJ^/sony-cyber-shot-rx100-v-21-0-megapixel-digital-camera/5655631?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"First I use this mostly for vlogging so for this it is near perfect. Only gripe is that the mount hole on the bottom makes it impossible to put any type of mounting plate on it because it is directly next to the hinge of the battery door. There is a slight crop when using more than the standard (active and active+) stabilization in 1080p mode. You can only get basic stabilization in 4k but there is no crop which is good. Over heating is definitely an issue when shooting in 4k. Indicator light comes on around the 3 minute mark
column2: and cap limit on 4k shooting is 5 minutes. Battery in 4k is bad too
column3: so get an extra battery or two. Slow motion on this is dope
column4: when used in the lower settings like 240fps or 480fps which looks ok in 1080p. Above that you are entering 480p-like video quality. Low light video quality surprised me for being a 1'sensor!

column1: For picture taking
column2: the camera has good dynamic range but I'm not a photographer so don't take my word for it. I come from using the Sony A6300 and bought this for its compactness.

column1: Hope this helps!"^5^Mar 17

column1: lyndsie^/polaroid-pop-20-0-megapixel-digital-camera-white/6090000?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^1^"saying that it is easy to turn the polaroid pop into a printer for your phone is literally the most wrong description of this product. I have been trying to connect my phone to the camera through the polaroid pop app for almost 5 hours. Even loading the paper took me so long because I thought you had to push the paper in all the way and for the longest time the camera kept reading that it was out of paper. LUCKILY I stumbled upon a discussion that states you have to put the paper ALMOST all the way in for it to be sensed by the camera. There is not one thing in the 'user manual' that even talks about that. who would've known that automatically? The camera comes with something they call a 'user manual' in reality all it is
column2: is a quick start up guide that is very
column3: very vague. It gives you no information on connecting the camera to your phone through wifi and the app which is probably the most complicated aspect of this camera. I tried calling their 1800 technical support number and it is closed until January 2
column4: what type of 1800 isn't 24/7/365? especially when Im sure they would be the busiest since so many people probably bought this product for Christmas. For the $200 it would probably be in your best interest to just buy a portable printer and a cheap grade instant camera. Also if you're someone who googles for answers
column5: good luck trying to find any answer on how to set this thing up. They're non existant. I did get ahold of the geek squad but the had to apologize because there was not one suggestion they could give me to help except wait until the polaroid tech support opens on jan 2. I really hope this saves atleast one person from the utter frustration that this instant camera is."^2^Dec 30

column1: lyndsie^/polaroid-pop-20-0-megapixel-digital-camera-yellow/6090003?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^1^"saying that it is easy to turn the polaroid pop into a printer for your phone is literally the most wrong description of this product. Even loading the paper took me so long because I thought you had to push the paper in all the way and for the longest time the camera kept reading that it was out of paper. LUCKILY I stumbled upon a discussion that states you have to put the paper ALMOST all the way in for it to be sensed by the camera. There is not one thing in the 'user manual' that even talks about that. who would've known that automatically? The camera comes with something they call a 'user manual' in reality all it is
column2: is a quick start up guide that is very
column3: very vague. It gives you no information on connecting the camera to your phone through wifi and the app which is probably the most complicated aspect of this camera. I tried calling their 1800 technical support number and it is closed until January 2
column4: what type of 1800 isn't 24/7/365? especially when Im sure they would be the busiest since so many people probably bought this product for Christmas. For the $200 it would probably be in your best interest to just buy a portable printer and a cheap grade instant camera. Also if you're someone who googles for answers
column5: good luck trying to find any answer on how to set this thing up. They're non existant. I did get ahold of the geek squad but the had to apologize because there was not one suggestion they could give me to help except wait until the polaroid tech support opens on jan 2. I really hope this saves atleast one person from the utter frustration that this instant camera is."^2^Dec 30

column1: lyndsie^/polaroid-pop-20-0-megapixel-digital-camera-pink/6090001?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^1^"saying that it is easy to turn the polaroid pop into a printer for your phone is literally the most wrong description of this product. I have been trying to connect my phone to the camera through the polaroid pop app for almost 5 hours. Even loading the paper took me so long because I thought you had to push the paper in all the way and for the longest time the camera kept reading that it was out of paper. LUCKILY I stumbled upon a discussion that states you have to put the paper ALMOST all the way in for it to be sensed by the camera. There is not one thing in the 'user manual' that even talks about that. who would've known that automatically? The camera comes with something they call a 'user manual' in reality all it is
column2: is a quick start up guide that is very
column3: very vague. It gives you no information on connecting the camera to your phone through wifi and the app which is probably the most complicated aspect of this camera. I tried calling their 1800 technical support number and it is closed until January 2
column4: what type of 1800 isn't 24/7/365? especially when Im sure they would be the busiest since so many people probably bought this product for Christmas. For the $200 it would probably be in your best interest to just buy a portable printer and a cheap grade instant camera. Also if you're someone who googles for answers
column5: good luck trying to find any answer on how to set this thing up. They're non existant. I did get ahold of the geek squad but the had to apologize because there was not one suggestion they could give me to help except wait until the polaroid tech support opens on jan 2. I really hope this saves atleast one person from the utter frustration that this instant camera is."^2^Dec 30

column1: Samuel^/polaroid-pop-20-0-megapixel-digital-camera-pink/6090001?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^19^15^"I was so excited to get this camera. I actually went back to BestBuy exchanged it for another brand new one and the quality was still complete ****. It shocks me that this product has ONLY positive reviews. column2: it wouldnt. I tried reseting it and charging it but nothing. I returned the second one and tried one more time. The third one turned on and printed pictures well. I turned it off and it never turned back on again. I wanted so badly for this camera to work but it simply doesnt. I think they should recall this product and start over. I ended up getting a Fuji camera and printer. Theyve worked well so far and they print onto actual Polaroid style paper instead of the zink gloss paper which is also not what I invisioned. column1: Eli90^/canon-eos-m50-mirrorless-camera-with-ef-m-15-45mm-f-3-5-6-3-is-stm-zoom-lens-black/6204310?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^47^16^"First off i will say i am not a Professional Photographer but i do Have Knowledge of Specs and i am using the M50 for Indoor shooting in Harsh Lighting that Tends to wash out my cell phone Quality.
I recently purchased the Canon G7X Mark ii and in the Short Few Days i was able to use it i Liked it alot
column2: but on the Day the Canon M50 Mirrorless Came out i went into my local Best buy to check it out
column3: it was limited quantity and not on display i asked to see what it looked like and read up on all the specs i knew i wanted it
column4: so i Exchanged my G7X for the M50
column5: for the Extra money that i put toward the M50 i was able to get some Cool Features Software and Hardware Wise. I love the Fact that i have options now for Other Lenses
column6: the stock Lense with IS works Great. Auto Focus with more Points is also a Plus. The Body of the Camera with out the Lense feels a bit plastic and i was concerned at first unboxing even compared to the way the G7X tough Build felt but as soon as i put the M50 Lense on it didn't matter as much and also helps in Making this Camera Compact and lightweight. In Hands the M50 Feels Very Comfortable in my Opinion. I know there are Complaints about th 4K Crop but i did not care and would much rather shoot in 1080p and have no use for 4K. I Purchased this Camera for Quality Photos and Ease of Transfering to Smartphone to Social Media and It does exactly that with the Canon Connect app and the new Auto Transfer Feature is Pretty cool. The Photo Quality is Crisp and Vibrant and some Great Features such as Background Blurring
column7: built in Filters etc... One Great Hardware Feature is Having the Hi resolution EVF (ElectronicViewFinder) it's Beautiful and fluid to work with and an Awesome Feature for Bright days when the LCD can Give some Glare. I could go on about other cool Features but i will conclude with this
column8: for the Price i know you can get a Full Size DSLR but if you're looking for Compactbuild
column9: QualityPhotos
column10: GreatVideos
column11: interchangable Lenses
column12: and all around Fun to Use Camera You won't Be disappointed i know im Definitely not and i made the Right choice."^5^Apr 6

column1: T535^/canon-eos-m50-mirrorless-camera-with-ef-m-15-45mm-f-3-5-6-3-is-stm-zoom-lens-black/6204310?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^22^0^"So this may not be the absolutly best specs on a camera
column2: but its a bit cheaper then some of the other mirrorless out there at the moment. But this isn't all about the specs for me
column3: its very easy to use and just pick up and go but still has the options to adjust and change what you need.

column1: - size and form - This is probably smaller then some of you may want but if your looking for something small and the still feels sturdy. I like this camera and I wish they made a battery grip for it. Now this fits my hands good and will be going every where I can take it which is a lot because its much smaller then others I have.
- features - The flip screen is a full touch screen and it works great
column2: this cameras screen is sensitive and works when you touch to focus or select in the menus. Auto focus works great I never really worry about it finding my face or not being in focus and if I want to check the screen flips out to adjust from all sides! I think there are some that won't like the menus and button layout but for the quick little shooter I wanted the auto select knob for present makes it very fast and easy to not search around for things on screen
column3: then in each of those there are very easy on screen menus that pop up with out having to leave the screen your looking at the photo or video with. Now there is some custom feature and great shooting modes like RAW + jpeg and its got wifi and bluetooth
column4: that will link to my phone for cool viewing through your cell phone to use the camera even if your not beside it. This comes in very handy and makes things like taking a quick review photo moving it to my phone or laptop
column5: editing it then posting or using that photo where ever I need it.

column1: - lens selection- this is where the camera with this m mount miss out a little bit and I wish they made a lot more native lenses for this camera
column2: but it doesn't get knocked down because you can get an adapter and use your other EF and EF-s lenses. So that gives it a great selection to choose from and even the EF-M lens are pretty good that I have tried so far and keep it small and light weight!

column1: - battery life- I might get on here and say the full amount by the shot or hour it does but I haven't had time to test it so far and I just got an extra battery and I don't have problems with it dying very fast. Along with that these are also small and easy to take so you can just throw your extra in any pocket on your bag or back pack and it should fit.

- Photo and video - Im not going to get technical with this because its just a review for people looking to buy and if you want specs and things go to you tube. But this camera to me takes great video right out of the box even with the kit lens. On top of taking great video the photos are really good as well and it does much better in low light then I thought it would! But I'm pretty sure its got the Digic 8 processor which is a bit newer then some out right now so that probably helps. The photos have been pretty easy to use and edit along with being able to set the video the way you want it on the camera most the time and not having to edit in post much to get it looking good.
One bad but doesn't matter to me the 4k has not got the same auto focus as the 1080 but it still has some type of focus
column2: but it still works and I think some would be happy with this all I can say is the colors looked good when I tried it. But I would test this out for your self and for me right now the 4k takes up way to much space and the 1080 looks great with this little thing to me.

column1: Now for pros I can't say get it for sure but I wouldn't over look it just because of others saying bad things about the 4k or something sill because its so easy to use and fun on top off that and last but most important of all it has a great price I think most people can afford and will make me feel much safer with being rough on it because I know the body of the camera doesn't cost crazy amounts to replace!
Either way I like it and would recommend you guys at least check it out and it would be a good back up and travel camera as well.
** by the way those photos I put with it my not be the best but I was just showing how it does in low light with the enjoy photo
column2: and with the detail on that out side shot with no filter**"^5^Oct 24

column1: mennioo^/canon-eos-m50-mirrorless-camera-with-ef-m-15-45mm-f-3-5-6-3-is-stm-zoom-lens-black/6204310?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^23^3^"I bought this exclusively for Youtube videos. I originally shoot with a Nikon D850 and am very comfortable with DSLR's of the professional kind. I do want to mention that this camera has a 24MP APS-C CMOS sensor which means it is a cropped sensor. The fact that this is mirror-less means it is amazing for videos. Mirror-less cameras are made to be smaller and lighter and generally better for video. The facts that the camera has Canon's amazing DPAF (Dual Pixel Auto-Focus)
column2: makes this great for focusing on faces blazing fast. This camera albeit small and compact
column3: has some downfalls. My review is solely based on my experience with editing videos and pictures. I usually like to shoot 4K since I do a lot of nature shoots
column4: I want to give this an honest review. First and foremost
column5: it has a pretty great stabilizer for walking and filming. Shooting at 1080p 60 fps
column6: you can get some nice smooth slow motion shots when edited in post. The lens that it comes with is a 15-45 mm which is not the best in my opinion for photography or videos
column7: it is a great introductory camera for any beginner to enjoy and the ease of use makes it that much better. Now for the 4k video
column8: it does have a crop factor and only shoots at 24 fps. 24 fps gives it a pretty nice cinematic look but the crop factor is what kind of ruins it. It has a 1.7x crop which means that you're gonna need a wide angle lens in order to get a bigger picture (Downside- This camera uses special lenses and there isn't a huge variety out there). The other downside is that at 4K
column9: it loses the DPAF that I mentioned above. At 720p you can shoot up to 120fps which means SUPER SLOW MOTION... Which is awesome in my opinion. You do lose some resolution but anyone getting introduced into the DSLR world
column10: this is the way to go. It isn't a 1DX Mark II
column11: or a Sony Alpha 7R II
column12: but you get what you pay for and get some great quality videos and pictures. I immediately took it off what I like to call 'beginner mode' and start shooting in manual. But I perused beginner mode and it was very user friendly. I'd definitely look into this if you want to get into the awesome world of DSLR's. I know There's a lot of key points I missed but when I look at reviews what I mentioned above is what I mostly look for just to keep it short and sweet. I'm also not going to scrutinize it and compare it to a professional camera worth thousands of dollars. I knew what I was getting myself into so I'd definitely recommend this to a newcomer."^5^May 9

column2: I'm old school) and this camera is making it easy. EVERYTHING else about this camera makes it the best value for exactly what I need - a lightweight
column3: mirrorless (WITH a viewfinder!!) camera with excellent photo and video specs
column4: a great kit lens
column5: a side-oriented viewing screen that doesn't interfere with any other function of the camera
column6: an external mic jack
column7: enough valuable accessories to make up for anything that other reviewers have found lacking (they are comparing this camera to others that cost hundreds if not thousands more
column8: which amplifies the value of this camera that much more!!)
column9: outrageously good auto-focus
column10: and the perfect video specs allowing me to make high quality videos that I plan to turn into DVDs to sell as part of my presentations. I need 1080p60fps and this camera does that brilliantly! I love this camera!! I'm not knowledgeable enough to know what it's 'missing' (for someone who is/wants to be a professional vlogger) but you can find their reviews on line. It has everything that I need; lightweight
column11: small profile
column12: easy to navigate touch screen menus
column13: with tutorials on the essentials right inside the camera
column14: AND I can use my older Canon EF lenses on this camera with a reasonably priced adaptor. My only complaint is that every once in a while I need to eat and get some sleep! Otherwise
column15: I'd be filming with this great camera 24 hours a day!!"^5^Apr 20

Tina^/canon-eos-m50-mirrorless-camera-with-ef-m-15-45mm-f-3-5-6-3-is-stm-zoom-lens-black/6204310?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This is my 2nd camera (next to my 5d mark 4)
column2: I wanted a camera that gives me amazing photos without all the bulk. I tried a couple of the Sony cameras and thought their images were washed out and not as sharp as I wanted. I researched this gem and watched YouTube videos- this was the one for me. I went into the store and once it was in my hands it just felt right. I loved the dials. I loved the options this thing has. I ordered the better lens option- I took this on vacation and was able to effortlessly send the images to my iPhone for immediate sharing. This camera also has a smaller lossless compressed raw file option! The screen tilts. It has a super fun and easy to access double exposure option. You can be full manual or full auto. Keep the guide handy because this powerhouse has a lot to learn even for experienced shooters
column3: that are more about learning this particular system. Such as
column4: I couldnt get my pop up flash to fire no matter what I did- but later learned it wont flash on silent mode! So I had to change that and it fixed it. I recommend this camera to everyone!! The images are beautiful
column5: colorful
column6: tack sharp with great bokeh when used."^5^May 18

column1: LC4508^/canon-eos-m50-mirrorless-camera-with-ef-m-15-45mm-f-3-5-6-3-is-stm-zoom-lens-black/6204310?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I purchased this camera as a replacement to my Canon - EOS M3 Mirrorless camera
column2: which had to be returned due to factory defect. I loved that camera too; so
column3: I was really sad to let it go. However
column4: I turned my frown upside down and purchased this model above it. I knew in whatever decision I made
column5: the replacement needed to have a few more capabilities that the M3 didn't have. And luckily
column6: the M50 fit the bill.

column1: The selling point was a full
column3: vari-angle (rotational) touchscreen - the M3 only had limited moveability with the touchscreen. Another selling point was the viewfinder. Honestly
column4: it was the MAIN reason why I purchased this camera because as an original user of the Nikon D70s
column5: I am fairly old fashioned when it comes to shooting. I love a good viewfinder but I also love to have the capability to shoot using the screen. So
column6: I appreciated that the M50 had this feature. And lastly
column7: it has the ability to record/shoot in 4K. Those 3 features alone had me SOLD.

column1: It's only been a couple of months
column2: and though I am still learning my way around the camera
column3: I am very pleased. It is easy to use (even has the option to turn on and off tips). It shoots clearly. Has the ability to use traditional canon lenses with the addition of an adapter. I'll really get to test out its muscle power on my upcoming trip to Puerto Rico and see how well the battery life fairs because I did read reviews that the battery life is not as strong as it is in other models. So
column4: while I am abroad
column5: I'll see how well it fairs. Outside of that
column6: I am happy with the purchase and would recommend this model to anyone looking for something lighter and smaller but with full capabilities of a traditional DSLR. It's also a great camera for beginners dabbling in the art of photography but wants something a bit more powerful than a normal point and shoot camera."^5^May 16

column2: the Canon EOS M50 is a good value for those seeking an entry-level camera. Although it is not fully competitive with some more expensive mirrorless APS-C cameras
column3: it is a capable
column4: compact camera which produces very good results. It has many advanced features that can be used by more experienced photographers
column5: but these are mostly embedded in the menus. Its primary weakness
column6: given the mirrorless competition
column7: is that it lacks in-body image stabilization and does not have as many lens choices as some other mirrorless manufacturers. Nevertheless
column8: it is a very good entry-level camera. For the future
column9: it would be good to see Canon and Nikon get more serious about mirrorless camera products. Overall
column10: they seem to be lagging behind the competition in this market."^4^Jul 21

column1: BarnDweller^/canon-eos-m50-mirrorless-camera-with-ef-m-15-45mm-f-3-5-6-3-is-stm-zoom-lens-black/6204310?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^9^"I purchased this camera for some work projects and personal use. I was getting ready to record my Grand Daughters play she has the lead in at school this weekend. I purchased a external mic and was testing the camera because I was worried about my 128 gig card not being large enough to record the just over a hour play. The camera kept turning off at 30 min. Battery is fine. I did a google search and wish I would have before I purchased it. The camera is limited for 30 min max record time. What a joke.

My other problem is the manual they include with the camera is TINY many pages but its only like 4x5 inches and TINY letters. Now everyone buying these are 18-25 years old with great eyes some of us are in our 60's with less than perfect eyes."^2^Apr 24

Novicecameragirl^/canon-eos-m50-mirrorless-camera-with-ef-m-15-45mm-f-3-5-6-3-is-stm-zoom-lens-black/6204310?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^7^"I purchased this camera a day prior to me traveling to Africa
column2: for the first time in my interior life! I was excited to take better pictures than I get with my phone. However
column3: My experience was far
column4: far from enjoyable using this camera.  First
column5: I mislead by the sales associate who told me I could use my existing canon lens with this camera (lies). I was also interested in this camera for the LCD screen. The LCD screen on the Canon M50 can flip to The front. To use the flash feature
column6: you manually need to flip the lens light up; this featured should be automatic.

column1: For the price
column2: youre unable to take fast moving or action photo
column3: the quality is poor; the flash is not automatic."^1^Nov 16

column1: Brian^/sony-alpha-a6400-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/6324856?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^17^3^"I shot on Nikon for years before moving into Sony mirrorless.

I currently own an a6000 and an a7ii and am very familiar with them. I was looking for something to shoot video with (specifically YouTube and interview videos) so I liked that this didnt have the 30 minute limit. I had no clue how many advances had been made since the a6000 was released. I try to avoid new camera info because it always leads to me getting excited and buying one.

The flip up screen is great and I love being able to monitor myself while recording. I know you can always add a monitor to other cameras (I even own one) but when I have a video idea I want to get it going as quickly. That means I usually forgo looking for the monitor and hoping Im in the shot correctly.

The videos have come out INCREDIBLE so far and Im beyond happy with the purchase. The only thing Im not excited for is re-configuring all of my custom buttons and menus but thats the case with any new camera and if thats my biggest issue then life is pretty good :)
If you own an a6000 or are looking for a camera that does both video and photography really well then definitely give this a good

If you're sitting there with an a6300 or a6500 then the decision to upgrade (or is it sidegrade?) is a little trickier. Go to a camera store and test it out... if you love the a6300 then youll absolutely love this camera but if you have the a6300 then you most likely dont *need* this camera. If that makes any sense."^5^Mar 7
Stan^/sony-alpha-a6400-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/6324856?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"The A6400 replaced an A6000
column2: which I was very pleased with.  I upgraded to the A6400 because of the advances in AF
column3: mainly the addition of tracking and both human and animal eye focus.  The animal eye focus feature does
column4: at this point
column5: require a simple online firmware update.

column1: The pros with this camera are its compact size and light weight
column3: very usable EVF
column4: very good low light performance
column5: and overall fine image quality.  That
column6: plus the advanced AF features
column7: make for a formidable little camera.

column1: The downside is that it may be too small for larger hands
column2: and definitely does not balance well with larger
column3: heavier lenses.  Although improved
column4: Sony menus are not what I would call intuitive.  The manual that comes with the camera is very basic
column5: and really leaves much to the new owner to figure things out.  Also
column6: as with most mirrorless designs
column7: battery life is relatively poor.

column1: So
column2: if you're looking for a carry camera that doesnt require a padded shoulder strap because of its weight
column3: and want the image quality of an APS-C sensor
column4: the A6400 may be a perfect fit.  Just expect to spend some time with the menus
column5: and a lot of time online figuring out how to set it up so you can take advantage of its many features."^4^Aug 9

column1: Gerry^/sony-alpha-a6400-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/6324856?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"Its basically an upgrade on the a6300 and while it does not have IBIS like the a6500
column2: its a much better performing camera in AF. It will also has no recording limit and does not overheat as fast as the a6500. It may last 5 to 6 times longer than the a6500 before it shuts down about 2-2.5 hrs. I had 2 Canon 70d and had the a6300. although the a6300 had the continuous eye AF in photos it did not match Canons dual pixel AF in video. But now I can truly say that the a6400 surpassed the Canons AF."^5^Mar 29

column1: Picoluvx19^/sony-alpha-a6400-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/6324856?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Hey guys Im new with this Sony camera and Im just going to say wow I love it a lot Im so happy with my product it take good pictures and 4K videos :) Im so happy"^5^Jun 5
Evelyn^/sony-alpha-a6400-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/6324856?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Pros:
-light weight
-the viewfinder is on the side opposed to the center (a7's) which I like because my face oils don't smudge the screen
-weather sealed
- auto focus is very fast
cons:
NO IBS! but just make sure your lens does and problem solved!)
battery life sucks
I don't mind the 'hot shoe being in front of the flip up screen' because there are work arounds like the hot shoe mountain that has double hot shoes (center and left/right)
Pretty user friendly considering it is my first Sony!"^5^May 20

TheEdge^/sony-alpha-a6400-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/6324856?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Been doing a lot of reviews of many of the new cameras. Wanted one that would provide excellent focus and 4k video. The 6400 was a lot less money than I was willing to spend
column2: which allowed me to get more lenses and a gimbal and still spent less than many other brands or models. Such a great value.

column1: Once my wife and I started to take pictures and video
column2: I found the camera went way beyond expectations for this price point. 10 frames per second of fast moving objects and found 95% perfect focus on what should have been in focus. If your willing to increase the iso in low light
column3: even better percentage of in focus! And the higher iso looks really good."^5^Mar 25

column1: Gerry^/sony-alpha-a6400-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/6324856?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^1^"I used the a6300 and the a7iii and the a6000. I sued to have the 2Canon 70d used for photos and videos during my kids concert. was not really impressed with the a6000 AF. but when the a6300 with the continous EyE AF i was blown away by the accuracy. i then started to sell my canon gear to save for the a7r2. but then the a7r3 came out and the the a73. i settled for the a73 which is much better than the a6300 as far as AF. then i purchased the a6400 and its like night and day as far as AF tracking in photos and video. so now im waiting for the next gen Sony cameras which will have all this new features. No more 30minute video recording restrictions and much better af tracking that surpass the canon dual pixel AF. I just hope sony upgrades the touch screen for better Touch AF experience like canons. also sonys overheating issue is kinda fix. it will probably record 5-6 times longer than the a6300 before yu get the overheating icon."^5^Mar 22
Sean^/sony-alpha-a6400-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/6324856?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I've been waiting for the mysterious A7SIII to come out with no luck
column2: so I grabbed one of these in the mean time. Does great in low light
column3: has an articulating LCD screen and it compact in size. I with the touch screen did a little more. The battery life is meh. The video record button is in a horrible spot. But that aside
column4: it's a great little camera."^4^Nov 22

column1: Vaporswift^/sony-alpha-a6400-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/6324856?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This camera is powerful with 4K 24fps and flexibility to also shoot 1080 120fps for really solid slomo. column1: Thatstaindphotographyguy^/sony-alpha-a7-iii-mirrorless-video-camera-with-fe-28-70-mm-f3-5-5-6-oss-lens/6213100?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^32^2^"I purchased the last generation A7ii back in 2015 and loved the camera. Not because it was perfect but rather because I saw where it was going and its potential. Coming fronm the Canon 6D
column3: the feature set was more robust
column4: and I knew that mirrorless was the future of photography so I decided to become an early adopter.

column1: The biggest issues I had with the A7ii model was the slow autofocus speeds as compared to the A7Rii
column2: the lack of continuous eye autofocus
column3: and a single memory card slot. Sure
column4: there were a few minor others
column5: but nothing that I couldn't live with. Fast forward three years to the announcement of the A7iii; Sony literally fixed EVERY problem I had with the a7ii...and then some.

column1: Is this a perfect camera? No
column2: that doesn't exist. Is it close to the perfect camera for me? Yes
column3: indeed! I don't need the 42 megapixels of the A7Riii. I don't need the low-light capabilities of the soon-to-be-released A7Siii. The A9 is a great camera but the benefits of the superior buffer speeds and frames per second just don't warrant the $4K price tag
column4: for my use. The A7iii is the sweet spot between them all!

column1: The autofocus system was borrowed from the A9 and is super fast and reliable. It now has two memory card slots making event photography more of an option than in the previous generations. It now has continuous eye autofocus. Its like Sony was with me through every gripe and complaint of the A7ii. The price point is just right
column2: the feature set beats all competitors in its class
column3: and it makes shooting fun. With the addition of the previously missing feature sets
column4: I can now spend more time taking photos and focusing in on composition and creativity. I love it!

column1: Now
column2: the bad. The electronic view finder (EVF) is a bit worse than the A7ii's EVF. it was noticeable at first glance but not a deal breaker. The buffer won't clear as fast as the A9 making the silent shooting mode a moot point in LED lighting (due to banding issues) and the resolution is almost half of what is possible on the A7Riii. And...that's all! Literally. I cannot find any other reason to give pause to purchasing this camera. So much so that I bought a second one as a backup for my event photography. With that said
column3: why are you still here reading this!?! Go buy the A7iii and get out there and start taking great photos. Happy shooting my friend!"^5^Jun 21

column1: Elfudge^/sony-alpha-a7-iii-mirrorless-video-camera-with-fe-28-70-mm-f3-5-5-6-oss-lens/6213100?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^17^0^"Anyone hesitate going to Sony's mirrorless: don't. There's a reason why this camera is sold out everywhere. There's a lot of raves about this camera.
When Sony came up with NEX 7 more than 5 years ago
column2: it was a head turner in terms of design and image quality. A really small camera can produce image and 1080p video that is good if not better than other APS-C cameras of its generation. The A7 series live up to the expectation with one important upgrade: full frame sensor. Coming to the third iteration of the A7 series
column3: Sony not just give you the best bang for the buck it is now already a mature system with full options of lens line up and accessories.

column1: Compare that to Nikon and Canon
column2: they are just becoming more serious in the mirrorless game. But the true and tried is Sony and the camera for the general purpose shooting is the Sony A7 iii.

column1: The camera feels and looks good. It is a solid camera in terms of design and portability.
Image quality is great
column2: enjoy it with your 4K screen so you can realize how good it is. Noise control
column3: sharpness and color is pleasing. Dynamic range is great
column4: the camera is able to capture some really complex lighting conditions. Low light performance is great
column5: will likely to turn heads of Canon 5D series owners. High ISO feels useful not just some gimmicks though you may want to limit shooting above iso 6400.

column1: Menu customization is great and well structured. Compatibility to Sony A-mount lens is available through a separate mount adapter and it works great although you're going to waste the A7 iii auto focus system by using the adapter's AF system.
Kit lens is not bad. It is actually good for the money. If you compare it with the Zeiss F/4 lens of the same focal length
column2: you will appreciate your kit lens more as there are not a few people keeping their kit lens rather than getting the Zeiss lens due to insignificant image quality differences between these lenses.

column1: Video quality is also great and options for great video lens are there. You can buy cheaper APS-C power zoom lens
column2: which works great for A7 iii video. No 4K 60fps but that is okay because that is the standard 4K framerate nowadays. Video is still limited to not exceed 30 minutes per clip. Built-in microphone is okay but most people will eventually use external mic anyway if they are serious about their video. One feature that no Canon and Nikon give you even with their newest mirrorless camera that they just announced: dual slot cards. This gives you another layer of security so you know that your image will not get corrupted due to some memory card error. You can also assign the first slot to take JPEG and the second slot to take RAW.

column1: Transferring image from camera to computer and even to smartphones are easy. The app works well.
For those of you who consider getting the A7R iii or A7 iii
column2: the former does give you more resolution. If you have tons of APSC E mount lens
column3: it does more make sense to get the A7R iii because the A7 iii will automatically crop your image to 10mpix while A7Riii will give you several more mpix. When you come to think of it
column4: even with the cropped 10mpix image that can make good quality A4 size prints.

column1: A7 III is a good investment that will last you years."^5^Sep 10
