Tsnide92^/sony-alpha-a6400-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-e-18-135mm-f-3-5-5-6-oss-lens-black/6324859?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"I bought this camera mainly for autofocus in video. Video quality and autofocus is great. There is no IBIS in this camera so there can be a little shake. Also
column2: Ive noticed the rolling shutter. However this doesnt change my opinion. This is a powerful little camera.

column1: Its quickly becoming my main camera over my Nikon. The portability and versatility with this kit cant be beat. Even with the kit lens photos are pretty sharp.
I am pleasantly surprised how this camera does in low light. Ive taken a keeper for insta at 16000 iso.

One thing I do not like is that there is no in camera timelapse video. There is interval shooting built into the camera. On the a6000 with the playmemories app it would make a video file as well as raw images. Now it takes a little more time to convert raw image to timelapse video on the computer.

One of my favorite things about this camera is silent shooting. Keep in mind at higher shutter speed or fast moving subjects there can be rolling shutter in the image. However I use this feature when doing timelapse with a slow shutter speed. The battery seems to last a little longer and theres no physical wear and tear on the mechanical shutter."^5^May 3

column10: remote control
column11: power options
column12: and accessories listed for this camera. Many of these items are available on Best Buy. Sonys site will tell you exactly what is compatible with this camera and the items part number. Better yet
column13: I can put the camera on a tripod and remote view and shoot using Sonys mobile app or desktop app.

column1: One feature I liked is the Auto White Balance. Yeah
column3: auto white balance tends to be terrible for all cameras. The Alpha 6100
column4: in my opinion
column5: does a better job
column6: at this price point
column7: than most. Indoor

column1: shots are still yellowish. Outdoor shots
column3: are a different story. I took the camera on a hike along a snow-covered trail. I Left everything at full auto. The camera auto adjusted its settings for macro shots
column4: portraits
column5: and for different lighting conditions. The white balance was pretty good. Now
column6: this could have been the position of the sun
column7: the time of day
column8: or having snow as the backdrop. Regardless
column9: I am pleased with the results. I also took a few videos of a waterfall. The videos were clean
column10: well balanced
column11: and detailed. The sound was good for not having an external mic. Moving from still to video was super easy. There is a record button near where your right thumb will naturally rest while holding the camera. Press once to start recording. Press a second time to stop. It does not get any easier than that.

column1: Auto mode has two modes: Intelligent Auto and Superior Auto. From Sony
column2: Intelligent Auto automatically identifies a scenes characteristics and shoots a photo. Superior Auto beautifully shoots automatically while reducing blurring and noise. As a test
column3: I took two photos of my shed using each setting under natural lighting conditions. White balance threw a little grey into the shot but not much. You will want to consult with the online users guide for more details. I included the two shots with my review.

column1: Another auto mode
column3: gives you more control. This is an auto mode for all the cameras major shooting modes such as Portrait
column4: Sports Action
column5: Macro
column6: Landscape
column7: and more. There are two ways to set the SCNs shoot mode. First
column8: you can take the long way around through the cameras menu system. I found this method slow and clunky. The second way is via the Function button located above the D-pad. Press the button and then use the D-pad and built in scroll wheel to quickly chose your shoot mode.

column1: The options here
column3: are enormous and much more than a simple Best Buy review can get into. I will say that the flexibility here is rich and appreciated for those of us who did not go to photography school. For those who did go to photography school then you will be happy to know that you can adjust any of the other modes on the camera to your hearts content. For example
column4: Program Auto
column5: P on the dial
column6: has eleven pages of options under the image setting and another 9 pages under the movie settings. Press the Function key and all the options directly related to your shot are available via a simple to navigate graphical interface. These include Drive Mode
column7: Focus Mode
column8: Focus Area
column9: Exposure Comp.
column10: ISO
column11: Metering Mode
column12: Flash Mode
column13: Flash Comp.
column14: White Balance
column15: Creative Style
column16: and Silent shooting.

column1: The Alpha 6100 can also take panoramic photos
column3: and quick motion videos. I have no need
column4: yet
column5: to shoot slow motion or quick motion videos. Panorama
column6: however
column7: is pretty darn impressive. I took a panorama of my workspace
column8: the camera must have taken 50 photos
column9: and then stitched them together like it only took a single photo. The image was in focus and detailed. I did not like the default length of the panoramic shot. I wanted to stop early but the camera continued shooting until I had completed the pre-defined panoramic field. One issue I did run into with Panoramic is with anything moving in shot. For example
column10: I took a Panoramic of a track and field facility. The people walking across the grounds during the shot had a double exposure affect. This may entirely be due to my lack of experience with panoramic photos
column11: the cameras software
column12: or some setting I failed to turn on. Just be aware to take some sample shots of what you want to capture before you pull the trigger on the real shot.

column1: The LCD screen is not a touch screen. This may seem strange in a world where cell phones have become the dominate photography tool. Sony delivers an excellent button layout to help navigate the screen. The buttons are all properly marked. The D-pad doubles as a scroll wheel. And the Scroll wheel has a selection button in the middle. There are also functions located to each compass point on the scroll wheel for easy access and navigation.
The scroll wheel is used to zoom through features
column3: and options. You can quickly scroll through your images by rolling your thumb left or right along the scroll wheels track. You can also quickly zoom in
column4: zoom out
column5: and navigate an image that you want to take a closer look at after shooting. I thought it was a bit awkward when I first used it. After using it for a bit
column6: I cannot image owning another camera without it. Home run for Sony!

column1: Finally
column2: the screen itself has multiple functions available. Pressing up on the D-pad switches between four screen layouts with differing levels of details including a preview of your image
column3: shot features
column4: information about your photo
column5: and histograms. Pretty much whatever you want to know about your shot before pressing the shutter button is accessible.

column1: The screen is attached to a mechanical arm that allows you to move the screen away from the camera body. This allows you multiple viewing angles while you shoot. The screen can also be flipped 180 degrees allowing for selfies. The Alpha 6100 automatically flips the LCD image when in selfie mode. Sony also added interactive features between the viewfinder and the view screen. There is a sensor in the eye piece that detects your eye
column3: that
column4: when triggered
column5: automatically turns off the view screen and activates the view finder screen. All the same information is present. My old camera used to keep both on regardless of which one I was using. I always found this distracting. Thank you
column6: Sony!

column1: Sony made connecting your camera with your cell phone super easy. The camera will display a QR Code that your phone uses to establish a connection. Another QR Code is used to acquire the mobile app
column2: Imaging Edge. You can control the camera from your phone
column3: view photos
column4: setup location information
column5: check current news related to the app
column6: review help files
column7: and remote control the camera. Unfortunately
column8: the app needs a major usability pass. For example
column9: if I remotely capture photos then I cannot view any photos until I first shut down the app and restart the app. Some screens do not have a back button.

column1: Another thing I cannot do from the app is set the cameras photo function. I must spin the function wheel manually to get what I want. Then the options for that mode will be made available to me from the app. I would have preferred the ability to control all camera features and functions remotely. One word of caution. Turn the remote features off when you travel. Bluetooth is easily compromised. The good news is that there is an Airplane Mode under the Network settings in your cameras menu. Turn this on when not using Wi-Fi or Bluetooth to protect yourself and your photos.
What I did not like:
The built-in flash is harsh. Period. I would avoid using it unless absolutely needed."^5^Jan 6

Gizmo^/sony-alpha-6100-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-e-pz-16-50mm-lens-black/6375665?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"This camera could not have come at a better time! Ive been a long time Canon SLR user

Overall

column1: mojo^/sony-alpha-6100-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-e-pz-16-50mm-lens-black/6375665?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Having owned the a6000

column1: MizuNoHane^/sony-alpha-6100-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-e-pz-16-50mm-lens-black/6375665?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I have always been interested in purchasing a mirrorless camera
column3: but as smartphones get better and more expensive
column4: a dedicated camera is harder to justify. That said
column5: the tiny sensor size in phone cameras limit them in some key ways. I now feel it's worth getting a mirrorless camera (APS-C or full-frame) if you need the following from your photos:

column1: 1. Resolution and quality that can be printed A4 size or larger
2. Depth of field (the 'portrait' or background blur effect that is still poorly replicated on phones)
3. Significant telephoto for long-range photography/videography.
4. Good low-light performance.
This camera does all of those things. Its upgrades over the a6000 are substantial. Battery life is better
column2: both in terms of shots you can take and standby time. The expanded and more accurate autofocus also now includes eye autofocus. This makes portrait shooting a breeze
column3: and now works with pets. The stabilized lens
column4: eye-AF and wider sensor allowed me to get sharp shots of my dog in low light - things I never could have hoped for with my phone. The other thing that works wonderfully is the flip-up screen
column5: great for selfies and vlogging. It's not as versatile as a screen that flips to the side
column6: which would allow you to shoot from weird and interesting new angles
column7: but I appreciated any additional flexibility compared to the a6000. For me
column8: these additional features
column9: including high-res 4K video recording
column10: strike a nice compromise between the a6000 and the a6400
column11: a more expensive version of this camera
column12: which has a few more features for an even higher price
column13: such as video color-grading. Really
column14: the only major thing one would upgrade further for is the in-body image stabilization in the a6500 and a6600
column15: which are significantly more expensive than the a6100 or a6400. In most situations
column16: purchasing an Optical SteadyShot (OSS) lens
column17: or a lens with stabilization built in
column18: will get you similar results without having to step up to the a6500.

column1: So about that included lens. This one comes with a kit lens
column2: and I wholeheartedly recommend this camera with the major caveat that a buyer should expect to purchase at least 1-2 additional lenses to justify owning this as opposed to just sticking with their phone. That's not an insignificant price increase
column3: especially with autofocus lenses (each about $200-400). The kit lens is flexible
column4: but its slow aperture - f3.5 at the wide end and f5.6 at the telephoto end - makes RAW photos suffer in some key ways
column5: which I can illustrate with the uploaded photos below. In low-light
column6: the kit lens is noisy. Further
column7: it's not particularly sharp
column8: and because of the slow aperture
column9: the bokeh effect you get with your portraits is minimal. Do not get me wrong. In all these respects - noise
column10: sharpness
column11: bokeh
column12: printability - it is still markedly better than your smartphone. But if you are hoping to really maximize the potential in this camera - and trust me
column13: there is a LOT of potential - I would budget at least a few hundred dollars more to purchase at least one more lens to get either that portrait or telephoto effect. I also included some shots taken with a Sony 50mm f1.8 OSS lens
column14: and the differences are readily apparent. If you're wanting to just shoot low-light portrait shots of posed friends/family
column15: etc
column16: you can save the money
column17: get a Sony a6000 used or renewed
column18: and purchase a third-party manual focus lens with a fast aperture
column19: which can be had for as low as $120. But if you step up to the a6100
column20: it's because you want to shoot video in 4K
column21: or shoot high-quality portrait photos of fast-moving objects you want to track with continuous autofocus like athletes
column24: or because you want to vlog. If the last use case is the only reason you are buying this
column25: the kit lens may do just fine as at 16mm you have noticeable bokeh in good lighting. But if you want to use this for anything else
column26: I would strongly recommend budgeting the cost of additional lenses into your purchase. If you are more familiar with the types of lenses you would want
column27: you could also consider buying the a6100 body only and then individually purchasing your lenses.

column1: That was a lot
column2: but the short answer is that mirrorless cameras
column3: and dedicated cameras in general
column4: are still much better than phones and will likely continue to be for several years. I think the a6100 is a worthy upgrade to the a6000
column5: an already very good camera

DrWMJ^/sony-alpha-6100-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-e-pz-16-50mm-lens-black/6375665?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This is a very fine and powerful camera
column3: but a few annoyances. First
column4: the good stuff:

column1: - With a large image sensor and 24M image capacity
column2: this camera that only weighs a pound and can fit in the pocket of your cargo pants
column3: can shoot beautiful
column4: crisp
column5: and highly detailed pictures.

column1: - The automatic focusing tech that Sony brings to this device is truly astonishing. Subjects eyes and facial features are always in focus
column2: even when they are moving. Sony is ahead of the competition in this area.

column1: - The lens that is supplied in this kit is not the best glass you can get. Thankfully
column2: there is a wide variety of high-quality lenses that one can use with this camera

column1: - Color accuracy is excellent; I very rarely need to adjust my images in Photoshop.
- There are options for many automatic adjustments
column2: such as multiple image acquisition for backlit or low light scenes. Alternatively
column3: the photographer may assume full manual control.

column1: Now for some nit-picks:

- With robust features and flexibility comes complexity; there is a bit of a learning curve to become facile with all the menu and shooting options. I have been using this camera on my vacation in Mexico for the past week

column1: - I did watch some videos on-line to help with the initial set-up
- The battery is rated to take over 300 images on a charge. I am shooting high definition images
column3: and using the Panorama and HDR functions. With this I may get 200 images/charge. Happily

column1: - The transfer of images by wi-fi works only so well. It is still much faster to put the SD in a card reader or attach the camera to the computer by USB.
- On 2 or 3 occasions I have had the camera freeze
column2: necessitating turning it off and then restarting. I may have done something wrong
column3: or this may be the consequence of having complicated
column4: sophisticated imaging software being deployed.

column1: All in all
column2: I am very pleased with this camera. It has all the flexibility for creative photography that I need as an active hobbyist
column3: at a fraction of the price and weight of traditional DSLRs. I am particularly happy with the ability to capture active grandchildren in low light
column4: and consistent beautiful bokeh effect in portraits. I recommend this product highly but bear in mind you will need some time to learn to use it.

column1: bredeker^/sony-alpha-6100-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-e-pz-16-50mm-lens-black/6375665?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I have owned a few Sony mirrorless cameras over the past 7 or so years
column2: and the new Alpha 6100 impressed me with its great balance of features - especially the improved auto-focus system. Sony provided the camera in exchange for this review
column3: and I was pleased to be able to use it to capture some shots over the last two weeks
column4: during the Christmas holiday season. I'll mention my impressions of the features I found noteworthy.

column1: If you're considering purchasing this camera
column2: you may already understand quite a bit about digital camera technology and why you would want to invest in one in order to capture pictures that smartphones simply aren't capable of. If you haven't
column3: the short answer is that these cameras have dramatically bigger sensors that capture more light and can produce the shallow-depth-of-field ('blurry background') effect without all the digital processing tricks that smartphones rely on. In the enthusiast stand-alone camera market
column4: there are two primary types of cameras - DSLR's and 'mirrorless' cameras (the Alpha 6100 is a mirrorless camera). Without saying too much about the technical differences
column5: the latter are so named because they eliminate the physical mirrors that DSLR's use - the viewfinder is actually a tiny LCD screen that shows you exactly the picture the camera is going to take
column6: including helpful information overlays. Traditionally
column7: the downside of mirrorless cameras has been slower autofocus systems and perceptible lag in the viewfinder. However
column8: Sony and other companies have been relentlessly tackling these problems
column9: and even the industry giants Canon and Nikon are producing mirrorless systems now to cater to people that like their advantages.

column1: As mentioned
column2: I have used multiple Sony cameras - mirrorless always appealed to me as the inevitable future for stand-alone cameras
column3: and I have invested in a few additional lenses for Sony's mirrorless camera system. In the meantime
column4: Sony has really improved their technology and made some waves amongst professional photographers. The Sony Alpha 6100 takes their current state-of-the-art auto-focus system with real-time tracking and adds it to a model in reach of hobbyists and families that want to capture gorgeous photo memories. The auto-focus system can be switched between person and pet tracking modes
column5: and has an uncanny ability to lock onto subjects' eyes. Once locked onto a subject
column6: continuing to hold the shutter button half-pressed will keep the focus locked on
column7: and does a fantastic job of following that subject as they move and turn - often even if the subject is partially- or fully-obscured momentarily. This is definitely the best auto-focus system I've used on a Sony camera
column8: and from other reviews of the Alpha 6100's siblings
column9: Sony seems to have one of the top focusing systems right now. If you're thinking of this camera as an investment to capture pictures of children in motion
column10: the auto-focus system is a very good reason to purchase the Alpha 6100. The only downside is that you will need to change some of the options out-of-the-box to enable the real-time tracking and tweak how it works to your preferences.

column1: Another improvement over Sony's older models that I really like is the improvements to smartphone connectivity. Sony has had an optional companion app for mobile Android and iOS devices for a while
column2: and they renamed it from 'PlayMemories' to 'Imaging Edge' since my previous camera model. The app is not the most intuitive
column3: and I did find it a little cumbersome to get it connected initially. (I was using an iPhone; maybe it would be slightly easier with Android. However
column4: NFC did work - I'm not sure if that improvement in Imaging Edge is due to an improvement by Sony or Apple
column5: but it's cool that NFC can be used on iOS now to simplify the Wi-Fi connection.) I have found it to be reliable enough - no dropped connections between camera and phone yet. Sony's app has always allowed you to turn your phone into a remote control for the camera
column6: which is a great feature if you want to set up the camera on a tripod and take a group photo that you can be part of. It's also long supported transferring photos from the camera to the phone
column7: to make it easier to share them (or edit them with another app). However
column8: one feature that is new with latest series of Alpha cameras is an additional Bluetooth connection support which the app leverages to 'geotag' photos using your phone's GPS. I always thought it was really neat to be able to see my vacation photos taken with a smartphone on a map based on where they were taken
column9: and had wished that data could be integrated with my 'good' camera. Although I've used apps that log your phone's location and then use that to add the data to photos later based on timestamp
column10: it's pretty cool that it can now be integrated right as the photos are taken. This is a feature that some of Sony's competitors have already had for a while
column11: but it's a nice-to-have on the Alpha 6100. (Of course
column12: if you use this feature and are conscious about privacy
column13: be careful to consider removing geotag information before sharing photos online.)

column1: The Alpha 6100 takes great pictures. It takes some practice to get the hang of adding effects that everyone is used to adding with filters in smartphone apps
column2: but the results really are great. With a 24MP sensor
column3: the images capture a lot of information and are great for printing. Due to the larger sensor
column4: pictures taken in low light exhibit less digital noise than smartphones (though smartphones can compensate with more software corrections). I've very pleased with the color and sharpness I've gotten. I do not typically shoot a lot of video
column5: but this camera can take 4K footage and I thought the video quality was quite good on a 4K TV. It does not support some of the more advanced videography features (like S-Log)
column6: though higher-end Sony models do.

column1: The Alpha 6100 is typically sold in a bundle with a small
column2: 16-50mm power-zoom lens. The lens is compact enough
column3: especially compared to typical DSLR lenses. It's a OK starter lens and works well with the auto-focus system. Sony and other manufacturers make a number of E-mount lenses with a range of prices. Although many will cost as much or more than the camera (which is common for any interchangeable-lens camera system)
column4: there are some reasonably-priced gems and many of the expensive ones are highly rated.

column1: I really appreciated that Sony is still using the same battery that earlier cameras in their NEX and Alpha 6000 series used. This means all my spare batteries work with any camera and charger. On the downside
column2: Sony's higher end models are now beginning to use a newer batter that has longer life
column3: but I found battery life to be more than sufficient for my needs. (The batteries are small and it's easy to care a spare or two.) If you're not already a Sony camera user
column4: this may not matter to you - but I would like to point out that all of Sony's cameras have featured USB charging built-in
column5: which is actually quite convenient (they can charge with a simple micro-USB cable; no need to to travel with a charger unless you want to).

column1: The Alpha 6100 uses a slightly lower resolution LCD screen in its electronic viewfinder than in higher-end Sony models
column2: but I still find it very clear to use. One feature I miss that Sony has included on other models is an artificial horizon overlay in the viewfinder (or rear screen) that makes it easy to get level horizons in your shorts. The rear screen is touch-sensitive
column3: though the interface still must be operated with the controls on the rear of the camera - the touch is mostly used for tapping to pick a focus point if you can't get the camera to focus where you want. The rear touch screens of Sony's latest models now do flip up 180 degrees - basically a 'selfie mode.' I think using this camera for selfies is a bit silly
column4: but it could certainly be very practical if you're interested in making YouTube-style videos.

column1: My existing investment in the Sony mirrorless system makes me admittedly biased
column2: but Sony has been making some very good cameras. There are highly-regarded competitors
column3: but the Alpha 6100 is still a great purchase. It's an extremely nice upgrade to older cameras at the lower end of Sony's Alpha 6000 lineup
column4: adding the latest auto-focus and smartphone connectivity features while retaining lens and battery compatibility. And for anyone considering the investment in a stand-alone camera
column5: the Alpha 6100 has a nice blend of features for a reasonable price."^5^Jan 7

column1: skylog^/sony-alpha-6100-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-e-pz-16-50mm-lens-black/6375665?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This is my first real camera
column2: and I have a lot to learnbut so far

column6: but it feels sturdy and nice in the hand. The viewfinder is very useful and although I still need to get more familiar with the software and button layout
column7: everything is straight forward and easy to understand.

column1: Taking pictures has been great. The camera itself as well as auto focus is very
column2: very fast. Pictures are extremely crisp
column3: and while I like my results so far
column4: once I get more into lighting
column5: focus and other things
column6: I think they will only get better. Video is much of the same
column7: but here I really need to learn a few things. That said
column8: to shoot in 4K is crazy to me
column9: but the little samples I have shot look better than I thought they would. Again
column10: here
column11: the viewfinder shows its value with added versatility. I am ready to explore this more.

column1: One of the things I am most excited about with this camera is to be able to improve it as I do. As is
column2: the camera is great and has all the tools I need at the moment
column3: but the ability to add lights
column4: mics and other tools is very exciting. Most importantly though
column5: are lenses. The included lens has performed well
column6: but when I get to the point where I want to do more
column7: I can add new glass to help get me there.

column1: My only real issue with the camera is the battery (sort of). While it does last fairly long when dealing with photos
column2: it does take a hit when taking video. That is expected
column3: and
column4: honestly
column5: it still does well
column6: but I do not understand why Sony did not include a charger with the camera. To have to plug the camera in to charge it is not optimal. I will end up picking up batteries and a charger anywaybut it would have been nice to see something included.

column1: In the end
column2: I am very happy with this camera. I think it is a great value. You get a feature-rich camera (with some higher end features at a lower price point)
column3: a great all-around performer in both picture and video
column4: and access to a system that allows you to improve on what you just purchased down the road. I think it is a great choice for all
column5: but certainly for those just getting started."^5^Jan 6

column1: PapawJeff^/sony-alpha-6100-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-e-pz-16-50mm-lens-black/6375665?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This Sony Mirrorless Camera is packed with features that will serve you well no matter your experience level.
Just put it on Auto and let the camera do the work

column1: The large sensor and mirrorless operation of the camera produce truly beautiful photography. We have had it a few weeks are are still playing with its features and settings because it has many to pick from.
Lifelike skin tones and realistic color reproduction are both very impressive and perfectly captured at a pixel rate 24.2-megapixel11 Exmor CMOS sensor.
4K videos can be captured as well.
Between 300 to 400 photos on a full battery and can be powered by USB if your battery runs out of juice.
There are many more features of this compact and easy to carry and use camera to read about on Sony's website that will be sure to please the photographer in you"^5^Jan 6
Capshroud^/sony-alpha-6100-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-e-pz-16-50mm-lens-black/6375665?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"The Sony a6100 is an upgrade of the a6000
column2: Sonys successful and well-regarded entry-level mirrorless camera. It kept the best of the 6000 while improving picture quality and adding some high-end features. Here are some initial thoughts after using this new camera for a couple of weeks.

column1: Physically
column2: the build quality is quite good with a substantial and rigid feel for a plastic body. The rear screen is now touch-enabled for focus and exposure and can pivot 180 degrees up allowing selfies or v-blogs. The OLED viewfinder is good but not a match to the higher resolution EVFs on Sonys more expensive models. There is a small pop up flash
column3: but if you plan much flash use
column4: Id recommend buying a separate TTL (smart) flash to attach to the cameras hot shoe. Overall it has a good feel in the hand
column5: and the plastic construction makes it very light. Its numerous controls are well laid out except for a very awkwardly placed video button. On the minus side
column6: I found it awkward to insert or remove SD cards since the slot is very close to the battery door hinge. It uses the small FW-50 battery and although battery life is reasonable
column7: youll want to carry extras. Neither the body or kit lens is weather-sealed
column8: so dont plan on using it in rainy or very dusty locations. Lastly
column9: Sony chose to use a USB micro connection rather than the newer
column10: better and more robust USB-C for in-camera charging and PC connection.

column1: Internally
column2: it uses Sonys proven 24mp APS-C sensor. Using Sonys current BIONZ X processor makes for fast picture processing. Burst mode can shoot at 11 frames per second and buffer up to 75 jpegs. The big news is that it now includes a 425 point focusing system with face and eye detection with real-time tracking. Thats a big step up in focus ability and arguably Sonys is the best in the industry. This same system is used in several of Sonys high-end mirrorless cameras. The focus is fast and accurate
column3: and it will continuously track moving subjects and while maintaining focus. However
column4: to make full use of this and many of the advanced features
column5: you need to find your way through an extensive and somewhat obtuse menu system. This camera has the capabilities of many substantially higher priced cameras
column6: but you have to be willing to investigate
column7: read and learn to make use of all its power and features. Once you do
column8: you can customize function buttons
column9: build your own personal My Menu and customize the pop-up menu selections to quickly access the settings you change most often. It has every shooting
column10: focusing
column11: and exposure mode and picture setting you can imagine and probably more. It shoots in JPG
column12: RAW
column13: and RAW+JPG still formats. It records video up to 4K UHD while still continuously focusing. Its WIFI and Bluetooth enabled allowing you to send pictures directly to your phone
column14: receive location info from your phone
column15: or operate the camera remotely. Theres NFC built in to quickly connect your phone at a touch.

column1: The 16-50mm kit lens has been around for a while and was designed to meet a price point and to be very small. It keeps the camera quite compact  more than pocket-size but much less than a DSLR or most superzooms. The 16-50mm zoom range is equivalent to a 24-75mm on a full-frame camera. Thats a reasonable walk-around lens
column3: its only a 3:1 zoom
column4: so with this lens
column5: youll have to do much of the zooming with your feet. It is stabilized
column6: and since the camera does not have stabilization built-in
column7: thats a real asset. With a maximum f-stop of 3.5 to 5.6
column8: stabilization is needed for low to moderate light conditions if you want to keep the ISO and noise reasonable. This is packed into an amazingly small body  almost pancake size when off and not extended. The camera has very effective lens correction built-in so theres almost no image distortion throughout the zoom
column9: but the corners get somewhat soft at the wide end. Ive read reports of variations in quality from unit to unit and some durability issues
column10: but at this point
column11: my lens is performing well. A faster f-stop and/or longer zoom would be more versatile. There are many excellent e-mount lenses that can be used with this camera
column12: but good lenses are expensive. The a6100 is also available with an additional 70-210mm lens
column13: and that may be worth considering if you want a longer zoom and are willing to carry an additional lens. Theres also a highly rated 18-135 Sony zoom Im considering.

column1: Is this the camera for you? If you want extensive features
column2: one of the best action tracking focusing systems
column3: and great picture quality this gets you into an excellent mirrorless camera system at a modest price. If youre a serious photographer and want a small
column4: walkabout camera with semi-pro features
column5: its a solid choice. If all you want is a point and shoot camera and will leave it set on auto rather than make use of its capabilities
column6: there are many other choices that may be more suitable.

column1: All things said
column2: theres a whole lot here to recommend. A lot of technology is packed into this compact body. At the price
column3: this may be the best deal out there as far as features and price. If Sony would update the arcane menu system and improve the kit lens
column4: it would easily get a 5-star rating from me. As is
column5: it gets a high 4."^4^Jan 6

column1: I'm used to lager more user adjustable dslr cameras that are super Bulky. I like the smaller form factor of this mirrorless camera

column1: Pea123^/canon-eos-m50-mirrorless-camera-two-lens-kit-with-ef-m-15-45mm-f-3-5-6-3-is-stm-and-ef-m-55-200mm-14-5-6-3-is-stm-zoom-lenses-black/6204312?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^12^0^"I decided to look into replacing my 8 year old Canon G12
column2: as I banged it up a bit
column3: the lens closing had acted up but it then cured itself. And I was looking forward to upgrading a bit and having a tele lens option.

column1: I looked seriously at the Sony A6000 (my daughter likes hers) and A6300
column2: but I was somewhat concerned with the % of people who had an issue with at least one of their lenses making reliable connection when in place. I was hoping to obtain a well rated mirror-less 2 lens kit for about $1000
column3: which is asking a lot. When I looked over the Canon offerings
column4: I had to get past the confusion of their numbering system. I considered the M6 (virtually the well rated M5 w/o a viewfinder). Then I sorted out that the M50
column5: which just came out in 4/18
column6: also had some great similar qualities (APS-C sensor)
column7: dual pixel focusing
column8: and upgrades such as more focus points and newer Digic8 processing. The 4K video has numerous compromises
column9: per many reviews
column10: but I have no need for that level. I did pay attention to the more standard video settings having decent auto-focusing
column11: which my G12 did not and was a sore point.

column1: I read many online reviews and felt I knew what I was getting. Canon does not get the kudos on mirror-less of some other brands
column2: but it does get good marks for image quality and the various features. The key competitive negatives seemed to be the 4K video and the lower battery life / number of shots (not the same as the M6/M5
column3: but still more than I use in a day). And the M50 has one main dial instead of two on many other cameras. Do check out the various online reviews for better understanding

column1: I was looking in early May and the price for the 2-lens kit (w/15-45 and 55-200mm) was at the initial list price of $900 camera w/15-45 plus $350 2nd lens
column2: more than I preferred to spend. Those lenses are 24-72mm and 88-320m as 35mm camera equivalents. Some googling noted that Canon typically drops the price after some 6 months
column3: but here they did it in 1 month
column4: so the camera (next day) was lowered to $700 and the (typically $349) 2nd lens adds only $230
column5: so the kit was $929. That got me headed to a nearby BB
column6: which had the 2-lens kit. (That store did not even have it on display yet).

column1: I am quite happy with my initial experience. The paper manual is very compact so I recommend the downloadable pdf version. I do not think the single main dial (instead of two) will bother me. Many of the features are much like my G2; i.e.
column3: Program (to adjust flash for example)
column4: Time or Aperture priority
column5: etc. I am having to figure out some key (for me) items such as where to get to the close-up setting
column6: how to set up occasional auto exposure bracketing
column7: how to vary flash output
column8: etc. The small flash is good to around 15'
column9: so I was pleased that my older compact Canon hot-shoe 270EX flash is compatible.

column1: Again
column2: the 4K video is not generally rated for prime time due to its compromises. But if that does not matter to you either
column3: this camera seems a good candidate vs the M5 in the Canon family
column4: especially if upgrading from a non-DSLR Canon. While Canon did not get great marks on their slower push into mirrorless
column5: I think this camera is a good quality / value proposition
column6: especially if you (like me) might choose to rule out the Sony's. While you will find others with great ratings in the 'top 10' lists
column7: some of those are also quite a few $ more. I think the current $929 2-lens kit is very reasonable and I hope to have my initial impressions pan out longer term.

column1: I did puchase a pair of non-Canon supplemental batteries
column3: and some nice elastic lens cap retainers. On those
column4: I recommend the kind where the cord loops through holes in the cap (vs. the stick-on kind)."^5^May 20

column4: etc.).  Photography is fun again with this small camera - I really don't want to lug around large camera bodies and lenses anymore!  The lenses auto focus ability is superior with the mirrorless system - no more need to calibrate the lenses to the mirror-type focus system (AF Micro adjustment). I must admit
column5: the image quality
column6: even with the kit lenses is terrific.  Of course without weather sealing and premium (L) lenses
column7: one is limited. However
column8: I have printed large format photos that only a professional would be able to tell the difference (pro cameras and lenses)  - and not always.  The sensor is very good

column13: so low light photos are going to require a higher ISO or flash. I used the 55-200 Zoom at a grandson's ball game with great results - up to 10 fps that is more than adequate to catch 'just the right shot'.  The EVF works well in bright daylight. The battery is adequate
column14: but just so.  If traveling or videoing

column16: so I can not provide a good opinion on the video capabilities for the VLoggers out there
column17: but what I do turns out great. The audio preamp is quite good. I use a Rode VideoMicro and that works out great for sound quality - the external mic jack is a great feature on this camera.  The camera is small
column18: but easy to hold and is 'carry all day' comfortable. I will add that I added a ef-m 22mm
column19: f2 pancake lens - this little prime lens is reasonably fast and the image quality is very
column20: very good and an ideal size when on the m50.  Do I miss my pro equipment?  Sure
column22: but I never miss lugging them around! For the casual shooters - travel
column24: etc. this is a very nice system

Shooting a documentary soon so this will be my start into film"^5^Oct 4

BenT^/canon-eos-m50-mirrorless-camera-two-lens-kit-with-ef-m-15-45mm-f-3-5-6-3-is-stm-and-ef-m-55-200mm-14-5-6-3-is-stm-zoom-lenses-black/6204312?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I've been a Canon shooter for quite awhile
column3: I mainly used the Canon G-series point & shoots. Decided it was time to go back to ILC cameras and decided to go with the EOS M50.

column1: So far
column2: I'm having a great time shooting with this camera rekindling my love of photography. Picture quality is superb
column3: and being quite familiar with Canon
column4: I've had no issues getting used to the camera. Size and weight are just right. I only wish Canon would weather-seal their lenses and cameras in this class of camera.

column1: I ended up picking up an EF 35mm f/2.0 prime  lens and adapter and really like the combination."^4^Aug 20

Norberto^/canon-eos-m50-mirrorless-camera-two-lens-kit-with-ef-m-15-45mm-f-3-5-6-3-is-stm-and-ef-m-55-200mm-14-5-6-3-is-stm-zoom-lenses-black/6204312?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I wanted to get back into serious photography again
column2: but was not sure how much I wanted to spend to get back in. When I saw this mirrorless unit available for a great price I decided to give it a shot.

column1: The first thing I noticed is that it has a similar OS as the rest of the Canon point and shoot line. Those in turn
column2: came directly from the old AE1 and A1 cameras. The system is simple for former users
column3: and would not confound a first time user. Canon has had the edge on user friendliness for 40 years
column4: and it does not appear that they are ready to relinquish that lead soon.

column1: I still enjoy using manual modes at times
column2: and having had experience in the manner in which Canon handles this
column3: the whole experience was a breeze. Again
column4: first timers who wish to go 'off line' and try experimenting with manual
column5: shutter or aperture priority modes will find this a pleasant surprise in ease of use.

column1: I was not disappointed in the image quality. Although it has a compact sensor
column2: which I swore I was going to avoid
column3: and requires an adapter to work with the entire line of Canon lenses
column4: I was impressed. No flares
column5: no distortion at the edges and a great deal of detail from the compact lenses.

column1: As a former professional
column2: I am often discouraged by reviews of amateur equipment written by pros or former pros who somehow expect miracles at bargain prices. I came into this with an open mind
column3: expecting to be underwhelmed after reading some low rated reviews
column4: but I had an entirely opposite experience."^5^May 17

column2: This camera is different than all my other canon cameras. The electronic view finder is way better than my expectations. It was a surprise that I could review my shots in it. You can zoom the image up after it is taken to get a close look at what you have captured. Took me a bit to figure out! I have only used it hand held so far but the pictures seem decent. The remote shutter plug is different than all my other canons but they do make an adapter where I will be able to use my old releases. I bought this as a kit so it had the RF 24-105 F4 with the control ring. It does have a safety switch in software where you can set it so you can not inadvertently change what you set if you wish. The same goes with several other programmable switches. So far so good!"^5^Oct 13

column1: theB82project^/canon-eos-r-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-rf-24-105mm-f-4l-is-usm-lens/6298174?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I had the EOS R for a few days
column2: but only one shooting session so far. So
column3: very preliminary impressions:

column1: - the new RF lenses seems a step ahead in usability
column3: and performance

column1: - The control ring is a great addition. The adapter with the control is almost indispensable if you start shooting with the EOS R and EF lenses
- Portability - size
column3: and ergonomics - are excellent. Had to familiarize a little to the new button layout and slightly modify the grip
column4: but overall feeling and maneuverability great

column1: - I had some initial troubles configuring Bluetooth connectivity to enable GPS
column2: but all sorted out. I consider GPS coordinates to be an integral part of a photo experience

column1: - Shot 700+ RAW photos in roughly 3 hrs
column2: and drained the entire battery. Lesson learned: will always keep a spare one with me

column1: - need to familiarize with the focus system
column2: but setting the Multi-Function bar to round-robin all AF modes seem logical
column3: natural and a no brainer after few minutes

column1: After some months
column2: I can confirm the first impression. Actually
column3: from an ergonomic perspective
column4: I find the EOS R excellent
column5: and the multi-function bar extremely useful and an integral part of the overall experience. I am looking forward to more RF lenses in the second half of 2019.

column1: I usually shoot with a Canon 5D Mark iv and the Canon 1 D X mark II. I now consider the EOS R my first choice for travel
column3: urban architecture
column4: and portraits."^5^Nov 28

column1: Rooster^/canon-eos-r-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-rf-24-105mm-f-4l-is-usm-lens/6298174?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^2^"After 26 photos
column2: the camera hung up trying to record to the card. Then it failed completely. I called Canon support less than an hour after buying it and they advised me how to do a reboot which didnt work. I returned to Best Buy and they replaced it.  The following day
column3: I needed to use it on a professional job and did so without a problem. Ive used Canon equipment since the AE1. Allow ample time to get used to the blackouts in the EVF when shooting even if you turn off image playback. The ergonomics are very good except for the video recording button placement. The camera is extremely customizable. Its easy to accidentally touch settings in error (i.e.: the video mode button is also the info button on the touchscreen. Really?) Most users hate the touchbar. It didnt work as intuitively as Canon claims. The image quality is excellent as expected from Canon equipment. The camera looks good on paper but Im still undecided. A huge plus is that I can use all my EF lenses and the AF works perfectly as opposed to the Sony mirrorless with non-native lenses."^3^Nov 15

column1: TPGG^/canon-eos-r-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6298167?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^13^1^"This is not a technical review. It is the opinion of a Family/sports shooter with 40 years of various camera experience and 50
The EOS R is different than the SLR or DSLR. Some good
PROS
The basics you know still apply. Shutter
column3: ISO

column1: - Lens from your old Canon will (mostly) still work as well as the lens did on your old Canon.I saw no need to upgrade my lens.
- ISO performance is great with acceptable noise even at 10
- Shots per second and shutter speed are mostly the same
- Still has the very useful articulated flip screen
- You can see menus and review pictures in the high res digital view finder. Very Nice!
- Almost every button is programmable. Geeks will like this.
- The grip is a little deeper on your finger tips so it is very nice to carry with one hand.
- A little lighter than the big DSLR cameras. If you want a large camera body to impress your friends
CONS
- Price. $2500 with the adapter. A big price for the new features but a Geek has to follow the technology. (wife does not agree)
- No flash. Just hot shoe. I miss the pop up flash. Even with impressive ISO
column2: a quick flash is often helpful.

column1: - The digital view finder can be annoying. Pop up reviews and sleep settings to preserve energy
column2: waste valuable time between shots. A show stopper in sports photography. Turn those things off.

column1: - Hours you will spend watching youtube videos to learn the menu system and make the camera your own. Just when you had learned your old Canon.
- Video is still doable
column2: but they moved a very convenient button to a very inconvenient location. I just don't get it.

column1: - A new touch bar that you drag your finger on or touch correctly to do what ever you program it to do. Guess I'll learn it but is weird for now.

- Just 'feels' a bit slow when you move it from your lap to your eye to catch an interesting moment of action in the big game. The 80D may have the advantage so I set the EOS R view- finder to never sleep and auto focus always on so the camera is ready for action but using more battery full time. Best on a mono-pod kept at eye level to reduce the time between 'I want the shot' to 'I got the shot'.
If you are a Nikon or Sony or Fugi user
I love Canon and have a bunch of Canon stuff so I'm ok with it.
Like Nebraska
Jerryrigged^/canon-eos-r-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6298167?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"Got the EOS R as a backup to my 5D Mark IV. Photo and video quality is excellent
column3: I can use all of my EF lenses. Just shot my first wedding (photos) using the EOS R along with my 5D4. The EOS R images look great
column4: and I actually got a higher percentage of keepers with the R: Autofocus is really excellent. I've also shot a bit of video with the R. I find the video looks great
column5: but auto white balance can wander a bit... so I use a specific Kelvin temperature for my white balance whenever possible. I'm also finding that my SD card sticks a bit when I try to remove it from the camera. Not sure what is causing that. In general
column6: I think the R is a really great camera at $1000 LESS than the 5D Mark 4."^5^Jan 21

column1: JoeM^/canon-eos-r-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6298167?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"Bought this camera to replace my 1DX as i am a serious hobbyists. Took to Buenos Aires on vacation - it takes awesome shots
column2: lots of new features. Lightweight - although the R lens are big and heavy. Mid-way thru my trip in a rain down pore - the camera got wet despite protective plastic protective sleeve coving most of the computer - somehow the electronics stopped working. After a day of drying up most buttons and features seemed to return except the shutter. Luckily after a call to support they suggested i use the touch screen to shoot. Not optimal but it allowed me to take photos the rest of the trip. Upon returning home i shipped the camera back to canon for repair. There was a disconnect with requesting a repair and whether it was subject to the canon care plus warranty. Initially they billed me for $600 for corrosion. When i pointed out that i had the care plus package i got a revised no cost quote. The care plus package had some contradictory descriptions on what is and isnt covered. It should water damage as subject to coverage but also states that it isnt. Anyway
column3: they are not charging me. I should have the camera back in 5 days. Will update my review. Ultimately like the camera
column4: and like the service and response i received. I don;t like that the camera is not as water proof as the 1DX. Lesson learned. Btw canon would not post this review on their website"^5^Jan 31

column1: Peter^/canon-eos-r-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6298167?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"The camera stop working on us during 2 separate occasions. My wife and I own a photography business and loved the quality of the camera but when you have to return a product 2x during a 4 week period that tells me this is a issue with the camera. The rep at best buy said that he heard of the same issues on line but was the first he encountered."^2^Dec 30

GeorgeH^/canon-eos-r-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6298167?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"I've been a Canon shooter for many years and have found their photography equipment to be of high quality
column2: durable and reliable.  Canon also has outstanding customer service and support.  In addition to my recent purchases of two Canon EOS R bodies
column3: I also have a 5D Mark IV
column4: 7D Mark II and the holy trinity collection of Canon 'L' lenses.

column1: In my opinion
column2: the 'R' has received a bad rap from supposedly professional reviewers
column3: especially with Canon's recent firmware updates that have made significant improvements since the R's initial introduction.

column1: Pros:
1.  The body feels so good in the hand
column2: not too large and not to small.  Just right!  Lenses balance well on the body.

column1: 2.  Image quality (stills) is outstanding and more than enough dynamic range to deal with highlights and shadows.
3.  I'm probably biased
column2: but I think Canon's color science is the best in the industry.

column1: 4.  Fast and accurate auto focus especially with the recent 1.4 firmware update.  Subject tracking and eye detection is excellent.
5.  The EF/EF-S to R lens adapter allows you to use all of the EF/EF-S lenses with no loss in functionality.
6.  The electronic viewfinder resolution is outstanding and the ability to see exactly what your image will look like before taking the shot is a game changer versus an optical viewfinder on a DSLR.
7.  The articulating LCD screen is high resolution and allows you to get the shot at any difficult angle.
8.  If you have the funds I also recommend the new Canon RF lenses.  I also purchased the RF 24-105mm f/4L lens and it is outstanding and a great focal length for a walk-around lens.
9.  The touch & drag function to move the focus point is much speedier than a joy stick and is easy to use.
10.  Shooting in lowlight conditions is outstanding and very minimal noise in higher ISO ranges.
Cons:
1.  Some complain about only having a single card slot which I can understand if you're a paid photographer.  However
column2: if you need redundancy you can use wifi to easily send to your cell phone as you shoot.

column1: 2.  Some have complained about the crop factor when using 4K video.  I don't do video with my cameras so really not fair of me to comment.
For the money
column2: the Canon EOS R is a deal!!"^5^Dec 21

Much better high ISO noise performance than my 7D ii. The silent mode is great for close shooting of wildlife. However quick moving subject may be distorted on silent mode.

Photolover^/sony-alpha-a7r-iv-ilce-7rm4-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/6361762?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^1^"I'm coming from a Nikon d850
column2: D3 and D500.  I tried a Sony A7III and it was ok but this camera what made me switch from the Nikon system.  The details are incredible. I take lots of wildlife photos as well as portraits.

column1: Pro:

1. High Megapixel allows a ton of work in the post especially cropping. This is useful for wildlife photos when you are limited by the lens. High pixels is useful for me because I do a lot of composited images.

2.  Autofocus is better than a7III.  It is substantially better than Z6.  The accuracy is very reliable for most situations.  The only time it failed was on the fastest of my four dogs.  It works for most wildlife situations.  For sports
column2: I would still recommend the A9.

column1: 3.  The body is a huge step up from previous generations.
4. EVF is incredible at 5.76m resolution. It also allows me to see the exposure live.
5. Compact
column3: powerful and incredibly sharp.

column1: 6. Low Cost for this quality and performance is insane. This competes with the medium format hybrids from Fujifilm and Hasselblad.
Cons:
1. low light focus still isn't perfect.  By this
column2: I mean I had a very fast-moving dog running around in a cloudy evening.  Invest in a good Speedlite or strobe. The ISO does pretty well for most situations.

column1: 2. You better have a fast computer.  These are very large files if you shoot raw.  I purchased a diskless raid array
3. I'm still not 100% on Sony colors. It appears underexposed and less on the magenta and yellow.  I will say this is not oversaturated like the A7III.

4. The body still feels cheap next to the NIKON Z7. It almost feels hollow but light.  I realize it is still an improvement on a7iii.  LCD- Resolution of 1.4M doesn't cut it in 2020. It also lacks pinch zoom and touchable lcd.
This is a very critical review and in spite of all of it
column2: it is still the best all-around professional mirrorless camera on the market."^5^Dec 30

column1: Sharma76^/sony-alpha-a7-iii-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6213101?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"At this point
column2: I have had the A7iii for a couple months now and have clicked roughly 3000 images - mainly of family
column3: pets
column4: and my 6 months old babygirl. I can honestly say that these are some of the best images I have ever clicked and that this camera has helped elevate my photography to a whole new level. I would recommend it to anyone in a heartbeat!

column1: A little background and more details...

I had been a dedicated Canon user for 10+ years with 70D (APS-C sensor) for my last camera. Unfortunately that camera had front and back focusing issues even though I had micro-adjusted all my lenses to it. I was so used to clicking 3-4 extra images for those can't-miss moments just to be sure one of them was a keeper.
Earlier this year
column2: I decided to go full-frame and lucky for me
column3: Sony had just announced the A7iii with features that were years ahead of anything Canon/Nikon had to offer at similar price point. After weeks of reading rave reviews from pros and amateurs alike
column4: I pulled the trigger and ordered my A7iii along with the 24-70GM lens. After 2 months of using Sony gear
column5: I couldn't be happier with my move.

column1: Here are a few pros and cons that you may not find in other reviews.
Pros:
- Eye AF: The hype is real! The Eye AF works (90% of the time) incredibly well and makes it super easy to take portraits. With it on
column2: most pictures are so razor-sharp that I can zoom into the eyes of the subject and find my own reflection. And that's not an exaggeration!

column1: - Excellent Low-light capability: On my Canon
column2: I rarely pushed past 1000 ISO because of high noise in low-light images. With A7iii
column3: I haven't purchased a flash yet so I am regularly forced to shoot in 10
column5: 500 range and the images still looking stunning after processing.

column1: - Less time in post-processing: Compared to 70D
column2: I find that less of my images need post-processing now and the ones I do have to process take less time.

column1: - File size: At one point
column2: I was seriously considering the A7(R)iii but now I am glad that I chose this camera. The 50MB files (uncompressed RAW) from this camera already make my 2014 Macbook Pro feel slightly sluggish. Can't imagine what 80-90MB files from A7Riii would have done to my computer.

column1: Cons:
- Sony software is worthless: the RAW processing software installed 3 different apps - a photo manager
column2: an editor and a remote shooting app. I found the apps a pain to use so ended up uninstalling after the first week and purchased Capture One Pro.

column1: - No built-in flash: I personally miss having a built-in flash. In most low-light situations
column2: I could take out my 70D from the bag and start snapping in seconds. I don't own an external flash for A7iii but past experience tells me it will definitely take longer to get snapping when I have to attach an external flash.

column1: With all that said
column2: I still rate this camera a solid 5 stars because of the incredible difference it has already made in my photos."^5^Sep 16

column1: NOTAFANOFBESTBUYANYMORE^/sony-alpha-a7-iii-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6213101?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"i've been waiting for awhile to get a full frame camera . i look at several different cameras. ended up with this Sony A7III
could not be happier with my choice. This camera has so many  functions and so many different ways to customize this camera function. very happy with the purchase"^5^Aug 12
SamPho^/sony-alpha-a7-iii-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6213101?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^5^"It's great when it works. I babied the camera. However
column2: two months out of warranty and the mechanical shutter causes a strange halo effect. Seems there are a lot of people with this issue online. Buy your extended warranty. The mechanical shutter shouldn't be this weak after only a year of use."^1^Jul 1

column1: MisterCrispy^/sony-alpha-a7-iii-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6213101?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"If you're still waiting for the A7sIII to come out
column2: this is a great solution to your problem.

column1: This camera has wonderful low light capabilities and is a dream to work with when it comes to shooting real estate photography.
RAW photos combined with 5-9 bracketed allows for wonderful HDR photography.
For video purposes
column2: I've paired the Sony XLR-K2M by connecting it via the Multi-Interface Shoe Adapter - allows me to capture 2 channels of audio and feeds directly off the battery.

column1: Lastly
column2: I'd have to say the biggest improvement with Sony's line of mirrorless cameras has to be the extended battery life...now I've taken it a step further and added a 2nd battery using the Sony VG-C3EM Vertical Grip.  This gives me hours of usage for both 4K video and photography.

column1: All in all
column2: it's a great camera and I'm glad I purchased it when I did.  I found an excellent open-box deal down in Fort Lauderdale and saved 25% off MSRP.

column1: The lens I'm using is the SONY 16-35mm f/4
column2: I opted for the f/4 over the f/2.8 because I felt the reason I'm purchasing this camera in the first place is for low light sensitivity
column3: so I just push the ISO up a bit more and it works just fine.

column1: Thanks for reading."^5^Sep 16

TimH^/sony-alpha-a7-iii-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6213101?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"This is A7iii is my second Sony camera. My other Sony is A77II. As much as I have enjoyed that camera it isn't even in the same realm. The images this camera produces are beautiful. I find the camera to be very user friendly with the exception of the menu system. I watched several videos on how to use/set the menu up and although those few hours were a bit dry did help me become confident in using the DEEP menu structure. The A7iii ability to gather light is nothing less than spectacular. The auto focus is as close to instantiations as seems possible as well as very accurate. I have not shot any video with it yet
column2: so I will leave those functions to others to comment on. The body is a bit small for my hands especially when paired with the 24-70 2.8 GM lens which is my only lens as this time. I felt the need to purchase a third party grip right away since I didn't feel very confidant in the grip I had with the enormous lens. The ability to set custom functions to several buttons makes many common tasks easy. I do miss the fully articulating screen of my other camera but I usually use the EVF anyway. The A7iii and A7Riii both have some firmware issues at the time of this review which have caused me to be unable to view pictures I have taken in camera. Yes that is frustrating but having read several articles I believe Sony will be releasing a Firmware update in the next week or two which will fix this bug. This is the sole reason I didn't give this camera a 5 star review. The lack of an included dedicated charger
column3: while annoying was not a major issue for me since I knew about it before purchasing my camera so ordered a charger at the same time. The menu structure while very DEEP allows a lot of customization which I appreciate. This camera allows the user to create their own menu for the settings which one most frequently uses and that is brilliant! I was disappointed Sony did not include a PC sync port on this camera but the Sony wireless adapter has one on it
column4: so not a major problem. The battery life is better than any camera I have ever had including several Cannons I had before switching to Sony. All in all I am very happy with this camera and encourage anyone on the fence to give this wonder a shot."^4^Dec 12

drew^/sony-alpha-a7-iii-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6213101?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"The good:

As full frame cameras go it's a great price. I've been very happy with the image quality and video capabilities. The battery life is significantly better than my A6500 crop sensor Sony. The build quality is also top notch.
The OK
You've already probably heard about the terrible menu
column2: terrible manual and lack of touch screen menu interaction. That actually doesn't bother me quite as much as it does other reviewers. There are tons of setup guides for it on Youtube and tons of customization with the hardware buttons and with the Fn menu. There are a few things I want to put on the Fn menu that I can't
column3: but overall once it's setup to your liking it's pretty easy to operate.

column1: The Bad:
No flip out screen. I mean
column3: that's been a staple of DSLR's for decades. Also
column4: no charger in the box. If I'm dropping 2 grand on a camera body
column5: you could either go ahead and provide one or just raise the price by $5 or $10. I guarantee nobody will notice that as much as they notice having to plug the body in to charge.

column1: The worst:

Sony really needs to get their act together with regards to software. Most camera companies turn out some pretty bad software but Sony really takes the cake here and in fact seems to be worse now than it was a couple years ago with my a6500. Transferring images to a mobile device is a hassle. Getting them to the computer relentlessly is a hassle. The NFC connection setup doesn't seem to work at all regardless if you're on Apple or Android. And this brings me to my final point:
This camera is not platform agnostic. It
column2: at least as of this review works MUCH BETTER on Android. I can't even get the app to connect to the camera on my iphone XS with everything updated
column3: and a few months ago when I could
column4: getting it to do so was a pain and only sort of worked. On my Samsung Galaxy S 10: no problem. Connected and working like a charm."^4^Jul 7

column1: Negative287^/sony-alpha-a7-iii-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6213101?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^24^88^"I bought this Kit a few weeks back
column2: as every review out there spoke about how good it is. Well
column3: reality vs potentially sponsored reviews are not always in sync.

column1: Heres what was actually good about the camera...
AF was very fast with native lenses.
Sensor has very low noise.
Video has a ton of good features and works fairly well.
Heres whats not so good about the camera.
The Meter is not in sync with the capabilities of the sensor and things that should be better handled by the meter often leave you with lost data in the Highlights (I know how to use a cameras meter
column2: this one is just very liberal with its settings).

column1: Skin tones are among the worst Ive ever had in a camera and two other people who bought this camera reached out to me to tell me they felt the same way.

Eye Auto Focus only works if the subject is facing the camera and even then it depends heavily on the lens for locking on. As soon as your subject turns their head at even the slightest angle away from the camera
column2: it is unable to get a lock on the visible eye.

column1: Sony set the contrast so low in the images
column2: in order to get a bette Dynamic Range out of the camera
column3: that you literally have to use their best lenses (with great microcontrast) in order to get a decent looking image out of the camera.

column1: Another point of failure is the fact that the camera doesnt come with an external battery charger and that creates major issues where youre likely to snap the door off while trying to charge the camera via the plug that was provided.
Even more
column2: the menu driven controls has you going through about 100 pages of controls just to configure the camera. Its one of the worst menu systems youll ever use and this is compounded by the ridiculously poor content in the cameras manual! The literally layout the whole camera menu system in the manual and fail to thoroughly explain several settings.

column1: If youre looking st this body and you dont need the 5 FPS burst rate
column2: just go ahead and grab the A7R II
column3: you wont regret that decision."^3^Jun 23

column1: Vlogger111^/panasonic-lumix-g7-mirrorless-4k-photo-digital-camera-body-with-14-42mm-f3-5-5-6-ii-lens-black/7588027?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^25^1^"Golden rule of great cameras is that it is the one that is with you everywhere you go. Smartphones rule. My Samsung S7 is amazing including credible 4K video capture included. But hold on a minute. Need a longer focal range
column2: want real soft focus blurred bokeh. You are out of luck. Low light performance is okay
column3: not great. That tiny sensor is the reason there. This camera still to a lesser extent has that issue too. More later.

column1: Body and Handling
Excellent placement of the programmable buttons
column2: and mode dials of which there are 2. Canon
column3: and Nikon say make do with 1. Tough! Price point folks. The flip screen with tilt is a joy too. Plenty sharp
column4: and easy in most lighting conditions
column5: and color rich. Full touch enable focus
column6: and menu functions
column7: and much much more
column8: make the handling a joy
column9: not a bust unlike my D7100
column10: and other DSLR cameras that bury it all in menus. The light body is a great go everywhere camera for Vloggers your ship has arrived. The grip is great for Gorilla hands like mine. But still small
column11: and light enough for petite hands. The Terrific EVF is a joy to see your image work with
column12: and the playback too! It is well contrasted
column13: and detailed to give you great information on your composition. You cannot do that on a DSLR Pentaprism system. Also the small lens size form factor is great. Though some lenses may approach APS-C size lenses
column14: but I will rarely need those anyway. So no hit there. This is my adventure camera while it will not necessarily be about the far away things for now
column15: it is about sharing my video adventures with my audience
column16: not so much about still images. Coming back to the controls
column17: and buttons
column18: the layout is perfection. Customization buttons allow you to create the just right instant control that is right for your workflow
column19: or preference. Everything is where I expect it even without reading the manual
column20: though I did anyway read it.

column1: Image Quality
Images in great bright light are excellent
column3: it will not beat the Sony a6300 or other APS-C cameras
column4: nor did I expect it
column5: but with a Metabones speed adapter
column6: and fast glass
column7: this will not be an issue for long. Color is vibrant
column8: and the white balance accuracy excellent. Detail is quite good. Though I want to get more with primes. The 30mm Sigma Art lens in an f1.7 is next on the list. The Rokinon Cinema glass is next too.

column1: Focus is contrast detect
column2: so this is not for real fast sports. It is slower
column3: but I didn't really find it a problem for me. Also note that Micro four thirds has a 2 to 1 crop. So a 30mm lens is really 60mm on this system.

column1: Video is outstanding. Couldn't be easier or more fun. The built in microphones are merely adequate just like any camera with built mics
column2: and so so preamplifiers. I use my Tascam DR-100 mk.3 SD audio recorder for the important must have great audio in the videos
column3: and marry in post. The Zebra Pattern
column4: and Focus Peaking
column5: and other unexpected video tools are welcome at this price
column6: and the leveling tool makes setup with my tripod which lacks a spirit level a breeze. Use a Vlog selfie tool
column7: or Joby minipod for your vlog work
column8: and you have the start of a great vlog sharing camera.

column1: So who is this camera for?
A beginner into an anything do it all camera they want to expand
column2: and grow with. It is for someone who hates big cameras
column3: heavy cameras
column4: and is not likely to take those beasts of burden with them. Or the complexity of DSLRs with their nested menus.

column1: This camera fits in my center console easily. Cannot say that with my Nikon D7100
column3: D70s
column4: Pentax K5mk.2
column5: or KS-2. This one is so handy. Also for folks with small hands
column6: for students in school who are doing vlogs for their yearbook
column7: or social pages
column8: and such. Or anyone wanting to do a vlog. This camera comes with a Mic Jack for external Rode mics
column9: or whatever for better sound. So while certainly not perfect
column10: this little camera that can

column1: Carrie^/panasonic-lumix-g7-mirrorless-4k-photo-digital-camera-body-with-14-42mm-f3-5-5-6-ii-lens-black/7588027?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^24^7^"I received a Panasonic LUMIX G7 camera. All opinions are my own.

column1: I reach for this camera when I want to take action shots of the kids. The 4K mode allows you to take several seconds (or up to 30 minutes) of video. You can break the video down into about 30 frames per second
column2: and pull any of those images from the video without losing any quality. So
column3: I can get a little video of my child jumping and then look at every frame and pick the ones that catch that exact moment I was looking for - which makes for some seriously amazing photos!

column1: Also super handy is the Panasonic app that allows you to connect your device to the camera and download the photos of your choice directly to your phone. This makes it super easy to share your pictures online
column2: because you don't need to go through the whole process of downloading them all on to you computer before you can share them (although I have done that
column3: too
column4: for editing purposes).

column1: This camera is exciting - it takes my photography to another level and really lets me capture movement in a new way."^5^Jul 20

column1: Leanne^/panasonic-lumix-g7-mirrorless-4k-photo-digital-camera-body-with-14-42mm-f3-5-5-6-ii-lens-black/7588027?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^17^4^"I received a Panasonic LUMIX G7 camera. All opinions are my own.
As someone who has a camera with me at all times
column2: the struggle is always between whether I want quality pictures or I want lightweight options
column3: because up until now there was no real compromise in my eyes. But
column4: in my never-ending search for a lighter weight camera
column5: I earmarked the Lumix G7 because it has interchangeable lenses as well as being mirrorless (which is quite possibly my favorite advance in cameras in the recent years). The fact that it has a touch-enabled screen so it is really user-friendly was the tipping point. But it wasnt until I tried it that I truly fell in love.

column1: The Lumix G7 totally blew me away in the DSLM (M= Mirrorless) category and took away the bulk and weight of traditional DSLRs without sacrificing image quality. In fact
column2: it has so many features that I adore that its now my most-used camera because it can do everything I need but can fit easily in my purse or diaper bag for days out without the gear.

column1: Some of my favorite features I didnt even know I needed:
The 4K shooting modes that allow you to shoot Ultra HD Video taken at up to 30 frames-per-second. Once you have your 4K file taken
column2: you can extract individual frames and save them as an 8-megapixel still image right from the back of the camera so you never miss that perfect moment. No more head swapping in Photoshop because everyone blinked or looked away at the wrong moment because the 4K mode takes all the guesswork out of timing the perfect photo.

column1: The Micro 4/3 lens system that makes for some super tiny lenses that pack a big punch. While I dont adore the lens it came with straight out of the box (14-42)
column2: I do love that its clear
column3: it has good range
column4: and it is impossibly small.

column1: The touch-enabled monitor will be your best friend. You can change most everything simply by touching the screen back and choosing settings from there
column2: including selecting those 4K images for saving. You can also focus right from the screen so you can simply tap what you want crystal clear and let the camera do the rest.

column1: The iAuto setting that automatically adjusts and selects the correct scene setting so you can get the best picture on the fly. Ive never tried an Auto setting I liked
column2: even on my super expensive cameras Ive owned or rented
column3: but I truly love the iAuto setting on the Lumix G7 for life with fast-moving kids. I can simply flip on the camera
column4: set it to iAuto and shoot away and I almost always end up with gorgeous shots.

column1: Built-in Wi-Fi to share all your beautiful photos on the fly. The Lumix G7 allows me to share right to my cell phone or tablet on the fly via the Lumix app.
While I could go on and on about all the features I love
column3: I should just say that I adore this camera. It allows me to capture that perfect moment easily
column4: which is perfect for the adventures we go on as a family as well being a great secondary camera for work without adding 10 pounds to my gear. It is so small that it slips easily into my purse or backpack
column5: which means I can always have it with me to grab at a moments notice. If you are sick of all the closed eye shots
column6: or pictures where your child is a mere blur across the image but you cant take a huge DSLR with you everywhere
column7: you will adore this little camera as much as I do."^5^Jul 21
