column1: sgaro^/panasonic-lumix-g7-mirrorless-4k-photo-digital-camera-body-with-14-42mm-f3-5-5-6-ii-lens-black/7588027?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^5^"I participated in an Ambassador Program on behalf of Influence Central for Panasonic. I received product samples as well as a promotional item to thank me for my participation.
I recently received a Panasonic LUMIX G7 camera and while I'm still getting comfortable with it
column2: I already know I love it! The 4K feature is key for capturing the good stuff
column3: those quick moments where smile are biggest
column4: eyes are brightest and time has really stood still. The first time I used the camera
column5: I wasn't familiar with how to use the 4K feature. But I loved the photos that I took just the same. The camera is lightweight and easy to take with you on whatever adventures you are setting out on. It's much less intrusive than when I bring my big DSLR camera. It is now the only camera I will take with me on a trip or even just heading out on an outing with my kids. And then I learned a little more about the 4K mode. I'm hooked! Shooting in 4K felt a little odd for me since I'm used to shooting the moment with a click of the shutter. Since we were at the beach
column6: and the kids were playing in the water
column7: I decided to try out the 4K Start/Stop mode. What this means is that you are basically taking short videos where you can then extract the perfect image after the fact! As I sat down with my camera once we got home from that trip
column8: and really started to go through the footage
column9: it became clear that this is THE way to shoot when you are taking picture of active children. I got some amazing shots of the kids in the waves that I would never have gotten in a regular mode. To be able to scroll through these videos
column10: frame by frame
column11: with the touch screen monitor is awesome. I was able to save some truly special moments captured this way. The fact that this camera has wifi and you can share you photos immediately is too cool and I'm beyond excited to play around with the Panasonic Image App which means I can control the camera from my phone! This technology is truly changing photography and how moms capture their kids!"^5^Jul 16

column1: PhotogVA^/panasonic-lumix-g7-mirrorless-4k-photo-digital-camera-body-with-14-42mm-f3-5-5-6-ii-lens-black/7588027?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"I have owned many mirrorless cameras. The G7 has very fast focusing and produces wonderful JPEGs
column2: something Panasonic camera's have not always done in the past.

column1: A great set of configurable external control buttons and wheels allow quick control of the shot parameters.
Panasonic has a lot of experience with 4K video and the G7 shows the results. With the 4K photo
column2: you can extract frames from video at 30 shots per second
column3: which allows you to capture just the right moment.

column1: The one missing feature on this camera is in-body stabilization. You need to have stabilized lenses with the G7 and the result is not as good as what Olympus is producing in their stabilized bodies

GeeZ2100^/panasonic-lumix-g7-mirrorless-4k-photo-digital-camera-body-with-14-42mm-f3-5-5-6-ii-lens-black/7588027?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"This camera makes me want to shoot more pictures more often! It's small and compact yet easy to hold and grip with confidence. It is very light and a bit plastic yet robust and not like a toy at all. Micro 4/3 comes with challenges such as finding a wide enough lens in order to deal with the crop factor. I was able to find a fairly inexpensive 9mm Olympus lens (which seems like a toy) and that becomes a 18mm equivalent as on a full frame sensor camera. Being a mirrorless camera makes it able to adapt many lens types such as old manual Canon FD lenses. Images can look super cool and with a wide open aperture
column2: you can get some very nice 'boke' as a result of shallow depth of field. The kit lens does perform well and yes
column3: the auto focus is not super quick like the new Sony cameras. I wouldn't use this to film fast moving subjects or sport events. It does shoot 4K and the images are stunning! The video is very crisp and the color is pleasing. It doesn't have the magenta tint Sony cameras seem to have. It doesn't have the golden richness of the Canon's either. Panasonic is in a nice place in the middle. Of course you can change things in the edit
column4: but it's nice having great color right out of the camera. There are some excellent guides out there that will help you set the camera for 'filming' video. This thing is a brilliant little 4K camera that's very affordable compared to its big brothers (G4 and G5
column5: G5s
column6: and G9). May not have all the features as they do but at this price point
column7: it pack a pretty considerable punch with light weight and wide range of adaptability
column8: the G7 is not only super for video but awesome for on-the-go picture taking.

column1: The swivel monitor swings out and can be tilted in many directions. So selfies or vlogging is easier than with most other cameras.

There a is a con: the battery door. It's on the bottom and can be difficult to place on a tripod because the plate can cover and block the door. Also the SD card is in the same compartment as the battery instead of on the side. This can be cumbersome to switch out a card or battery.
Despite the battery door
column2: I love this camera and it just makes picture and video taking more of a joy than any other digital camera I've ever had. Pleasure to use!"^5^Mar 3

column1: dennyordinary^/panasonic-lumix-g7-mirrorless-4k-photo-digital-camera-body-with-14-42mm-f3-5-5-6-ii-lens-black/7588027?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"everything about this camera is out there on the internet so theres no need for me to explain it in detail in specs wise. but from my personal experience while using it
column2: the g7 Blew my mind in overall quality and performance that i got for what ive paid for it. it was on sale for such a even great price! i have made a vlog using the g7 and uploaded it on youtube if you are curious about the video quality. the video is amazing although you wont get any professional features like the GH5 but for casual user like my self
column3: this camera should be more than enough!

column1: Now since i didnt really play around too much with the photo performance i cannot really tell if the g7 is a great camera for pictures or not but ive shot some pictures with it and i was pretty happy with the result. i tried manual then auto both resulting in good pictures as is without post editing. now the cons about this camera to me are only the build quality and the pretty slow auto fucusing when shooting video
column2: but those are not enough reasons for me to not giving this camera 5 star. they say you get what you pay for but for me
column3: i got more then what ive paid for this little amazing camera to be honest. not too long after i purchased the g85 came out! so unfortunatelly i had to exchange it with the g85 ( Thank you best buy for the hassle free return policy that cannot be beat!!) just because of its 5 axis in body stabilization which is AMAZING! Well Now thats going to be another review i suppose!LOL

column1: If you can find this camera for a discounted price or on sale and you are looking for your very first camera for mainly video rather than photos get this! if you care so much more about photo than video
column2: well maybe this camera is not for you look for canon or nikon or even sony cameras. good luck and have a great day!"^5^Jan 9

This camera has been of greater use and value to me than I ever expected it to be."^5^Nov 27

CamilleG^/panasonic-lumix-g7-mirrorless-4k-photo-digital-camera-body-with-14-42mm-f3-5-5-6-ii-lens-black/7588027?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"I received a Panasonic LUMIX G7 camera. All opinions are my own.

Every mom wants a great camera to help her capture her family's memories. I went from a basic point and shoot to a DSLR as my family has grown. Now I have moved on to the Panasonic Lumix G7 and I love it! I couldnt believe how lightweight the Lumix is compared to my DSLR. No more lugging around a heavy camera while juggling kids on vacation. The Lumix has a touch screen monitor which makes finding what I need in the menu very easy. The Lumix uses a 4K technology which means it takes a mini video of shots when you take a photo. You can then choose the frames you want out of the video and save as a photo. No more begging kids to stand still for just one second longer while I try to get the perfect shot. They can keep moving and I still great the photos I want. One of my favorite features of the Lumix is the phone app. I can now take an amazing photo on a great camera and then wirelessly send it to my phone to share immediately on social media. No more waiting to get home to download the photos to my computer to then upload them to the internet. If you are a mom looking to upgrade her camera and photography
column2: I highly recommend trying the Panasonic Lumix G7 for a lightweight
column3: high quality option."^5^Jul 20

column1: AprilC^/panasonic-lumix-g7-mirrorless-4k-photo-digital-camera-body-with-14-42mm-f3-5-5-6-ii-lens-black/7588027?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^2^"I received a Panasonic LUMIX G7 camera. All opinions are my own.

Panasonic Lumix DMC-G7 Mirrorless Micro Four Thirds Digital Camera with 14-42mm Lens is an easy to use camera and lens combo that you can take anywhere. It is extremely lightweight and user-friendly. There is an intelligent auto setting for video and photos so if you want to let the camera do this work
column2: you can without worrying that you'll miss something. If you prefer manual mode
column3: as I do most of the time
column4: all the important settings like ISO
column5: F-Stop
column6: White Balance and Shutter Speed have their own button or dial. This is important
column7: so you don't have to hunt for an important setting to catch the perfect picture.

column1: The 4k is the coolest thing I have ever used! I haven't missed capturing a baby smile since I got this camera. The 4k mode allows you to take 4k video and photos at the same time. All you do is hold down the shutter
column2: and it will keep going. Afterwards
column3: choose the shots you want to save! I've tried to get screen shots of videos on other cameras and it is just blurry and poor quality even with very high-end DSLR cameras.

column1: My next fave feature is the WiFi download ability. I can take photos and immediately transfer them to my phone so I can upload them to social media or just email or text them to my family. It's a huge time saver. This is also pretty simple to accomplish as you don't have to put in any password and just pair your phone and camera. You grab the photos from the Panasonic Image App."^5^Jul 20

column1: Shellche^/panasonic-lumix-g7-mirrorless-4k-photo-digital-camera-body-with-14-42mm-f3-5-5-6-ii-lens-black/7588027?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^5^"I participated in an Advocate Program on behalf of Panasonic USA. I received product samples as part of my participation. All opinions are my own.

When I was asked to participate in this program I was a little nervous. I am a iPhone photographer and have never used a proper camera before. When I received the camera it was slightly heavier then I expected
column2: but the weight makes it feel substantial. It feels good to hold and is comfortable in your hands. It is pretty small though
column3: which makes it easy to cart around and not awkward. One of the things I like most about using my phone is that it's always with me. Having the GX85
column4: was an easy transition to make because of its size.

column1: The touchscreen is also something that makes it easy to navigate through the menus. I liked how the screen flipped up and down
column2: making easy to take at different angles and perspectives. I mainly take street photography and the screen made it easy to use quickly when necessary. The camera is very quiet
column3: almost silent which I really liked because it doesn't draw attention.

column1: I also found I liked the viewfinder on this camera. It's bright and gives you a clear shot of what you are taking. I also liked how you can see the settings in the viewfinder making them easy to adjust. The pictures are very clear and sharp and the camera has very good capabilities in lowlight
column2: something that my phone is not very good at.

column1: I also liked the wifi capabilities. At first I had a bit of trouble connecting to the app
column2: but once I got the hang of it it was convenient.

column1: The battery life on the camera is decent
column2: but I found it went from two bars to no bars very quickly. Also
column3: having to charge the battery with the camera is not very convenient. If you are shooting for a long period of time or traveling I would suggest getting an extra battery.

column1: For this campaign I focused solely on taking pictures and did not use the 4K video at all. Now that I'm more comfortable with the camera I look forward to seeing what else it can do.
Overall
column2: I really enjoyed using the GX85
column3: it was easy to use and took very sharp images. I really liked the size of it and it made the transition into using a mirrorless camera effortless. I would recommend this camera to those who want something on the smaller side
column4: but do not want to sacrifice the quality of the images."^5^Jul 29

column1: WhitneyBITM^/panasonic-lumix-g7-mirrorless-4k-photo-digital-camera-body-with-14-42mm-f3-5-5-6-ii-lens-black/7588027?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^4^"I received a Panasonic LUMIX G7 camera. All opinions are my own.
I'll admit when I first saw the Panasonic LUMIX G7 camera
column2: I was intimidated. I am comfortable with my DSLR
column3: but it's so heavy and inconvenient to carry around every day. I have my phone
column4: but I was continually missing great photos of my children because they are constantly in motion.

column1: The Panasonic LUMIX G7 allows me to capture just the right moment with the 4K feature. Don't know what that is? It's awesome! The camera basically takes a video
column2: and allows you to choose which still from the video you want to save. You save it right on the camera with the touchscreen. It's unlike anything I have ever seen before! You can then send the pictures to your phone via wi-fi and an app from Panasonic. From there you can upload them to your phone and share across social media. As a mom
column3: it's great. As a blogger
column4: it's essential. I LOVE this camera!

column1: If you are looking for a lightweight camera that allows you to capture incredible moments even with constantly moving children
column2: and that's easy to share photos
column3: look no further. This is the camera you've been looking for."^4^Jul 22

column1: sgauger^/panasonic-lumix-g7-mirrorless-4k-photo-digital-camera-body-with-14-42mm-f3-5-5-6-ii-lens-black/7588027?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^4^"I participated in an Ambassador Program on behalf of Influence Central for Panasonic. column2: then you have to try this camera! I have been a long time Nikon user so it did take a little time to get used to the new settings. Overall I think it's very user friendly. It has so many neat features that my Nikon does not have.

column1: So far I love it! I can't get over how light weight the camera is. It's so easy to bring this in my diaper bag or purse and it does not take up a lot of room. My daughter is a playing soccer and I can't wait to take more pics of her playing. With the burst shooting
column2: I'll be able to take some awesome action shots. So far my favorite feature is the camera app you can get to easily share pictures fast! No more waiting on pics to download to your computer."^5^Jul 16

SouthwestJoe^/nikon-z6-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/6292226?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^21^0^"I'm a long-time Nikon user
column2: going back to film camera days. I've eagerly awaited Nikon's first full-frame mirrorless cameras
column3: and the new Z6 exceeds my expectations.

column1: First
column2: this is truly a Nikon. Build quality if outstanding
column3: and the look and feel is 100% Nikon. If you've used a Nikon DSLR
column4: you'l be right at home here. First and foremost
column5: picture quality is just outstanding. Detailed images
column6: with natural colors
column7: especially skin tones. I've always thought Nikon's colors were a standout
column8: and the Z6 continues in this tradition.

column1: There's tons of options for shooting different effects
column2: and the Z6 expands to include many additional filter effects I've not seen on prior high-end DSLRs (you can find these under the 'Set Picture Control' option
column3: most easily reached by pressing the 'i' button on the back. The touch-screen is a great feature here
column4: it makes navigation from the 'i' button quite natural and easy. I didn't notice any banding or moire effects in various outdoor shots at smaller apertures (shooting both the 24-70 Z lens and a number of my older AF-S lense via the excellent FTZ adapter). Hi-ISO performance is stunning. Even at 12
column6: there's amazingly little noise in the Z6 images. In sum
column7: the Z6 produces excellent images in either Raw or out-of-camera JPEGs.

column1: Highlights with the Z6 controls and usage are the huge
column2: bright no-lag electronic viewfinder. This is a joy to use! Even in very-dark scenes
column3: the viewfinder shows a bright
column4: clear image
column5: almost like night vision for very dark night scenes. There is truly no discernable lag here
column6: either.

column1: Nikon *finally* added U1-U2-U3 settings to the program dial
column2: a much better system than the 'shooting banks' from prior high-end offerings. This allows you to setup 3 different camera states (I use 'landscape'
column3: 'portrait'
column4: and 'action') and recall each with a simple turn of the dial. So much easier than the old method.

column1: Many early reviews (especially of the Z7) raised some issues with autofocus
column2: especially in tracking modes of faster-moving subjects. I've just not had issues in this area in a few days of usage of the Z6. The single point modes are great
column3: and cover nearly the entire image area. There's a 'nub' controller on the back
column4: perfectly placed under my right thumb
column5: that allows you to move this point easily over your subject. The Z6 was tack-sharp in nearly every photo using this method
column6: especially with the native 24-70 Z lens. The auto modes worked well
column7: too. It's not quite as quick to pickup less-contrasty subject in AF-C modes compared to my D500
column8: but it's pretty close. There is 3D subject-tracking mode under 'auto'. Press the center OK button
column9: and a white box appears. Move this over your subject (by either re-framing or the nub control)
column10: and half-press the shutter. The Z6 will now track this subject throughout the frame. Give a full shutter press when you want to take the shot. The framing box will continue to track the subject
column11: so you can keep taking shots as you like. Work's great. The Z6 uses a combination of shape and color info to recognize the subject
column12: and follows it throughout the frame. To reset the box
column13: you have to hit 'ok' again
column14: and you can start again. Easier to use than describe here
column15: actually.

column1: There's just so much more to say about the Z6. I haven't dived into video modes
column2: but all the other reviews say this is an extremely capable video camera. In-body vibration reduction (called IBIS - in body image stabilization) is another game changer on older lenses that lack this feature. Focus peaking (courtesy of the electronic view finder) means use of older
column3: manual focus lenses is quite easy! Between IBIS and focus peaking
column4: those older Nikon telephotos are starting to look like a real bargain.

column1: Mirrorless really is a game changer
column2: and Nikon's first full-frame versions are an outstanding advance. So many features here: in-body stabilization
column3: autofocus covering nearly the entire frame
column4: an outstanding
column5: high-res and no-lag viewfinder
column6: tons of picture and shooting options
column7: it all adds up to a highly recommended camera in a great
column8: compact form.

column1: I'm not selling my D810 or D500 just yet
column2: but the Z6 has become my go-to camera for most usage (I'm still shooting wildlife on the D500). Well done
column3: Nikon!"^5^Nov 21

column3: and portraits and a D700 for sports and theater.

column1: I have not had an opportunity to try the Z6 at any sporting events so I cannot comment on fast focusing or tracking fast moving subjects.

I have taken the Z6 camera out to shoot waterfalls and it performs wonderful. One of the main reasons for having an interest in this camera is because of all the focus points; covers almost entire sensor. This makes framing a scene very easy
column2: especially if your focus point is not in center of frame.

column1: The other feature that I was interested in was the Silent shutter; really works in this camera. The Silent shutter combined with the vibration reduction makes shooting slower shutter speeds handheld very easy.
I did not purchase any of the new Z-Series lens. I chose to purchase the FTZ adapter. All of my F-Mount lens work with no drop in performance.
Controls through touch-pad are very handy and easy to navigate.
Even though the camera is much smaller than my D3X or D700 w/grip
column2: the Z6 is very easy to hold.

Jimsgambit^/olympus-om-d-e-m10-mark-ii-mirrorless-camera-with-14-42mm-lens-silver/5044300?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^57^3^"I have been shooting with Nikons and Cannon both in Full Frame and dSLR format for the past 9 years. Suffice to say
column2: it becomes cumbersome carrying a large body camera and lens when trying to capture candid moments at events... or even Burning Man.

column1: I made the switch to Mirrorless before attending Burning Man this year. Partly because I did not want to sacrifice my 'good' camera but I definitely did not want to sacrifice quality shooting.
I cannot express how overwhelmingly impressed I am with the quality of photos I gather with the Olympus. I. Am. Sold.
#1. The fact it shoots in RAW is great for post edit (watch out LR5 users. the format requires a plugin'.
#2. It's so unbelievably small and light! I was able to carry it on me without any issues. It's the perfect fusion of point and shoot and SLR when it comes to compactness and features.
#3. I'm considering using this over dSLR for all my non-commercial/professional events. I'm shooting at the same level of quality with the Olympus. I've only tried 3 of the Olympus lenses
column2: none of the ones I've used are equal to my 24-70 Nikkor Lens- but who cares when you are just trying to capture the moment without having to lug the big gear!

column1: #4. This price point is BETTER THAN BUYING AN ENTRY LEVEL DSLR! Why spend $500 on an 'entry level' dslr when this will supercede that. I never thought I'd endorse a mirrorless as a starter camera- but you can do some great work with this Olympus. If it can survive 2 weeks in Black Rock Desert --- this is a solid quality camera."^4^Sep 19
Pagro^/olympus-om-d-e-m10-mark-ii-mirrorless-camera-with-14-42mm-lens-silver/5044300?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^4^"I was looking to upgrade my camera from a Nikon Coolpix P600. The Nikon worked
column2: but I wanted more. More definition
column3: better editing (RAW)
column4: more clarity
column5: more options. I did my research and kept coming back to the OM-D E-M10 Mk II. I am sure glad I bought it.

column1: Positives:
Lightweight - I use the same bag for this camera but have added a great 25mm prime lens. I can hike all day with this around my neck ready to shoot and not realize its there.
Fantastic features - the built in Image Stabilization (IS) has paid off in spades already. Shutter say 1/40 no problem
column2: clear as a bell no flash
column3: Less? steady yourself a bit
column4: you're probably okay.

column1: Drawback:
Menus go on forever - There are some shortcuts
column2: but I am not sure I will ever figure out all the menus. Not a serious issue
column3: since I have have also gotten into post processing
column4: so I shoot everything in RAW and JPEG - which you have to dig into the menus to turn on. But I bet if I mastered the settings my straight JPEGs would be even better
column5: and I could share more without editing.

column1: Not weather sealed - In the pacific Northwest you need to be careful to not destroy your camera in the weather.
Overall -- . A great camera and a good value. The kit lens has a pretty high minimum f stop
column2: and you can find some pretty good 25 mm primes
column3: with a 1.7 f stop for really good narrow depth of field shots and low light shots. But it is very serviceable
column4: I leave it on most of time.

column1: The photos I attached were taken on my first and second hikes with the camera. Its easy to get comfortable with."^5^Aug 18

Peter^/panasonic-lumix-gx85-mirrorless-camera-with-g-vario-12-32mm-f-3-5-5-6-asph-mega-o-i-s-lens-black/5163503?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^44^1^"I originally visited my local BestBuy for a different mirrorless camera that can record 4K video
column2: but saw they have the Panasonic GX85 in stock and ready for purchase 3 weeks before its actual retail release date! So I did not hesitate to pick this up.

column1: So far photos look great
column2: but 4K video recording is one of the best in class at this price range.

column1: Some important things to note if you are looking to get this camera:
1) Dual Axis Image Stabilization: The camera body has its own image stabilization and if you attach a Panasonic Lens (the lens will have its own built in image stabilization
column2: too) - the GX85 will use BOTH at the same time = dual stabilization for better photos and video. At the time of this review
column3: you cannot find a DSLR or Mirrorless camera for under $2000 with this feature!

column1: 2) New Sensor does not have low pass filter: Some camera brands have low pass filter built into the lens or the camera body's sensor. The purpose of low pass filters works as Anti-Aliasing to by blurring the outlines of the objects to help minimize or eliminating moire - but at the expense of sharpness. Since megapixels are higher in modern cameras
column2: low pass filters are no longer needed and the GX85 has no low pass filter = up to 10% sharper images.

column1: 3) It has Direct Wifi connect: You can remote control the GX85 with your smart phone by directly connecting to it (no need for router wifi). You can adjust the camera functions and transfer photos to your smart phone too. Just download and install the Panasonic app to your smart phone.
4) Make sure you have a SD Card that is U3 rated - otherwise you won't be able to use all the camera's features.
5) Micro 4/3 - other Micro 4/3 lens from other brands will work with this camera with no need for an adapter
column2: so you will have a good chose of lens or use lens from your current Micro 4/3 camera if you decide to make the GX85 your main camera.

column1: So far I am happy with this camera and just purchased a Panasonic Lumix 25mm f/1.7 lens to go with it - it takes much sharper images and video than the kit lens."^5^Jun 10

xdreamer^/panasonic-lumix-gx85-mirrorless-camera-with-g-vario-12-32mm-f-3-5-5-6-asph-mega-o-i-s-lens-black/5163503?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^24^1^"had this camera for 30 days. Took brilliant pics right out of box.
bought 2 lenses 42.5 mm portrait and 150 mm zoom lens.
pic of park in this review is not edited just out of camera

column3: iso 250

column1: I have been taking lots of 4K video
Have not used tripod yet.
Sales people at Bestbuy were very great
column3: 2 lenses
column4: strap
column5: cleaning kit
column6: tripod
column7: lens filters. All of those were price matched."^5^Jun 14

Well I took the pling and the pics from the GX85 puts the NEX 7 to shame. Color saturation
column2: detail are far superior. The biggest negative the GX85 has is it's so full features that it may take a year to learn everything. But the results will be worth it in the end."^4^Oct 14

It definitely exceed my expectations because it is an excellent walkabout camera and lightweight."^5^Jul 28

column1: Mark^/panasonic-lumix-gx85-mirrorless-camera-with-g-vario-12-32mm-f-3-5-5-6-asph-mega-o-i-s-lens-black/5163503?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^2^"My reason for purchasing a pocket camera is as a backup to my larger gear. I wanted very similar control of the settings that I have with the DSLR.
The LUMIX GX85 delivers on that requirement. The image quality is excellent with good saturation
column2: and the ability to shoot RAW allows a lot of latitude in post processing. Video quality is excellent also
column3: both in HD and 4K
column4: though 4K video requires a modern processor for smooth playback. The image stabilization seems to work really well. Most rolling movements are compensated very nicely and smoothly. It makes taking videos without a stabilizer pretty easy
column5: but still requires a gently
column6: slow
column7: steady hand for best results.

column1: Interchangeable lenses promise more creative uses for the camera
column2: but I've not explored that aspect yet.

column1: There are some drawbacks
column2: especially when compared against the DSLR cameras...

column1: There is a shutter lag
column2: even when the exposure is set to full manual. The short lens doesn't have a manual focus ring
column3: so the camera still performs that function
column4: and it's not as fast as I'd like. Still
column5: off-to-image time is very short.

column1: The rear view screen is really good in subdued light but almost useless in bright light. Fortunately
column2: the camera has an electronic viewfinder that switches automatically when it detects a face (or stray finger). It provides an adequate quality image for framing
column3: but the optics of the eyepiece create a distorted image to my eye. Part of the internal screen is blurry
column4: and I have to move my eye around to be able to focus on different parts of the screen. I was a bit surprised to find that sort of anomaly in such a high end compact.

column1: The panorama feature really does a great job. Most images come out looking simply beautiful. But the is one part of the process that I found difficult. If the light levels in the panorama are significantly different
column2: the camera doesn't hold the exposure I asked it to. My examples are subsets where the sun is still slightly above the horizon. The images are stunning
column3: but there is a very noticeable line where the exposure was reset by the camera. That may be a firmware issue and can be fixed in an update. My solution was to play with the starting point and width of the panorama to get one that was a consistent exposure.

column1: The supplied strap is too short for my style of shooting. I sling the camera under my right arm so it rides on my side or back
column2: limiting the potential for it to swing out when I bend or lean. The strap is too short to simply twist into position as I do with my DSLR
column3: and is a bit tight for letting my elbow slip easily through to bring it to a normal around-the-neck position. I've replaced it with a commercially available strap that ends up being as large as the camera. Adding maybe 6' to 12' to the strap would make a lot of difference (hint hint Panasonic...). Also
column4: a wrist strap would be a handy addition to the packaging. I've installed one in addition to the replacement strap for when it really does get carried in a pocket.

column1: As a true pocket camera
column2: this one doesn't quite make it because it is still a bit bulky. It won't go into any of my pants pockets like my little Canon
column3: but then none of the true pocket cameras I looked at gave me the image quality or control I was needing.

column1: Also
column2: the documentation says this camera is not weather sealed in any way
column3: so I'm still looking for a waterproof bag or enclosure that allows me retain control of the camera while letting me shoot in the rain. To date
column4: a gallon zip-lock bag and dry cleaner bags have served as weather gear.

column1: As a pocket camera
column2: this is a bit large and requires either a strap or a jacket to carry. But as an alternative to carrying a large DSLR for capturing sharp
column3: rich photos
column4: this is a wonderful little camera!"^5^Feb 27

column1: baldtat^/panasonic-lumix-gx85-mirrorless-camera-with-g-vario-12-32mm-f-3-5-5-6-asph-mega-o-i-s-lens-black/5163503?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I got interested in M43 cameras with a Panasonic G1. I found this one on open box special

I love the dual stabilization and ability to match vintage lenses to this camera. The rangefinder style is great for a mirrorless SLR style camera. When I put my right eye to the viewfinder

It was really sunny and the viewfinder let me take pix when people with just screens couldn't see what they were shooting. Video and low light capability is great

column1: jomo^/panasonic-lumix-gx85-mirrorless-camera-with-g-vario-12-32mm-f-3-5-5-6-asph-mega-o-i-s-lens-black/5163503?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^4^"This camera was a huge step up from my other gear. It performs better than any other camera I've ever owned in low light. There are enough features to have you reading the manual and the forums for days. Being a Micro Four Thirds camera
column2: it can accept a huge number of lenses
column3: and the kit lens it comes with is very versatile. You can shoot 4K video handheld in relatively poor conditions and still be amazed by the results. One huge advantage...NO 30 minute limit for videos (provided you have a big enough SD card). Good luck finding that feature on other cameras anywhere near this price point!

column1: The only real 'cons' are the lack of a hot shoe
column3: if you're serious about video production you'll have a separate audio recorder anyway) and the fact that you cannot use the camera while charging it. A simple purchase of extra battery/charger fixes that
column4: and anyone using these types of cameras with any serious level of frequency has an external card reader anyway."^5^Jul 17

ward^/panasonic-lumix-gx85-mirrorless-camera-with-g-vario-12-32mm-f-3-5-5-6-asph-mega-o-i-s-lens-black/5163503?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^1^"I really like the size and weight of this camera. It encourages me to just go out and shoot
column2: which I don't look forward to with a DSLR. It's very discrete
column3: especially using the tilting screen as a waist level viewfinder
column4: so you can get some great candid shots of people
column5: where as people often avoid you or pose if you've got a big DSLR up to your face.

column1: The image quality is very good although not quite up to the standard of a good APS-C or full frame camera
column2: but the differences are not likely to be noticeable unless you are making gallery sized prints or using very high ISO.

column1: Initially I thought the 4K photo modes sounded silly
column2: but they do turn out to be useful in some situations. You only end up with an 8MP image which can be limiting if you need to do some post capture cropping or make very large prints. The GX85 is not the best for capturing sports or other fast motion subjects because the auto focus can't always track a moving subject
column3: but the 4K photo capture mode allows you to get some cool still images at just the right moment of action
column4: assuming the auto focus worked well enough to get a sharp image.

column1: Again
column2: my favorite thing about this camera is the size
column3: but there is a downside to the compact dimensions - there's not a lot of room for your thumb. I found myself occasionally inadvertently hitting the buttons near the thumb grip. There is an after-market thumb grip that might help that situation
column4: but I haven't tried it yet. I'm hoping that I get used to it and learn to keep my thumb in the right spot. The kit lens is decent and very light and compact. If you like to reach out with a telephoto
column5: you'll need to get another lens as the max reach on the kit lens is 32mm (equivalent to 64mm on a full frame).

column1: I don't do much video so I won't comment on that aspect.
Overall it's a really fun camera at a reasonable price."^5^Feb 27

GeooeG^/canon-eos-rp-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6331672?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^0^"First
column3: I am a photographer
column4: not a videographer. So
column5: I don't use the video features and will not be reviewing those. I have been a long time Canon user. I started with a 630 SLR
column6: then moved to digital with an XT
column7: T2i
column8: 6D and now the RP. The main driver for this purchase was a 2 week trip to Ireland this fall. I wanted to find smaller camera. After doing a bunch of research
column9: it came down to the Canon R or RP. (I am sticking with Canon because I own several 'L' lenses.) I decided on the RP over the R primarily on price. I have been testing the camera for various situations like landscape
column10: street
column11: flowers/macro
column12: etc. and have been very
column13: very happy with the results. Specifically
column14: I am really thrilled with the electronic viewfinder. There are several aspects of the EVF that are a significant improvement:

column1: (1) the EVF is a what-you-see-is-what-you-get. So when shooting in Manual
column2: you see the effect of changing the F-stop
column3: aperture
column4: ISO as you change it. No more fishing for the depth-of-field button like on the 6D to see what is in focus.

column1: (2) seeing the light meter and histogram live in the viewfinder ... huge to be able to keep the camera at my eye and be able to assess the light levels when composing a shot.
(3) touch screen to move the focus point and see that in the viewfinder (along with a huge improvement in the AF function thanks to dual pixel).
(4) ability to review shots in the EVF ... at 57
column2: I need reading glasses to see up close and now I can skip the glasses and just review shots in the EVF in focus!!!

column1: There are a bunch of features I have yet to explore (4K time-lapse
column3: etc.) I don't find issues with hanging heavier lenses on a light body. I have only used my 24-105 F4 L Mark I with the RF/EF adapter so far and I have not had any issues with balance.

column1: Pros:
EVF
Dual-pixel autofocus
Touchscreen
RF to EF lens adaptor
Controls are well laid out
Built in intervalometer!!!
Cons:
Body is a bit small for big hands
column2: but I plan to purchase the grip extender.

column1: Battery life is quoted at 250 photos
column2: but most reviewers got way more than that. I have yet to run through the charge on the first battery
column3: but I bought a second one anyway.

column1: Overall
column2: I am super happy with the purchase. BB did not have the currently 'free' RF/EF lens adapter in stock
column3: so I had to way a few days to try the camera out. (Shipped to my house for free!) I plan to purchase the RF 35mm macro lens to use as a travel lens when I need a smaller/lighter lens."^5^Apr 25

column1: Anonymous^/canon-eos-rp-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6331672?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^0^"If you have Canon EF or EFS lenses or just want a small light and very capable mirrorless body this EOS RP is a good choice. This 26 MP sensor (much like the one found in the Canon 6D Mll) is very capable of producing outstanding still images. RAW converters are not yet out so I imagine those files would be even better. I haven't used it with all my lenses but using the Canon adapter my EF 35mm f2 focused fast and accurate. If you starting out the new 35mm f1.8 RF lens would be a better choice.
Not the best body for video
column2: Canon uses a crop of the FF sensor. The flip rear screen is a plus. I only use my cameras for still images so I can't comment on actual results.

column1: All and all this is a well built body at a great entry price."^4^Feb 27

column1: My only complaint is battery life so I do recommend that if you do purchase the RP

column1: Mindcontrol^/canon-eos-rp-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only/6331672?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Image quality is awesome. My APS-C Canon EF-S lenses also work well. The only issue is it shoots as a 1.6 crop at only 10megapixels. This is still fine for uploading to social media
column2: but for printing 10mp will give you about an 8x10 picture (max) with good resolution. The 1080p video is awesome. The feel of this camera and ease of use is unbeatable. There is really not much to dislike about this camera. My only concern is the RF lens prices are pretty astronomical. I'm not sure if they may a cheaper body only to upsell you on all these lenses. I'll have to save up for all these lenses that I want. For now I got the 35mm 1.8. It is a very good prime lens to pair with this camera. For now I've just been shooting around the house
column3: but I can't wait to see what kind of images it makes when I go out. As always
column4: Canon has some of the best colors around. They are so natural and vibrant. It does not compare to something like a Sony a7iii
column5: but that is around 700 more. For a first FF camera you really cannot go wrong with this."^5^Jan 23

column1: SA00^/nikon-z6-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-nikkor-z-24-70mm-lens-black/6292227?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^16^0^"I actually drove about an hour each way to see this camera in person and try it out (since these are difficult to find in stores). I actually was looking at it as a essentially a sanity check
column2: because I was strongly leaning toward the D750 instead of this camera.

column1: One of my main concerns about switching to mirrorless was
column3: EVFs vs OVFs. I will say this - the EVF on most modern mirrorless cameras is excellent
column4: but what Nikon has done with the Z series OLED EVF is a step above. In certain very low light situations
column5: an OVF is probably a little bit better
column6: but overall
column7: I now prefer the EVF. The exposure preview is excellent (although this is true on just about any mirrorless).

column1: The main advantage to this camera over other mirrorless cameras is usability and ergonomics. This camera has an excellent user interface and the ergonomics are superb. It feels great to hold.
Not all is perfect about this camera. Many reviewers complained that the camera only has one card slot. This is a valid concern
column2: but it is not insurmountable. For photographers that need redundancy
column3: the camera has WiFi built-in
column4: and can automatically transfer files to a computer over that WiFi connection. It isn't perfect and I certainly would prefer two card slots
column5: but for me at least
column6: it isn't a dealbreaker.

column1: This camera does use XQD instead of SD cards. Some users have complained about the switch because XQD is much more expensive than SD. This is true - XQD cards are expensive. However
column2: I'm very happy with the switch - 14-bit uncompressed RAW files out of this camera get close to 50MB. The data transfer speed of XQD is much
column3: much faster than SD
column4: and this is the kind of camera that needs it.

column1: Nikon says CFExpress support is coming soon in a firmware update
column2: so I would probably buy as few cards as you need (along with a card reader) and wait for the even faster CFExpress. For now though
column3: I'm really impressed with XQD compared to SD - I think it is worth the significant price bump.

column1: Some might like the touchscreen
column2: and I've found it useful in a few instances. However
column3: I've also accidently taken pictures I didn't want to with the touchscreen. I generally find the buttons easier
column4: but the touchscreen is there if I want to use it.

column1: Battery life is not a good as many DSLRs
column2: but that is the nature of mirrorless. A second battery is probably a good idea with this camera (although it was also a good idea with DSLRs).

column1: Technically
column2: the camera handles high ISO very well
column3: but eventually
column4: if ISO is high enough
column5: of course images won't be usable. The included 24-70 f/4.0 S lens is extremely sharp at every aperture. Of course
column6: many photographers will find the f/2.8 version of that lens to be more suitable for their work.

column1: Many reviewers (and even Nikon themselves) have compared the Z6 to the D750
column2: and the Z7 to the D850. I would argue that these comparisons are somewhat inaccurate - the only things that are really similar between the cameras are the resolutions. Essentially
column3: the Z6 is really just a lower resolution Z7 (and fewer autofocus points). Everything else is basically identical (with the Z6 actually being higher performance on a few specs). For example
column4: the Z6 and Z7 both have built-in focus stacking features. On the DSLRs
column5: the D850 has that feature
column6: not the D750. So in some ways
column7: other than resolution
column8: the Z6 is closer to the D850 than the D750.

column1: Overall
column2: this is a great camera. Is it perfect? No. But it was the only camera that 'wowed' me enough to get me to switch to mirrorless. For that
column3: in my opinion
column4: Nikon has a winner."^5^Mar 14

column1: Zathras^/nikon-z6-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-nikkor-z-24-70mm-lens-black/6292227?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^17^6^"I'm a professional photographer. Have been since '84. I've used Leica
column3: Canon
column4: Pentax
column5: Contax
column6: Hasselblad
column7: Rollei
column8: and even 4x5 Sinars and Linhofs. I have been waiting for mirrorless to be taken seriously by the big two (Nikon and Canon)
column9: or was going to go Sony. Now I know which way to go. This is a fantastic camera. The image quality is phenomenal. Video too. The kit lens that came with it
column10: the 24-70 f4 Nikkor S
column11: is amazing. Matched with this camera or the Z7 from Nikon
column12: it's a stunning performer. As good as anything I've used
column13: zoom-wise
column14: and even better than most prime lenses I've used in the past. The camera takes some study and getting used to. It's definitely not point and shoot. But with practice and study
column15: it becomes an extension of you with very easy to use menus. Way better than the competition. And it has much better weather sealing than the Sony mirrorless cameras. It is now my favorite camera. I'm selling everything else."^5^Dec 13

column1: v3rlon^/nikon-z6-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-with-nikkor-z-24-70mm-lens-black/6292227?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"Nikon took a while to get into the mirrorless full frame camera market
column2: but the result is an unmistakably Nikon Camera. If you are a Nikon lover that has been waiting to make the jump
column3: but see that the future is mirrorless
column4: this is a solid camera.

column1: I came from a D750. I tried a GH5 because of outstanding video and people were talking about how much smaller and lighter M43 was. The truth is
column3: you do not save much of anything. A D750 with an 85F1.8 compared to the GH5 with a 42.5 F1.2 (35mm equivalent to 85mm with F2.4 DOF) was within one battery of weight
column4: and you needed the extra battery on the GH5.

column1: I went through a Sony A7RII and A7III. One
column2: Sony lenses are expensive and heavy. I also didn't like the menu system. I thought it was far to much trouble to just manually focus when the camera and I disagreed on the subject. Finally there are the options for saving images.

column1: The latest firmware on A7III give us 1. Uncompressed Raw (giant files). 2. Jpegs (except for certain use cases
column2: why spend this kind of money to shoot cell phone images)
column3: and 3. Compressed RAW - but it is a LOSSY compression. Why would anyone want that?

column1: The Z6 is a Nikon. It gives a Dynamic range that matches or exceeds the D750. You get a stabilized sensor to help with slow shutter or video. The firmware in May will bring eye tracking AF
column2: but the current subject tracking isn't bad at all. The pictures coming out of the camera look good
column3: even at higher ISO.

column1: The battery life could be better
column2: but if you don't leave wifi on and work reasonable
column3: a single battery will last a LOT longer that 330 shots. I have been able to go all day on one battery.

column1: Memory card slots. Yes
column2: this camera has only one XQD/CF Express slot ( and yes
column3: they are expensive). They are quite reliable. I didn't have trouble with SD cards as far as it goes
column4: but these are even better. One slot is good enough for Aria
column5: and they are FAR more expensive than this. Your mileage may vary
column6: but it was never an issue for me. I WISH there were two
column7: but I can easily leave with one.

column1: I also really like the display on top for things you see on the other Nikons. It boots up and take pictures faster than the Sony
column2: especially after a batter swap. The A7III could take a good 15 seconds if the batter was changed. 1.2-1.5 on the Nikon.

column1: The FTZ adaptor gets all the old F mount glass work so you can patiently wait for your favorites
column2: but the 24-70F4 is probably the best kit lens in the history of kit lenses. It is a cut WELL above what you usually see."^5^Mar 29

baadnewsbear^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^17^6^"Obviously this is a great camera
column2: and we purchased this for a couple reasons. Here are my Pros and Cons after messing with the camera for a week.

column1: Pros
1. More compact than my Canon 5d Markii
2. Video quality is amazing (resolution/auto focus)
3. Wifi capabilities to transfer images straight to web
column2: Ironic because with such a high quality camera all i've done so far is upload images to Facebook and instagram...

column1: 4. Quick and quiet shutter
5. In-camera filters
6. exposure compensation easily adjustable
7. zeiss lenses <3
Cons:
1. Battery. Be ready to purchase a couple of these because they drain very fast. Im assuming its because it uses both screens along with lots of other features.

2. I've tried to use the camera without the back screen on but you have to look through the view finder to go through menus which is not easy. Not sure why Sony didn't add a feature where you can just view the menu on the back screen and use the view finder as just a view finder.
3. metabones adapter for canon lenses is disappointing. I understand that communication between 2 different models can cause confusion and is limited
column2: but it shouldn't effect sharpness. Im really disappointed that my 70-200 ii isn't as sharp as it is on the canon. Oh well
column3: just means i need to save for more Sony lenses.

column1: 4. While I'm ranting about lenses
column2: Sony doesn't offer a Zeiss Lens that is larger than 70mm

column1: 5. Was having difficulty recognizing raw file on photoshop CS6
column2: but works with CC. So that means more purchases in order to edit raws.

column1: Overall
column2: this camera was a great purchase for our family. Seems to be great for what we use it for. This camera delivers on the fact that it is convenient. As all cameras have their strengths and weaknesses I always say go with the one that feel best in your hands."^4^Dec 8

column1: SonyCameraGuy^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^1^"This camera is a significant advance over the SLR and SLT cameras I have owned (film and digital). You will need very good lenses to keep up with the sensor resolution
column2: but Sony has quite a few now (SEL2470Z and SEL90M28G are currently serving me well in that capacity). The multitude of focusing options take a while to master
column3: but are well worth the effort. The high ISO performance is excellent! I routinely use 6400 with stunning results. The A7RII provides an adequate frame rate for stills (5 FPS in Speed-priority Continuous mode)
column4: but one cannot expect images of this size to transfer quite as quickly as with other Sony cameras (e.g. 12 FPS for A77). Sony has e-mount specifications freely available and there are mount adapters for almost any lens you can name. Some even allow the functioning of in-lens stabilization with Canon and Nikon lenses. The batteries are small (to match the size of the body) relative to SLR and SLT models so you may need 3 or more for an all-day outing. Be warned of three potential consequences of purchasing the A7RII: 1) you will pixel-peep
column5: 2) you will get a serious case of lens lust
column6: and 3) you will spend a more time with your camera (and have fun doing it)."^5^Jan 6

column1: Louie^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^6^"This camera is absolutely amazing. So all that being said i would recommend this to a serious photographer or someone looking to start a small business in photography. The A6000 is also a great little camera to start out on. But why not go the distance and 'Go Big Or GO HOME' So buy and buy now!
Also the Pictures attached were with a Zeiss 55mm lens"^5^Aug 11

column1: colonial66^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^12^4^"The 43MP sensor on this camera is ahead of anything offered by other pro system makers in the full frame 35mm sensor market. Hats off to Sony for their engineering brilliance. I recommend the Sony Vertical grip which holds two of the puny batteries and keep two more spares in the bag. That should cover the longest scenario of a 12-hour still shoot."^5^Sep 4

dcisive^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"I've been a professional digital photographer since 1999 having owned several Canon pro and half a dozen pro Nikon bodies and their top lenses. Multiple flashes and more along the way. DSLR's still rule regarding fast moving subjects in lower light
column2: BUT this Sony A7RII is the NEW King of the Hill for shear image quality. It has the finest dynamic range
column3: best low noise in higher ISO's and is a pure joy to use ditching the huge and heavy DSLR gear in general. To maximize one's results you are best off going with primes in the 20mm to 90mm range if possible as the resolution on this camera is so tremendous that in order to appreciate and realize it primes are the best lens choice I don't recommend the 24-70 f4 Zeiss as example for it's full of too many compromises. I recommend the 35mm f2.8 Zeiss for walk around and for serious and special results you can NOT beat the 55mm f1.8 being about perhaps their finest overall lens. If you need longer and can swing the price
column4: there is NO question the 70-200G f4 lens is THE lens to own. Sharp wide open from one end to the other and solidly and professionally built. If you need a lens that can do it all don't hesitate to consider the FE 24-240 as it covers it ALL for general use. The HVL-43M is THE best flash for this camera no doubt. The plethora of picture adjustment possibilities are endless. The Jpeg results are by far the finest Sony has ever accomplished. RAW is no longer essential for dramatic results. The Video is industry leading for quality and so easy to use. I was amazed at the quality of the sound just from the built in mics. The screen is plenty large
column5: bright and sharp. The buttons have a quality feel and are NOT mushy by any means. Its a lot of money but this is an ultimate body and deserves great lenses."^5^Jan 29

column1: Hank^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I love this camera. The images are great and there are many options available for tweaking and creating excellent stills and video. The five axis internal stabilization is excellent and works well. However
column2: the menu system takes a lot of getting used to and the manual is sparse particularly regarding settings. If you have already used any of the alpha cameras from Sony you should be able to quickly adapt. Brian Smith has a very good book available at Barnes and Noble and Gary L. Friedman has a 642 page manual with lots of useful detail available on line."^4^Jun 20

column1: Scott^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"I love this camera. It does so much so well. Wifi
column2: special apps that allow for real time HDR
column3: water smoothing
column4: etc. The 42.5MP backlit sensor is giving me beautiful images. I'm able to shoot up to 3200 ISO for events and it looks great. I may try to push it further. E-Mount lens focus functionality is second to none. You can use A-Mount lenses also with an adapter with great results too
column5: though you lose some of the focus functionality available with e-mount lenses
column6: but I've used both with great results. Battery life is not as good with my Sony A700
column7: but with I added a vertical grip so I could put in two batteries. It is acceptable and I can generally get through an event. PLUS this camera does 4K video with excellence. There is nothing about this camera I don't like. That being said
column8: if you shoot stills and have all A-mount lenses
column9: you may wish to wait for the new Alpha 99 mk II coming out in November 2016. The video functionality is not as good
column10: but you don't need to move to e-mount lenses. If you shoot mostly video
column11: you may prefer the Sony A7S mk II. It has a very special sensor for low light video that the A7R does not have
column12: but it's only 12MP for stills. If you want the best of both
column13: the A7R mk II is simply outstanding. I'm very happy with the purchase. Now -- for those of you who do not think of Best Buy as a destination store for cameras
column14: I understand -- BUT -- They were able to get the camera when no one else was
column15: the staff was great
column16: maybe not as knowledgeable as a 'true' camera store
column17: but if you add the Geek Squad protection (at an extra cost) you are set. When I need a camera repair
column18: it's always a minimum of $400. My cameras are in the shop way more than I want them to be (I'm hard on cameras and lenses). The first repair will pay for itself. I'm sold."^5^Oct 17

column1: Nestor90^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^1^"I have had this camera for about a month now and I am still blown away with the video and pictures this thing outputs. It is expensive but I can honestly say that it is priced this high for a reason. When i bought into it I was not happy with the lens selection but it really seems like Sony has listened and came out with the 50mm 1.8 that is affordable as a starter lens. I mainly use this camera for church events that are indoor and sometimes not well lit except on stage. This camera has made it possible for me to take pictures and video with such good quality and visibility in low light giving me more options for angles I never knew could be attained during some of the church services. Now the only thing I am waiting for is more budget friendly lenses like the 50mm."^5^May 31

ImagineAkira^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"For months I compared it to canon and Nikon. Review after review on YouTube. I started w the A6000 and made the jump to my A7rii. Trust me
column2: nothing compares to the dynamic range of this camera. There's tons of features and specs
column3: but I'll get to the point
column4: I'm a portrait and landscape photographer. This camera is amazing for me because it's so light and so powerful in every department. Highly recommend this. I have the Zeiss 16-35 f4. Just purchased the 85mm 1.4 g master. Waiting patiently for it to ship. Suggest pairing this w the rotolight and mono pod (for portraits). Incredible combo."^5^Mar 5

column1: darver^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"Having been a Canon shooter for 10 years it was a hard choice but Sony did just enough to make me switch (and Canon hasn't been too impressive lately anyways). That being said
column2: this camera is a FANTASTIC VIDEO camera and a mediocre Photo camera. The S-log footage that was passed on to me in post processing/editing is what made me have to have this camera. It is amazing to be able to edit with. The dynamic range captured with this camera hold up fantastically in post. Add in 120fps and I was in. The bad news is that the auto focusing hunts when it is not in full sunny perfect conditions. The adapter for my Canon lenses is ok
column3: but if you want to shoot seriously with this you better be ready to switch to all Sony Lenses (which are not bad at all). Just don't expect your 3rd party glass to hang with this adapter. I usually manual focus everything anyways since I'm doing mostly video and when I do do photos its usually not with a moving model. I'd say if nailing the photo shot is what you are looking for this is not the camera for you. If you want an AMAZING video camera with internal 4k that is a fraction of the cost and the size of the other 'big boy' cameras that offer this
column4: then this camera is definitely for you."^4^Oct 28

column1: eVojlib^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"Its amazing how much Sony was able to put into this camera while maintaining a fine balance of Image Quality and features.
There really isn't anything this camera can't do well; however
column2: with adapted lenses and even native lenses this camera will focus good but not perfect with faster objects.

column1: Some will complain the shadows show high levels of posterization
column3: if you shoot a black bear inside a coal mine around midnight no lighting your asking for trouble. (Basically don't expect the camera to recover 15 stops of shadow detail and you may want to properly compose the shot next time)

column1: I personally shoot everything from landscape to urban city scape and this camera delivers
column2: I can't say the same for the A7R which was still a fantastic camera but shooting handheld can yield some slightly blurred images if you didn't increase the shutter speed.

column1: Overall with its new stabilized body
column3: Improved auto focus and a host of other features this camera will promise to match or exceed the results from say the 5Ds and D810.

column1: Every camera will have an area where it will fall short
column3: this camera does a lot of things very well and better composition and planning of the shot will go a long way in achieving the best results."^5^Sep 18

column1: NedD^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"i got the camera to replace my Sony a7 r and am very happy with the new version It did not work with an old Sigma wide lens but works well with all my other camera lens. column1: Quint^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I had outgrown my old Nikon (entry-level DSLR) and was ready for an upgrade. 1. weight
2. great image quality (especially during low-light scenarios)
3. great lens family (something I had not done in the past
column2: but knew I was going to do going forward).

column1: PRO

I've been shooting in various location and lighting scenarios over the last month and LOVE the image quality. Night shots are beautiful too! ISO range allows me to capture small details with no/little graininess. My entry-level camera night shots always left me wanting more clarity. I can't look at night shots taken on my mobile phones anymore. Why did I ever bother? Haven't done much with video yet so can't speak to that....yet.
CONS
Batteries don't last long. Two full batteries lasted a half-day excursion at a forest in Fire Island. Just ordered more for days I know will last longer
column3: this adds to the overall price of the system. This does keep the camera weight down though. A tradeoff for wanting a lighter camera.

column1: price? This is some pricey equipment. Something cheaper might be good for what I currently do
column2: but this is also something I want to grow with as I step up my photography game."^5^Aug 11

column1: BestD^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Ive had this camera for over a year now and have shot 1000's on 1000's of photos. It produces some really great pics!

column3: for stills and video. Lightroom processes RAW very well too.

column1: Animorfix^/sony-alpha-a7r-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-4k-video-camera-body-only-black/9591139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^4^"This camera is a beast. I have both the a7sII and the a7rII and both are amazing cameras. I am a videographer who does occasional still photography and I would chose the R over the S mainly because I shoot in some light and the autofocusing is better on the R versus the S.
The low light is better on the S model but the R holds its own. If you don't plan on shooting on pitch darkness
column2: the R might be a better choice due to the ability to hold focus better (in daylight). I must also ad that the low light is comparable when the R is in APSC mode. The full frame mode in low light is abysmal. With that being said
column3: I use canon glass (both FF and APSC) and they work great with this camera. I am also using a Metabones IV Canon to Sony E-mount and the autofocusing is almost native.

column1: I would highly recommend the Sony a7rII for both stills and video. Though
column2: if you plan on shooting in extreme low light conditions
column3: go with the S. If you have some light
column4: the R is a better all around camera."^5^Jan 30

column2: the A7R II hits the mark very well. Relative to that full-frame DSLR this thing has the following pros:

column1: - amazing electronic viewfinder that works very well
- compact package
- image quality is superb
- so much detail
These are the negatives:
- high ISO is decent but not great (5DIII was better for me)
- AF is good for people
column3: outdoor/landscape photog etc but not great once the lights get low or when your subject is moving quickly

column1: - lens selection could be better but with the amazing 35mm collection and 85mm Batis I am mostly covered for now
- menus are just not as good
I considered going back to the 5D III
column3: considered the 5Ds/R and just couldn't find an overall package that was going to be better than this once the right lens (Zeiss Batis) was released and the A7R II was released. Go read some reviews and see for yourself. If you have the money you won't be disappointed."^4^Aug 19

column2: watched all the videos and decided to sell all my Nikon equipment and make the change. That is really important here because this camera is amazing in every way possible EXCEPT for sports shooting. The focus system is extremely complicated but one you figure it out it is AMAZING! Ok now for the down
column3: this doesn't affect me because I mostly shoot portraits but this would make me very nervous at a wedding or paid event. If you shoot high speed continuos first of all its only good for about 10 shots before it slows down and shortly after stops. The camera has froze on me twice doing this so bad that I had to wait a long time and then take the battery out to get it reset. I love the size
column4: I love that I can see what is being exposed prior to shooting very accurately and the quality of photos even at ISO 6400 and above are unbelievable. I will note I am only shooting with Carl Zeiss lenses but none the less. If you are looking for a light way low light beast and you are not shooting events or weddings for a living this is your camera. Amazing! I hope Sony will fix the bugs as this was a LARGE investment to have these types of freezes happen. Overall I still rate it five stars because the results don't lie and this has improved my results far beyond what I even imagined when prior purchase."^5^Feb 21

mgphoto^/sony-alpha-a7-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-video-camera-body-only-black/1633004?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^15^0^"I am a Canon 5D Mark 3 shooter who bought this Sony a7ii as a lighter weight travel alternative. I tried point and shoot cameras but they just didn't take the quality of photos that I was looking for. This camera is almost as good as my Canon 5DM3 but not quite as good in low light but it's a trade off I'm willing to make when I am traveling. The smaller size makes up for it. I bought the 55mm Sony lens and have been very happy with the clarity I get with this combination of camera and lens. In normal shooting instances it's on par with my Canon 5DM3 and the Canon 50mm L series lens. I guess if I had to complain about anything it would be the lack of Sony prime lenses that are available for the Sony a7ii. I do understand that there are new lenses being released this year which should help. I have used some of my Canon lenses with this camera using an adapter. The results aren't as good as I had hoped. Autofocus isn't available on all of them and when it does work
column2: it's slow so I usually end up manually focusing. Overall I'm very happy with the image quality and portability of this camera and would definitely recommend it to others looking for a full frame
column3: lightweight travel alternative to a large DSLR."^5^Apr 3

column1: Marrow^/sony-alpha-a7-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-video-camera-body-only-black/1633004?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^1^"I shoot Canon 5Dmkii with a series of EF prime EF lenses. column1: iso500^/sony-alpha-a7-ii-full-frame-mirrorless-video-camera-body-only-black/1633004?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^4^"As a professional photographer
column2: who has recently switched from traditional DSLR camera bodies
column3: to the new wave of mirrorless cameras
column4: this new Sony a7ii model
column5: is packed with pro functionality

column7: this camera blows away everything in it's price point and up to around $5k. The body is rock solid. (I actually dropped it the first day I purchased it
column8: from about 3feet in the air
column9: and it bounced around 3 times on parking lot pavement
column10: and I only ended up the a scratched lens hood?). The weather sealing is excellent
column11: all around. The dials and function buttons are laid out in a very usable way
column12: and can be customized to fit a very simple or complex workflow. The viewfinder is very sharp
column13: with great color. The LCD back panel has a 'retina' display look about it. I coupled it with a Zeiss 24-70mm f4
column14: and the image quality is superb
column15: with robust color
column16: contrast

column18: with the sharpness and dynamic range of a Nikon full frame. The 5axis sensor stabilization
column19: and the ability to retro-fit Canon and Nikon glass
column20: are 2 amazing features that put this camera body in a class of it's own. Sony is paving the way for future mirrorless technology!! I would recommend this to a beginner because
column21: the improved workflow through the camera's functionality allows a new photographer to concentrate more on composition and lighting
column22: and not have to worry about frustrating things like making sure that your subject is in focus
column23: due to it's face detection technology. Novice photogs will also benefit from AUTO mode
column24: due to the factory programming preference
column25: that prioritizes a fast shutter speed
column26: so that good focus and exposure are achieved
column27: with little to no thought process from the camera operator. But
column28: I also recommend this camera to experienced and professional photographers
column31: and the customization of menus and buttons for providing a very intuitive and efficient workflow(focus magnification
column37: etc.) This is truly the most under rated camera by far
