column1: NotSoNoob^/sony-alpha-a6500-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/5655633?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"There really isnt another camera that compares with the A6500. I have seen comparisons between this camera and the Canon 80 D
column2: but that isnt fair to Canon. The A 6500 is superior to every Canon
column3: Nikon or Panisonic camera that has an APS-C or Micro 4/3rds sensor. The advantage starts with 4K video
column4: in body image stabilization and one of the best auto focus systems available. All of this in the smallest interchangeable lens body that makes it super handy to take anywhere with you. This is a true hybrid system and while some cameras might compete in the photography arena
column5: none give you the best of both video and photography.

column1: There are a few areas that Sony can improve and these are areas that other big names like Canon and Nikon have the edge. The biggest downer is battery life. While Sony has developed better batteries for the full frame cameras
column2: the A6500 still uses the smaller battery. This was not a deal breaker for me. I just got extra batteries and Keep on shooting. The lens selection is still limited compared to Nikon and Canon. However
column3: this is improving and I have never been in a position in which there was not a lens that would do what I wanted. Finally
column4: there are better menu systems. You might try an A6000 if you are new to SLR cameras. I have one of those as well and after a year of use
column5: I felt comfortable stepping up into the A6500. It is a big jump.

column1: Some other highlights of the A6500 is the ability to record at 120 frames per second so that you get buttery smooth slo-mo. You also have access to an App Store to get additional functions added. The A6500 has WiFi and Bluetooth so you can remotely connect to your phone to wirelessly control
column2: upload photos and video or use as a monitor. The A6500 has a high speed shutter speed of 11 frames per second for action photography and a huge buffer so that you can just keep churning out the shots. Thats another feature that most other cameras reserve for there higher end full frame models if they can shoot at that speed.

column1: Eduardo007^/sony-alpha-a6500-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/5655633?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I
column3: looked all over the internet for reviews on this and many other cameras. That meant countless hours watching reviews
column4: reading reviews on here
column5: looking up guides
column6: and so on. I came to the conclusion that this one was the one for me. The selling points for me were the small form factor
column7: the evf
column8: and steadyshot. The evf was a big deal to me as it would let me see what my shot would look like in real time and it shows a lot of information on there as well. Steadyshot was necessary as I wanted to make videos and I didn't want shaky videos so I went with something that had optical image stabilization. Lastly the small form factor makes it easy to take anywhere. The only downside that I could think of for getting this camera is that you would have to invest in the lenses. They are not cheap by any means. So if you want this camera you have to have a good amount set apart for lenses as well since they will always work better than cannon or Nikon lenses with an adapter. That being said it's an excellent camera and the lenses are some of the sharpest I have seen for both video and photography so I would say it is worth it. If you are debating whether to buy it or not
column9: I would say to go for it as it's one of the best value cameras on the market right now."^5^Jul 23

column1: RLW2017^/sony-alpha-a6500-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/5655633?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"The Sony A6500 is a nice camera for the consumer from beginner to enthusiast. I spent time researching before purchasing and several major reviews listed it as a good choice. The camera has excellent photo quality and video quality as well
column2: a strong comprehensive package. The trio of Sony Alpha 6000s share most features; however. The model differences are important to operation. The 6500 has the same rating on its photo quality as the 6300 as they share the updated copper designed innards given them the one-up on the previous models. The other difference is that video is better on the A6500 as Sony seems to have gotten the Video to no longer have a time limit before thermal shutdown. Something you read a bit on with regard to the previous models. The camera is an APS-C sensor design which classifies it in most circles as a non-professional camera due to its ability in lower light settings over that of a full-frame but there are other considerations- price and lens price specifically
column3: that make the APS-C a great choice for all but those perhaps with photography as a career. I recommend this camera to those who want a smaller platform to take photos and videos that are really good but don't want to break the bank getting a nice camera."^5^Jun 30

I recommend starting with what you know (full auto if you are new to photography) and then take time each week to learn at least one new features. You'll be surprised how versatile this camera can be.

column1: HelloMikee^/sony-alpha-a9-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/5865600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^24^3^"-- SUMMARY --
While the Sony a9 is marketed hard towards sports photographers
column3: the added features
column4: upgrades and improvements the Sony a9 offers over the a7 series makes it a workhorse of a camera to suit a variety of photographers needs. Workhorse is a term used mostly for robust DSLR's and something you never really associated with a mirrorless system. All that changes with the Sony a9. It's most definitely capable of handling almost any photography assignment.

column1: -- BUILD & CAMERA CONTROLS --
The build quality of the body of the a9 feels very much like the a7R II with an unnoticeable gain in weight and grip size. With that said
column2: thats pretty much where the similarity ends. Everything else feels more robust in the hands
column3: Im assuming that has a lot to do with upgrading the buttons and dials which feel much more substantial and tactile.

column1: The back dial is much more firm so you wont be accidentally turning the wheel when shooting. I do wish the dial was a bit bigger because now that its more robust
column2: it does take a tiny bit of effort to turn and when its that small
column3: it isnt necessarily the easiest. Of course
column4: thats a minor complaint because in use
column5: its totally fine.

column1: The buttons themselves arent as recessed as they are on the a7R II making them feel more clickable. Its funny how such small details can really elevate a product to a more premium level. I never thought the buttons on the a7R II felt toy like
column2: but as I go back and forth
column3: the difference is undeniable.

column1: -- UI & OPERATION SPEED --
The a9 takes on Sonys new menu UI. Like Ive said before
column2: I never really had issues with the organization of the older menus. Theyre ugly but that was about all I thought about them. That thought process has chanced now that I have a camera like the a9
column3: where it is so feature-packed
column4: a good menu really is key. Add to that the ability to pretty much custom assign all the buttons
column5: the quick access menu and the customizable My Menu configuration
column6: you are absolutely covered in terms of finding key functions quickly.

column1: One of the few things I hated about the a7R II is how slow and unresponsive the camera can sometimes be. I rely a lot on photo review and zoom to make sure peoples eyes are open. For large important group portraits during a wedding
column2: I want to make sure all eyes are open and reviewing that on the a7R II is painfully slow. The a9 is now almost instant when reviewing and really fast when zooming in.

column1: The screen on the back LCD
column2: while only gaining a little bump in resolution
column3: looks more clear and crisp than it does on the a7R II. You notice it when looking at the menu. It could be also because the menu in the a7R II is the older style UI
column4: but still
column5: the a9 looks more crisp and clear overall. Where there is a big difference however is the EVF. Its much more clear and crisp. Its not even that the a7R II has a bad EVF
column6: its just the a9 is better.

column1: -- DUAL CARD SLOTS
Yes! Dual slots! I have never had a memory card go bad on me
column2: but I have heard countless stories of other photographers loosing images or paying for a third party to recover them
column3: some even with just no luck. Just because it hasnt happened to me doesnt mean I dont often think about it during a shoot. Thankfully
column4: my mind is more at easy and Im able to have a backup card. Ive also run into companies that wouldnt hire me unless I was using a camera with dual slots.

column1: The only gripe I have with the dual slots is the set up. For something like shooting Raw to slot 1 (faster slot) and JPEG to slot 2
column2: its a bit confusing as you have to set the record media to slot 2 in order for the JPEGs to be stored there. Yea its weird and seems backwards. One of the only times Ive ever actually had to read a camera manual.

column1: The new dial on the top left is a nice addition. Allowing for quick access to drive modes and AF modes. I do wish the locking button for that dial had an on and off switch. It would be nice to change those on the fly without first pressing in a button.
And finally! The joystick! Why it took them so long to add an AF joystick is besides me. I
column3: find that a joystick is the fasted and most convenient way to change your AF point while composing your shots.

column1: -- IMAGE QUALITY --

But it doesnt have the resolution and dynamic range of the a7R II Is what I kept telling myself to keep me from investing in the a9. Its also what a lot of people are saying in reviews and forum posts and probably for the same reason. But in all honestly
column2: aside from the dimensions of the file itself
column3: its pretty hard to distinguish an a7R II file vs an a9 file unless you zoom in at 100%. But honestly
column4: I sometimes cant even tell when Im working with an a6500 file.

column1: So if you have those reservations
column2: you can put them to rest. The resolution is just fine and the dynamic range is plentiful. You can also be assured that the a9s high ISO is really good. Some of the wedding images below show how it tough lighting (backlit
column3: combination of harsh light and shadows
column4: mix lighting
column5: etc.)
column6: the a9 is capable of producing fantastic results with a lot of room to push and pull shadows and highlights.

column1: -- VIDEO QUALITY --

I am a super amateur videographer so I wont go in depth about the quality or lack of S-Log. What I have read is that apparently the a9 downsamples 6k footage to 4k which makes the quality really awesome. Theyve also heavily reduced rolling shutter during quick panning. Nice! But like I said
column2: Im just barely starting to get into video so I definitely dont have much knowledge about this.

column1: -- ALL THE OTHER AMAZING FEATURES --
Eye AF has been game changing for portraits and it just got better on the a9. It tracks your eye flawlessly. I mean
column2: the ability to shoot at f/1.4 and be confident that your subjects eye will be in focus is just crazy.

column1: I also love the fact that your AF selection changes whether youre shooting in landscape or portrait mode. This I something that is super useful when dealing with portraits.
Then theres the 20 FPS. Honestly
column2: I dont think Ill use it much
column3: maybe just key moments at a wedding or cool action shots while traveling. Im sure some of you are wondering why Id buy an a9 if I dont need the 20 FPS
column4: but thats just part of why this camera is amazing. Besides
column5: when I got the a7R II
column6: I said I didnt need the resolution but here I am
column7: holding onto the camera specifically for resolution.

column1: 09/05/17 Update: Wow. 20 FPS is DOPE. Yea
column2: didnt think it would be of much use to me but being able to shoot away as the bride walks down
column3: during a sparklers send off
column4: or even just while theyre dancing the night away at the reception has been a much welcome addition. Having that speed allows you to get that perfect shot. Was I able to get the shot before? Yea
column5: I think there was always at least one shot good enough. But now
column6: its more like 10 shots to choose from which in my opinion really takes away that margin of error.

column1: Silent shooting and no black out with the electronic shutter. Its kind of weird
column2: but awesome! In the two weeks Ive owned the a9
column3: Ive already gotten use to the no black out
column4: its pretty epic. However
column5: I still have yet to get use to silent shooting and dont think I ever will get use to it. I am excited though that I can use it during ceremonies at quiet churches and even more excited I can be super discreet while I travel. Other than that
column6: I need the sound. Also
column7: rolling shutter has been greatly improved when using the electronic shutter.

column1: 09/05/17 Update: I am still not use to silent shooting and I dont think Ill ever get use to it. Personally
column2: I feel like I either need the sound or the black out. At a few weddings
column3: I had to make sure I was taking photos by pressing the play button haha. Im sure this is great for sports and nature photographers who are in a more controlled space while shooting and need to be silent (think tennis match point!). But for weddings Im finding people are actually listening for the click to go off. There were a few awkward moments when Id put the camera to my face
column4: theyd pose for a photo and not hear a sound and Id put the camera down. Theyd ask
column5: Did you take a photo?

column1: This camera of course has pretty much all the features carried down from their other cameras. Stuff like IBIS (still one of the best things ever)
column2: touch screen (I have mine off because the joystick is more than capable to change focus)
column3: 4k
column4: S&Q (slo motion capture and play) and everything else great about the latest Sony mirrorless cameras.

column1: -- BATTERY LIFE --
09/05/17 Update: I shot my first wedding with the a9 in 100F weather and thankfully
column2: there was no heat warnings of sorts even though my camera was hot. Regarding battery life
column3: I fired off over 2k shots with about 15% remaining after 7 hours. The only thing I really made sure to do was turn off the camera when not in use during those waiting periods. Amazing!

column1: -- CONCLUSION --
So to conclude
column2: the a9 is awesome. Its not just an awesome sports camera
column3: its an awesome everything camera. I am most excited about the AF system (with the better Eye AF and joystick) as well as the battery life. I know people say
column4: just bring extra batteries
column5: but looking back at traveling through a place like India
column6: I stressed over making sure I had enough charged batteries and portable battery packs and converters to last a long day of adventure and shooting. Its in those moments that I look back and it becomes annoying and cumbersome and something Id rather not have to deal.

column1: The a9 brings back some of what DSLRs were only capable of doing. Lightning fast AF and really good battery life. Its an exciting time to be invested in mirrorless and it can only get better from here.
And two months in shooting with the a9
column2: I can confidently say this is indeed
column3: a game changer."^5^Sep 14

column1: jay19945^/sony-alpha-a9-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/5865600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^14^0^"I'll start by saying I've been a professional wedding photographer for 17years. I've shot Nikon for the vast majority of that time.(short time with canon). I can honestly say this is the best camera system I have ever had the pleasure to shoot with. I was expecting a couple shining points to stick out to me but after shooting 6 weddings with the gear I can't find an area where I am less than thrilled. Focus system is amazing
column2: low light..amazing. Coming from the d5 I was a bit nervous about stepping into a small frame camera but it feels great in the hand even with the 70-200 2.8. For me it was a great change and would do it again without question."^5^Aug 4

column1: SoccerDad^/sony-alpha-a9-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/5865600?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Im not a professional photographer but photography has been my passion and hobby for years. The A7II was my transition camera from the smartphone/digital camera world to the DSLR/Mirrorless level of the game. It was my starter camera which I purchased at best buy on black Friday 2017 got a great deal and I've been taking pictures daily ever since. I decided to upgrade this year but was stuck between A7RIII and the A9. Im not going to go all tech talk here but the main difference between the two is 1. with the A7RIII you can take 'bigger' pictures (at 42.4 mp it captures enough information so you can print pictures big enough to hang on the side of a building!) 2. with the A9 you can take 'faster' pictures (you can basically stop time and at 20 frames per second you can select the shot with the best moment ). I went with the A9 because it can do everything the A7RIII plus more. The trade off is it has 693 point phase detection for auto focus vs 425 on the A7RIII
column3: and 24.2 mp vs 42.2 mp on the A7RIII. They both record movies at 4k but im not a video guy so i didn't read too much into the video spec. The reason I bring up the A7RIII on this review because it seems to be the topic all over the internet when people are deciding which mirror-less camera to get next. At the end of the day if you are into portrait photography - A7RIII
column4: if you are into sports and nature photography A9. If you are rich
column5: get both. I also went A9 because my son is into sports plus - it was on sale and i had gift cards and points saved from best buy rewards program
column6: I basically got it at the price of the A7RIII with 24 month no interest financing on my best buy credit card. The opportunity was worth the sacrifice and budget adjustment. I don't regret it!!! I just need to save money for the FE 100-400mm f/4.5-5.6 telephoto lens."^5^May 12

column1: Redwing^/olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-ii-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/5684901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"A definite improvement over the E-M1 mk i if you need the extra speed
column3: incredible improvement in the image stabilization (which was excellent in the original model)
column4: and other newer features.... there are far too many improvements to summarize here.

column1: Not such an big improvement if you are strictly looking for higher ISO performance over the mk i version. If this is your main consideration in upgrading from mk i to mk ii
column2: you might not get the jump in low light /high ISO performance you are hoping for.

column1: The increase from 16 to 20 MP helps outright resolution
column2: but it's not a quantum leap in improvement.

column1: AF performance for moving objects is definitely better.
I was tempted to get the Nikon D500 but decided the overall size of that system was too large for my needs."^5^May 15
Nerves^/olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-ii-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/5684901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^1^"I purchased this camera in December 2017 for the holidays. I am a long time Canon user
column2: owning several bodies and a significant collection of 'L' lenses. Suffice to say that my 1D (x)'s have taken me everywhere. Over that last years (several)
column3: I found myself just using the camera phone and not my Pro-Gear; to the point that it just sat there.

column1: The weight
column3: and other factors let me just to walk away. Fast forward 2 years ago
column4: and a long vacation trip. I purchased the Sony (A6300) with some good lenses. Mirrorless
column5: experience in my past was horrid but
column6: the Sony performed well. That camera system was lighter and much smaller than my canon but
column7: never felt a 'connection' with the system. My best description of someone it felt like a software company made a camera and not the other way around.

column1: The Olympus E-M1 Mark II has been that camera (It doesn't solve everything) that I take most often and everywhere. It's been to a severe and long-lasting downpour in the Appalachian trail
column2: with no protection for over 2 hours. It's been dropped on a tile in a bowling alley
column3: it's been in freezing weather with Snow..still going without a single issue.

column1: The Single focus is blinding fast (faster than the Sony). There's virtually no shutter lag
column2: the creative modes (live time and live composition) changed the way I see and capture moments. Not carrying a tripod because of this mind-blowing IBIS is makes me take the camera everywhere. It's NOT a 'Night Ninja'; meaning FF (Full Frames) still have an edge on paper but
column3: for street photography at night...it's incredible (if you like the film look like I do and hate the surgical look). Nobody notices you
column4: so no one is possing or angry.

column1: For travel
column2: the main reason I bought it...imagine carrying 5-7 lenses
column3: camera
column4: spare batteries
column5: chargers
column6: memory cards/readers
column7: backup drive
column8: and more on a trip...and it's less that 8LBs!!!!!! The C4K video is impressive and Capable of 237Mbits (higher resolution than the sony's)
column9: and with the IBIS it looks like you have a gimbal while walking.

column1: No to the downside...video Continuous Autofocusing at night while tracking is not as good as the Canon or the sony...the Eye tracking is not as good as the new A7III sony. Battery life is about 488 (low- lots of 4k videos)-780 (avg with some footage) and 900-1100 (with no video).

The primes lenses (45-75mm) none pro are genuinely amazingly sharp. The 75mm is as good at my Canon 70-200 L v2 if not better (the Bokeh)...the 12-40 F2.8 Pro is the leading workhorse...and stay's on the camera 90% of the time. I know own 14 Lenses (Olympus
column3: and Laowa)...and the M4/3 (Micro Four Thirds) platform works amazingly!!! In Europe
column4: you'll find places that you will NOT be allowed in with a typical DSLR of the Mirrorless FF (the lenses are about the same size on FF mirrorless as traditional DSLR's). In Certain Park tours in Africa the FF with command a higher 'Tax' or entrance fee. I can take and hand hold an 800mm (Panasonic Leica) zoom all day. Try walking around with an FF
column6: and a 24-70 F2.8 and a wide angle (all fast glass)...tell me how you feel at the end of the day. I typically only have 1 lenses for street photography...and maybe 2 for 'Urban/city' travel (add a super wide angle)...so its not just about giving up light dominance (for pixel peepers)
column7: it's not about walking away from 14Bit color
column8: it's not about having less dynamic range. It's a compromise and acknowledgment that my 20MP is enough for my medium and needs. I post mostly online...My audience is online
column9: so I'm deliberate on the use case and in that the Olympus ROCKS! For Sample please go to Instagram #mirrorlessphoto"^5^Aug 13

column1: jrsweb^/olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-ii-mirrorless-camera-body-only-black/5684901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"I was initially concerned about the price but had read so much about it. I had used Olympus digital cameras many years back before moving to Sony

I really like that I can use both since I eventually plan to get the Pany GH5 for video. Getting really great results and I am still learning. Once I get up to speed

column1: PolarTheCameraGuy^/canon-eos-m5-mirrorless-camera-with-ef-m-18-150mm-telephoto-zoom-lens-black/5623278?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^2^"I originally came looking for the M5 as the perfect Vlogger camera
column2: along with the occasional B roll and video shots I need to get from time to time. The Internal Stabilization is great for video and does everything I expected it to
column3: which makes editing a breeze later. Video quality is also really good. But one thing i wasn't expecting was for the I.S. to be SO good that I can shoot at shutter speeds blow 1/3 of a second hand held and still get a sharp Image! What?! its great
column4: not that you need that all the time but just think of all the epic stills you can get hand held at lower ISO's now.

column1: as for Cons: ISO performance is ok. Nothing close to current DSLR's like my Nikon D750
column2: but still ok. the sensor is APS-C and its mirrorless so that tends to be the standard honestly. Just know that you will start getting some noticable noise around 6400 ISO (but still usable depending on your taste) If you are a perfectionist
column3: then its not for you.

column1: The focusing system is great
column2: but again coming from DSLR's it could be more accurate
column3: and it could be faster. Continuous focus in still shooting is iffy and can sort of miss and overcompensate alot. On video however its pretty spot on and shifts focus SUPER smoothly.

column1: and lastly. I hate the multi page menu system. Id rather just scroll down through all related options in one tab rather than have 4 tabs just for camera settings that i need to scroll through sideways
column2: along with all the other tabs.

column1: Final thoughts: Great video camera
column3: B-roll
column4: and Vlogging thanks to that flip down screen that makes you look like you are always looking at your audience. Could be better focus
column5: and noise performance wise
column6: and with a neater menu but if you can get past that
column7: its a great little camera for when you don't want to lug around the heavy beasts that DSLR's tend to be."^4^Jun 24
